description: Ask many Americans about their ancestors and you'll be told that their great-grandfather was one of seven and their great-grandmother the fifth of nine. They themselves, however, will most likely be parents of two or three at most. Why? Because, like the residents of other industrialized countries, they know that smaller families mean bigger futures -- and are able to act on that knowledge.

title: N.C.A.A. Vote On Athlete Aid Irks Coaches
description: An impassioned effort by basketball coaches to restore a 14th scholarship to Division I men's teams, an effort that escalated into a symbolic appeal to provide greater opportunities for minority-group athletes, was decisively defeated at the National Collegiate Athletic Association convention today.

title: FORD RAISES PRICES ON 1994 MODEL CARS AND TRUCKS
description: The Ford Motor Company raised prices on 11 car and 6 truck lines yesterday, resulting in an average price increase of five-tenths of a percent, or $97 a vehicle. Truck price increases average between $50 and $280 a vehicle, Ford said. Ford is the second of the Big Three auto makers to raise prices for the 1994-model year, which began on Oct. 1. The General Motors Corporation raised its United States car prices an average eight-tenths of a percent, or $164, as of Jan. 3. G.M. truck prices were increased six-tenths of a percent, or $131.

title: Retailers' Drive to Consolidate
description: If Federated Department Stores succeeds in merging with R. H. Macy & Company, it would become the largest department store company in America -- but it would probably not hold the top spot for long.

title: Reproductive Revolution Is Jolting Old Views
description: Suppose that Leonardo da Vinci were suddenly transported to the United States in 1994, says Dr. Arthur Caplan, an ethicist at the University of Minnesota. What would you show him that might surprise him?

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Elias Ladino Ensemble Washington Square Church

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Russian Chamber Chorus of New York Christ and St. Stephen's Church

title: Beit Shemesh Journal; To Israel! And the Trip Is Not Just for the Living
description: In 1993, more than 72,000 foreigners resettled in Israel. For about 1,000 of them, this was unquestionably the final stop. They came not to live but to be buried.

title: A Suspect in Summer Abduction of Girl
description: After months of searching the woods and cornfields outside Utica, N.Y., the New York State Police said yesterday that they had a prime suspect in the abduction of a 12-year-old girl who disappeared last summer on a mile-long bicycle ride between her home and the church where her father is a lay minister.

title: Trying To Keep A Lid On Ryan
description: Buddy Ryan was called on the carpet yesterday -- again -- by Houston Oiler management that wished its defensive coordinator would end his tirades against Kevin Gilbride, the offensive coordinator.

title: Waiting for an Electronic Safe-Deposit Box
description: THE hard disk drive in my subnotebook computer is about the size of a deck of playing cards. It is a marvel of miniaturization, with delicate mechanisms that would impress a Swiss watchmaker. It can store more than 200 megabytes of information.

title: An Inflation Index Is Said to Overstate the Case
description: Researchers at the Bureau of Labor Statistics believe that its Consumer Price Index overstates annual inflation by up to six-tenths of a percentage point, a finding with implications for policy makers and the public.

title: Beyond That Rainy Day
description: The raincoats that will provide protection from spring's showers are now trickling into the stores. They offer new as well as tried-and-true ways to keep dry while looking cheerful on doleful days.

title: The Ice Palace
description: New York has so much of everything -- so many subways, skyscrapers, races, creeds, controversies, pizzerias, bodegas and dim sum parlors -- that it is only right that it has so much weather. Only a few summers ago the temperature and humidity were, for forty days and nights, comparable to those along the Amazon; several recent Aprils have featured snowstorms; and no year goes by without threat either of drought or downpour. So of course New York is now an ice palace. It's just putting on another face, that's all.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Since it began publishing three months ago, the weekly newspaper Her New York (which was a daily for its first three weeks) has become known for the tumultuousness of its staff changes.

title: 4 Countries In Audition For NATO
description: When President Clinton arrives here Tuesday to explain the partial membership in NATO that Washington is offering Eastern European nations, he will find four leaders who are essentially eager for the regional security.

title: 50 Million Smokers Say, 'Give Us a Break'
description: To the Editor:

title: A Co-Worker Is Charged In Slaying of Drug Aide
description: A man who the police say helped arrange the $150 contract killing of an accountant in a Bronx drug rehabilitation program was arrested last night and charged with murder.

title: Middle-of-the-Roader Rides High With His Own Health Care Plan
description: With all the barons on Capitol Hill eager to get a piece of health care reform -- from Kennedy to Rostenkowski, Moynihan to Dingell -- it would be easy to underestimate a 39-year-old representative from Tennessee with nary a subcommittee chairmanship to his name.

title: 2 Officers Are Indicted on Injuries to Van Driver After Arrest
description: Two New York City police officers have been indicted on assault charges in a case in which a prisoner was left a quadriplegic after his head smashed into a Brooklyn station house door, the police said yesterday.

title: Well, There Goes the Neighborhood
description: IN a way, the Schneiders are not entirely alone.

title: No. 21 Meets Cellar Dweller: Shade Your Eyes, It's Ugly
description: The bold and not so beautiful showed up to play hockey in a game between two of the National Hockey League's lowest-ranking teams tonight. The Islanders, No. 21 over all, faced the last-place Ottawa Senators, No. 26, and stumbled to a 3-3 tie in front of 10,275 fans at the Ottawa Civic Centre.

title: Human Guinea Pigs Are American as Apple Pie; How Much Is Safe?
description: To the Editor:

title: Childhood Depression May Herald Adult Ills
description: CONTRARY to popular belief, even mild episodes of depression in childhood are often harbingers of repeated, more serious bouts of depression later in life, according to results of the first major study to track depressed children into their early adult years.

title: Part of Ameritech Account in Review
description: The Ameritech Corporation, the Midwest regional Baby Bell telephone company, said yesterday that it had placed in review the creative portion of its consumer telephone services account, which has been handled by Tatham Euro RSCG in Chicago since 1989. Though billings were not disclosed, Advertising Age estimated them at $50 million.

title: Pope Praises the Achievements of Italy's Old Guard
description: At the start of a decisive week, Pope John Paul II launched himself combatively today into Italy's muddied political debate, urging Italians to cleave to Christian values, eschew separatism and see some good in a political elite disgraced by Europe's worst corruption scandal.

title: Philadelphia Inquirer Plans a TV Newscast
description: The Philadelphia Inquirer, one of the country's leading newspapers, will move directly into television news production with the broadcast of a local nightly newscast, officials of the newspaper and its corporate parent, Knight-Ridder Inc., announced today.

title: BARCLAYS TO INCREASE JOB CUTS AT BRITISH BRANCHES
description: Barclays P.L.C., Britain's largest retail bank, said yesterday that it planned to eliminate an additional 3,000 jobs in Britain by the end of next year. Barclays said in September that it would cut 500 jobs from retail branches in London and southeast England. The bank has eliminated about 16,000 jobs since 1991, reducing its work force to 68,500.

title: McCormick & Co. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After a charge of $ 26,626,000, or a loss of 33 cents a share, from effect of a change in accounting for postretirement benefits.Latest quarter's share earnings included a charge of 2 cents a share from change in accounting for postretirement benefits and from the increased federal income tax rate retroactive to Jan. 1, 1993.Latest fiscal income from continuing operations of $ 1.22 a share included a charge of 3 cents a share from change in accounting for postretirement benefits and charge of 3 cents a share from the increased federal income tax rate.Year-ago fiscal income from continuing operations of $ 1.16 a share included a gain of 2 cents a share from sale of industrial cleaning supply business.

title: UKRAINE GIVES IN ON SURRENDERING ITS NUCLEAR ARMS
description: President Clinton announced tonight that the United States, Russia and Ukraine had reached an agreement for the destruction of Ukraine's entire nuclear arsenal, 175 long-range missiles and more than 1,800 warheads. He described the deal as "a hopeful and historic breakthrough" that would not only benefit the three signers but enhance world security.

title: Review/Recital; Fassbaender in Program Of Wolf 'Morike' Songs
description: Twenty-five Hugo Wolf songs at a single sitting turned out to be not enough. When "Der Feuerreiter" -- rumbling, frenetic, very nearly hysterical -- brought Brigitte Fassbaender's Alice Tully Hall program to a close on Sunday afternoon, one almost regretted there were not 25 more.

title: 8 Police Officers Hurt in Clash at Harlem Mosque
description: New York City's new Police Commissioner ordered an inquiry yesterday into the Police Department's handling of a confrontation between the police and members of a Harlem mosque in which eight officers were injured and one officer's gun was taken away.

title: Husband Tells of Mutilation as Wife's Trial Starts
description: John W. Bobbitt testified in graphic detail today about how his wife cut off his penis as he slept. But Lorena L. Bobbitt's lawyers said she was striking back after a marriage to her dream marine turned into "a reign of terror" with repeated rapes and beatings.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; A start-up airline doesn't promise the world, only a somewhat reduced level of aggravation.
description: IT may still take a few minutes short of forever to get through its computerized switchboard to a real person, but Ultrair has nevertheless taken a step toward truth in airline advertising with a campaign that bills the start-up carrier as "the least annoying airline."

title: Nation of Islam Speech Creates Tensions at New Jersey College; Rights Only for Some
description: To the Editor:

title: Canadians Curbing TV Violence
description: Canadian broadcasters have resolved to reduce television violence, and the first casualty is "Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtles."

title: Whitewater: No Longer a G.O.P. Plot
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's call for a special prosecutor, now joined by several prominent Democratic colleagues, puts a hole in the White House's argument that the furor over President Clinton's Arkansas land dealings is nothing more than a Republican vendetta.

title: Jay Blackton, 84, Music Director Who Won Oscar for 'Oklahoma!'
description: Jay Blackton, who was the music director for a string of hit shows in the golden age of the Broadway musical and who won an Academy Award for scoring the 1955 film of "Oklahoma!," died on Saturday at Granada Hills Community Hospital in Granada Hills, Calif. He was 84 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: 2 Hospital Chains to Join; 2 H.M.O.'s Also Merging
description: Continuing a surge of consolidations in the face of growing market and political pressures on the price of health care, two of the country's largest investor-owned hospital chains and two big managed-care insurers announced separate merger agreements yesterday.

title: INSIDE
description: New Phase in Bank Inquiry

title:
COMPANY NEWS;
Sega Game Faces Delay Over Rating
description: Sega of America Inc. faces a possibly lengthy delay before it can release new copies of its Night Trap game because of the video game industry's squabble over a rating system for interactive video games.

title: Oberhof Shows Lugers Its Positive Side
description: Once again, Duncan Kennedy found himself surrounded in this quiet, thickly forested town. Only this time, the group of Germans hemming him in wanted nothing to do with Nazi power, racial slurs or swift kicks to the ribs.

title: Observer; Man Here Took the Bait
description: Several months ago the authorities at the Mark Twain house in Hartford, Conn., asked if I would come and make a speech.

title: U.N. Sanctions Against Haiti Are Hampering Relief Efforts
description: The embargo on fuel and military supplies imposed on Haiti by the United Nations Security Council in October has prevented international relief agencies from delivering vital supplies of food and medicine to the poor in many outlying rural areas.

title: Cold War Chill Lingers Downwind From a Nuclear Bomb-Testing Site
description: In a 1955 Government brochure distributed to people living near the nuclear weapon test site in the Nevada desert, an official greeted readers by telling them, "You are in a very real sense active participants in the nation's atomic test program."

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: It's Official Now: Rangers Are in a Slump
description: Mike Keenan didn't rant or rave or even act unhappy. Mark Messier was calm and philosophical. No one threw a stick or punched a locker or did anything to indicate that all is not perfect in the Rangers' world at this time.

title: Review/Dance; Urban Artworks, the Sequel
description: The second program of Urban Artworks, an ambitious festival of dance by new and familiar choreographers, got off to a fine start on Sunday afternoon at the Pace Downtown Theater. The opening dance was "Better Left Unsaid," a recent work choreographed by Mary Bruce Blackburn and performed by her American Dance Ensemble company. The piece, set to a score by Peter Jones, sent five young women boiling and tumbling through empty space and interlocking like puzzle pieces with one another's bodies. The dance needed tightening. But Ms. Blackburn created an undercurrent of serene and troubled emotions to go with the dance's resilient physicality. The performers, all compelling, were Jennifer Binford, Merceditias Manago, Amy Prensky, Wendy Samuels and Katrina Thompson.

title: Electronic Journal Is Indexed
description: FOR the first time, the standard international index for papers published in medical journals, Index Medicus, will now include reports published electronically.

title: New Capital-Risk Ratings Guide Insurers
description: When the Prudential Insurance Company sold half of its Macy's mortgages to Federated Department Stores for $449.3 million at year-end, it did more than make a slight profit and give Federated a stronger voice in any effort to acquire Macy.

title: Human Guinea Pigs Are American as Apple Pie
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Theater: Stitches; Of Stardom and a Tyranny of Images
description: In "Stitches," the corrosively funny, if overextended, comedy by the brother-and-sister team of David and Amy Sedaris at La Mama E.T.C., irony doesn't take the form of a wink but of a steady, wide-eyed gaze that flattens everything to the absurd dimensions of a macabre animated cartoon.

title: Clinton's Damage Control Is Faltering
description: The White House officials and advisers who shape the Administration's public image have been hobbled in their effort to control debate over the Clintons' involvement in the Whitewater Development Corporation by President and Mrs. Clinton, who have resisted internal calls for further investigation.

title: Peace Corps Aid in Sub-Saharan Africa
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 23 about the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington omitted a word in quoting its director of communications, Naomi Paiss. She said the museum's ultimate goal was to establish an "en masse understanding that we are not only about what the Germans did to the Jews but what people did to people."

title: Prices of Treasury Issues Mixed
description: Prices of Treasury issues were mixed yesterday, as investors failed to follow through on last week's rally, which had been stimulated by a December jobs report that showed economic growth was easing.

title: Barge in Oil Spill Was Barred by New York
description: The barge that fouled San Juan with oil is one of 19 expelled from New York State waters nearly three years ago because of pollution violations by the owners, the Frank family of New York and New Jersey.

title: Another Giuliani Hams It Up on TV
description: It didn't have the verve of Vice President Al Gore smashing glass ashtrays and calling David Letterman a "pinhead." But little more than a week into office, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani got his own moment on the "Late Show" last night -- and he wasn't even upstaged by his 7-year-old son, Andrew, who was absent but had been the guest of choice.

title: Gillette Will Cut 2,000 Jobs During Next 2 Years
description: The Gillette Company said today that it would shed 2,000 jobs, or 6 percent of the company's total, in the next two years, as part of a worldwide realignment that will result in a one-time fourth-quarter charge of $164 million. Most of the job losses will come in Europe.

title: Croats and Bosnians Battle
description: Bosnian Government forces attacked Croatian-held villages near Vitez today for the second consecutive day in an attempt to seize a key road, United Nations officials and local radio reports said.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Dec. 23 with an article about classical-music radio misstated the revenues generated by classical broadcasts in Houston. The annual revenues of KRTS-FM and KRTK-FM, which carry identical programming on separate frequencies, are estimated below $1 million, not below $100,000 (the stations do not disclose their revenues).

title: Stocks Fall After Blasts In Mexico
description: In its first trading session since several powerful bombs shook Mexico City and signaled a possible expansion of the violence in the southern part of the country, the Mexican stock exchange recorded its biggest one-day loss in six years today, dropping 166 points, or 6.32 percent.

title: Investors Seem to Favor Offer From QVC
description: Wall Street appears to believe that QVC Network Inc. will win the bidding war for Paramount Communications Inc., judging by how the stocks of the companies involved in the deal performed yesterday.

title: Cave Find Shows Man And Apes Coexisting
description: VIETNAMESE and American anthropologists have discovered a jumble of fossils pointing to the likelihood that early humans and a surprisingly large number of other primate species lived in close touch with each other 250,000 years ago.

title: Chicago Firm Ousts Four
description: Rodman & Renshaw Capital Group Inc. dismissed four executives today, including its president, and announced the resignation of its chairman, almost two months after the company agreed to be acquired by the Mexican brokerage firm Abaco Casa de Bolsa.

title: In NATO Talks, Bosnia Sets Off A Sharp Debate
description: The NATO summit meeting opened today with continuing tensions over Bosnia -- mostly between France and the United States -- that competed for attention with the signing of a document opening the alliance's doors to the countries of Eastern Europe.

title: Patterns
description: Embracing What Works

title: Blast Jury Sees Defendant's Items, in Detail
description: In the wake of the World Trade Center bombing, F.B.I. agents mounted searches of two apartments in Jersey City where one suspect, Mohammed A. Salameh, lived at different times in the months before the explosion took place. Yesterday, as the trial of Mr. Salameh and three other defendants accused of the bombing entered its 17th week, agents took the stand to show the jury what they found.

title: Cuomo Says President's Health Plan Will Hurt New York Public Workers
description: In a sweeping critique of President Clinton's health plan, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has warned New York State employees that under the proposal they would generally have to pay more for less comprehensive benefits than they now have.

title: Yeltsin Extols 1921 Rebellion, Denouncing Its Repression by Lenin
description: In a report meant to strike a new blow at the memory of Lenin and to undermine latter-day Communists, President Boris N. Yeltsin today officially rehabilitated the victims of the deadly Bolshevik repression of the Kronstadt uprising of 1921.

title: People
description: * Kathleen Hall, executive vice president and director of media and marketing services at Leonard Monahan Lubars & Kelly, Providence, R.I., was promoted to partner and chief operating officer, succeeding Fran Kelly, who resigned to consider offers from two agencies based in Boston. Edward Binder, senior vice president and account group director, was named to the additional new position of director of client services.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: HEALTH PLAN SEEN HURTING NEW YORKERS

title: Market Place; Aiwa weathers the recession with a tight focus and some luck.
description: EVEN in one of the hardest-hit sectors of hard-hit Japan, it is possible for a company with the right strategy, and a little luck, to grow and prosper.

title: Mexico Leader Names Negotiator To Seek Political End to Uprising
description: Signaling that Mexico may seek a political rather than a military solution to the armed rebellion that started in southern Mexico on New Year's Day, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari named one of the country's most powerful politicians today to negotiate with the rebels.

title: Weekend of 'Quality Time' for Pentagon Officials
description: Call it a case of New Age management meeting the Defense Department.

title: Study Backs Safety of Whooping Cough Vaccine
description: IN a new study that may help diminish a longstanding dispute about the safety of the standard vaccine against whooping cough, researchers have found that the vaccine does not lead to increased risk of serious neurological illness.

title: From a Fortified Hilltop, A Clarion for Apartheid
description: Surrounded by two trenches, a fence topped with loops of razor wire, a four-foot wall of sand bags and a few men with guns, Johannes van der Walt cued an Olivia Newton-John record and prepared to read the news.

title: The Charade in Brussels
description: As far back as anyone remembers, the leaders attending NATO summit meetings have put on a display of Western unity, no matter how contentious the issues.

title: Nation of Islam Speech Creates Tensions at New Jersey College; The Price of Freedom
description: To the Editor:

title: Rice Against Collins: A Magnificent Matchup
description: Jerry Rice, the best receiver in football, knows all about Giants cornerback Mark Collins. He has the utmost respect for him and isn't going to be fooled into thinking that because Collins has two sprained knees he'll be able to take advantage of the injuries.

title: Doubts Ease on Protecting Ozone
description: A TEAM of atmospheric scientists has concluded from experiments and theoretical calculations that doubts about the ozone-friendliness of a group of compounds being substituted for ozone-destroying chlorofluorocarbon refrigerants are probably groundless.

title: Charles (Chub) Feeney, 72, Dies; Ex-President of National League
description: Charles S. (Chub) Feeney, the high-spirited baseball executive who helped guide his family's Giants to two National League pennants in New York and one in San Francisco before spending 17 years as the league's president, died yesterday at California Pacific Hospital in San Francisco. He was 72.

title: Donald Smiley, 78; Was Chief Executive Of R.H. Macy & Co.
description: Donald B. Smiley, an Iowa storekeeper's son who retired as chairman and chief executive of R. H. Macy & Company in 1980 after 35 years, died on Sunday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 78 and a resident of Greenwich.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-9 NUCLEAR ACCORD WITH UKRAINE President Clinton announced in Brussels that the United States, Russia and Ukraine had agreed on the destruction of Ukraine's entire nuclear arsenal: 175 long-range missiles and over 1,800 warheads. A1

title: Volt Information Sciences Inc. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-After a gain of $ 959,000, or 20 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting.c-Net incomeThe company has adopted the Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No. 109, ''Accounting for Income Taxes'', in the first quarter of fiscal 1993 and has not restated prior years' financial statements.The results of operations for 1993 included a pretax charge of $ 4.3 million, or 58 cents a share, after tax benefit for the fourth quarter, and a pretax charge of $ 6.4 million, or 87 cents a share, after tax benefit for the year, for anticipated cost overruns on its Computer System segment's two initial contracts for its directory assistance systems.(Loss)

title: New Russia Parliament: More of Same Expected
description: Three months after Russia's last Parliament came to a violent end, a newly elected Federal Assembly starts work on Tuesday amid signs that it, too, will become mired in confrontation and political grandstanding.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Review Set on Medicare At University Hospitals
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to interpret a Federal policy aimed at curbing Medicare payments to hospitals affiliated with medical schools. The policy is intended to prevent the hospitals from using the federally financed Medicare program to cover increased expenses of running graduate teaching programs for interns and residents.

title: A Move to Michigan
description: MAKHTAR NDIAYE, declared ineligible to play basketball for Wake Forest University because of recruiting violations, signed a letter of intent with Michigan yesterday and will suit up for the Wolverines on Thursday against Ohio State.

title: Dow Soars 44.74 and Hits 4th Straight Record Close
description: Stocks soared to yet another high yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average hitting its fourth consecutive record close.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about a trustee of the New York Public Library who died on Saturday misspelled her first name in some copies. She was Sonny Sloan, not Sunny.

title: NBC Wakes Up the Echoes for Five More Years
description: Notre Dame football will remain in NBC's ecstatic embrace through 2000.

title: Sydney C. Cooper Is Dead at 74; Police Official Fought Corruption
description: Sydney C. Cooper, a former New York City police commander who fought against corruption in the department, died on Sunday at his home in East Norwich, L.I. He was 74.

title: Exel Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Mayor's Remark About Weather Offends Advocates for Homeless
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani appeared to make a joke yesterday while answering a reporter's question about what the city was doing to help the homeless in the cold weather, and some advocates for homeless people immediately criticized the remark as insensitive.

title: German Steel Output
description: German crude steel production fell 5.3 percent last year, to 41.4 million tons, the Federal Statistics Office said today. Pig iron production in 1993 fell 5.5 percent, to 29.5 million tons. Output of both iron and steel in the second half of 1993 was higher than for the corresponding period of 1992.

title: A Gene Named Sonic
description: NAMING the varieties of hedgehog genes, which play a key role in embryo development, has been a source of friction among research teams. One group wanted to give the varieties numbers, another letters.

title: Prudential Settlement Complicated
description: Allegations of fraud against the accountants in a series of limited partnerships sold by Prudential Securities are raising questions about the future of a $120 million class-action settlement reached with the firm over those partnerships, lawyers said yesterday.

title: BE Aerospace Inc. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
Strawberry Is Healthy
description: DARRYL STRAWBERRY attended the first winter workout of the Dodgers yesterday and said his chronic bad back was 100 percent.

title: Our Irrational Pastime: Division Setup Still Not Set Up
description: Less than three months before the start of the season, major league clubs and players still don't know if they will compete in two divisions in each league or three.

title: It's Auld Lang Syne For Giants And 49ers
description: They are, as Lawrence Taylor said, old friends. The San Francisco 49ers and the New York Giants have gone against each other so many times in the post-season, it's as if the 49ers are in the Giants' division. But they aren't the kind of friends who invite the other over for dinner to meet the family. There is respect, but that's about it.

title: One 3-Pointer Is Worth More for UConn
description: With the score tied, Doron Sheffer took an inbound pass from Kevin Ollie, paused, shot and sank a 3-point field goal for Connecticut. The basket broke a 61-61 tie with four minutes left in the second half. More important, it broke Syracuse's momentum, and the Orange never got it back as the Huskies went on to a 75-67 victory tonight at the Civic Center.

title: A Plea to Reno For Prosecution On Crown Hts.
description: Brooklyn District Attorney Charles J. Hynes pleaded with Attorney General Janet Reno today to make an exception to a longstanding Justice Department policy and quickly bring Federal civil rights charges against two men for the killing of a rabbinical student more than two years ago during the unrest in Crown Heights.

title: Bridge
description: For players in the New York metropolitan area, the tournament year always begins with the Tri-State Regional Championships at the Rye Town Hilton in Port Chester, N.Y. This year, for the first time, it will last a full week. This is the schedule of major events:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League BALTIMORE ORIOLES -- Agreed to terms with Leo Gomez, third baseman, on a one-year contract.

title: New Approach to Museum-Show Design
description: For most Americans, Motown means an infectious beat and great rhythm-and-blues singing. That's the Motown story: one hit after another coming out of Berry Gordy's talent factory.

title: In an Era of Change, Polish Film Industry Struggles to Stay Vital
description: At a recent conference in France on the future of European film, the Polish director Krzysztof Zanussi took a pessimistic line. Freedom, he said worriedly, had proven a very mixed blessing for the Polish film industry: protective barriers had been lowered and Hollywood had conquered all. "Before, we were dominated by the Russians," he said. "Now, it's the Americans."

title: Sale to Zurich Insurance
description: The Zurich Insurance Company has become the sole owner of Centre Reinsurance Holdings Ltd. after buying out the Bermuda-based company's minority shareholders. Zurich Insurance said today that it had bought 30 percent of Centre Re's shares from the Kemper Corporation, ACE Ltd., the Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Comapny and Marsh & McLennan Risk Capital Holdings Ltd.

title: Crowd of 1,700 Attends O'Neill Funeral
description: Thomas P. (Tip) O'Neill Jr., a bread-and-butter Democrat who told his granddaughter that the Sermon on the Mount was "the greatest political speech ever written," was mourned at a funeral Mass today by ordinary neighbors from Cambridge and grand associates from Washington.

title: Work for Lennox Is Shopped Around
description: Lennox Industries, the heating and cooling systems manufacturer based in Richardson, Tex., said yesterday that it had placed its account in review after 20 years at Ross Advertising in St. Louis. Though billings were not disclosed, the trade publication Adweek estimated them at $8 million, with the potential to grow to $12 million to $14 million.

title: Promotions at Sony Music
description: Sony Music Entertainment Inc. announced several internal promotions of executives yesterday at its various record and entertainment divisions.

title: Strangling Serbia's Democrats
description: The economic sanctions imposed on Serbia 18 months ago -- meant to bring down the regime of Slobodan Milosevic -- have succeeded only in isolating the Serbian people and pushing them into economic ruin. As a blind weapon of retaliation, the sanctions have utterly failed to stem Serbia's aggressive and oppressive policies. If the West sincerely seeks to save lives and end the starvation and cruelty, they should be lifted as soon as possible.

title: Biologists Find Key Genes That Shape Patterning of Embryos
description: RARE indeed are the scientific findings that make jaws drop and spirits do cartwheels. But the discovery of a class of genes, given the cheeky name hedgehog, has aroused the passions of developmental biologists so vigorously that their normal reserve and skepticism have dissolved, leaving them groping for ever-stronger ways to express the beauty and consequence of what has been divulged.

title: Yanks: Bandages, Not Bats
description: The controversy over the mini-camp that cannot be a mini-camp took another spin yesterday when the Yankees insisted that they never intended to conduct organized workouts with players they had invited to Tampa, Fla., this week. The Yankees maintain the invitations were solely for monitoring injuries.

title: 49ers' Defense Showing Made-for-Hampton Tag
description: The San Francisco 49ers did not have a bye last week; they had training camp. Quarantined for four days, the offense was re-taught how to pick up the blitz, the defense was re-taught how to tackle and Coach George Seifert publicly called the team "pathetic."

title: SCHOOL FUND-RAISING COMPANY SOLD IN $55 MILLION DEAL
description: The Tyler Corporation of Dallas said yesterday that it had purchased closely held Institutional Financing Services of Benicia, Calif., for $55 million plus assumed seasonal working capital debt. Under the terms of the transaction, Tyler may make additional payments if the new unit meets certain profit goals. Institutional Financing assists schools in fund-raising activities by arranging for students to sell company-supplied gift items.

title: Fight Before the Bout
description: The first punches have been thrown two months before the heavyweight bout between MICHAEL BENTT and HERBIE HIDE . The fighters traded blows in London yesterday as they posed for photographs to promote the March 19 bout, Bentt's first defense of his World Boxing Organization title.

title: Correction
description: An article yesterday about President Clinton and Russia misidentified the author, Peter Reddaway, in some editions. He is professor of political science at George Washington University.

title: THE NATO SUMMIT: Reporter's Notebook; Clinton Sizes Up Team: Summit, Yes; Sumo, No
description: Weighty matters were on the mind of President William J. Clinton (for so the President is being called on his European trip) this morning as he entered the meeting room where he and other leaders of the alliance were to discuss partnership with countries that used to be Communist, the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina, and so on.

title: Chess
description: It is inevitable that the most distinctive weapon in a player's arsenal will usurp all the attention directed at him. If devil-may-care attacking play is his forte, his games that illustrate this will be the ones that get published. Yet some of his followers may finally begin to wonder what he does when he cannot brazenly walk a tightwire of attack.

title: New Phase For Inquiry On B.C.C.I.
description: A joint team of investigators from the Justice Department, the Federal Reserve Board and the Manhattan District Attorney's office will go to Abu Dhabi next week to begin the next stage of their investigation of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International, District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan said yesterday.

title: Group Videotron reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Study Says Clinton Plan To Burden Hospitals
description: While applauding the goals of President Clinton's health plan, a task force appointed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has concluded that the plan could cost New York hospitals $6.5 billion in its first four years and would place a modest financial burden on state government for two years before eventually benefiting the state budget.

title: Hillenbrand Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
description: b-Included gain on disposal of discontinued operations of $ 11,554,000, or 16 cents a share, in the quarter, and the year included a gain of $ 13,332,000, or 18 cents a share, from combined effect of income from discontinued operations of $ 1,778,000, or 2 cents a share, and gain from disposal of discontinued operations of $ 11,554,000, or 16 cents a share.c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 5,411,000, or 8 cents a share, for the quarter and $ 5,642,000, or 8 cents a share, for the year. The year also included a gain of $ 10,747,000, or 15 cents a share, from cumulative effect of change in accounting for income taxes.Latest year's income from continuing operations of $ 132,486,000, or $ 1.86 a share, included charge of $ 14 million, or 20 cents a share, from the write-down of goodwill related to acquisition of Block Medical.

title: Anthony Borden, 79, Greek Church Leader
description: Dr. Anthony G. Borden, a radiologist and former national commander of the Order of St. Andrew the Apostle, an organization affiliated with the Greek Orthodox Church, died last Thursday at the Fox Chase Hospital in Fox Chase, Pa. He was 79 and lived in Rydal, Pa.

title: F.B.I. Begins Own Search For Kerrigan's Assailant
description: The F.B.I. has joined the search for the attacker of Nancy Kerrigan, the figure skating star.

title: Bankruptcy Update Service Sees Slowdown in Big Cases
description: Peter A. Chapman went from chasing deadbeats to writing about them. Now he may soon be out of that business.

title: NATO AGAIN PLANS POSSIBLE AIR RAIDS ON SERBS IN BOSNIA
description: Members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization voted today in Brussels -- unanimously but with varying degrees of conviction -- for a broader but still highly conditional plan to use air strikes in the war in Bosnia.

title: Review/Opera; A 'Lucia' Motivated By Large-Scale Ideas
description: Francesca Zambello's production of "Lucia di Lammermoor" took something of a drubbing when it first appeared last season at the Metropolitan Opera. It is back for another try. The revival began with a performance on Monday night and there will be eight more this month and next. Its pretensions and wrongheadedness, I am afraid, survive intact.

title: For CBS, Longer Pregame Show But No N.F.L. Game to Telecast
description: CBS has escalated the network football wars by planning to continue televising its studio show, "The N.F.L. Today," despite having lost to the Fox Network the rights to National Football Conference games over the next four years.

title: SunTrust Banks Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: SunTrust Banks adopted FASB 115 on Dec. 31, 1993. As a result, total assets were increased by $ 1.2 billion at Dec. 31 to reflect the adjustment of investment securities to market value. The unrealized gain is not included in net income.SunTrust said that the results for 1992 were restated due to 1993 acquisitions accounted for as poolings-of-interest. It said that increased earnings per share were due to cost control, growth in fee income, a lower provision for loan losses and common stock repurchases that reduced the number of shares outstanding.

title: Boat in Oil Spill Had Faulty Cable, Crewman Says
description: The barge that fouled a beach in San Juan with 750,000 gallons of heavy oil on Friday was being towed then by a tugboat with a worn cable in need of replacement, a member of the tugboat crew said today.

title: Adrian Lambert, 84, A Thoracic Surgeon
description: Dr. Adrian Lambert, a chest surgeon and fourth-generation Manhattan physician, died on Friday at Roosevelt Hospital, where he was on the staff for more than 50 years. He was 84 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Bosnia's Legacy
description: In the end, the summit meeting President Clinton called to assure the future of NATO could not escape the alliance's past failures, and those of the United States as its leading power, in Bosnia.

title: Disarming Diplomacy in Ukraine
description: In a victory for its nuclear diplomacy, the Clinton Administration has persuaded Ukraine's leader to get rid of the nuclear arsenal he inherited from the Soviet Union. In agreeing to the deal, President Leonid Kravchuk recognized that Ukraine's nuclear legacy may be worth more converted into fuel than as arms. The chief concern now is that nationalists in the Ukrainian Parliament will find a way to block the pact.

title: Humbled Spanish Banker Responds
description: The ousted chairman of Spain's third-largest bank, Mario Conde, defended his management today and argued that intervention by the nation's central bank late last month had been unnecessary.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Associates Corp. of North America, Dallas, a unit of Ford Motor Co., is offering $300 million of 4.625 percent notes due in 1996 at 99.954 to yield 4.644 percent through Morgan Stanley. The noncallable issue is rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and AA- by Standard & Poor's Corp. and Duff & Phelps. * Federal Farm Credit Bank is offering $100 million of medium-term notes due in 1996 at 100 to yield 4.095 percent through Goldman, Sachs. The issue is callable in one year.

title: Review/Music; It's a Bird! It's a Plane! It's a Symphony!
description: The obvious question to be asked of Michael Daugherty's "Metropolis Symphony," played by the Baltimore Symphony on Sunday at Carnegie Hall, is whether it deserves to be called a symphony at all. Its five movements, each inspired by a character or situation in the Superman comics, have more the character of a suite of scherzos or lively overtures, or what are now called concert openers. Yet an American composer trying to make his living at orchestral music is hard pressed to write anything but concert openers, so the symphony's somewhat ad hoc character might be overlooked.

title: Self-Esteem and Friendship In a Factory on Death Row
description: The death row garment factory is humming at midday. Condemned murderers wield scissors and razor-sharp knives as they snip and finish piles of work pants at their sewing machines. A few chat at the coffee urn within relaxed sight of their caged-off guard.

title: A Time Editor Is Said to Get New York Magazine Offer
description: Kurt Andersen, an editor at large at Time magazine and a founding editor of Spy magazine, has been offered the job of editor of New York magazine, people at its parent company, K-III Magazines, said yesterday.

title: Emily Jordan Boxer, Television Producer, 65
description: Emily Jordan Boxer, a television producer who arranged book interviews for NBC television's "Today" show in the 1980's, died yesterday at New York Hospital. A resident of Manhattan and Amagansett, L.I., she was 65.

title: Karachi Journal; With Blood Tie Sundered, Blood Divides Bhuttos
description: "She tells a lot of lies, this daughter of mine," Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's mother said.

title: Illinois Jacquet: Still a Master, Still Learning
description: Illinois Jacquet is a short man with big hair, and when he hits the stage he's liable to do just about anything. He may dance a bit, or play puffy, billowing notes on his tenor saxophone. He may sing, or tell a joke. Or he'll bend backward, howling on the saxophone, waving his band on to bigger and bigger riffs. His performances -- part vaudeville, part music -- span a good portion of the century, and have a story to them.

title: Begging and Giving
description: Begging. Most people, especially in New York, are conflicted about begging. Panhandlers can be annoying, menacing or pitiable. They remind the rest of us of matters we'd rather ignore, from poverty and deprivation to mental illness and drug addiction. What to do when approached by beggars -- give them some loose change to help them, or withhold money to discourage them? And what of the desire of the rest of us to go about our lives free of hassle and guilt?

title: Camden Diocese Settles Sexual-Abuse Cases
description: Over the last three years, the Roman Catholic diocese of Camden, N.J., has paid at least $3.2 million to settle lawsuits charging sexual abuse by nine priests, it was reported yesterday.

title: Theater in Review
description: The Courtesan and the Eunuch 28th Street Theater 120 West 28th Street Manhattan Through Jan. 30 By Terry Bradberry; directed by Dan McKereghan; sets and costumes by Keven Lock; lighting by Christopher Caines; stage manager, Sonia Belochi. Presented by New Globe Productions. WITH: Blythe Baten, Jennifer Fleming, Eleonora Kihlberg, John Marino and Paolo Seganti.

title: Review/Film: Sure Fire; Living by Old West Code on a Modern Frontier
description: "Sure Fire," Jon Jost's scathing character study of an ambitious land developer in the rural part of Utah that has been called the Mormon Dixie, might as well have been called "The Last American Patriarch." The film's central character, Wes, who is portrayed by Tom Blair with the intensity of a coiled cobra about to strike, isn't just any old modern-day frontiersman. He is presented as the grimly self-righteous and puritanical embodiment of primitive code of values in which the meaning of life is defined by the ritual of the deer hunt.

title: Ireland to Lift Radio-TV Ban on Speakers From I.R.A. Wing
description: The Irish Government said today that it would rescind the 20-year-old regulation that has prevented representatives of Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, from speaking on television and radio.

title: Market Place; Changes at Reliance Group seem to be overcoming bad memories.
description: CAN leopards change their spots? Securities dealers on Wall Street seem to think so, at least in the case of the Reliance Group Holdings, an insurance company controlled by Saul P. Steinberg.

title: Foley's Lawyers Argue Against Limits on Terms
description: Waving pocket-sized copies of the Constitution, lawyers argued in Federal court here today over whether voters can set term limits for members of Congress. The case, brought by Representative Thomas S. Foley against term limits in Washington State, is the first major legal challenge to state initiatives passed last year.

title: New Tack on Technology
description: Few subjects are closer to Vice President Al Gore's heart than developing an advanced communications network for the country, but on this matter the Administration has decided it is wiser to coax than to dictate.

title: The Pop Life
description: The twin-pronged assaults of grunge and hip-hop may have made significant commercial inroads in the pop marketplace in 1993, but in the final tally of the year's best-selling records, adult contemporary music more than held its own.

title: Long Road to Harvard for a South Bronx Youth
description: Rey Ramos stood in front of the two dozen seniors in the dimly lighted classroom of his old high school, James Monroe, in the South Bronx. He had not returned just to see friends; he had an important message about expectations and goals for students whose odds of graduating on time are only one in four, students who are searched daily for weapons.

title: Receiver Jackson Fears Slight by Simms
description: He is, without question, a solid and talented receiver. But by all accounts, the confidence level of Mark Jackson right now is low.

title: Edward Duke, Actor, 40
description: Edward Duke, a British actor who appeared on Broadway, died on Saturday in London. He was 40.

title: Movie Shows How Nazis Dehumanized Jews; Spielberg's Mastery
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Examining Reeves's Reasoning
description: LET us pause in the deification of Dan Reeves and Phil Simms, get off our knees if only to stretch, and at least consider the question of whether Reeves chose the right quarterback to remain with the Giants.

title: Change Seen at Conde Nast
description: Steven T. Florio, president and chief executive of The New Yorker, is expected to be named president of Conde Nast Publications later this month, succeeding Bernard Leser, who is expected to retire after 35 years with the company, according to published reports.

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column in Business Day on Monday, about Viacom Inc.'s new offer for Paramount Communications Inc., referred incorrectly to the stock part of the offer. It includes Viacom's nonvoting class B shares, not the voting class A shares.

title: Theater in Review
description: How Far to Jaisalmeer? Theater for the New City 155 First Avenue, at 10th Street East Village Through Jan. 23 By Martin Worth; directed by Bina Sharif; lighting by Paul Smithyman; set by Kevin Martin; stage manager, Dawn Spring. Presented by Theater for the New City, George Bartenieff, executive director; Crystal Field, executive artistic director. WITH: Mohamed Djellouli, Marilyn Gholson, Hesh Malkar, Emmett McConnell, Christopher Nissley, John Edwin Payne, Bina Sharif, Wonderly White and Jemima Yorke.

title: Westinghouse to Lay Off 3,400, Cut Dividend
description: In his first major action as chairman of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, Michael H. Jordan cut the dividend in half yesterday and announced a pretax charge of $750 million to cover the costs of laying off 3,400 employees, selling operations and settling legal disputes.

title: Advertising; Absolut Switch: Image Maker to Sell Rival Vodka
description: It's vodka with a twist. And vodka marketing with a vengeance.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: A New Tabasco

title: Gore Outlines Data Highway Policy
description: Outlining the Clinton Administration's formal policy for the telecommunications industry, Vice President Al Gore said today that the Adminstration would propose legislation that would create a new regulatory structure to insure open access to a new world of information services.

title: New President For Atlantic
description: Danny Goldberg, who joined Atlantic Records in 1992 as senior vice president, was named president yesterday of the label, which is a division of the Atlantic Group.

title: Bronx Proves What a Publicly Run Open-Air Market Can Do
description: To the Editor:

title: Accounts
description: * Bakers Square Restaurants, Matteson, Ill., to Tatham Euro RSCG, Chicago, to handle the chain's account, previously at CME KHBB Advertising, Chicago. Tatham was awarded the account, with billings estimated at $8 million, without a review. * United Parcel Service, Atlanta, to Brierley & Partners, Dallas, as the first agency to handle direct marketing aimed at the delivery company's special customer segments. Though billings were not disclosed, Adweek estimated them at $5 million to $10 million.

title: Mellon Wins an Eclipse
description: PAUL MELLON, owner of the Kentucky Derby winner Sea Hero, won the Eclipse Award of Merit yesterday for his contributions to thoroughbred racing. When Sea Hero won a $1 million bonus for collecting the most points from the Triple Crown races, Mellon donated the money to the Grayson Jockey Club Research Foundation. (AP)

title: Wine Talk
description: In matters of food and drink, the southwestern part of France, commonly known as Gascony, is enjoying a wave of popularity here in the capital.

title: Erica Wallach, 71, A Prisoner of Soviets In Cold War Intrigue
description: Erica Glaser Wallach, who spent five years in Communist prisons at the height of the cold war on espionage charges that the Soviet authorities later said were false, died on Dec. 22 in Fauquier Hospital in Warrenton, Va. She was 71.

title: Editorial Notebook; Rascals to the Rescue
description: The law of supply and demand is constantly flouted at my local video library. I've got the machine at home; I've got the money to rent the videos; what's lacking is anything worth taking home for the kids.

title: Some Seizures Tied To Flashing Lights
description: A YOUNG woman is transfixed by the pulsating strobe lights at a discotheque and suffers a seizure.

title: Succession Questions For Lilco
description: Anthony F. Earley Jr., who helped guide the Long Island Lighting Company through a rocky period after it shut down its Shoreham Nuclear Power Station, has resigned as president to take the same position with the Detroit Edison Company.

title: Abduction Suspect's Moves Receiving Multistate Scrutiny
description: As the parents of 12-year-old Sara Anne Wood joined the grim search for her body today in a snowswept area of the Adirondacks, investigators here said the suspect in her disappearance in August had become the object of a multistate investigation into child abductions as far back as 1990.

title: Paramount's Advisers Said To Be Favoring Bid by QVC
description: Advisers to the board of Paramount Communications Inc. are strongly leaning toward urging acceptance of QVC Network Inc.'s takeover bid over the latest offer from Viacom Inc., a person close to the Paramount board said last night.

title: Witnesses Say Mutilated Man Often Hit Wife
description: A series of witnesses for Lorena L. Bobbitt, the 24-year-old manicurist charged in the cutting off of her husband's penis, testified today that John W. Bobbitt, 26, boasted of enjoying brutal forced sex with women and repeatedly hit her, pulled her hair and threw her against the wall before she maimed him.

title: Star Banc Corp. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Star Banc said that its results reflected strong growth in both net interest income and fee income, tight controls over noninterest expenses and a lower loan loss provision due to a reduction in the level of charge-offs and a decrease in the level of nonperforming loans.

title: Mozambique Working Hard to Build Its Future
description: To the Editors:

title: Herzog Resigns As General Manager
description: WHITEY HERZOG resigned as general manager of the California Angels yesterday and was replaced by BILL BAVASI. Herzog, 62, submitted his resignation, effective Saturday. He will remain as a consultant.

title: Bridge
description: Dictionaries rarely have photographs, and one with cartoons may be unique. The Bridge-Player's Dictionary has both, and also 1,400 terms, both technical and colloquial. It is a 280-page hard-cover book, obtainable for $22.95, including shipping, from Baron-Barclay Bridge Supplies, (800) 274-2221.

title: CHRONICLE
description: After what was described as a long spiritual journey, the DUCHESS OF KENT is leaving the Church of England to become a Roman Catholic. Historians said her conversion was unprecedented for a member of Britain's royal family, according to news reports from London.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday, about a steep drop in prices at the Mexican stock exchange, referred incorrectly to a record set on Monday by a larger percentage decline. That drop -- 166 points in the exchange's index, amounting to 6.32 percent -- was the biggest percentage loss in more than four years, not six.

title: Military Court Assails Navy in Ruling on Tailhook
description: The nation's highest military court today rejected the appeal of a Navy aviator who is trying to avoid trial on charges that he was involved in the Tailhook sexual harassment scandal. But in strikingly strong language, the court accused the Navy of displaying a "careless and amateurish approach" to the case.

title: Encouraging Schoolgirls to Enter a Mostly Male World
description: A gasp rose from the audience of 300 Long Island schoolgirls when Cynthia Burrows, a chemistry professor, projected the slide onto the screen.

title: Premier Bancorp Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 43,921,000, or $ 1.57 a share, from change in accounting for income taxes.c-Included an extraordinary tax benefit of $ 4,412,000, or 16 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 9,952,000, or 37 cents a share, in the year.

title: Personal Health
description: IN the seven years prior to May 1992, Dr. Loren M. Fishman, a New York specialist in rehabilitation medicine, had treated 34 patients with a form of sciatica called piriformis syndrome, his special research interest.

title: Consumer, Beware of Banking 'Reform'
description: To the Editor:

title: The Bankruptcy Business Hits Hard Times
description: The legions of lawyers, accountants and investment bankers who have made good livings in the last few years working out the bad-debt cases of the 80's are about to face their worst fears: the bankruptcy business is going bust.

title: Scoring Is Down but Fights Are Flourishing
description: As the National Hockey League regular-season schedule reaches the midway point, some trends are becoming clear. Scoring is down, fighting is up, suspensions are numerous, expansion is a success, labor-management relations are touchy, key injuries are plentiful. And whatever happened to Gil Stein? Pleasant Surprises

title: MERCEDES-BENZ TO ELIMINATE FEWER JOBS
description: Mercedes-Benz said yesterday that it would cut 8,000 jobs this year, rather than the 14,000 that it announced in August. "The reason is that many more employees than expected have taken up the offer of early retirement in 1993," a company spokesman said. That allowed the company to cut 11,400 jobs last year, instead of 8,400 as planned. The auto maker also agreed last month with German unions to freeze layoffs in return for more flexibility on working hours.

title: National Medical Enterprises Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included $ 13,576,000 in pretax gains in the quarter and $ 28,975,000 in the 6 months on disposals of facilities and long-term investments. The periods also included losses from discontinued operations of $ 287,371,000, or $ 1.73 a share, in the quarter and $ 441 million, or $ 2.66 a share, in the 6 months. The 6 months was also after a gain of $ 60,121,000, or 36 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.c-Net income and included $ 39,932,000 in pretax gains in the quarter and $ 42,730,000 in the 6 months on disposals of facilities and long-term investments. The periods also included losses from discontinued operations of $ 25,651,000, or 15 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 25,411,000, or 15 cents a share, in the 6 months.The 1992 periods have been restated to reflect the psychiatric hospital business as a discontinued operation.(Loss)

title: New York State Police Chief May Get Top U.S. Drug Post
description: Thomas A. Constantine, the superintendent of the New York State Police, has emerged as the leading candidate to run the Drug Enforcement Administration, the Federal agency responsible for fighting the war on drugs, Clinton Administration officials said today.

title: Seagate Technology (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a pretax charge of $ 1.3 million for the completion of the acquisition of Caltex Software Inc. in the quarter and 6 months.

title: Leader to Quit Post-Riot Panel In Los Angeles
description: In the latest upheaval for the riot-recovery effort here, Rebuild L. A., the group's chief operating officer said today that he would announce his resignation on Wednesday as part of a revamping of the organization.

title: Seaway Food Town (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $ 256,000, or 11 cents a share, from a tax accounting change.c-Net income(Loss)

title: Movie Shows How Nazis Dehumanized Jews; A Danish 'Schindler'?
description: To the Editor:

title: House Inquiry Is Urged On Clintons' Land Deals
description: The leading Republican critic of President Clinton's involvement in a failed Arkansas real estate venture said today that even if the Administration installed a special counsel to investigate, he would press for a separate Congressional inquiry.

title: Black Coaches Threaten a Boycott of Basketball
description: A rapidly escalating dispute between black coaches and leaders of higher education approached the confrontation stage today, with the coaches threatening to boycott college basketball games as a result of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's decision not to add a 14th scholarship to its Division I men's teams.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Seeking to honor those who have worked for ethnic unity, the Greater Harlem Chamber of Commerce will give its Living the Dream awards to six people on Thursday night as part of its celebration of Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday.

title: Chief of Teamsters Union Ousts A Leader of a Powerful Local
description: Ron Carey, the head of the international teamsters' union, yesterday ousted the leader of a powerful New York City local whom a Mafia defector had identified as a major mob associate in the union's airline employees division.

title: Whitewater, and Other Thin Ice
description: When Danny Ferguson denied in an affidavit that President Clinton had offered him and other Arkansas troopers Federal jobs for covering up trysts that occurred when he was Governor, most of us were relieved. This had been the most troubling element in the stories of sexual scandal in The American Spectator and Los Angeles Times.

title: Memorial for Shirer
description: A memorial service for the author William L. Shirer is to be held on Saturday at 2 P.M. at the Church on the Hill, Main Street, Lenox, Mass. Mr. Shirer, author of "The Rise and Fall of the Third Reich," died on Dec. 28 at the age of 89. The historian James MacGregor Burns, a friend of the author, will speak at the service, which is open to the public.

title: Cogeco Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Reiner G. Stoll, 80, Scientist Who Led Research in Textiles
description: Dr. Reiner G. Stoll, a retired business executive, scientist and inventor, died on Thursday while vacationing in La Jolla, Calif. He was 80 and lived in Sherman, Conn.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Protesting Changes, Leader Steps Down At Cold-War Radios
description: The president of Radio Free Europe-Radio Liberty, William W. Marsh, has resigned, criticizing a plan to move the stations that were created in the cold war from Munich to Prague.

title: Ornda Healthcorp (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Revenue represented total revenue.

title: Red Tape Leaves Owner Only Part of Her House
description: ALL Catalina Lopez wants is to gain possession of the second floor of the tiny house she owns so she and her 33-year-old paraplegic son can each have a bedroom.

title: Collective Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 2,642,000, or 13 cents a share, from the adoption of SFAS 109.Year-ago per share earnings for both the quarter and 6 months were restated to give effect to the 3-for-2 stock split effected in July 1993.Collective Bancorp. attributed its higher earnings in the latest quarter and 6 months to an increase in the level of net interest income generated by its core banking activities. Net interest income for the latest quarter was $ 34,097,000, compared with $ 26,203,000 in year-ago period.The compant also attributed its ''record earnings'' to an increase in other income, which included fee income generated by its loan servicing and deposit activities and gains on the sale of loans and securities. For the quarter, other income totaled $ 4,304,000, compared with $ 2,355,000 in year-ago quarter.

title: UKRAINE HESITATES ON NUCLEAR DEAL
description: The Ukrainian Government, taking a markedly more reserved approach to the agreement President Clinton announced on eliminating Ukraine's nuclear weapons, said today that the accord was still under discussion and might not be signed in Moscow on Friday.

title: Cut Bowe Cancels Bout
description: RIDDICK BOWE, the former heavyweight champion, was cut while sparring yesterday, forcing the cancellation of his scheduled Feb. 5 bout in Las Vegas, Nev., against FRANCOIS BOTHA of South Africa. Bowe required 10 stitches to close the cut, which occurred during a sparring session in Washington, said a Caesars Palace spokeswoman, DEBBIE MUNCH. Munch said she was not sure where Bowe was cut in sparring. (AP)

title: Public & Private; Hillary Rodham Candor
description: It is the end of Hillary Rodham Clinton's first year in office. That description alone illustrates how successful she has been at transforming the notion of how the spouse of the President can serve the nation.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DONNELLEY MARKETING INC., Stamford, Conn., purchased FDC Inc., a data base and computer mailing service provider, from Fingerhut Inc., Minnetonka, Minn., a mail order and direct marketing company. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Loan Expert Leaves Post At Chemical
description: Darla D. Moore, the banker who pioneered the profitable business of lending to bankrupt companies, said yesterday that she had resigned from the Chemical Bank.

title: Low-Fat Diets: How Low to Go?
description: THE mantra for the 90's is "Eat more, weigh less," but diet experts are starting to ask questions about this latest in a long line of magic bullets intended to take off weight painlessly.

title: Prudential Hearings To Proceed
description: Rejecting objections from state securities regulators, a Federal judge in New Orleans yesterday ordered that hearings proceed on Prudential Securities' biggest class-action settlement stemming from the fraud scandal at the firm.

title: New Mayor Tests Magic of the Airwaves
description: Some staff salaries still have not been set. And governing initiatives seem weeks away. But less than two weeks into office, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has quickly adapted to one aspect of the job: the image-age possibilities of talk radio and late-night television for selling himself directly to the public.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: The Party's Over, for Now

title: CHRONICLE
description: Talk radio, hardly the most mellow of media, is about to become a bit more edgy. EDMUND G. BROWN JR., the former California Governor, sometime Presidential candidate and longtime gadfly, will soon jangle the airwaves with his own nationally syndicated radio show.

title: Irving Goodman, 68, an Executive For Two Book Publishers, Is Dead
description: Irving Goodman, a former president of Viking Penguin and former head of the trade-books division of Holt, Rinehart & Winston, died on Monday at New York University Medical Center. He was 68 and lived on the Upper East Side.

title: In This Tournament, 2 Is Better Than 1+1
description: Some members of the Senior PGA Tour say they want to leave the Mercedes Championships at the La Costa Resort and Spa and start their own version of the annual season-opening tournament of champions.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Young Gives Fox a Moving Target
description: It was not a pretty picture as Mike Fox hurled his 285-pound frame at Jim McMahon last Sunday and bear-hugged the quarterback into helplessness. Along came Keith Hamilton to deliver the blow that led to a concussion.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday, about new allegations of fraud in the limited partnership scandal at Prudential Securities, misstated the given name of the lead lawyer in a class action against the firm. He is Edward Grossmann, not Stanley.

title: Phoumi Vongvichit, 84, Is Dead; Laotian Was Lifelong Communist
description: Phoumi Vongvichit, a Communist leader who helped guide Laos on its route from colonial rule to independence as a Communist state, died on Friday. He was 84.

title: Books of The Times; Reflections on Endings And Family Secrets
description: Diary of a Lost Boy By Harry Kondoleon 183 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $20. Decorations in a Ruined Cemetery By John Gregory Brown 244 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $19.95

title: Carnegie Announces 1994-95 Season
description: The conclusion of a two-year Mahler cycle, performances by the Vienna Philharmonic under Sir Georg Solti and the London Symphony Orchestra led by Pierre Boulez, and a series in which Emanuel Ax and friends will explore orchestral, chamber and solo works by Brahms and Schoenberg are among the highlights of Carnegie Hall's 1994-95 season.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: SKIING Aamodt Beats Course Kjetil-Andre Aamodt of Norway produced his two best runs of the season yesterday on the longest and toughest giant slalom course on the World Cup circuit, at Hinterstoder, Austria, and scored his first victory of the season. Aamodt's performance widened his overall World Cup lead. He had a winning aggregate time of 2 minutes 49.63 seconds on the Baerenalm Hoess slope, which had a vertical drop of 440 yards with 62 gates in the first run and 65 in the second. Aamodt held an edge of 0.71 seconds over Christian Mayer heading into the second heat. (AP) TENNIS Sampras Wins Easily The defending champion, Pete Sampras, beat Jonas Svensson of Sweden, 6-4, 6-2, in an opening-round match in the New South Wales Open yesterday in Sydney, Australia. Andrei Medvedev, seeded second, was forced out by a knee injury, which could keep him from this year's first Grand Slam tournament, the Australian Open, which begins Monday. His place in the main draw was taken by Jamie Morgan of Australia, who defeated Marc Goellner of Germany by 6-1, 7-6 (7-4). Richey Reneberg turned in a surprise by eliminating eighth-seeded Karel Novacek of the Czech Republic by 6-1, 6-3. (AP)

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: 49er Tension Is High Where Seifert Roams
description: George Seifert was a zoology major in college, and this is some zoo he has got himself into. The San Francisco 49ers are either in the Super Bowl, or in ruins, and they are now almost four years between Lombardi Trophies. Defeats can be traced to Joe Montana's rickety elbow or to Steve Young's eccentricity or to Eddie DeBartolo's decision to shut the bank vault, but, recently, blame has been put at the doormat of Seifert, the head coach.

title: Movie Shows How Nazis Dehumanized Jews
description: To the Editor:

title: Price of Heating Oil Climbs As Cold Weather Lingers
description: Heating oil prices surged yesterday, leading crude oil prices higher, as the continuing cold snap in the Northeast pushed up demand and raised hopes that bulging stockpiles would start to decrease.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption on Jan. 3 in the special Outlook '94 issue of Business Day, about new technologies, misidentified a company in Westborough, Mass., that produces superconducting materials. It is the American Superconductor Corporation, not American Superconducting.

title: Swarthmore Would Pay Student if He Transfers
description: To resolve a sexual harassment complaint that deadlocked its disciplinary committee, Swarthmore College has offered to pay for the accused student to attend another college for the spring semester.

title: People
description: * Steve Troy, president at Ketchum Directory Advertising, New York, was promoted to the new position of chairman. John Joseph, executive vice president of strategic planning, was promoted to president, succeeding Mr. Troy. * Allan Winneker, president and chief executive at Wunderman Cato Johnson, Chicago, was named to the additional new position of president of Wunderman's North America division, overseeing units in Chicago; Detroit; Newport Beach, Calif.; Rochester, and Toronto.

title: Getting Down: The Take-a-Deduction-to-Lunch-Bunch Blues
description: THE business lunch once seemed so blithely simple. Shepherd some clients to a nice restaurant, order a steak and a few highballs, make a couple of deals, gossip over the cheesecake. Hand a charge card to the waiter after barely glancing at the check.

title: Sitting Down With Syria
description: The meeting this Sunday in Geneva between President Clinton and President Hafez al-Assad of Syria once again reminds Americans that Mr. Assad is a major player in Middle East peace making.

title: SEQUENT PLANS FOURTH-QUARTER CHARGE
description: Sequent Computer Systems Inc. said yesterday that it would set up two new divisions and take a fourth-quarter charge of $15 million to $20 million. The charge will pay for eliminating about 5 percent of the company's jobs and writing off some assets. Sequent, which is based in Beaverton, Ore., employed 1,640 people at the end of the third quarter.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: LEADING CANDIDATE FOR D.E.A. POST

title: Bratton Urges a Shared Covenant of Reverence for Law
description: Police Commissioner William J. Bratton appealed yesterday for "a new covenant" between the police and the community in which both "share the same reverence for the law."

title: BanPonce Corp. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Gay Rights Advocates Brace for Ballot Fights
description: Gay rights advocates are facing a record number of state ballot initiatives this year that would forbid laws specifically protecting homosexuals from discrimination.

title: Survival at Ground Zero: For the Hard-Core Homeless, Life at 15 Degrees
description: The vast sheet of ice under the Brooklyn Bridge was smooth and still Monday night on the streets of lower Manhattan. A rat had been trapped and frozen in the amber of the glacier, and the only sign of life was the distant rumble of traffic far above.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Company News page of Business Day yesterday, about the Gillette Company's plan to eliminate 2,000 jobs, referred incorrectly to the distribution of the cutbacks. The company said most would occur outside the United States, not just in Europe.

title: Synovus Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $ 2,912,000, or a loss of 4 cents a share, from a charge related to early extinguishment of debt.

title: Yield A-Test Data, U.S. Is Told
description: In a public meeting with Energy Secretary Hazel R. O'Leary, environmentalists, doctors, scientists and critics of the United States' nuclear testing programs called today for the release of thousands of classified documents that describe the Government's nuclear activities since the 1940's.

title: With One-Party Control, No Top Democrat to Fault
description: The 206th New Jersey Legislature settled into the 120 seats in the Senate and Assembly today, with Republicans once again in control of both legislative houses. But those seats lack one cushion the Republicans have had the last two years: a Democratic chief executive who can be blamed for problems.

title: New Chief Is Named at Phillips Petroleum
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company announced today that Wayne Allen, its president and chief operating officer for the last two years, will become chairman and chief executive on May 1.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-9 BROADER BOSNIA DEFENSE PLAN NATO voted to broaden the plan for the use of air strikes in Bosnia, but it is still highly conditional and some officials say they fear it is another case of words without weight. A1 BALKANS OVERSHADOWED SUMMIT News analysis: Despite the United States' intention to focus discussion on its plans for Eastern Europe, in the end the NATO summit meeting could not escape the past failures to deal with the Balkan crisis. A8

title: School Board Gives Parents Power to Veto Condoms to Children
description: In a decision that appeared to signal the end of a bitter three-year struggle, the New York City Board of Education voted yesterday to modify its program of distributing condoms on demand to students in high schools by allowing parents to prohibit their children from participating in the program.

title: Lukas Is Out of a Coma
description: The trainer JEFF LUKAS is out of a coma and has been moved to a private room in a hospital, a family spokeswoman said yesterday.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Football National Football League INDIANAPOLIS COLTS -- Fired Dwain Painter, receivers coach.

title: International Paper Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included charge of $ 25 million, or 20 cents a share, to revalue deferred tax balances resulting from the increase in the U.S. statutory federal income tax rate.c-After an extraordinary charge to cover costs associated with a productivity improvement program change of $ 263,000,000, or $ 2.17 a share, in the quarter and the year, the year also included a charge of $ 6,000,000, or 5 cents a share, for extinguishment of debt and a charge from the cumulative effect of change in accounting for income taxes of $ 50,000,000, or 41 cents a share.d-Net loss(Loss)

title: Ignorance of the Law Can Be an Excuse, Justices Rule
description: People who keep their cash transactions with banks to under $10,000 to evade Federal reporting requirements cannot be convicted without proof that they knew such action is illegal, the Supreme Court ruled today.

title: Polian to Panthers?
description: BILL POLIAN, a two-time National Football League executive of the year who built the Buffalo Bills from losers into a three-time Super Bowl team, will become general manager of the the Carolina Panthers, according to newspaper and television reports. The Charlotte Observer and WBTV-TV said the Panthers owner, JERRY RICHARDSON, has called a news conference for today to announce Polian's hiring and the elevation of the current general manager, MIKE McCORMACK, to the new position of team president. (AP)

title: Mixed White House Signals on Prosecutor
description: The Clinton Administraton issued a stream of confusing signals today in the face of intensifying pressure from Senate Democrats to appoint an special prosecutor to examine President Clinton's past business dealings with the owner of a failed Arkansas savings and loan.

title: Review/Jazz; Veteran Drummer Returns, With a Multitude of Friends
description: In the late 1960's, the drummer Pete (LaRoca) Sims quit jazz to become a lawyer. He made one classic album on Blue Note records in 1965, "Basra," and worked with Sonny Rollins, Jackie McLean and others, but then he fell off the face of the jazz world. Over the last decade or so he has been making appearances, and recently has led a fine group recruited from a revolving band of musicians. He had been working at Yardbird Suite; the club went under, and now he will be leading his band every Monday night for the next several months at Down Beat, a new club at 70 Grove Street, at Seventh Avenue South.

title: Officer Wounded and Man Is Killed in East New York
