title: U.N. Chief Dismisses Top-Ranking Aide From U.S.
description: After months of barely concealed disagreements, Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali has dismissed the highest-ranking American official at the United Nations, Administration officials said today.

title: Temple of Dendur Opens Front Porch
description: For 15 long years, those who sought to visit the Temple of Dendur were forced to worship from afar.

title: NORTHWEST AIRLINES PLANS A STOCK OFFERING
description: The Northwest Airlines Corporation said yesterday that it had filed an initial public offering of 20 million common shares that would raise about $400 million of new equity in the first quarter. Northwest, the nation's fourth-largest airline, has been struggling under the $3 billion of debt remaining from its 1989 leveraged buyout. The airline had been widely expected to raise additional capital since late July, when it won $886 million of wage and benefit cuts from its employees over three years.

title: 1972 Davis Cup Case Reopened
description: The United States Tennis Association is reconsidering its decision to strip Dennis Ralston of his 1972 Davis Cup captaincy 20 years after the fact.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-6 ISRAELIS WARNED ON SYRIAN PEACE Yitzhak Rabin told Israelis that peace with Syria might require them to pay a more "painful price" than they expect in territorial concessions on the Golan Heights. A1 TOWNSHIPS TO LOSE POLICE UNITS South Africa is withdrawing its security units from the townships and squatter camps east of Johannesburg that are the center of the country's worst factional violence. A3

title: THE EARTHQUAKE: The Overview; Tallying Losses From Quake, Los Angeles Stirs and Hopes
description: A day after the deadliest earthquake in two decades struck the city, the people of Los Angeles began to tally the devastation around them today, even as they struggled to calm the tremors within themselves.

title: Why N.A.A.C.P. Won't Disown Nation of Islam
description: To the Editor:

title: Agent Says Raid on Cult Had Flaws
description: A Federal agent testified today that the raiding party serving arrest warrants on the Branch Davidian compound outside Waco, Tex., was ambushed, but he acknowledged significant flaws in the planning of the raid.

title: Executive Changes
description: CMS ENHANCE INC., Irvine, Calif., appointed Peter D. Lytle senior vice president for operations. COGNITRONICS CORP., Danbury, Conn., a maker of voice-processing equipment, appointed Brian J. Kelley president and chief executive.

title: CRANE OFFERS TO BUY MARK CONTROLS FOR $13 A SHARE
description: The Crane Company proposed yesterday to buy out the Mark Controls Corporation, a manufacturer of industrial valves, for $13 a share in cash, or $56.6 million. The offer could be sweetened, Crane said, and Mark's stock soared to $13.875, up $2.625, or 23 percent. Crane already owns about 13.2 percent of the shares outstanding of Mark, which is based in Skokie, Ill. Crane, a maker of engineered industrial products, is based in Stamford, Conn. Representatives of the two companies are to meet next week to discuss financial information, Crane said.

title: The Final 4 Emerge Through Hard Work
description: It is a one-shot deal now, a shoot-for-the-top, all-or-nothing battle in each conference championship game on Sunday. It is where all 28 National Football League teams hoped to be when they dived into free agency during the off season seeking the right mix, began grueling training camps back in July and then embarked on the regular season.

title: Review/Film; Business of Abduction, Told by a Victim's Sister
description: "Secuestro: A Story of a Kidnapping," Camila Motta's documentary film about an abduction in Colombia, is really the story of an excruciatingly delicate, drawn-out business negotiation. There is no overt violence or melodrama in this laborious day-by-day account of the kidnapping of the film maker's 20-year-old sister, Sylvia, in 1985 by 10 armed men while she was on her way to school.

title: How to Aid the Victims
description: Interaction, a coalition of more that 150 not-for-profit American humanitarian aid groups, has issued this list of agencies to which money may be sent to help earthquake victims in the Los Angeles area:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: KEYSTONE FINANCIAL INC. , Harrisburg, Pa., signed a definitive agreement to acquire Frankford Corp., Horsham, Pa., for $132 million in stock. SAGE TECHNOLOGIES INC., Stamford, Conn., signed an agreement to acquire CBM Inc., a computer reseller based in Lexington, Ky., for a combination of cash and stock. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Bentsen Seeks Freer Asian Markets
description: Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen today laid out the Clinton Administration's strategy for gaining access to foreign markets for American financial service companies, which say they are being shut out of some of the world's biggest emerging economies.

title: Food Notes
description: New Carryout Shop

title: THE IRAN-CONTRA REPORT: News Analysis; The Inquiry That Couldn't
description: The Iran-contra affair was a serious constitutional scandal, but its gravity was obscured by the prolonged and ultimately unsuccessful prosecution and by the Congressional investigation seven years ago, which turned into a political sideshow.

title: Cowboys Going From a 'Headache' to the 'Flu'
description: If the Dallas Cowboys are to beat the San Francisco 49ers Sunday for the National Conference championship and a Super Bowl berth -- and the Cowboys are favored -- they must control the 49ers' passing game. And that means putting the reins on Jerry Rice, perhaps the best receiver in National Football League history; John Taylor, perhaps the most underrated wide receiver in pro football; Steve Young, perhaps the best quarterback going; a wise, veteran offensive line and a few other assets. Did we forget Ricky Watters's running?

title: People
description: * Tom Quinn was named to the new position of director of marketing services at McAdams, Richman & Ong, Bala-Cynwyd, Pa. He was previously president at DeDonato, Gladstone & Quinn, Wilmington, Del.

title: Reviews/Music; Purcell, Faure and Rorem, As Sung by a Countertenor
description: In a remarkable recital on Monday night at the Walter Reade Theater, Brian Asawa showed the kind of pure, effortless countertenor voice that comes along only once in a long while. It is hard to convey the uncanny effect of his full, fluid, lustrous tone, poised in the extreme upper register without the slightest strain. Close your eyes for a moment, and you would think you were hearing a mezzo-soprano.

title: Inquiry Into S.& L. Reconvenes
description: A Federal grand jury looking into the collapse of a failed savings and loan association reconvened today in Little Rock, Ark. There was no indication that it heard any evidence about the ties between the association and President Clinton's land development company.

title: Eating Well
description: THERE are a lot of people who think that all Italian food is good for you, even if it is swimming in olive oil.

title:
Downtown Renewal;
Education Gives Store A New Life
description: After six years of vacancy, a downtown building here that since the 1920's housed a leading department store is being redeveloped as a center for higher education.

title: We Minimize Lyme Disease at Our Peril; Cooperation Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: Change at Ailey Foundation
description: Barbara Hauptman has been named executive director of Dance Theater Foundation Inc., which administers the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater and the Ailey school and junior company. Ms. Hauptman was formerly director of the Bardavon 1869 Opera House in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. She was also director of the Twyla Tharp Dance Foundation and worked with the Theater Development Fund, New York State Council on the Arts, the Williamstown Theater Festival and Saatchi & Saatchi Compton Inc. She succeeds Michael M. Kaiser, who will return to Kaiser Planning Group, a consulting firm.

title: The Pop Life
description: Hall of Fame

title: Old Kent Financial (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NATIONSBANK CORP. (N)
description: The Nationsbank Corporation, the country's third-largest banking com pany, said its profit in the fourth quarter was $373 million, up 59 percent from the comparable period a year earlier.

title: PROCTER & GAMBLE TO PHASE OUT CLARION COSMETICS
description: The Procter & Gamble Company of Cincinnati said yesterday that it would begin an immediate phaseout of its small, unprofitable Clarion cosmetics brand in the United States and Canada. The consumer products giant said the move would allow it to focus on building its Cover Girl and Max Factor International brands. The phaseout would not affect earnings and would have minimal impact on employment at the cosmetics and fragrances operation, the company said.

title: Keystone Financial Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Esiason Says News Media Spurred Coslet's Dismissal
description: Quarterback Boomer Esiason said yesterday that he thought Bruce Coslet, dismissed as Jets coach 12 days ago, was done in by a news media campaign and that the real story behind Coslet's departure has not come out.

title: Russian Impasse Sets Off a Ruble Panic
description: As the ruble plummeted to new lows and ordinary Russians lined up to exchange them for dollars, President Boris N. Yeltsin and his Prime Minister apparently failed to agree today on a new Government, leaving the future of the reformist Finance Minister in doubt.

title: Cuomo Calls For Tax Cuts For Business
description: In an election year in which the economy looms large as a campaign issue, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo proposed today what he described as a pro-business budget that would cut an array of business taxes, provide modest increases for education and anti-crime efforts and establish new restrictions on health-care services for the poor.

title: Dauphin Deposit (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Grounds May Exist To Remove Harding
description: The United States Figure Skating Association may have grounds to remove Tonya Harding from the Olympic team, even though she has not been charged in the attack on Nancy Kerrigan, legal experts said yesterday.

title: President Is Named By Biogen
description: Biogen yesterday named as president and chief operating officer James R. Tobin, who left Baxter International Inc. in a surprise resignation last month. Wall Street had long considered him a leading candidate to become Baxter's chief executive.

title: Memo About Phar-Mor Destroyed, Report Says
description: A confidential May 31, 1991, memorandum that raised questions about apparent irregularities in the way Phar-Mor Inc. was conducting its business was ordered destroyed by Phar-Mor's chairman and chief executive, David Shapira, only days after it was drafted, a report released yesterday shows.

title: Rosemary Glyde, 46, Violist and Composer
description: Rosemary Glyde, a violist who performed frequently as a recitalist and was a founder and president of the New York Viola Society, died on Tuesday at the Northern Westchester Medical Center in Mount Kisco. She was 46 and lived in Golden's Bridge, N.Y.

title: Houghton Mifflin reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included loss on extinguishment of debt of $ 1,002,000.c-Net lossd-Included loss on disposition of foreign publishing operations of $ 13,527,000 in the quarter and the year included cumulative effect of accounting changes: post retirement benefits of $ 1,300,000.(Loss)

title: THE EARTHQUAKE: The Victims; The Unthinkable Occurs: Homelessness
description: Elizabeth Thomas has watched the homeless walk the streets of this city, carrying everything they own in a plastic bag. Never did she think she would be among them.

title: Lamson & Sessions Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: b-Included non-recurring charges of $ 9,642,000 in both the quarter and year.c-Included a charge of $ 26,860,000, or $ 2.04 a share, from an accounting adjustment for post-retirement benefits(Loss)

title: Egypt Seizes 60 Militants
description: Police and security forces raided a string of fundamentalist strongholds here in southern Cairo today, arresting at least 60 suspects in the biggest security dragnet in more than a year. In a gun battle after commandos stormed an apartment seeking fugitives, Interior Ministry officials said, a police officer and one militant were killed and one militant was wounded.

title: Revlon's Chairman Donates $10 Million To the Guggenheim
description: Barely four weeks after announcing that its landmark Frank Lloyd Wright building would be named in honor of the developer Samuel J. LeFrak and his wife, Ethel, the donors of $10 million, the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum said yesterday that it had received another gift of $10 million, from the financier Ronald O. Perelman.

title: Luminous Art That Softens a Subway
description: IT'S not the subway station to heaven. But the Matissean blues of the stained-glass triptych recently installed at a station in the Bronx may make many commuters think they've entered one.

title: Antiques Row Thrives Anew On East 60th
description: IT couldn't have worked out better if someone had planned it. If there are natural laws governing the creation of a full-fledged antiques district, they have certainly been at work on East 60th Street between Second and Third avenues.

title: House Proud
description: A TANNED woman backs away, hands put out to stop, as gently as a Bermudian traffic cop's, but alarm is closing in on her face. Seated on steps, a man with his eyes closed opens his mouth to speak. A young girl, head bowed, stands caught, before them, like a breath in the throat. It is the pause between a child's excuses and the parents' rebuke, when the great secret lesson of adolescence begins: you may be right; they may be wrong. The scene is a photograph, "The Conversation," by Tina Barney.

title: Colleagues Are as Much Baffled by the Way Inman Withdrew
description: In the end, Bobby Ray Inman simply did not want to be Secretary of Defense badly enough.

title: Topics of The Times; Fur Piece
description: There is a mystery bookstore in New York City that has as its featured attraction not a reading nook, not coffee on the house, not a remainder rack but a cat. This cat is the color of ginger and the size of a house. Weigh this baby and we're talking two digits.

title: Rebels in Colombia Kidnap 2 U.S. Missionaries
description: Left-wing guerrillas have kidnapped two American Protestant pastors from their rural mission 50 miles southeast of here, apparently in protest against United States military aid to Colombia.

title: INSIDE
description: Bentsen Warns China

title: Frank Carpenter, 91, Expert on Fossil Insects
description: Dr. Frank M. Carpenter, a Harvard University zoologist whose life's work was the study of insects, died on Tuesday at the Pine Knoll Nursing Home in Lexington, Mass. He was 91 and lived in Lexington.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Smith Corona Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss included an after-tax charge of $ 5.8 million, or 19 cents a share, for a change in accounting for income taxes.(Loss)

title: Teen-Agers and Pregnancy
description: To The Home Section:

title: Call the Government On Winter Depression
description: To the Editor:

title: A NOMINEE'S WITHDRAWAL: Washington Memo; Even Washington Insiders Are Bashers Nowadays
description: It has been a long time since Washington got any respect, but the last year has been particularly hard on the old capital.

title: Carpenter Technology Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a favorable effect from the last-in, first-out accounting method of 19 cents a share in the quarter and 45 cents a share in the 6 months.c-Net lossd-Included a favorable effect from the last-in, first-out accounting method of 4 cents in the quarter and 8 cents a share in the 6 months, and the 6 months also included a charge of $ 74,676,000, or $ 9.32 a share, from an accounting adjustment.(Loss)

title: NBD Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $ 3,950,000, or 3 cents a share, from a change in accounting for income taxes.c-After a charge of $ 37,885,000, or 24 cents a share, from a change in accounting for postretirement benefits other than pensions.

title: Bridge
description: The Cap Volmac World Top tournament, which begins today in the Hague, the Netherlands, will be one of the strongest events ever played anywhere. Among those invited are the three Dutch pairs who won the world team title in Chile four months ago and two French pairs who won a different world title a year earlier.

title: Nixon Library Receiving Gift of $5 Million
description: The Annenberg Foundation is giving $5 million to the Richard Nixon Library and Birthplace and a new center the library is creating on foreign and domestic policy issues, library officials said.

title: McKesson Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included $ 37.4 million, or 60 cents a share, in special items, including a $ 55.1 million gain on the sale and donation of Armor All stock, partially offset by a $ 4.3 million contribution to the McKesson Foundation and a $ 13.4 million loss on the termination of interest rate swap arrangements. The period also included extraordinary charge of $ 4.2 million, or 10 cents a share, from extinguishment of debt, and after a charge of $ 15.8 million, or 39 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: No Flowers for Russians: Pair Make Do With Gold
description: No roses were tossed onto the ice tonight for Yekaterina Gordeyeva and Sergei Grinkov. The few fans with the good fortune to be in the Brondby Arena already had used up all their flowers on a mediocre Danish skater dressed to resemble an electric cowboy.

title: Review/Theater; Kushner's Adaptation Of a French Classic
description: You could describe "The Illusion" as a new 20th-century comedy with a 17th-century accent. But then you could also call it a new 17th-century comedy with a 20th-century accent. Either way, the strange hybrid that opened last night at the Classic Stage Company will appeal primarily to collectors of theatrical oddities.

title: CBS Says It Should Break Even On Nagano
description: CBS officials yesterday defended their decision to spend $375 million on the television rights to the 1998 Winter Olympics in Nagano, Japan, saying the network will not lose money on the expenditure, the steepest price ever for a Winter Olympics.

title: 1 Quake, 2 Worlds
description: There's always a positive media spin for tragedy. In Los Angeles, it is that a city racked by racial and class divisions has come together after the earthquake. On TV and in the papers we are told how African-Americans, Latinos, Asians, Middle Easterners and Anglos have laid down their arms -- literal and rhetorical -- to pitch in and help their neighbors. But the truth is that even in disaster, the fault lines that divide L.A. are there for all to see.

title: Justices Weigh States' Tactic Of Using Tax to Fight Drugs
description: A new state tactic in the war on drugs -- taxation -- received a critical examination in a Supreme Court argument today as the Justices questioned whether the Constitution permitted a state to levy a special tax on the same drugs it prosecuted someone for possessing.

title: Minority Members on Council Give Giuliani List of Concerns
description: Responding to criticism that he had not reached out sufficiently to minority officials, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani met yesterday with black and Hispanic members of the New York City Council in discussions that the Mayor and Council members called productive.

title: Central & South West Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included loss of 27 cents a share for the quarter and 23 cents a share for the year for numerous charges relating to organizational restructuring and accounting changes.

title: Topics of The Times; Immortalizing Dallas
description: The Chisholm Trail came to Fort Worth, not Dallas, but that doesn't faze Trammell Crow, a real estate developer who plans to adorn his hometown with a life-size bronze cattle drive -- 70 longhorns and three cowboys on 4.2 acres in the heart of downtown Dallas.

title: Nunn Spurned A Clinton Offer Of Defense Job
description: The White House asked Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia last week if he would take the job of Defense Secretary, but he refused, Administration officials said today.

title: THE EARTHQUAKE: The President; Clinton Visits Quake Area And Feels the Earth Rumble
description: President Clinton rode out a strong aftershock here today and pronounced the damage from Monday's earthquake "amazing." He promised "unusual and unprecedented" steps to help the region recover after Gov. Pete Wilson told him the disaster might be one of the most expensive in American history.

title: Central Divisions Are Added to Baseball's Lineup
description: The major league owners, continuing their attempt to change the nature of how baseball is run, redrew another part of the game today. They reached agreement with the players association on the realignment of the leagues from two divisions to three and the addition of an extra tier of playoffs.

title: Raymond Sabinsky, Violist, 80, Is Dead
description: Raymond Sabinsky, a violist in the New York Philharmonic for 40 years, died on Jan. 9 in San Francisco. He was 80 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Digital Loss In 2d Quarter Stuns Market
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation is finding that the road to recovery is longer and more painful than it had expected.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with the text of the Iran-contra report misidentified a man shown with President Bush as he defended his pardon of Caspar W. Weinberger. The man, fourth from the left at the rear, was Ronald F. Lehman 2d, director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, not John F. Lehman Jr., Secretary of the Navy.

title: A NEW ROUND OF JOB CUTS BY BRITISH AEROSPACE
description: British Aerospace P.L.C. said yesterday that 510 jobs would be eliminated at three weapons plants. On Friday, the military and aerospace company said it was cutting 830 positions at its Avro International regional jet business. The weapons plants cuts will be made in the first half of the year. A company spokesman said 330 jobs would be cut at Lostock, near Bolton in northern England; 160 at the Stevenage site near London, and 20 at Bristol in western England. The company is initially asking workers to sign up for a severance package. Compulsory cuts have not been ruled out, the spokesman said. After the cuts, 4,000 people will remain at the company's Defense Dynamics unit. As recently as 1989, the unit employed 16,000.

title: Dispute Grows Over U.N.'s Troops in Bosnia
description: A bitter dispute between the United Nations Secretary General and the general commanding United Nations forces in the former Yugoslavia has drawn attention to the widening gulf between United Nations peacekeeping troops on the ground in Bosnia and the unwieldy bureaucracy that controls their mission.

title: Whitman's Tax Pledge: A Bold, Risky Surprise
description: In her first hours in office, Christine Todd Whitman has used a surprise announcement about a retroactive tax cut and two executive orders to build herself a political cushion against some of the blows that landed on her during the governor's race.

title: Architecture for, and With, Children
description: THE skyscraper of the future may end up having a mini-rain forest and a glass-encased subway system. The architects of the future may end up knowing what a dormer window and rotunda are at much younger ages than their parents.

title: Journal; Tonya Trashed
description: Spud City: Those haunting words began to make me feel sorry for Tonya Harding.

title: A Cowboy Stamp That Wasn't Is Recalled
description: Persuaded that an eagerly awaited new stamp does not depict a dashing black rodeo star but his portly back-office brother, the Postal Service has taken the bull by the horns and ordered the stamp's entire press run -- 20 million sheets in all -- stopped, recalled and destroyed.

title: Zairians Strike Over Plan to Close Parliament
description: Hundreds of thousands of Zairians stayed away from work today to protest President Mobutu Sese Seko's decision to dissolve the Parliament and name a new prime minister.

title: History Texts Made to Order
description: A unit of Paramount Communications Inc. is teaming up with Ohio State University to produce an on-demand history data base written by the university's history department.

title: Italy's Christian Democrats, Renamed, Seek Popularity
description: With little more than two months before national elections, the Christian Democratic Party has yielded to the political changes sweeping Italy and given itself a new name, new leaders and, it hopes, a new chance to salvage some of its former power base after the scandals of the last two years.

title: Allen Not Only Endures, He Prevails
description: For four years Marcus Allen was locked away in football's version of a cryogenic chamber. Al Davis, the Raiders' owner, put Allen in a deep freeze after Davis became upset with the running back over a contract dispute in 1989.

title: Synoptics Communications Inc. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included pretax charge of $ 2.25 million, or 6 cents a share, for settlement of two class-action shareholder lawsuits, in the quarter and year.

title: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Cortines Says Bad Schools Are Facing Takeovers
description: New York City Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines said yesterday that in a series of recent surprise visits to some of the city's most troubled schools he has discovered stunning educational mismanagement, including teachers without teaching plans and libraries without books.

title: Frozen Out of Fuel, Utilities Impose Scattered Blackouts
description: In an extraordinary emergency action, electric companies cut service to millions of people through all of New Jersey and southward as far as Virginia for up to an hour yesterday because cold weather had created high demand for power while making it impossible for some generating stations to obtain fuel.

title: John Blair Linn Goodwin; Writer and Poet, 81
description: John Blair Linn Goodwin, a writer and poet, died last Wednesday at Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital. He was 81 and had homes in Manhattan, West Palm Beach, Fla., and the Netherlands Antilles.

title: No Headline
description: "My cabdriver told me that he has been taking fares two or three blocks this morning. Nobody wants to walk." -- J. STEPHEN SHEPPARD, New York City lawyer. [ B6:5. ]

title: Review/Jazz; Regional Idiosyncrasies And Playing With Pitch
description: One of the greatest losses jazz has suffered over the years is a sense of regional identity. With the advent of music schools and the easy access to recordings, young musicians tend to gravitate to the same sources and the same ideas; idiosyncrasy is a long-forgotten notion. Von Freeman, the 71-year-old tenor saxophonist now at the Village Vanguard, is exactly that, idiosyncratic. He has lived in Chicago most of his life, and he sounds like it. His playing clearly has precedents, but in its distinctiveness, it can only have come from a place where jazz orthodoxy wasn't everything, where musicians had the time to experiment.

title: Howard S. Browne; Broker, 89
description: Howard S. Browne, a New York investment broker and founding partner in the securities firm of Tweedy Browne Company, died on Sunday at his home in Morristown, N.J. He was 89.

title: Knicks Ransack Mr. Robinson's Neighborhood
description: The outcome was no surprise. The San Antonio Spurs were without their best player, and the Knicks were without mercy.

title: Let's Take the Crime Out of the Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: North Korea Buying Old Russian Subs
description: North Korea has quietly begun purchasing 40 aging attack submarines from Russia's Pacific Fleet through a small Japanese trading company, according to Japanese, South Korean and American officials tracking the movements of the subs through the North Pacific.

title: THE EARTHQUAKE: The Work Force; 2 Days After Quake, a Taste of Traffic to Come
description: Los Angeles went back to work today, and the city's businesses concentrated on cleaning and coping. Their employees, reporting to the job in large numbers for the first time since the Monday morning earthquake, created some of the worst traffic tie-ups in recent memory.

title: In South African Vote, Blacks Still Face a Battle
description: To the Editor:

title: THE EARTHQUAKE: Why Buildings Collapsed; Quake Revealed Flaws in 'Safe' Structures' Design
description: The earthquake that battered this city on Monday inflicted heavy damage on a small number of modern, wood-frame apartment buildings that were supposed to be able to withstand moderate shaking, officials said today.

title: DHL Worldwide To Goodby, Berlin
description: DHL Worldwide Express, the international air express company, said yesterday that it had selected Goodby, Berlin & Silverstein in San Francisco to handle its account, which had been at Ketchum Advertising San Francisco for almost five years until they parted ways three months ago over financial issues. Billings were estimated at $7 million to $8 million.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: COLLEGE BASKETBALL Mississippi State Still Perfect in S.E.C. In Starkville, Miss., T. J. Honore hit two free throws in the final 33 seconds as Mississippi State beat No. 3 Arkansas, 72-71, last night and remained unbeaten in the Southeastern Conference. The Bulldogs (11-2 over all, 5-0 S.E.C.) overcame a 10-point, first-half deficit in taking a two-game lead over second-place Arkansas (12-2, 3-2) in the S.E.C.'s Western Division. (AP) Michigan St. 70, Wisconsin 60: In East Lansing, Mich., Michigan State dealt No. 14 Wisconsin its second straight road loss as Shawn Respert scored 16 of his 20 points in the second half of the Spartans' Big Ten victory. Before their visit to Breslin Center, the Badgers (12-2, 3-2 Big Ten) rebounded from a 90-53 loss at Minnesota with a 75-69 victory over previously unbeaten Purdue in Madison. But the Badgers missed 15 of their first 20 shots, fell behind 23-11, and really never recovered. (AP)

title: Haggar Corp. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp., known as Freddie Mac, is selling $250 million of notes due in 2004 priced at 100 to yield 6.27 percent through Goldman, Sachs & Co. The issue is callable in three years. * First Chicago Corp., is selling $200 million of 6.375 percent subordinated notes due in 2009 priced at 98.886 to yield 6.492 percent through CS First Boston Corp. The noncallable issue is rated Baa-1 by Moody's, A- by Standard & Poor's and BBB+ by Duff & Phelps.

title: U.S. Calls 7 Countries Backers of Terrorism
description: Administration officials said today that they had made no change in the Government's list of countries deemed to support terrorism: Cuba, Iraq, Iran, Libya, North Korea, the Sudan and Syria.

title: Robert Corroon, 71, Insurance Executive
description: Robert F. Corroon, a Manhattan insurance executive for 44 years, died on Monday in Greenwich Hospital in Connecticut. He was 71 and lived in Greenwich.

title: State of Emergency Declared in Kentucky As Bitter Cold Closes Interstate Highways
description: The Winter of '94 is just a few weeks old, but the people of Kentucky will no doubt remember it for a long time.

title: Laclede Steel Co. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $ 46,543,000, or $ 11.48 a share, cumulative effect of a change in accounting principle for post-retirement medical benefits.c-Included after-tax charges of $ 8,990,000 for restructuring the company's wire operations and $ 2,604,000 for the disposal of accumulated electric furnance dust.(Loss)

title: Reno Is Said to Choose New Yorker as Counsel
description: Attorney General Janet Reno has settled on Robert B. Fiske Jr., a New York lawyer and a Republican, to be the special counsel who will investigate the Arkansas real estate investments of President Clinton, a senior Administration official said today.

title:
HOCKEY;
McLennan Finally Loses One in the Nets
description: For the longest time tonight, it appeared as if the Islanders' Jamie McLennan would stay unbeaten as a National Hockey League goalie.

title: Burnett Picks Team For Asia Operations
description: Leo Burnett Worldwide, the overseas operation of the Leo Burnett Company in Chicago, said yesterday that it had formed an Asia-Pacific regional management group of three senior executives to oversee offices in 13 countries.

title: Elco Industries (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Microsoft Has 22% Rise In Earnings
description: The Microsoft Corporation reported today that it had a 22 percent gain in fiscal second-quarter earnings, which it attributed to strong sales of Microsoft Office, its "suite" of programs including word processing, data base, spreadsheet and graphics.

title: Bitter Cold Disrupts Power, Travel, and Life in General
description: Record-breaking cold imposed an icy disorder on the New York region and along the East Coast yesterday, from power shortages to disrupted school days, from frozen railroad track switches to scuttled dinner plans.

title: Samuel Steward, 84, A Writer About Stein
description: Samuel M. Steward, a writer who was a friend of Gertrude Stein, died on Dec. 31 in Berkeley, Calif. He was 84 and lived in Berkeley.

title: Earnings Dip At Pfizer; Stock Dives
description: Battered by competition in drug prices and an unexpected slowing in buying by wholesalers, Pfizer Inc. reported disappointing fourth-quarter earnings yesterday, news that sent its stock reeling.

title: FirstFed Michigan Corp.(NMS
A Japanese Star of the 80's Implodes
description: The Hanwa Company, a once-unknown Japanese steel-trading house that became a high-flying financial speculator, came crashing to earth today when it announced that it would report more than $1 billion in securities losses and that its aggressive president was resigning.

title: QVC Weighs Revising Its Paramount Bid
description: Neither side appears ready to quit in the takeover battle for Paramount Communications Inc. Now, faced with Viacom Inc.'s improved rival offer, QVC Network Inc. is seriously considering altering its bid for Paramount, according to an executive close to the QVC camp.

title: Ex-Husband of Harding Arrested in Skating Attack
description: Federal authorities today arrested Jeff Gillooly, the former husband of Tonya Harding, and said they had grounds to believe he has implicated her in planning the Jan. 6 assault on her figure-skating rival, Nancy Kerrigan.

title: Designed by Women, Made for Everyone
description: IN 1981, Nancy Perkins of Chicago helped design the case for the Diehard Incredicell car battery (below) for Sears, Roebuck & Company. In the late 1950's, Suzanne Vanderbilt was one of the first women to design car interiors (like the one at right) -- but never the dashboards -- for General Motors. And in 1987, Hedda Beese, the owner of Design Drei, a company in Hanover, Germany, created a sleek, minimalist watering-can prototype that reflected her ability to meld technology with style.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Sports of The Times; The Rush To Judge Harding
description: AS the web of suspicion draws tighter around Tonya Harding, there is a point that must not be dismissed lightly. Harding has repeatedly said she's innocent of any wrongdoing in the Nancy Kerrigan case. And she said it, again, through more than 10 hours of grilling Tuesday in front of the authorities in her hometown of Portland, Ore.

title: Sysco Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
Electric Fields
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Music; A Pianist Whose Intense Subjectivity Turns Listeners Into Eavesdroppers
description: It wasn't until Radu Lupu played two encores in Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night that this intriguing pianist's goals became clear. In those two pieces -- a Brahms Intermezzo (Op. 118, No. 2) and a Mozart Fantasy (K. 397) -- every phrase was articulate and refined; the pianissimos had a tactile presence. The runs and cadenzas of the Mozart were as lyrically played as the Adagio theme with its premonitory chromatic structure. Brahms's expressive lines and autumnal harmonies pulled at the ear. It felt as if the audience was eavesdropping on Mr. Lupu's private fantasies.

title: Human Rights Activist Disappears in Cairo
description: To the Editor:

title: American Electric Power Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included charge of $ 144,533,000, or 78 cents a share, as the result of an Ohio Supreme Court ruling upholding the Ohio Public Utilities Commission disallowing a portion of its investment in a generating station.

title: A Region of Crystal Beauty, or Weariness, or Fear; Icy Mountain Rescue
description: The urgent calls from the state police went out to three villages in western New Jersey between 1:15 and 1:30 A.M. yesterday: Find snowmobiles to rescue dozens of motorists trapped in sub-zero temperatures on either side of an ice-encrusted hill on Interstate 78.

title: How to Achieve Economies in City Services
description: To the Editor:

title: Pennzoil Challenged On Taxes
description: The Internal Revenue Service is preparing to demand nearly $1 billion in back taxes and interest from Pennzoil on the company's $3 billion legal settlement with Texaco Inc. in 1988, the company said today.

title: Compass Bancshares Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AmSouth Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Fiscal 1993's per share earnings reflects the restatement of the company's earnings for the first three quarters of 1993 to include the historical performance of the institutions merged in pooling-of-interest transactions in the fourth quarter. The sum of the company's originally reported quarterly earnings for 1993 was $ 3.19 a share.

title: WLTW-FM finds success with an ever-evolving definition of 'soft' adult contemporary music.
description: ERIC CLAPTON, Sting, Phil Collins and Bruce Springsteen, whose music has saturated American radio for several decades, are also:

title: TAKECARE SHAREHOLDERS SUE OVER ACQUISITION BY FHP
description: Takecare Inc. shareholders with a 22 percent stake have sued the company, a health maintenance organization, contending its chairman, Jack R. Anderson, engineered the board's rejection of a takeover bid in favor of a lower offer. The suit, filed in Delaware Chancery Court, says that Mr. Anderson breached his fiduciary duties by working to insure that the FHP International Corporation's bid was chosen instead of an all-stock bid by the United Healthcare Corporation.

title: Agent Points to Cultist as Attacker And Creates Rift in Defense Team
description: Despite repeated efforts by the defense to shake his testimony, a Federal agent today identified Livingston Fagan, a 34-year-old member of the Branch Davidian sect, as the man who shot him twice during a botched raid on the sect's compound last Feb. 28.

title: Lennar Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included a $ 7.6 million charge, ($ 4,883,000 after tax), or 24 cents a share.

title: Japan's Chief Says U.S. Economists Oppose Trade Targets
description: Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa of Japan, in a reply to an open letter from American economists, has reiterated his opposition to setting targets for opening Japan's markets.

title: Crime Issue Spurs Giving To Neediest
description: In late December, a 34-year-old bond trader for Kidder, Peabody & Company sat down to mail off his annual contribution to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, dedicating his $500 gift to the memory "of all the victims of crime in 1993."

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Tuesday about Eleanor Holm, the swimmer who was thrown off the 1936 Olympic team for drinking champagne on the trip to Berlin, misspelled her married name. It is Eleanor Holm Whalen.

title: 3 Latest Targets of Calpers
description: The California Public Employees' Retirement System said today that it had filed shareholder resolutions calling for changes in the boards of the U.S. Shoe Corporation, Zenith Electronics Inc. and Boise Cascade.

title: Bentsen Says China Isn't Doing Enough on Rights
description: Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said Wednesday after meetings with China's leaders that the Clinton Administration was still not satisfied with the measures Beijing was taking to improve its human rights practices and that it must do more if it hopes to win renewed American trade benefits.

title: Comdisco Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 20,000,000 from an accounting adjustment.

title: Fleet Financial Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Per share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Olympic Aura at Vermont Mom-Pop Resort
description: When it comes to ski resorts, bigger is not always better. Take the Cochran Ski Area in Richmond, Vt. With only six trails and not a chairlift in sight, ski areas don't come much smaller. But measured in terms of stature, the place gets bigger.

title: Special Counsel Picked by Reno
description: Attorney General Reno has settled on Robert B. Fiske Jr., a 63-year-old partner in the Wall Street law firm of Davis, Polk & Wardwell and a former United States Attorney in Manhattan, to be the special counsel to investigate the Clintons' real estate investments in Arkansas, an Administration official said.

title: New League in Works
description: Talk about deja vu all over again. There were BOWIE KUHN and BOB WIRZ at a New York news conference yesterday, discussing franchises, rules and the relative appeal of strikeouts and home runs. They did not, to be sure, appear in their former roles as commissioner of baseball and major league baseball's chief spokesman but on behalf of a new commercial ball and bat venture, the National Fastpitch Association.

title: WHERE TO FIND IT
description: WHEN people ask Alex Shahgholi what he does for a living, he can show them a videotape of his daughter Tina's third-birthday party. Mr. Shahgholi's video-photo album, compiled by his company, International Video Services, features family slides of Tina punctuated by special effects and a soundtrack.

title: Brinker International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
Living Centers of America Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Living Centers of America said that during the latest quarter it implemented the provisions of F.A.S. 109, Accounting for Income Taxes, and retroactively restated its financial statements for the impact of this accounting change. The company said the restatement results in a decrease in net income for the quarter ended Dec. 31, 1992, of $ 97,000, or 1 cent a share.

title: Essay; Inman Out
description: Why did Adm. Bobby Ray Inman, sailing toward easy Senate confirmation as Secretary of Defense, suddenly flinch and withdraw his name? We do not yet know, but I suspect it was not for the reason given in the therapy session that was his departing news conference.

title: Torkham Journal; On the Khyber Road, the Afghans Shall Not Pass
description: "It breaks our heart," the Pakistani Army captain said. "They're our own people."

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: FOR many children who were home on Monday for the observance of the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and unable to play outside because of unusually cold weather, television was an obvious source of entertainment. But what they found on many stations was not the usual cartoons, soap operas and game shows, but live coverage of the earthquake in Los Angeles.

title: Market Place; Bracing for Northwest Air's Issue
description: Watching the frequent surges and drops in airline fortunes is enough to give even the most limber investor neck cramps. So, a restraining collar may be appropriate while considering the bid by Northwest Airlines to go public again.

title: Colonial Gas Co. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
First of America Bank Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included $ 25.9 million, noncash write-down of intangible assets in both the quarter and year, and the year also included charges of $ 23.9 million related to merger with Security Bancorp and $ 21.9 million for adoption of FAS 106.Per share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted.

title: Ground Round Restaurants Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
Giuliani Announces Plan For Jobs for Welfare Clients
description: In his first step toward delivering on a campaign promise to get more welfare recipients to work, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday that the city would begin paying a private company to find jobs for people on welfare.

title: Mets Sign Shortstop And Free-Agent Pitcher
description: The Mets signed the former Boston Red Sox infielder LUIS RIVERA to a nonguaranteed major league contract yesterday, which was fitting, since Rivera is now the Mets' nonguaranteed starting shortstop. Falling short in their quest for a front-line shortstop, the Mets have gone to a tandem system intended to find a veteran partner for the young incumbent shortstop, TIM BOGAR. Rivera, 30, who was a free agent, is that partner.

title: TALKING WITH: Bernice King; Shaping Her Own Dream
description: A FEW days before the nation celebrated her father's life Monday, Bernice King was talking about coming to terms with his death.

title: INTERACTIVE TELEVISION TEST SET FOR SILICON VALLEY TOWN
description: The Pacific Telesis Group's video services unit and A.T.&T. said yesterday that they would test an interactive-television system in the Silicon Valley suburb of Milpitas, Calif., beginning in November. About 1,000 people are expected to participate in the first part of the test, which will last between 12 and 18 months. The system will allow the companies to test consumer acceptance of various services, like movies on demand, home shopping and video games. Last November, Pacific Telesis pledged to spend $16 million to build a high-speed video and data network that would reach 1.5 million California homes within three years and five million homes by the end of the decade. At that time, the company said A.T.& T. would be its supplier of advanced switching equipment.

title: After Admiral Inman
description: There is no point in piling on. By withdrawing his nomination for Secretary of Defense, Bobby Ray Inman wrote a sad, puzzling end to a useful career in the Navy and the intelligence agencies. There was no politician or commentator so contrarian as to believe his improbable parting charge of a conspiracy between Senator Robert Dole and our colleague, the columnist William Safire.

title: New Publishers Selected For Fortune and Money
description: Time Inc. named new publishers for Fortune and Money yesterday to replace publishers who are retiring.

title: Bell Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net lossc-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 443,000, or 7 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 519,000, or 8 cents a share, in the 6 months. The 6 months also included a charge of $ 830,000, or 13 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment.(Loss)

title: Where Have All the Shovels Gone?
description: Well before the first snowflake fell, most tool makers shifted production from snow shovels to rakes, hoes and trowels. Little did they count on the fierce weather that has unfolded this winter.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-9 NORTH KOREA BUYING SUBMARINES North Korea has arranged to buy 40 Russian submarines through a Japanese company. The news is unsettling North Korea's neighbors, though Russia says the submarines will be used for scrap metal. A6

title: A Region of Crystal Beauty, or Weariness, or Fear; Another Day at the Beach
description: In Coney Island yesterday, summer seemed unimaginable. The sea breeze stung like a million needles, and the howls of the guard dogs around the moribund rides were the only sound. The deserted roller coaster, the Cyclone, hovered like an outsize Brontosaurus skeleton.

title: Crown Crafts reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The City Shuddered
description: Usually in an earthquake, I'm down three flights of stairs and out of the house in world record time. This quake, it didn't seem worth the bother. When it's this powerful, you just lie in bed and look at death (except for the poor man ejected out of his hotel bed and sixth-story window: he got to look at death on the way down).

title: New Study Links Gene to Risk of Bone Disease
description: Heredity has long been known to play an important role in determining who will get osteoporosis, the bone-thinning disease that afflicts some 20 million Americans and results in costly, debilitating and sometimes life-threatening fractures in older women and, to a lesser extent, men.

title: BANKAMERICA CORP. (N)
description: Profits at the BankAmerica Corporation, the nation's second-largest banking company, rose by 4.9 percent in the fourth quarter, to $496 million.

title: Mr. Cuomo's Election-Year Budget
description: All government budgets are political documents, and election-year budgets even more so. Gov. Mario Cuomo's plan for the coming year in New York State was clearly -- critics say cynically -- written with an eye on the campaign. In its optimism, therefore, it is a far cry from the sharp cutbacks of recent recession years.

title: Student, 18, Killed In Shooting on Bus
description: An after-school confrontation between students from rival high schools aboard a city bus in the Bronx ended yesterday in the fatal shooting of one of the students, the police said.

title: Poll Finds Increasing Confidence In Economy, and in the President
description: For the first time since the onset of the recession in mid-1990, the number of Americans expressing confidence in the economy has caught up to those with negative views about it, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll. The shift has helped restore President Clinton's public approval rating to the higher level he enjoyed when he first took office.

title: Rock Greats Hail, Hail Their Own At Spirited Hall of Fame Ceremony
description: A star-packed audience at the Rock-and-Roll Hall of Fame heard Bob Weir of the Grateful Dead reveal, "I've hated tie-dye all my life."

title: In a Rush? Help Is Available, for a Fee
description: BUYING an evening dress that needs alterations on the day it must be worn. Finding a reliable baby sitter for an impromptu night out. Arranging a catered party on a day's notice.

title: Serbs and Croats in Accord; Threat to Muslims Is Feared
description: Another round of talks between Bosnia's warring factions ended in deadlock today despite a last-minute effort by Serbia and Croatia to step up pressure on the Muslim-led Government by signing a separate accord to improve their relations.

title: Signet Banking Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Historical per share data has ben adjusted to reflect the 2-for-1 stock split declared June 23, 1993.

The year was also after a charge of $ 27.2 million, or $ 2.82 a share, from an adjustment in accounting.c-Net lossd-Net income and after a gain of $ 3,016,000, or 47 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.Income before items in the latest year included restructuring charges of $ 7,725,000, or 80 cents a share, and income before items in 1992 included a charge of $ 2,074,000, or 32 cents a share, related to a plant consolidation in the tobacco business.(Loss)

description: b-Included an $ 89.8 million tax benefit related to the recognition of tax deductions for the amortization of customer-based intangible assets acquired in connection with the company's 1991 public offering. It also included a charge of $ 150 million, ($ 92.9 million, net of tax), for the termination of a marketing agreement with an independent third-party marketing organization.MBNA said that per-share figures and weighted average shares outstanding have not been adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effective Feb. 14.

title: Events: Treasured Volumes
description: The Real First Printing Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street; (212) 685-0008.

title: Bam, Crunch, Thwack: Madden to NBC?
description: The John Madden Speculation Sweepstakes yesterday swept toward NBC, where he is said to be negotiating to become the network's No. 1 football analyst and a spokesman for General Electric, NBC's parent company.

title: Review/Fashion; Classically Couture
description: Back in the old days when Yves Saint Laurent's show closed each couture season here, the signals were easy to follow. He presented his styles with such vigor and insight that he established the direction in which fashion was going.

title: Here Sheep Count, Day and Night
description: THE cast-iron doorstop is in the shape of a ram. The hooked wool seat pads on the dining room chairs depict woolly sheep. There are fleecy sheepskins over the sofa, and a brochure on the desk touts "Herbal Moth Repellents."

title: Ruble Sinks Further in a Whirl of Political Rumors
description: Negotiations over a new Russian Government continued in secret today, aggravating confusion and panic over the value of the ruble, which plunged another 6.5 percent in record trading, to a low of 1,607 to the dollar.

title: R.S.V.P., Please!
description: To The Home Section:

title: Teachers and Parents File Suit Over School Repairs
description: Frustrated by the telltale signs of decades of neglect in public schools, from leaky roofs to cracked walls and broken toilets, some teachers and parents did what any New Yorker might do -- they sued the landlord yesterday.

title: Economic Scene; The two faces of Clinton's trade policy, one a frown for Japan.
description: IS there more at the root of the Clinton Administration's trade policy than an urge to demonstrate that Americans are mad as heck and aren't going to take it any more?

title: A Region of Crystal Beauty, or Weariness, or Fear
description: Off the frozen banks of the Hudson, a few hardy ferries slogged through the ice that cluttered the Manhattan shoreline like thousands of fractured panes of milky glass swept eastward by some gigantic broom. The ice parted, churned softly in the wake, then regrouped in conspiracy with the cold, sealing itself over the thin channel of greenish water.

title: Oakwood Homes reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included one-time gain of $ 214,000, or 1 cent a share, from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for income taxes.

title: If the Shoe Fits, Sell It (and Another Pair); With Brannock Device and Order Book, Foot Soldier of Footwear Stays on the Move
description: It grates on him. Here he sells people something that they wear every day and yet they usually don't really know their size and, anyway, there is no right size since every make and style are different. No matter how hard he toils to insure an ideal fit, too many intemperate people belittle him. He's just a clerk. He's a nobody. He's the bottom of the pit.

title: AMR, Citing Strike, Posts $253 Million Loss
description: The AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, said yesterday that a strike by its flight attendants last fall cost the carrier $190 million and led to a fourth-quarter net loss of $253 million.

title: Gallagher (Arthur J.) & Co. (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Man Charged Over Melee At a Mosque
description: A 29-year-old follower of the Nation of Islam was arrested yesterday and accused of taking part in a melee between New York City police officers and members of a Harlem mosque, the police said. One official said that the arrest, the first stemming from a brawl in which eight officers were injured, was made based on information gathered without cooperation from mosque officials.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DAVID N. DINKINS took a lot of heat during his mayoralty from critics who said that his support for Israel sprang out of his concern for the "Jewish vote."

title: CHASE OFFERS STOCK OPTIONS TO ALL EMPLOYEES
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation said yesterday that it had granted long-term stock options to its 33,500 full-time and part-time employees. Every full-time employee will receive options on 400 shares of Chase stock. Part-time employees receive options on 200 shares. If Chase's stock, which closed at $33.375 yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, reaches $60 a share within three years, employees will be able to exercise all the options; if it reaches $52, they will be able to exercise half of them. If the share price stays below that, the options vest in nine years. The program, a one-time offer for the duration of the three years, will be offered to new employees on a prorated basis.

title: Long Bonds Down on Profit Taking
description: Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, with the longer maturities down on profit taking after Tuesday's price gains and a concern over when the Federal Reserve might raise short-term interest rates.

title: School Showcase Set for St. John's
description: Twenty of the best high school basketball players in the United States will play each other on April 3 in an East-West All-Star game at Alumni Hall on the St. John's campus in Jamaica, Queens, the game's organizers announced yesterday.

title: AMERITECH CORP. (N)
description: The Ameritech Corporation, the regional phone company for the Midwest, reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 18.7 percent from a year earlier on a 6.1 percent gain in revenues.

title: Witness Says Lorena Bobbitt Earlier Threatened to Maim Husband
description: A woman who once worked with Lorena L. Bobbitt testified today that three years before Mrs. Bobbitt cut off her husband's penis, she had declared that she would do so if Mr. Bobbitt was ever unfaithful.

title: Net inc 10,195,000 9,180,000
description: b-Included a $ 5 million, or 26 cents a share, after-tax restructuring charge, recognized primarily in the third quarter, associated with the sale of three branches.c-Included a gain of $ 7,000,000, or 42 cents a share, from cumulative effect of a change in accounting for income taxes.Year-ago results are have been adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in the third quarter of 1993.Latest quarter's per share earnings are based on 1.8 million more shares outstanding than year-ago results due to the conversion of convertible debt during the first quarter of 1993.Year-ago quarter's per share earnings are restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in the third quarter of 1993.Fiscal 1993's shares outstanding reflects an increase in shares outstanding due to the conversion of convertible debt during the first quarter of 1993.

description: In percent

Legg Mason Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Legg Mason Inc. said revenues from commissions were $ 35,430,000 in fiscal 1994's third quarter, or 34.3 percent of total revenues, compared with $ 29,717,000 in the year-ago quarter, or 34.9 percent of total revenues.

title: How to Aid Los Angeles Quake Victims
description: Interaction, a coalition of more that 150 not-for-profit American humanitarian aid groups, has issued this list of agencies to which money may be sent to help earthquake victims in the Los Angeles area:

title: Washington Mutual Savings Bank (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included charges of $ 8,953,000, or 15 cents a share, from prepayment of Federal Home Loan Bank advance, and after an accounting gain of $ 13,365,000, or 23 cents a share.c-Included charge of $ 4,638,000, or 9 cents a share, from prepayment of Federal Home Loan Bank advance.

title: Poles Seize Half Ton of Cocaine on U.S. Tip
description: Acting on a tip from American customs officials, Polish customs seized more than half a ton of cocaine on Tuesday. It had an estimated wholesale value of $20 million.

title: Whitman and Cuomo Seek to Cut Different Taxes for Same Reasons
description: In trying to make their states better places to do business, Mario M. Cuomo, the long-time Governor of New York, and Christine Todd Whitman, the new Governor of New Jersey, may be talking the same talk but they're not walking the same walk.

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: Wild Geraniums

title: In Prosecution Evidence, Bombing Defendant Finds an Alibi
description: It was the turn of the defense lawyers in the World Trade Center bombing trial yesterday to cross-examine a Government specialist on telephone records, and one of them found a way to use testimony introduced by the prosecution the day before to fashion a partial alibi for his client.

title: No Bother, No Worries, But Still No Rings
description: It bothers Jim Kelly.

title: Winnipeg Official Out
description: The Winnipeg Jets dropped General Manager MIKE SMITH yesterday and replaced him with their head coach, JOHN PADDOCK. The Jets' president, BARRY SHENKAROW, said Paddock would hold the dual roles of coach and general manager until the end of the season.

title: Review/Dance; Brazen Feminine Rage Amid a Flow of Energy
description: The Altogether Different series at the Joyce Theater entered its final week on Tuesday night with Donna Uchizono, a choreographer who ended her program by pressing a red rose to her bare chest before chewing on the flower's petals.

title: Prevention and Punishment
description: Last year Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York appointed a special commission to study youth crime and violence. Its chairman is Andrew Stein, former president of the New York City Council; the vice chairman is Leonard Dunston, director of the state's Division for Youth. Its first public hearings were held last week, and the commission's 15 members heard some smart testimony on prevention from Ronald Mincy of the Ford Foundation.

title: Iran-Contra Isn't Over for Oliver North
description: The independent counsel's final Iran-contra report revealed nothing significantly new about Oliver L. North's involvement in the scandal, leading the former Marine officer and White House adviser to pronounce, "It's over."

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DRESSER INDUSTRIES, Dallas, said its shareholders had approved its $900 million purchase of Baroid Corp., Houston. KERR GROUP INC., Los Angeles, will close its Chicago home-canning and lid manufacturing plant and move the operations to Jackson, Tenn., by year's end.

title: A Decision: No New Commissioner
description: Major league club owners decided today not to name a new commissioner. Instead, Bud Selig, the man who has said for 16 months that he doesn't want to be commissioner, will continue to be exactly that with no end of his expanding non-term in sight.

title: Genentech Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Lam Research (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Review/Music; Spotlight on Women As Composers of Yore
description: Feminism has made an interesting mark on the musical world. On one hand there has been an effort to shine a spotlight on women who are composing now, of which there are many, some quite successful. But there is a concurrent movement to show that female composers are by no means only a modern phenomenon. The rediscovery in the mid-1980's of music by the 12th-century abbess Hildegarde of Bingen was a start in that direction, and in recent years, women who worked in the 17th century, most notably Barbara Strozzi, have slowly been drawn out of the shadows.

title: Man Is Killed as 2 Are Wounded
description: One man was killed and two others were in stable condition after a shooting at a cab-leasing business in an Upper East Side apartment building yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: Modine Manufacturing Co.  (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: b-After a gain of $ 899,000, or 3 cents a share, from the adoption of a change in accounting for income taxes.c-After a charge of $ 13.7 million, or 46 cents a share, from the adoption of a change in accounting for postretirement benefits.

title: A Moscow Agency Joins Ad Federation
description: The American Advertising Federation has accepted its first corporate member from Russia, a Moscow agency called Aurora.

title: Hunt Manufacturing Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
Prudential Securities Case Gets Its First Public Hearing
description: The cost to Prudential Securities of settling the largest class action stemming from its limited partnership fraud scandal has dropped from $120 million to about $90 million, a lawyer in the case said today.

title: Ollie's Coast-to-Coast In Last 0:02.8 Wins It
description: Connecticut's march through the Big East continued tonight with another victory, the sixth without a defeat, over a difficult opponent in a difficult place. The Huskies snatched the decision from the Providence Friars on an improbable basket by Kevin Ollie with 2.8 seconds left for a 79-78 victory.

title: M.G. Guerreiro, 69, Family Court Judge In New York, Is Dead
description: Manuel Gomez Guerreiro, a retired judge of the Family Court of New York City, died on Tuesday at Clinica Las Americas in San Juan, P.R. He was 69 and had homes in San Juan, Middletown, N.Y., and Hudson, N.Y.

title: Shaw Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: Year-ago periods ended Dec. 26, 1992.

title: Allegheny Power System Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said share figures are adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split, effective Nov. 4, 1993.Allegheny Power System said that its increased revenues reflect continued growth in retail revenues due to rate increases and greater kilowatthour sales to residential and commercial customers.

title: Johnson Controls reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss, which was after a charge of $ 122 million, or $ 1.51 a share, from an adjustment in accounting.Per-share amounts are after payment of preferred dividends.(Loss)

title: COLUMBIA GAS TRANSMISSION FILES REORGANIZATION PLAN
description: The Columbia Gas Transmission Corporation, operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection since July 31, 1991, has filed a reorganization plan that would pay creditors $3.3 billion. It provides $900 million to pay gas producers whose contracts to supply the pipeline company were canceled during the bankruptcy. Producers' claims total about $13 billion. Unsecured creditors other than gas producers would recover 80 percent to 100 percent of their claims. Secured creditors would receive 100 percent. The plan assumes the Charleston, W. Va., company will emerge from bankruptcy on June 30.

title: Carroll Hires a Coach
description: The Jets appointed BRAD SEELY special teams coach yesterday, replacing AL ROBERTS, who had been special teams coordinator for three years. Seely joins the Jets from the Indianapolis Colts, where he coached special teams and tight ends for six seasons. Before that, he spent five seasons as offensive line coach at Oklahoma State. He is the first assistant hired by PETE CARROLL, who replaced BRUCE COSLET as the Jets' head coach on Jan. 7. Roberts was dismissed with Coslet. (AP)

title: In the Mutual Fund Industry, New Worries About Trading
description: Putnam Investments,, a Boston-based mutual funds group, suspended Donald V. Dougherty, a securities analyst, in late September in a move related to his buying private stock for his own account.

title: Norwest Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reflected pretax charges of $ 93.5 million taken by Lincoln Financial Corp. to conform their credit and accounting practices to those of Norwest and other restructuring-related charges, in the quarter and year. The company acquired Lincoln on Feb. 9, 1993, in a pooling of interests transaction.The 1992 year was also after a charge of $ 76 million, or 26 cents a share, reflecting the cumulative effect for years ended prior to Dec. 31, 1992, of a change in accounting for postretirement medical benefits, net of tax.Year-ago periods were restated for a 2-for-1 stock split.

title: Integra Financial Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included gain of $ 60 million, or $ 1.78 a share, for accounting changes and also included is a one-time charge of $ 14 million related to restructuring of company's headquarters.c-Net lossd-Included charges totaling $ 90.1 million for merger-related expenses, foreclosed asset write-downs and loan-loss provision related to merger with Equimark Corp. in both the quarter and year.Integra Financial said that its net interest income in 1993 rose 7 percent from 1992 levels, to $ 554 million from $ 519 million. The company attributed the increase to higher average earning assets and declining funding costs.(Loss)

title: METRO DIGEST
description: METRO DIGEST BITTER COLD DISRUPTS POWER AND TRAVEL Record-breaking cold imposed an icy disorder on New York and the rest of the East Coast, from power shortages to disrupted school days, from frozen railroad track switches to scuttled dinner plans. The temperature was 2 degrees below 0 in Central Park at 6 A.M., the lowest ever recorded for the date, and rose to 10 degrees later in the day, making it one of the coldest days in the last half-century. A1. Electric companies cut service to millions of people from New Jersey to Virginia for up to an hour because the cold weather had created a high demand for power. B6.

title: THE EARTHQUAKE: Schools; With 150 Buildings Unusable, Education Waits
description: At Van Nuys Junior High School, a 70-foot chimney leaned precariously toward a courtyard that would normally be full of children. At Reseda High School rubble was strewn throughout the auditorium and jagged holes in the ceiling let in the clear blue winter sky of Los Angeles.

title: Sybron Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $ 400,000, or 2 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Ex-Sabre Wins in Court
description: The former Buffalo Sabres star RICK MARTIN was awarded $2.5 million Wednesday in a medical malpractice lawsuit against a surgeon Martin blames for cutting his career short. Martin wept as a New York Supreme Court jury in Buffalo announced the verdict against the estate of Dr. Peter Casagrande, a former orthopedic surgeon for the Sabres who operated on Martin's knee.

title: Cuomo School Plan Seizes the Middle of the Road
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's plan for distributing $9.3 billion in aid to local schools walks the middle ground between urban and suburban districts, insuring that poorer districts receive a slightly larger share of the total while most wealthier districts lose nothing, statistics released today show.

title: Inman Faced Scrutiny On Jailed Arms Dealer
description: While Bobby Ray Inman's confirmation as Defense Secretary by the Senate Armed Services Committee next week was considered a foregone conclusion, he faced potentially embarrassing questions about his work as a member of an outside board for a corrupt arms company.

title: Victory Runs Gamut From Coleman To 12th Man
description: When many in the crowd of 9,158 began to chant, "We want Rex," calling for the rookie Rex Walters with 2 minutes 25 seconds left in the third quarter at Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight, you had to suspect this was the Nets' night.

title: First Security (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included $ 11.12 million after-tax charge for costs associated with the acquisition of First National Financial Corp. in Albuquerque, N.M. Excluding the charge, per share net income was 66 cents a share in the quarter and $ 2.61 a share in the year.

title: SOUTHWEST CLOSES DEAL FOR 63 NEW BOEING 737-700 JETS
description: Southwest Airlines and the Boeing Company completed a $2.5 billion contract for the delivery of 63 twin-engine Boeing 737-700 aircraft beginning in October 1997, the companies said yesterday. The order, announced in November, was signed this week, making Southwest the first airline to buy Boeing's newest plane. The contract, which lasts through 2001, also gives Southwest, based in Dallas, the option to purchase another 63 of the aircraft.

title: Law on Cuba Trade Starves the Babies
description: To the Editor:

title: Meridian Bancorp Inc. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $ 7,221,000, or 13 cents a fully diluted share, from an adjustment in accounting.Per share earnings and shares outstanding were fully diluted.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Tuesday about an official inquiry into the export of arms-making equipment from Britain before the Persian Gulf war misidentified the country to which the equipment was sent. It was Iraq, not Iran.

title: Dover Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included $ 7.9 million, or 9 cents a share, and $ 11.4 million for the quarter and year, respectively, both from revenue from a government contract settlement at Dover Diversified's Sargent Controls company.c-Included gain of 1 cent a share from the net cumulative effect of two changes in accounting principles that were adopted at year end, retroactive to the first quarter of 1992.

title: Books of The Times; A Toast to Love and a Literary Family
description: The Partisan By Benjamin Cheever 261 pages. Atheneum/Macmillan. $21.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It's not often that Senator DANIEL PATRICK MOYNIHAN, Democrat of New York, speaks for Senator ALFONSE M. D'AMATO, his Republican counterpart, but he took it upon himself Tuesday to account for the sling on Senator D'Amato's right arm.

title: Review/Film; One Man, Two Women And Scenes Of Vancouver
description: "Intersection," a film about a man, two women and a traffic accident, could not have been more crazily miscast if those responsible had worn blindfolds and pulled names out of a hat. Its biggest gaffe -- and, naturally, its biggest drawing card -- is Sharon Stone's appearance in the role of Sally Eastman, a woman so sexually standoffish that she complains when her lover wrinkles her dress.

title: Bearings Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a charge of $ 440,000, or 6 cents a share, for accelerated vesting of some of the outstanding performance accelerated restricted common stock.

title: Becton, Dickinson reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and after a charge of $ 141,057,000, or $ 1.83 a share, from an accounting adjustment.(Loss)

title: Greece Finds Itself Obsessed By Unmentionable Neighbor
description: As Greece contemplates the morass of the Balkans to the north with some trepidation, it has sunk into a swamp of its own: the name of the problem is -- or, depending on the viewpoint, is not -- Macedonia. And, like any swamp, it is clinging messily, even as the new Socialist Government seeks prestige and respect from its current presidency of the European Union.

title: David Kirschenbaum Dies at 99; A Leading Dealer of Rare Books
description: David Kirschenbaum, a dealer in rare books and manuscripts who was regarded as the dean of American booksellers, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 99.

title: Commercial Federal (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 5.8 million, or 45 cents a share, from cumulative effect of changes in accounting principles.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;
description: Shortstop OMAR VIZQUEL and the Cleveland Indians agreed yesterday on a one-year contract worth $2.3 million, more than double his 1993 salary of $1,112,500. The agreement was midway between Vizquel's $2.5 million request in salary arbitration and the team's $2.1 million offer. Vizquel, 26, hit .255 with 2 home runs and 31 runs batted in in 158 games last season and won his first Gold Glove award. (AP)

title: Washington Defeated in This Cold War
description: This was Ross Perot's kind of day in the capital of the United States. This was the day the Federal Government finally shut down. And much of the rest of Washington, too.

title: Woman Begins Attending Class At The Citadel
description: As male cadets looked on with stony displeasure, a young South Carolinian today became the first woman to take classes with the corps of cadets at The Citadel, breaking a 151-year-old tradition at the historic military college and firing a resounding salvo in the nation's battle of the sexes.

title: Zombo Gets 10-Game Suspension
description: Defenseman RICK ZOMBO of the St. Louis Blue was suspended for 10 games without pay yesterday for shoving a linesman in the back during a Jan. 9 game against Dallas. Zombo shoved and slashed linesman KEVIN COLLINS after Collins collided with him. The collision caused Zombo to lose control of the puck, which was retrieved by a Dallas player who scored what proved to be the winning goal. (AP)

title: Musicland Stores Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary charge of $ 3.9 million, or 13 cents a share, from early redemption of debt.c-Included $ 703,000 in payments on preferred dividends, and extraordinary charge of $ 8,440,000, or 30 cents a share, from early redemption of debt.

title: Computer Associates' Net Up; Stock Falls
description: Computer Associates International Inc., a large computer software supplier, yesterday reported a 55 percent increase in earnings for the third quarter, but the strong performance was not enough to satisfy investors. The company's shares fell $3.50, to $41, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Computer Gives Odds on Jury Awards
description: Jury verdicts are supposed to reflect society's values, and a publisher of personal injury verdicts has now translated these societal reflections into dollar figures. One finding: jurors tend to award women significantly more money than men.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Chase Manhattan Corp., New York, is offering $150 million of 6.5 percent subordinated notes due in 2009 at 99.022 to yield 6.604 percent through Goldman, Sachs & Company. The noncallable issue is rated Baa-2 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation and Duff & Phelps.

title: Art in Review
description: Tanya Marcuse Yoshii Gallery 20 West 57th Street Manhattan Through Jan. 29

title: Crowds Besiege U.S. Agency for Earthquake Aid
description: An angry, tearful crowd pushed against the doors of a Federal disaster-relief center today as it was opening at the epicenter of Monday's earthquake. Thousands more ringed the block on a day when an urgent need for food, water and shelter clashed with bureaucratic procedures.

title: Review/Film; Animated Inventiveness
description: That an animated film can convey the feeling of being pummeled in a boxing ring with a visceral intensity that matches the prizefighting sequences in Martin Scorsese's "Raging Bull" says much about the advanced state of the art of movie animation. The film that accomplishes this, Daniel Suter's "Square of Light," comes from Switzerland and lasts less than five minutes.
