But with splaying crayon flashes, splats and swirls, synchronized with a soundtrack of thuds and crowd noises that vibrates with the dizzying sense of someone going in and out of consciousness, the film evokes brutal physical contact with a startling intimacy.

title: MCN Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included charge of $ 5.9 million for a one-time rate incentive refund to customers in the quarter and year.

title: The Visual Poetry Of a Japanese Master
description: WHATEVER your relations with your family, the films of Yasujiro Ozu will make you think about them. Because the Japanese director often focused on conflicts between parents and their adult offspring, a twitch on the umbilical cord awaits you. But you should always expect the unpredictable: the dislikable wife or sister shows a sudden warmth, the father who gave up drinking years ago goes on a bender, the mutinous children begin to forgive their parents. Pessimism is flavored with humor, and if most families are full of mine fields, the wounded usually offer bandages to one another.

title: After Arrest, Police Seek 2 Others in Mosque Clash
description: A day after making an arrest in the confrontation at a Harlem mosque, police officials yesterday identified two other suspects being sought in the clash that injured eight officers.

title: Article 936839 -- No Title
description: Baby Jake's, a rowdy New Orleans-style cafe in the East Village, has a lot going for it, and I will tell all as soon as my teeth stop chattering.

title: Dashing Toward Olympics at 90 Miles an Hour
description: From the top of old Canada Olympic Park, a mountain at the foothills of the Rockies, strange cries were heard this morning from people in weird garb. In the brittle, blue-sky cold, these people wore black rubberized suits, sneakers and red helmets like race-car drivers. There were five teams of them, four at a time, and they surrounded a sled, sometimes red, sometimes black -- one to a team -- that was shaped more like a torpedo than Rosebud. And what they shouted, among other things, were: "Woo!" "Dig in, dig in!" and "C'mon, baby!"

title: Samuel Kaplan; Jewish Historian, 87
description: Samuel Kaplan, a Jewish historian who conducted a Yiddish-language radio program on WEVD for 42 years, died on Jan. 14 at his home in Far Rockaway, Queens. He was 87.

title: Coleman Catches Flu; Anderson Gets Augmon
description: One day after he successfully returned from a two-game absence because of back spasms to score a game-high 24 points and lead New Jersey to a 112-91 victory over Minnesota at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, Derrick Coleman didn't report today. He called in sick with the flu.

title: Bourque, at 33, Is Still Mr. Defense
description: Ray Bourque will probably still be a Boston Bruin when the team leaves Boston Garden for its new arena in 1995. It only seems as if Bourque was playing when the old barn opened in 1928.

title: Firstar Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Finding Jobs for Welfare Clients
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani announced a plan this week to pay a commercial company to find jobs for welfare recipients in New York City. The plan, which had been rejected by the Dinkins administration, is a promising approach to boosting at least a few hundred people off the welfare rolls, with little risk of becoming a costly failure.

title: Jury Begins Deliberating Bobbitt Mutilation Case
description: A jury began debating this afternoon whether Lorena L. Bobbitt acted deliberately and maliciously when she cut off her husband's penis last June 23, or whether she was temporarily insane.

title: The Fed's Not Broken, So Don't Fix It
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: KARL LAGERFELD apologized to Muslims yesterday for inadvertently using passages from the Koran as decoration on three dresses in his spring couture collection for Chanel.

title: Executive Changes
description: BROWN BROTHERS HARRIMAN & CO. , New York, has named two new general partners: Hampton S. Lynch Jr. and A. Heaton Robertson. CHYRON CORP., Melville, L.I., appointed Mark C. Gray president and chief operating officer.

title: Monsanto Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included reserve of $ 7 million, or 6 cents a share, for the cumulative after-tax effect of several product sales and withdrawals. In addition, earnings included an after-tax gain of $ 19 million, or 16 cents a share, from a planned, permanent working capital reduction in LIFO inventories for Monsanto's Chemical Group, in the quarter and year. The year also included gain of $ 22 million, or 18 cents a share, from insurance settlement.c-Included after-tax charge of $ 425 million, or $ 3.44 a share, for cost-cutting and other actions, and income from discontinued operations of $ 554 million, or $ 4.49 a share, reflecting gain on the sale of Fisher Controls International in October 1992.d-Net loss, which included charge of $ 425 million, or $ 3.44 a share, for cost-cutting and other actions, gain of $ 554 million, or $ 4.49 a share, on sale of Fisher Controls International in October 1992, plus $ 24 million, or 19 cents a share, of earnings from the unit before the sale, and after a net charge of $ 540 million, or $ 4.38 a share, which included charge of $ 658 million for change in accounting for postretirement benefits other than pensions, and gain of $ 118 million for change in accounting for income taxes.(Loss)

title: DIALOGUE: The Bobby Inman Show; Who Is He To Wail?
description: The withdrawal of Bobby Ray Inman will, I suppose, provoke the customary lamentations about the evil wrought by a malevolent press in keeping the "best people" out of government. There will no doubt be the further suggestion that this press misbehavior is a new and deplorable departure in American politics.

title: Hospital Sought Out Prenatal Drug Abuse
description: A university hospital in South Carolina has been accused of testing pregnant women for drug use without their consent.

title: McDermott International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a one-time noncash charge of $ 100,750,000, or $ 1.89 a share, from change in accounting for nonemployee products liability asbestos claims.c-Included extraordinary charge of $ 610,000, or 1 cent a share, in the quarter and 9 months. The 9 months was also after a charge of $ 245,624,000, or $ 4.74 a share, reflecting the adoption of S.F.A.S. 106 and S.F.A.S. 109, accounting for income taxes.(Loss)

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY IN SEA OF WEALTH, HOMELESS DEFY COLD

title: A Wintry Winter Show of Antiques
description: THIS year's Winter Antiques Show is definitely the coldest in memory. The cavernous Seventh Regiment Armory, at Park Avenue and 67th Street, is a drafty space in the best of Januarys, but this week's subzero temperatures and dry atmosphere have made the interior of the armory feel more like the windy Park Avenue corner outside. And the dry cold has led dealers to worry about possible damage to their delicate antiques.

title: Come Monday, Islanders Hope to Air Out the Wash
description: When the New York Islanders reassemble Monday after the National Hockey League All-Star Game break, Coach Al Arbour will be hoping for a transformation of Jekyll and Hyde proportions from his Atlantic Division cellar-dwellers.

title: Kimberly-Clark Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a pretax gain of $ 9.4 million, or 4 cents a share, on the sale of Alabama forestland in both the quarter and year.c-Net lossd-Included after-tax restructuring charge of $ 172 million, or $ 1.07 a share, in both the quarter and year, and the year also included a net charge of $ 210,000,000, or $ 1.31 a share, which included a charge of $ 245 million, or $ 1.53 a share, for a change in how the company accounts for postretirement benefits and a gain of $ 35 million, or 22 cents a share, for a change in accounting for income taxes.(Loss)

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Laughing With an Edge

title: Serbia Sanctions Make West Feel Better
description: To the Editor:

title: The $6 Trillion Hole in Japan's Pocket
description: Many of the world's financial markets have recovered from a decade of excess in which problems were often measured in billions, or even hundreds of billions, of dollars. But Japan is now coping with an even more awesome debacle: the loss of at least $6 trillion from one of the steepest plunges in stock and property values of this century.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Audible Explorer

title: Washington Talk; The House Is Grappling With Itself On Crime
description: Even though crime and drugs have moved to the forefront of the public's concerns, the House is in no rush to take up the broad, $23 billion Federal crime bill that the Senate passed last fall.

title: Whitman Debating Sale Of the Sports Authority
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman opened the door today to selling off the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, owner of the Byrne Arena and Giants Stadium among other things, as a way of reducing the state's liability for debt and curbing the power of one of the state's most far-reaching independent authorities.

title: Apple's Earnings Plungs as Revenues Rise
description: In the midst of a delicate product transition involving its decade-old Macintosh line of computers, Apple Computer said today that its revenues increased 23 percent for the first quarter, but earnings fell 75 percent.

title: First Hawaiian (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
On Stage, and Off
description: Scott Ellis Joins the Nederlanders

title: XEROX GETS PENTAGON CONTRACT FOR FLAT-PANEL DISPLAYS
description: The Palo Alto Research Center of the Xerox Corporation has received a $21.4 million Pentagon contract to develop high-resolution flat-panel displays. The three-year contract, granted by the Pentagon's Advanced Research Projects Agency, calls for Xerox to develop and demonstrate color active-matrix liquid-crystal displays with resolution close to that of a printed page. The displays are intended for computers, work stations and communications devices, an agency statement said. The agency said 126 companies had bid for the contract.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Rise to Big Board Record
description: The American Stock Exchange reported that the short interest in its stocks rose 1 percent, to 102.4 million shares, slightly below the record for that exchange set in August.

title: American Home Products reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a net gain of $ 310,104,000, or 99 cents a share, which included a $ 383,2955,000, or $ 1.22 a share, gain from SFAS 109 and a $ 73,191,000, or 23 cents a share, charge from postretirement benefits, other than pensions.c-Included a one-time charge of $ 220 million, or 70 cents a share, for the portion of the purchase price of Genetics Institute Inc. that represented acquired research.The company said shares outstanding are assuming full conversion of preferred stock.

title: LEADING REFORMER RESIGNS AS YELTSIN PICKS NEW CABINET
description: Russia's Finance Minister, who has come to represent Moscow's commitment to rapid economic reform, announced tonight that he was quitting the Government after President Boris N. Yeltsin named a new Cabinet that is expected to put higher priority on protecting industrial jobs than in fighting inflation.

title: Quaker Oats Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of 14 cents a share for the sale of two Italian businesses and a charge of 8 cents for European cost reduction programs.c-Included a restructuring charge of $ 38.6 million, or 37 cents a share, for the consolidation of production facilities at a U.S. pet foods plant, and after a charge of $ 115.5 million, or $ 1.59 a share, from an adjustment in accounting.(Loss)

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in New York City that are to close soon: Closing This Weekend "ITERATIONS: THE NEW IMAGE," International Center of Photography Midtown, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 43d Street. More than 70 computer-generated images and installations, by 17 artists. Through today, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Admission: $2.50; $1 under age 12. Information: (212) 768-4680.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: International Shipholding reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge from early debt redemption of $ 124,000, or 2 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 1,716,000, or 33 cents a share, in the year.c-After a charge of $ 3,281,000, or 63 cents a share, from an accounting change related to retiree benefits.Latest quarter's income from continuing operations of $ 1,941,000, or 36 cents a share, included $ 865,000 charge to restate deferred tax liability.

title: Giuliani Tells Hospitals Unit to Reconsider Cuts
description: The Giuliani administration told New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation yesterday to reconsider its emergency budget plan unveiled this week that would impose a hiring freeze, cut services and delay a number of new health initiatives.

title: WELLPOINT COMPLETES ACQUISITION OF UNICARE FINANCIAL
description: Wellpoint Health Networks Inc. of Woodland Hills, Calif., said yesterday that it had completed its acquisition of the Unicare Financial Corporation, a workers' compensation underwriter based in Irvine, Calif. Wellpoint, a managed health care company with 2.3 million members, acquired Unicare for $29 a share in cash, or about $154 million. Unicare had 1992 revenue of $146 million. In the last year, Wellpoint has introduced two plans that use managed care techniques to help control workers' compensation costs. California's insurance department is encouraging the packaging of health insurance and workers' compensation as a cost-saver for businesses.

title: Reviews/ Film; Of Russian Rednecks In a Land Gone Mad
description: Made in 1991, Pavel Lounguine's "Luna Park" now seems eerily prophetic in its depiction of brawny Russian neo-facists, a gang of thugs who may look buffoonish but are capable of causing real danger. The goons who set this story in motion hold court in an amusement park, where they randomly engage in drunken, violent outbursts. It's some measure of this film's tumultuousness that Andrei (Andrei Goutine), the brutish central character, takes solitary rides on a roller coaster in order to collect his thoughts and calm down.

title: CSX Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included $ 61 million, or 59 cents a share, restructuring charge. Also included additional income tax expense of $ 51 million, or 48 cents a share, as the result of applying higher tax rate to deferred tax balances from the prior year. Before those items, earnings would have been $ 471 million or $ 4.53 a share.c-Included productivity charge of $ 450 million after tax, or $ 4.38 a share. Before the charge, net income would have been $ 470 million, or $ 4.57 a share.

title: Seles Attacker to Face a New Trial
description: The man who stabbed MONICA SELES is likely to go on trial again but no date for the proceedings has been set, judicial sources in Hamburg, Germany, said yesterday. GUNTER PARCHE, an unemployed lathe operator from eastern Germany, was given a two-year suspended sentence in October for stabbing Seles in the back during a tournament in April. The former No. 1 female tennis player in the world has not played since. Parche spent six months in jail before the verdict. The state prosecutor appealed the mild sentence immediately after the verdict.

title: Breed Technologies Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Rebellion in Mexico Is Putting the Heat on Salinas
description: Accustomed to battling inflation, not insurrection, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari and the inner circle of advisers who helped him rebuild the economy are struggling to extinguish the rebellion in Chiapas and avoid a political crisis that could imperil his party's hold on Mexico.

title: Eclipse Winners: Now They're Off for Horse of the Year
description: Thoroughbred racing crowned its 1993 champions yesterday when it bestowed 10 Eclipse Awards on prime horses and 5 on owners, breeders and jockeys. And the big winner was Kotashaan, who outpolled Lure for the grass championship and gained the inside track for the honor of Horse of the Year.

title: Global Marine reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net incomec-After an extraordinary gain on extinguishment of debt of $ 28,300,000, or 24 cents a share, in both the quarter and year, and a gain of $ 1,400,000, or 1 cent a share, which included credit of $ 3.3 million, representing cumulative effect of change in accounting for income taxes, less a charge of $ 1,900,000, representing cumulative effect of change in accounting for postretirement health care and life insurance benefits.Fiscal 1992 income from continuing operations of $ 27,500,000, or 24 cents a share, included an $ 1 million gain in the first quarter from the sale of a drilling rig and a $ 55 million gain in the second quarter on settlement of a take-or-pay lawsuit.(Loss)

title: U S WEST INC. (N)
description: U S West Inc. reported slightly higher income from continuing operations in the fourth quarter and for 1993. Previously announced one-time charges involving among other things accounting changes and the revamping of long-term debt resulted in a loss for the year of $2.81 billion, or $6.69 a share.

title: Croat-Serb Pact: The Agenda Is Hiding in Krajina
description: The agreement signed on Wednesday between Croatia and Serbia, longtime bitter enemies, appears to further complex political and diplomatic goals that could isolate the Muslim-led Bosnian Government.

title: Possible Alliance For Y.& R. London
description: Young & Rubicam Inc. said yesterday that it was considering changes at its troubled British agency operations. But it declined to comment on a report in Campaign magazine, the British ad trade publication, that it is negotiating an alliance with Gold Greenlees Trott P.L.C. in London.

title: F.D.A. Expected to Announce Tough Seafood-Safety Rules
description: The Federal Government is expected to announce this morning that for the first time it will require the seafood industry to keep detailed records of safety procedures and to label all shellfish to show where it comes from.

title: Fingerhut Cos.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Market Place; Odd Corporate Performance By a Broadway Leading Man
description: New York knows Robert E. Nederlander as the owner of Broadway theaters -- 10, at last count -- and a piece of the Yankees. But one of his lesser-known holdings is raising eyebrows along Wall Street, both for what he has and has not done with it.

title: White Reportedly Is Ready to Leave as N.L. Chief
description: Already in office for nearly a year beyond the end of his term, Bill White is leaving his position as National League president, a club official said yesterday. Another club official attributed White's sudden decision to events that unfolded at the owners' meeting in Florida earlier this week.

title: Morandini Doubles Salary
description: Second baseman MICKEY MORANDINI and the Philadelphia Phillies agreed yesterday to a one-year contract worth $750,000, more than twice his $300,000 salary last season. Morandini, 27, asked for $850,000 in arbitration while the club offered $625,000. Four Phillies are in arbitration: pitchers CURT SCHILLING, TERRY MULHOLLAND and DAVID WEST and first baseman RICKY JORDAN. (AP)

title: Abroad at Home; The Royal President
description: Edwin Meese, commenting on the Iran-contra report, saw no problem if President Reagan knew about the secret arms shipments to Iran in 1985. "Quite the contrary," he said. "The more the President knew, the more he was able to authorize this."

title: On My Mind; The Price Of Korea
description: For Americans, the most dangerous foreign problem of the moment is neither Bosnia, the Mideast nor Russia but the one they are paying the least attention to. It is playing itself out in Washington, Vienna and a country only a handful of Americans have ever seen, or want to.

title: Burlington Northern reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included $ 17 million, or 19 cents a share, credit to income tax expense as a result of an Internal Revenue Service settlement which allowed the company to recognize additional deductions for tax purposes in both the quarter and year, and the year also included an extraordinary charge of $ 21,000,000, or 24 cents a share, from cumulative effect of accounting change.

title: Lesson From Bay Area Quake: Need for Fathomless Patience
description: If the experience of this area after the 1989 earthquake offers any indication of what lies ahead for Angelenos, patience may prove to be the survival tool of necessity, if not of choice.

title: Chittenden Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $ 575,000, or 9 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment.The company said all per share data restated to reflect a 5-for-4 stock split distributed on Sept. 24.

title: Sports of The Times; What to Do About Jordan And Baseball
description: CAN we turn away from America's favorite sport, figure skating, for a few minutes and give a little public-service scrutiny to the downtrodden old pastime of baseball?

title: North Korea Reported to Balk at Inspection Terms
description: In a setback for Clinton Administration hopes that inspectors would soon be heading into North Korea's nuclear complex, the International Atomic Energy Agency said today that North Korea had rejected inspection procedures the agency says it must carry out to determine if nuclear weapons are being developed.

title: First Eastern Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income(Loss)First Eastern said that the 1993 fourth-quarter results were affected by other real estate expenses, an acceleration of the write-down of core deposit intangible, and other nonoperating expenses including a one-time loss due to credit card fraud.

title: DIALOGUE: The Bobby Inman Show; Who Can Blame Him?
description: It is easy to dismiss Bobby Ray Inman's abrupt and seemingly petulant withdrawal of his nomination with the truism that of all positions (save perhaps the Presidency), the Secretary of Defense cannot afford the luxury of an eggshell ego. Or perhaps, as some intimate, there were other reasons that caused him to pull his name. But many who have left private-sector lives of power, prestige and financial comfort in recent years only to face the ever more brutal costs of serving their country can empathize with the admiral's dilemma.

title: No Headline
description: "It's important for the country to get this done, and get it done as quickly and as thoroughly and as fairly as possible." ROBERT B. FISKE JR., who will investigate President Clinton's land dealings. [ A16:3. ]

title: Weprin's Kin Reveal Illness But No Details
description: Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin suffered a stroke on Tuesday, his family and Assembly officials said today, raising doubts about his ability to continue in office and throwing the State Assembly into confusion barely three weeks into its 1994 legislative session.

title: Arkansas Best Corp. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge from early extinguishment of debt of $ 332,000, or 2 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 661,000, or 4 cents a share, in the year.c-Net lossd-After an extraordinary charge from early extinguishment of debt of $ 122,000 in the quarter and $ 15,975,000, or 84 cents a share, in the year. The year also included a charge from cumulative effect on prior years of change in recognition of revenue of $ 3,363,000, or 18 cents a share.(Loss)

title: Pet Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss of $ 29.1 million, or 28 cents a share, from discontinued operations, in the quarter and 6 months.c-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 300,000 in the quarter and $ 1.3 million, or 1 cent a share, in the 6 months. The 6 months was also after a charge of $ 18.5 million, or 17 cents a share, from a change in accounting for postretirement benefits.

title: City National Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After-tax gain of $ 7,128,000, or 18 cents a share, from sale of its data processing division in the second quarter of 1993.c-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 139,000, or 1 cent a share, in the quarter and $ 59,348,000, or 3 cents a share, in the year.(Loss)

title: U.S. and China Widen Accords On Civil Rights
description: Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said today that China and the United States had agreed to reopen Chinese prisons to American customs officers to insure that their factories are not making products for export to the United States.

title: INSIDE
description: Drug Arrests at Issue In South Carolina Case

title: Text of Regulation on Jurisdiction of the Special Counsel
description: Following is the Justice Department regulation that will serve as the mandate for Robert B. Fiske, who was appointed today to serve as independent counsel in the investigation into the Clintons' real estate investments. Mr. Fiske wrote the text, including the reference to the section of the United States Code on obtaining evidence or testimony from recalcitrant witnesses, and it was issued as a regulation by Attorney General Janet Reno.

title: A Defense By Time Warner
description: After months of acting nonchalant about the growing stake being acquired by the Seagram Company, the board of Time Warner Inc. adopted defensive measures yesterday intended to prevent Seagram from buying more than 15 percent of Time Warner's stock.

title: Commerce Bancshares (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CBS Puts Summerall And Others On Spot
description: For Pat Summerall, there will be no more CBS football after Sunday's National Football Conference title game. He will utter his last promotion for "Murder, She Wrote." Then CBS, which lost the National Foootball Conference television rights to the Fox Network through 1997, will leave the football business.

title: Firstbank of Illinois (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 386,000, or 6 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment.The bank said results for prior periods are restated to reflect the First National Bank of Highland acquisition in January 1993.

title: In Consolidation, Cortines Gives New Aide Broad Powers
description: Carrying out a sweeping bureaucratic consolidation, Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines yesterday placed control of the city's high schools, special education programs and all other centrally controlled instructional programs under a single Board of Education executive and appointed a Queens district superintendent to the job.

title: Cold Wave Hits Bottom; A Slow Climb Out Begins
description: The cold set records across the Northeast yesterday, and forecasters said that this morning could be even colder in many places. But the weather will get warmer soon, they promise; the New York City area could be in the relatively balmy 40's by Sunday.

title: Advo Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
description: Year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding are restated for a 5-for-4 stock split distributed March 5, 1993, in the form of a dividend.

title: Ousted Lilly Chairman Joins Investment Bank
description: Vaughn D. Bryson, the former chairman and chief executive of Eli Lilly & Company who was ousted in a board room coup last June, will become vice chairman of Vector Securities International, a small health care investment bank, on April 1, Vector announced yesterday.

title: And More Today
description: But a cold front (of all things) promises relief this weekend. To avert blackouts, the nation's capital simply shut down for a day. Articles, pages B6-7.

title: Union Camp Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an accounting gain of $ 40,806,000 from adopting S.F.A.S. No. 106 and No. 109.The latest periods' share earnings included gains of 6 cents a share in the quarter and 17 cents a share for the year, on the sale of land. The year's share earnings also included a charge of 23 cents a share to align the deferred tax reserve with the recently increased federal income tax rate.Year-ago periods' share earnings included a charge of 8 cents a share related to the refinancing of debt in the quarter, and the year included a gain of 10 cents a share from the sale of land and several nonrecurring items which had the net effect of reducing earnings by 4 cents a share.Union Camp said that income from operations in the latest year was $ 217,038,000, compared with $ 182,292,000 a year ago, which included a $ 57 million special charge to cover future expenditures to enhance workplace safety.

title: Houston Rockets President Resigns
description: The Houston Rockets' president, TOD LEIWEKE, on the job just four-and-a-half months, quit yesterday to take a position with the Golden State Warriors. Leiweke, 33, will be president of the Warriors Arena Development Co., a division of the team working to build a 21,500-seat sports and entertainment facility in the San Francisco area. (AP)

title: Lee Enterprises Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. Offers Guide for Doctors On Care of Those With H.I.V.
description: Federal health officials released new guidelines today to help family doctors, pediatricians, nurse practitioners and other non-AIDS specialists diagnose the virus that causes AIDS and treat people infected with it.

title: Harris Bankcorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Harris Bankcorp. is a unit of Bank of Montreal.

title: Prudential's Investments Called Sound
description: In hearings on the largest class action stemming from the Prudential Securities scandal, two experts for the brokerage firm testified today that the business operations of its biggest series of energy partnerships were properly run and that the huge losses suffered by investors were the result of declines in oil and gas prices, not fraud.

title: GENERAL ELECTRIC CO.
description: The General Electric Company reported yesterday that its earnings rose a little more than 10 percent in the fourth quarter, to $1.477 billion, or $1.73 a share. The gains were led by G.E.'s appliance, financial services, plastics and electrical generating equipment divisions, and came despite the loss of income from the aerospace business, which was sold during 1993.

title: Albany Speaker Is Ill
description: The Speaker of the New York State Assembly, Saul Weprin, has suffered a stroke, his family and Assembly officials said, raising doubts about his ability to continue in office and throwing the State Assembly into confusion barely three weeks into its 1994 legislative session. The Speaker's illness comes at a difficult and politically sensitive time, as legislators are preparing not only to open negotiations on the budget but also to run for re-election.

title: U.S. PLANS TALKS ON VIETNAM CLAIMS
description: Continuing to tiptoe toward ending the trade embargo on Vietnam, the Clinton Administration announced plans today to open talks with Hanoi to settle millions of dollars in financial claims arising from the Communist defeat of the South Vietnamese Government in 1975.

title: Review/Dance; Joe Goode Group in Debut
description: The advance word on the Joe Goode Performance Group from San Francisco was more than good (no pun intended) and its debut in the Altogether Different series Wednesday night at the Joyce Theater was hardly a disappointment.

title: Pair Dance a Rumba to Remember
description: No matter what happens during Friday's decisive free dance; no matter whether Jayne Torvill, age 36, and Christopher Dean, age 35, do indeed succeed in outsmarting, outdancing and outscoring their younger, slinkier Russian opposition, the reason for their ice-dancing comeback is clear.

title: Canwest Global reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Imcera Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 700,000, or 1 cent a share, in the quarter and $ 1,500,000, or 2 cents a share, in the 6 months.c-Net lossd-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 1,500,000, or 2 cents a share, and $ 2,000,000, or 3 cents a share, in the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and the quarter and 6 months are after a net charge of $ 3,400,000, or 4 cents a share, from executive resignations resulting from the performance of Pittman-Moore unit. The 6 months also included a charge of $ 80,600,000, or $ 1.04 a share, from cumulative effect of accounting changes.(Loss)Imcera Group also said that shareholders at a special meeting on March 15 will be asked to approve a change in the company's name to Mallinckrodt Group Inc.

title: Bristol-Myers Squibb Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a special charge of $ 310 million after taxes, or 60 cents a share, for potential breast implant liability claims in both the quarter and year.c-After gains on disposal of operations of $ 626,081,000, or $ 1.21 a share, and $ 669,857,000, or $ 1.29 a share, for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also included a charge of $ 246,012,000, or 47 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment. Also, the quarter and year included a pretax restructuring charge of $ 890 million ($ 570 million after taxes, or $ 1.10 a share).The company said the special charge in the latest period consisted of $ 1.5 billion as a reserve for potential liabilities and expenses related to breast implant claims, offset by $ 1 billion of expected insurance proceeds.The company also said that the fiscal 1992 charge from an accounting adjustment reflected the cumulative effect of an accounting change of $ 390 million before taxes, 47 cents a share after taxes, resulting from the adoption of a new accounting standard for postretirement benefits, effective Jan. 1, 1992.Year-ago gain on disposal of operations reflected the results and gain on sale of the Drackett Company, which was sold on Dec. 31, 1992.Sales represented net sales.

title: Why Condoms Decision Needs to Be Appealed; To My Daughters
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Theater; A Surrogate Father In a Mother's Guise
description: "Celebrate your difference, baby," trills the title character of "Holiday Heart," who has a lot to celebrate.

title: Support Grows for Earthquake Insurance Bill
description: Federal legislation that would require homeowners in California and other earthquake-prone areas to buy quake insurance -- and thus reduce the taxpayer funds needed to help victims without insurance -- is gathering support in the wake of the Southern California earthquake.

title: Victims of China's Birth-Control Policy Are Entitled to Asylum, a U.S. Judge Says
description: A Federal judge ruled today that victims of China's coercive population control policies were eligible for asylum in the United States, despite the Clinton Administration's efforts to expel some of them.

title: FIRST UNION PLANNING TO MERGE TWO SERVICE UNITS
description: The First Union Corporation said yesterday that it planned to merge its corporate and commercial service units into a single group as part of its strategy to compete with Wall Street brokers, investment bankers and money center banks. The reorganization puts all nontraditional banking services -- including investment banking, syndicated lending and derivatives trading -- in one unit called the Capital Markets Group. First Union, based in Charlotte, N.C., has $71 billion in assets and more than 1,300 offices.

title: Jack H. Mohr, 82, Cosmetics Executive Active in the G.O.P.
description: Jack H. Mohr, a Manhattan cosmetics executive for 30 years, died last Friday at Mountainside Hospital in Montclair, N.J. He was 82 and lived in Upper Montclair.

title: First Financial Holdings (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 1,584,000, or 25 cents a share, from a change in accounting for income taxes.Year-ago per share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective Oct. 24, 1993.

title: Books of The Times; A Marital Split Amid French Chic
description: Separation By Dan Franck Translated by Jon Rothschild. 227 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $19.

title: U.S. Offers Trade Plan On Germany
description: Underscoring the Clinton Administration's commitment to increasing American exports, senior American officials have presented a new approach to doing business with Germany that could become a model for promoting trade with other industrial nations.

title: Advest Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $ 368,000, or 4 cents a share.

title: Prices Are Up for Treasury Issues
description: Prices of Government securities rose yesterday on expectations that the Federal Reserve will not move to tighten credit any time soon.

title: New York Vote in '90 Humiliated Governor, Not His Opponent
description: To the Editor:

title: Davis and Birden: Chiefs' Great Unknowns
description: The moment quarterback Joe Montana came to Kansas City in a trade with San Francisco last April, the lives of J. J. Birden and Willie Davis changed -- for better and worse.

title: PACIFIC AND READING IN THEATER PARTNERSHIP
description: The Pacific Theaters Corporation and Reading Cinemas Inc., a unit of the Reading Company of Philadelphia, have formed a partnership to provide more than $100 million for the acquisition and construction of megaplex theaters in California and Hawaii. Reading and Pacific will be equal partners in the venture, and the theaters will be operated under the names Pacific Theaters and Consolidated Amusements under a management agreement with Pacific. Construction is expected to start before summer on two projects in each state. Pacific Theaters and its affiliates have more than 300 screens in California and Hawaii.

title: The Pentagon's Pterodactyl
description: Old weapons systems never die -- even after the mission they were designed for vanishes and the service that wanted them changes its mind.

title: Loral Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss after a charge of $ 233,377,000, or $ 3.11 a share, from an accounting adjustment.The company said results reflect a 2-for-1 stock split of October 1993.(Loss)

title: Man in the News; Aggressive Prosecutor: Robert Bishop Fiske Jr.
description: Robert B. Fiske Jr.'s reputation for integrity and thoroughness is so entrenched that if he finds no wrongdoing during his investigation of the Whitewater affair, his findings could put rumors about Bill and Hillary Clinton's business dealings to rest.

title: Demons Replace Dolls and Bicycles In World of Children of the Quake
description: Justine Vargas's eyes narrowed under her long bangs as she summoned up memories of the earthquake.

title: Real Estate
description: A COOPERATIVE is suing its former sponsor in State Supreme Court in Manhattan for maintenance owed -- not by the sponsor, but by the investor-owners of 5 of the 159 apartments. The investors who own those apartments at 3 Sheridan Square owe $66,857 in back maintenance, and the $8,063 maintenance due monthly on the units is not being paid.

title: Gonaives Journal; The Bogeyman's Back, Striking Fear Into Haitians
description: Michel Francois, the local leader of a far-right group that is Haiti's fastest growing political movement, sat in a rocking chair in the backyard of his home here, regaling two young women with war stories, when a foreign visitor interrupted.

title: Inland Steel Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included pretax charges of $ 30 million related to a planned blast furnance outage, $ 22.3 million write-off for the closure of a coke plant, and a gain from a favorable last-in,first-out inventory adjustment of $ 17.8 million in both the quarter and year.c-Included a charge of $ 656,203,000, or $ 19.99 a share, from cumulative effect of change in accounting principles.(Loss)

title: Air Products & Chemicals Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a net gain of $ 14,300,000, or 12 cents a share, from adoption of FASB 106, 109 and 112.c-Included a gain of $ 4.2 million, or 4 cents a share, on sale of business venture and partial sale of stock options in an insurance company.Latest quarter's income from continuing operations of $ 75,100,000, or 66 cents a share, included benefit of $ 2.3 million, or 2 cents a share, from favorable tax treatment of remaining shares of stock investment in an insurance company.

title: Review/Art; A Confluence of Old Masters, Made Better by Their Company
description: New York's art scene often goes into a deep freeze for a few weeks after the holidays. But this January is turning out to be unusually lively thanks to high-quality gallery shows of Old Master works in Manhattan, mounted to coincide with recent auctions of European art at Sotheby's and Christie's and last week's opening of the Metropolitan Museum of Art's starry "16th-Century Italian Drawings in New York Collections."

title: Vindicating a Lawyer With AIDS, Years Too Late; Bias Battle Over Dismissal Proves Costly Not Only to Worker, but to Law Firm
description: Toward the end, Geoffrey F. Bowers came to define himself by his work as a lawyer. His job with the New York office of the world's largest law firm, a friend said, "gave him a sense of belonging, a sense of worth, the fact he could continue his job even though he had this deadly disease."

title: Why Condoms Decision Needs to Be Appealed
description: To the Editor:

title: KeyCorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary restructuring charges related to the pending merger with Society Corp. of $ 41,100,000, or 41 cents a share, in both the quarter and year.c-After an extraordinary restructuring charge related to the 1992 merger of Puget Sound Bancorp. of $ 32,400,000, or 33 cents a share, in both the quarter and year, and the year also included a gain from the adoption of SFAS 109 of $ 6,600,000, or 7 cents a share.

title: PPG Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $ 272.8 million, or $ 2.57 a share, from an adjustment in accounting.PPG said the latest quarter includes after-tax charges of $ 44.2 million, or 42 cents a share, related to the pending divestiture of medical electronics operations.The company said that ''excluding the effect of the medical electronics divestment, our anticpated annual effective tax rate was lowered in the fourth quarter by about 2 percentage points.'' This, it said, increased reported fourth quarter income by about $ 11 million, or 11 cents a share.The latest year included the charges described in the fourth quarter, as well as a restructuring charge of $ 87 million pretax, or 48 cents a share, recorded in the third quarter. In addition, it included a gain of 16 cents a share recorded in the first quarter from the sale of an interest in an insurance company.The latest full year also reflected adoption, in addition to those noted in the table, of F.A.S.B. 112, retroactive to Jan. 1, 1993. That accounting change reduced net income by $ 6.1 million, or 6 cents a share. The previous year included an after-tax charge of 21 cents a share for an arbitration award.

title: Pippen Charged With Gun Possession
description: The Chicago Bulls star SCOTTIE PIPPEN was charged with unlawful possession of a weapon after the police said they noticed a handgun in his car. The Chicago police said he was arrested shortly after midnight yesterday after an officer checking out his illegally parked car noticed the loaded semiautomatic weapon.

title: Sun Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 6 million from the adjustment of reserves created in 1992 for its withdrawal from international exploration activities, a gain of $ 10 million from the sale of a domestic pipeline and $ 3 million in income from its coal and real estate operations ''held for sale.''c-Included a gain of $ 19 million on the sale of Suncor stock, a gain of $ 80 million on divestment of exploration and production properties, charges totaling $ 12 million for restructuring Suncor's downstream business and $ 3 million in income from its coal and real estate operations held for sale. The period also included a gain of $ 5 million for a change in accounting for income taxes.d-Net loss, which was after a charge of $ 261 million for an accounting change.(Loss)

title: CCB Financial Corp. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $ 1,371,000, or 17 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment.

title: Carter-Wallace reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $ 43,819,000, or 96 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment.c-Net income, and included income of $ 6 million, or 13 cents a share, related to licensing agreement with Scheering-Plough Corp.Latest 9 months' income from continuing operations of $ 20,103,000, or 44 cents a share, included increased continuing costs for postretirement benefits as a result of the adoption of SFAS 106 totaling $ 1.6 million after taxes, or 3 cents a share. Also included credit of $ 815,000, or 2 cents a share, from a tax adjustment.(Loss)

title: Unexploded Bombs
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: * Michael O'Rourke, executive vice president and general manager at the Portland, Ore., office of Borders, Perrin & Norrander, was promoted to president, succeeding Bill Borders, who continues as director of creative services. Also, Mike Jaglois, senior vice president and general manager of the Seattle office, was promoted to the new position of executive vice president. * Kenneth G. Trantowski was named to the new position of executive vice president at Porter/Novelli, Chicago. He previously held a similar position at Burson-Marsteller, Chicago. * Dan Dawson was named to the new position of marketing director at Aka Communications Inc., Los Angeles. He previously held a similar post at Frontiers Newsmagazine, Los Angeles.

title: Smith Is Activated by Knicks
description: When the Knicks' team bus left here after practice this afternoon for the flight that would take them to Orlando, Fla., Charles Smith was on it. He was activated from the injured list and Gerald Paddio was waived today. Now, the only question is: Will Smith play against the Magic Friday night?

title: Tandem Computers reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included pretax gain of $ 23 million from sale of subsidiary, and after a gain of $ 12,371,000, or 11 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Almost a Nation: The Kurds in Iraq -- A special report.; Kurds Rebuilding Shattered Land, Winning a Precarious Autonomy
description: High in the treeless plateaus and snow-capped mountains of northern Iraq, Kurds are rebuilding their devastated towns and villages and drawing them together into a de facto state that stops just short of nationhood.

title: Corrections
description: An article by Reuters on the Company News page of Business Day yesterday, about the profit-sharing payment by the Chrysler Corporation to its unionized workers, misstated the cost to the company. It is about $280 million, not $28 million.

title: TV Weekend; Alan Bates, Cast Adrift On the Atlantic's 2 Sides
description: Alan Bates as a playwright in the throes of alcoholic angst is entertaining company for almost an hour as he suffers indignities and causes havoc on two continents. The problem is that Simon Gray's play "Unnatural Pursuits" lasts for two and a half hours, veering crazily as though there were a drunk in the driver's seat as well as in the passenger's seat.

title: U.S. Sees Double Blow to Russia Reform
description: Clinton Administration officials voiced serious concern today about the announced resignation of Russia's Finance Minister, Boris G. Fyodorov, an advocate of rapid economic reform, fearing his departure could slow Moscow's move to a market economy.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Double Time for Denver Reggie Williams and Brian Williams hit baskets in the final minute of the second overtime last night, lifting Denver past the visiting Houston Rockets, 111-106, as the Nuggets snapped a four-game losing streak. Houston, losing its fourth in a row, rebounded from an 18-point first-quarter deficit to draw into a 92-92 tie at the end of regulation. The Rockets ran off 7 straight points early in the first overtime, but Denver countered with a 7-0 run of its own. A tip-in by Dikembe Mutombo with 11.6 seconds left made it 103-103, forcing a second extra session. After an exchange of turnovers and missed shots early in the second overtime, Mutombo hit a hook shot, and Reggie Williams followed with a layup on a pass from Brian Williams for a 107-103 advantage with 56 seconds left. (AP) Timberwolves 93, Spurs 83: Chris Smith and Thurl Bailey came off the bench to spark a 14-3 second-half run last night as the undermanned Minnesota Timberwolves defeated the San Antonio Spurs, 93-83, in Minneapolis. Doug West scored 23 points for the Timberwolves. David Robinson returned to the Spurs' lineup after missing two games with soreness in his right knee and scored 25 points, but he missed 15 of 24 shots as San Antonio shot just 41 percent to Minnesota's 50 percent. The Timberwolves played without their top reserve, Chuck Person, who checked into a hospital earlier yesterday with an foot infection. (AP) GOLF Broadcaster Plays, Too Gary McCord, much better known in recent years as a golf broadcaster, was back in the playing mode yesterday and was one stroke out of the lead of the Northern Telco Open in Tucson. McCord shot a 7-under-par 65 to finish in a tie with Larry Nelson, one stroke behind Dillard Pruitt.

title: Testing Giuliani's Single Standard
description: When he campaigned for Mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani often told his supporters that he favored "one standard" of justice in the city, a message that resonated strongly with those who believed Mayor David N. Dinkins had been too slow to enforce the law against blacks picketing Korean-owned grocery stores in Flatbush or black youths rampaging in Crown Heights.

title: In Sea of Wealth, Homeless Defy the Cold
description: In the bitter cold of night, the lights in the windows of Leggiadro, a boutique on the fancy upper reaches of Madison Avenue, cast their glow on $40 tights, cashmere leggings and on Fred Nardella, a man wrapped in a green Army surplus blanket who was trying to get some sleep in a cardboard box.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about pilots at a United States air base in Italy ready to fly raids in Bosnia and Herzegovina included an incorrect account of Croatian warplane action in the no-flight zone in Bosnia, as provided by a United Nations official in Bosnia. Croatian aircraft did not attack Muslim-held positions twice in one week.

title: Jeremiah Driscoll, 84; Supplied Fuel to Ships
description: Capt. Jeremiah T. Driscoll, whose companies supplied fuel oil to ships and boats in New York City waters for more than 40 years, died on Saturday at St. Vincent's Hospital. Captain Driscoll, who lived in Manhattan, was 84.

title: To put a human face on high technology, MCI chose an 11-year-old from New Zealand.
description: IN a snowy forest out of the Brothers Grimm stands a little girl in a large hat and a swirling cape. She looks directly into the camera. "Some people call it the Information Superhighway," she says. "MCI just calls it empowering technology."

title: Cuomo Urging Caution on Plan To Fingerprint Those on Welfare
description: A two-county pilot program to combat welfare fraud by fingerprinting applicants electronically could save New York at least $46 million a year if it were extended to the rest of the state, according to a Cuomo administration study released today.

title: German Politics: A Step Forward, a Step Back
description: At the start of an election year that will decide the fate of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's 12-year-old conservative coalition Government, German politics seems to be staggering around in circles.

title: Taxi Panel Requires Bullet-Resistant Partitions
description: Most yellow cabs in New York City will soon be required to have bullet-resistant partitions and emergency warning lights to protect drivers, under rules adopted yesterday by the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article and a picture caption in some editions yesterday about the Nets' game against Minnesota misidentified the category in which Kenny Anderson of the Nets approached a career total of 1,000. He had 9 assists, not rebounds, leaving him 1 assist short of 1,000.

title: Bank South Corp. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $ 32.3 million pretax gain from the swap of the company's Pensacola, Fla., bank for Barnett Banks metropolitan Atlanta franchise in both the quarter and year, and the quarter and year included $ 11.9 million and $ 14 million, respectively, of expenses related primarily to restructuring programs, the sale of the Pensacola bank, legal reserves, above target incentive and profit sharing payouts.Bank South said that net charge-offs for the fourth quarter were $ 6.3 million, compared to $ 12.4 million a year ago. Net charge-offs for 1993 were $ 15 million, compared to $ 38.9 million in 1992.

title: Russell Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: b-Included a $ 34,583,000 noncash, pretax charge associated with the write-down of certain fixed assets and goodwill. The charge lowered net income by about $ 23 million, or 56 cents a share.Preferred-share dividends were $ 3,000 in the latest quarter, compared with $ 6,000 in year-ago period, and $ 18,000 in latest year, against $ 292,000 in year-ago period.

title: Despite Assurances, Complex Factors Drive Up Tax Bills
description: Westchester County property owners, who were assured just before the November election that county taxes would not go up this year, were jolted this week by the news that their tax bills would indeed be rising -- by as much as 11.6 percent in one town.

title: Blue Devils Escape In Week Of Upsets
description: Duke 92, N. Carolina St. 65 Grant Hill scored 19 points as No. 5 Duke avoided a week of top-10 upsets by shooting a season-high 77 percent in the first half en route to a 92-65 victory over North Carolina State last night in Raleigh, N.C.

title: Prosecutors Weigh Moves After Arrest Of Gillooly
description: District attorneys from Oregon and Michigan met here today to discuss where and how to proceed against four men charged in the assault on the figure skater Nancy Kerrigan as a Multnomah County grand jury met to hear evidence in the case.

title: For Children
description: 'Rain or Shine' The Paper Bag Players The Kaye Playhouse 68th Street (between Park and Lexington Avenues) (212) 772-4448 Recommended ages: 4 to 9 Through March 6

title:
COMPANY REPORTS;
AST's Strong Results Propel Stock
description: AST Research Inc. reported better-than-expected net income and revenue yesterday for the quarter that ended on Jan. 1. Its shares rose more than 15 percent on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Bratton Picks a Chief Known as an Innovator
description: Signaling a desire to shake up the police hierarchy, the new Commissioner, William J. Bratton, dipped into the ranks yesterday and elevated a relatively junior officer to be the top uniformed officer in the department.

title: Japan's Premier Presses Coalition To Back Electoral System Reform
description: The six-month-old Government of Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa struggled today to put down a rebellion in the Socialist Party, the largest in his ruling coalition, that threatened to scuttle his effort to pass a restructuring of Japan's electoral system and to tighten restrictions on political donations.

title: Review/Theater; The Art of Making Lists Vivid
description: One has never doubted that the magnificent Irene Worth could, in fact, read a telephone directory aloud and make it sound utterly dramatic. But surely no one would have predicted she would come as close to proving the supposition as she does in segments of her "Portrait of Edith Wharton," which she is performing at the Joseph Papp Public Theater.

title: Federated Plan on Macy
description: Federated Department Stores Inc. plans to work on a competing reorganization plan for R. H. Macy & Company, an analyst who attended a meeting with company executives said yesterday.

title: A New Prosecutor
description: By choosing Robert Fiske as independent counsel to take over the Whitewater Development Corporation case, Attorney General Janet Reno has finally moved to clean up a mess that has embarrassed her Justice Department and the White House. Whether she has put Whitewater behind her will depend on whether Mr. Fiske, a moderate Republican, is perceived as the ruggedly independent lawyer she says he is.

title: Stillness Along the Potomac
description: Make no mistake, the Big Chill is serious business. As the Times headline said yesterday, this week's record-and-bone-breaking cold has disrupted "power, travel, and life in general." Trains have been canceled, stores closed, emergency blackouts ordered. The one redeeming feature in all this misery is that we may learn to survive with a smaller Federal Government.

title: At Center Of Storm With Cars In Tow
description: Through a blur of 12-and 16-hour days this week, Dave Sandstrom has witnessed just about every variation of what arctic air and ice can do to the internal combustion engine and the human spirit.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Convincingly Tropical

title: Chemist Can't Pinpoint Bomb Contents at Trial
description: A forensic chemist with the F.B.I. took the stand in the World Trade Center bombing trial yesterday and said that he had been unable to form a definite conclusion about the contents of the device that shook the trade center on Feb. 26.

title: Art in Review
description: Jennifer Bartlett Paula Cooper Gallery 149 Wooster Street, at Houston Street SoHo Through Jan. 29

title: For Red Meat and a Sense of History
description: IF you are a native New Yorker, steak is in your blood. Long before there were egg creams or Coney Island hot dogs, there were beefsteaks.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: HOST MARRIOTT TO SELL 26 FAIRFIELD INNS FOR $115 MILLION
description: The Host Marriott Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell 26 Fairfield Inns hotels for net proceeds of about $115 million to a joint venture that includes the Carlyle Group L.P., a Washington investment firm. Host Marriott, part of the old Marriott Corporation, said it had signed a nonbinding letter of intent to sell the hotels to a venture formed by Carlyle and Sage Hospitality Resources Inc. of Denver.

title: Accounts
description: General Media International, New York, to Avrett, Free & Ginsberg, New York, to handle consumer and trade advertising for Compute, Longevity, Omni and Penthouse magazines, previously inactive. Billings have not been determined, but the Penthouse portion was estimated at $2 million to $3 million. * Nabisco Foods Group, Parsippany, N.J., to Foote, Cone & Belding's spot broadcast unit, New York, to handle the local television and network radio media buying portion of its estimated $10 million account, previously at Lowe & Partners/SMS, New York. The unit already handles Nabisco Foods' national television buying.

title: Raychem Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $ 1.7 million, or 4 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: A Danish 'Schindler'
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Make Wives a Cardiac Risk Factor
description: To the Editor:

title: BancTec Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: b-Included a gain of $ 835,000, or 7 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment.Share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted.

title: Social-Service Efforts Imperiled as Donations to Neediest Lag
description: While individual donors have reached deep this season to give more to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, fewer people have contributed than last year at this time, resulting in a shortfall of more than $100,000 as the appeal enters its final five weeks.

title: International Rectifier Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss(Loss)

title:
PRO FOOTBALL;
Burden of Proof: 49er Defense the Suspect
description: George Seifert, the 49ers' head coach, has had little to say about his team's defense as it prepares for Sunday's National Football Conference championship game against the Dallas Cowboys.

title: CHRONICLE
description: RON D. DANIELS, the former executive director of the National Rainbow Coalition and deputy manager of the Rev. Jesse Jackson's 1988 Presidential campaign, has been named executive director of the Center for Constitutional Rights. He succeeds Miriam Thompson, who resigned to work as consultant on social justice issues.

title: BANKERS TRUST NEW YORK CORP. (N)
description: Unusually strong trading revenues led Bankers Trust New York Corporation to report profits for the fourth quarter that were sharply higher than expected.

title: Anchor Bancorp Inc. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $ 7,066,000, or 39 cents a share, from change in accounting method for purchased mortgage servicing rights.Anchor Bancorp said that the latest quarter included a $ 2.7 million pretax gain from the sale of deposits and the year-ago quarter included a $ 5.8 million pretax gain from the sale of securities.

title: Midlantic Corp. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included provisions totaling about $ 44 million for problem loans and foreclosed properties the company expects to dispose of in a pending bulk sale. Period also included income tax benefit of $ 65,698,000. As of Dec. 31, company had about $ 107 million in FAS 109 valuation reserves representing unrecognized federal and state tax benefits.c-Included $ 111,043,000 income tax benefit and gain of $ 38,962,000 on an accounting change and $ 78 million of special reserves for credit losses related to problem loans and OREO sold, or expected to be sold, in bulk transactions.d-Included a $ 3 million restructuring charge in the quarter; the year included $ 22.5 million pretax restructuring charge, and $ 35 million in net gains on disposition of assets.

title: Restaurants
description: If Dix et Sept were a person, it would be your most amiable friend.

title: Wisconsin Rewards Its Coach
description: BARRY ALVAREZ, who coached Wisconsin to its first Rose Bowl victory, has reached an agreement that would keep him at the university for 15 years. "This reflects his commitment and strong feelings that he wants to remain in Madison," Athletic Director PAT RICHTER said Wednesday. Alvarez, 47, the Big Ten coach of the year, is coming off a 10-1-1 record and 21-16 Rose Bowl victory over U.C.L.A. (AP)

title: 3 Partners Leave Botto, Roessner
description: Botto, Roessner, Horne & Messinger, the health care communications division of Ketchum Communications Inc. in New York, said three of its original partners had left the agency they helped to found 14 years ago.

title: Union Pacific Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $ 61 million one-time deferred tax adjustment resulting from the 1993 tax act, and after a charge of $ 175 million, or 85 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Uni-Marts Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Cable Ratings on Violence
description: The cable television industry is completing an agreement to develop a rating system for violence that would include measures stricter than parental advisory notices adopted last year by the major broadcast networks, an industry official said tonight.

title: Home Video
description: Into the Stores

title: Review/Art; A Raucous Caucus Of Feminists Being Bad
description: If you approach "Bad Girls," the raucous exhibition of feminist art at the New Museum of Contemporary Art in SoHo, as a smorgasbord of feminist expression from various sectors of contemporary culture, you will have a good time. The show includes drawings for feminist cartoons like Lynda Barry's "God's Gift" and Jennifer Camper's "If Men Got Pregnant." It has a reading area with books like "The Four Elements," by Roz Chast, "Bad Girls Do It: An Encyclopedia of Female Murderers," by Michael Newton, and the comic book anthology "Twisted Sisters: A Collection of Bad Girl Art."

title: At the Bar; After a beer commercial lassos lawyers, a lawyer replies in kind.
description: There was much ire among lawyers last summer when the Miller Brewing Company tried to prove that bashing one kind of bar could produce business at another. At issue was a beer advertisement depicting "the big lawyer roundup." In it, a porcine man in a three-piece suit, identified as a divorce lawyer who has profited handsomely from human misery, is lassoed at a rodeo.

title: U.S. Market Is Closed Tighter, Japanese Insurers Argue
description: The volume in the angry trade dispute between the United States and Japan was turned up another notch today, this time with the Japanese insurance industry vigorously denying that it is closed and countering that the American market goes further in discriminating against foreign competition.

title: Closed Roads Forcing Drivers to Try Trains
description: In Southern California, where automobiles are almost second homes, thousands of wary people this week stepped onto commuter trains and buses for the first time in their lives.

title: Raytheon Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ABBEY HEALTHCARE GROUP INC., Costa Mesa, Calif., a home health care services company, said it would acquire closely held Protocare Inc., Boston, a regional provider of home infusion therapy and nursing services, for $12 million in cash and an undisclosed amount of stock. ASEA BROWN BOVERI INC., Stamford, Conn., announced that one of its subsidiaries had recently received a contract worth about $285 million to build 222 rapid transit vehicles for the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority.

title: Seventeen's New Editor
description: Caroline E. Miller, editor in chief of Lear's, has been named editor of Seventeen magazine, K-III Magazines announced yesterday. She replaces Midge Richardson, who was named editor at large of K-III Magazines in September after 18 years as editor of Seventeen. Ms. Miller, 41, was executive editor of Variety from 1988 until 1992, when she went to Lear's. She has also held a variety of senior positions at New York Newsday. Seventeen is the leader among teen-age publications in advertising pages and circulation. Its ad pages were up 7 percent last year, and its circulation, 1.9 million, was up 1 percent.

title: Berlin Spy Trader Is Free on Bail
description: Dr. Wolfgang Vogel, a Berlin lawyer who became famous in the cold war for trading spies and political prisoners between East and West, was freed on bail today after six months in jail under suspicion of tax evasion, perjury and other charges brought against him since unification in 1990.

title: Stuart Scheftel, 83; Executive Took Part In Many Civic Posts
description: Stuart Scheftel, a Manhattan businessman who was a politically active civic leader, died yesterday in New York Hospital. He was 83.

title: Weyerhaeuser Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $ 52,052,000, or 25 cents a share, from extinguishment of debt.

title: Testing Giuliani's Single Standard; In Two Cases, the Mayor Takes His View to Black Audiences
description: When he campaigned for Mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani often told his supporters that he favored "one standard" of justice in the city, a message that resonated strongly with those who believed Mayor David N. Dinkins had been too slow to enforce the law against blacks picketing Korean-owned grocery stores in Flatbush or black youths rampaging in Crown Heights.

title: Critic's Choice/Film; Robert Altman Then and Now
description: Robert Altman has always been ahead of his time. Long before "Unforgiven" made revisionist westerns trendy, Mr. Altman directed "McCabe and Mrs. Miller," a lyrical and hardheaded masterpiece with Warren Beatty as a two-bit gambler and Julie Christie as a madam in a ramshackle mining town. The 1971 film only looks better with age. It will be playing through Feb. 3 (except Mondays) at Film Forum, 209 West Houston Street in the South Village.

title: COUNSEL GRANTED A BROAD MANDATE IN CLINTON INQUIRY
description: The special prosecutor chosen to investigate President Clinton's Arkansas land dealings said today that he planned a broad inquiry that would include questioning the President and his wife, Hillary, under oath and an examination of any possible links to the suicide of a senior White House aide.

title: Violence, Evert Says, Has to Do With No. 1
description: Tennis's own golden girl, Chris Evert, in town to tout her $400,000 Evert Cup next month in the California desert, where Monica Seles may make her comeback, instead found herself mulling the pattern of violence lately directed against some of the most prominent female athletes in the world.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Football National Football League

title: Pacific Gas & Electric reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Latest year's share earnings included charges totaling 54 cents for the reorganization of the company, restructuring of its natural gas operations and the proposed decision in the 1989-90 gas purchasing reasonableness review by the California Public Utilities Commission.

title: Rudman Declines Top Defense Post
description: Warren B. Rudman, the former Republican Senator from New Hampshire who was under consideration for the post of Defense Secretary, has asked that his name be withdrawn, White House officials and an associate of Mr. Rudman said today.

title: Exabyte Corp. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: b-Included charge of $ 13,469,000 or 62 cents a share from the purchase of R-Byte Inc.
