title: SCEcorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest periods' results included nonrecurring charges of 1 cent for the quarter and 18 cents for the the year, compared with nonrecurring charges of 3 cents a share and 8 cents a share, in year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Bank of Boston Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 24,200,000, or 23 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment.c-Included an extraordinary tax benefit of $ 17,300,000, or 16 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 73,000,000, or 72 cents a share, in the year.Fiscal 1993's income from continuing operations of $ 274,800,000, or $ 2.28 a share, included $ 85 million restructuring charge.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-11 RUSSIA LOSES 2D TOP REFORMER A Finance Minister who has come to represent Russia's commitment to rapid economic reform announced he was resigning. The decision came after President Yeltsin named a new Cabinet that is expected to put higher priority on protecting industrial jobs than fighting inflation. A1 The United States voiced concern about Boris Fyodorov's exit. A10

title: How to Help Victims of the Earthquake
description: Interaction, a coalition of more that 150 humanitarian aid groups, has issued this list of agencies to which money may be sent to help quake victims in the Los Angeles area:

title: Georgia Gulf Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge from early retirement of debt of $ 13,267,000, or 32 cents a share, and a gain of $ 12,267,000, or 32 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment.

title: Layoff Plan Scaled Back 14% at Boeing
description: Seeing a glimmer of hope on the economic horizon, the Boeing Company today scaled back the work force reduction it had planned for 1994. With a go-ahead from the airlines for its new 737-700 aircraft, Boeing said it would begin adding employees at its plant in Wichita, Kan.

title: Shawmut National Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income tax benefit of $ 70.2 million in the quarter due to the reduction of the deferred tax asset valuation allowance recorded in the first quarter, and pretax securities gains of $ 400,000; the year included a tax benefit of $ 140.7 million, pretax securities gains of $ 5.7 million, and after an extraordinary credit of $ 46.2 million, or 49 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of accounting changes.c-Includes pretax securities gains of $ 6.3 million in the quarter and $ 85.9 million in the year. The periods also included extraordinary credits of $ 3.2 million, or 4 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 18.4 million, or 21 cents a share, for the year, both from the realization of net operating loss carryforwards.The earnings for 1993 also included restructuring charges of $ 36 million, foreclosed properties provisions of $ 20 million and a $ 14 million write-down in the value of excess servicing righs, all recorded in the first quarter of 1993.Expenses of $ 3.5 million related to the settlement with the Justice Department and the strengthening of fair lending compliance programs were included in the latest year's results. In addition, the company reported an increase in annual employee benefits expense of $ 14.7 million as a result of adopting a new accounting standard for employee postretirement benefits.An after-tax charge of $ 6.6 million relating to the adoption of a new accounting standard for certain postemployment benefits, was part of Shawmut's 1993 results.

title: U.S. Trust Corp. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included pretax securities gains of $ 3 million.c-Included pretax securities gains of $ 256,000 in the quarter; the year was after a charge of $ 7,780,000, or 80 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of accounting change.Per share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Nathaniel Watson Baritone St. Bartholomew's Church Manhattan

title: Spurning QVC, Paramount Embraces New Viacom Bid
description: The board of Paramount Communications Inc. terminated its merger agreement with QVC Network Inc. yesterday and endorsed the latest bid from QVC's rival, Viacom Inc.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: New York Philharmonic Avery Fisher Hall

title: Snowstorms and Earthquake Put Retailers to Test
description: Across the nation, logistics experts for retailers ranging from huge department stores to fast-food outlets are wrestling with problems that include brutal winter weather in the East and Midwest to the aftermath of the Los Angeles earthquake.

title: MAC FRUGAL'S STOCK FALLS ON EARNINGS FORECAST
description: The stock of Mac Frugal's Bargains Close-Outs Inc. slumped 17 percent yesterday because of worry about the company's earnings outlook. Mac Frugal's stock fell $3.125, to $14.375, on the New York Stock Exchange, where 1.5 million shares changed hands. The retail chain said earnings for the year ending on Jan. 31 would be hurt by the earthquake in Los Angeles, which damaged 30 of its stores. Four of the stores remain closed. The company said the damage from the earthquake would result in a pretax charge of $3 million against this year's earnings to repair buildings and cover inventory losses. The company manages a chain of 237 stores in 12 states, called Pic "N" Save and Mac Frugal's Bargains. The company also operated a chain of seasonal Christmas stores in nine states from August through December.

title: Baltimore Gas & Electric Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Baltimore Gas & Electric said that 1993 fourth-quarter and full-year per-share net income figures included an $ 11 million after-tax charge, or 8 cents a share, for employee severance programs initiated in 1993. Not included in this charge is the cost of the company's voluntary special early retirement program, which will be spread over the next five years.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: 'I Lombardi' Metropolitan Opera

title: Oginga Odinga, 82, A Longtime Leader In Kenya's Politics
description: Jaramogi Oginga Odinga, who helped guide Kenya to independence in 1963 and was an important political leader there for more than 30 years, died on Thursday. He was 82.

title: Slower, but Surer, Arms Curbs
description: The U.S. has traditionally tried to stop the spread of nuclear arms by talking nations out of wanting the weapons in the first place or by denying them the technology to make arms. But now that proliferation ranks high among the dangers to U.S. security, the Clinton Administration faces pressure to pursue a third course, military action.

title: Bahamas Burdened by Haitian Refugees
description: To the Editor:

title: Bronx Cheers for Some Stars
description: It didn't surprise Mark Messier, or Adam Graves, or even John Vanbiesbrouck, who does not play for the Rangers anymore. On a night designed to honor legendary National Hockey League players and to showcase the skills of the league's current All-Stars, the Madison Square Garden crowd still managed to find plenty of things to boo.

title: G.O.P. SEES CRIME AS A MAJOR ISSUE
description: It was the winter meeting of the Republican National Committee, but it more resembled a convention of prison builders today as party leaders put a new emphasis on an old assertion: that Republicans are tougher than Democrats against crime.

title: New Gifts Advance WNET Arts Project
description: With two donations totaling $3 million, the public television station WNET, Channel 13 in New York, says it has received more than $38 million in its campaign to raise $65 million for new arts and cultural programs. The station this week announced the creation of a division to produce series and specials on the visual arts, architecture, social history and popular culture.

title: Flowers Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 18
Praise of Innis Wins Rebuke For Giuliani
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that a fund-raising dinner on Monday to benefit a conservative black politician, Roy E. Innis, was "probably the most significant Martin Luther King celebration in the New York City area" and complained that the press had not covered it.

title: PNC BANK ACQUIRES UNITED FEDERAL BANCORP
description: The PNC Bank Corporation said yesterday that it had completed the acquisition of United Federal Bancorp Inc. for about $166 million, bridging the gap between its markets in Pittsburgh and Philadelphia. United Federal, based in State College, Pa., has assets of about $900 million and 18 branches. United Federal shareholders will receive $32.50 a share in cash. The core of United Bancorp's unit, United Federal Savings Bank, will form a new company for PNC Bank. It will be headed by Charles C. Pearson Jr., a former president and chief executive of United Federal. PNC, based in Pittsburgh, has more than 550 offices in Pennsylvania, Delaware, Ohio, Kentucky and Indiana.

title: Computer Sciences reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 4,900,000, or 9 cents a share, which reflects adoption of SFAS 103, and also included is a 3 cents a share charge resulting from 1993 tax legislation during the second quarter.Share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted for a 200 percent stock dividend distributed on Jan. 13.

title: A Fixer-Upper That Becomes a Home and More
description: In a few weeks, Carol F. Darbyshire expects to move into a newly renovated house that will offer real comfort and a measure of financial security.

title: 2d Detective Implicated In Plot to Sell Information
description: For the second time in a month, another New York City police detective assigned to a premier investigative unit has been implicated in a scheme to sell confidential information to organized-crime figures, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Sold! Time to Call Them the New England Permanents
description: The future of the New England Patriots was settled in New England's favor yesterday when Robert Kraft, a Boston businessman who bought the team's Foxboro Stadium six years ago, won a bidding war that included a nominally higher bid from a group that hoped to move the team to St. Louis.

title: Guilford Mills Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
Electronic Arts Inc. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Philharmonic Named Orchestra of Year
description: The New York Philharmonic was named Orchestra of the Year at the Classical Music Awards ceremony at the Royal Albert Hall in London yesterday. The awards, which were first given last year, were started by Bob Geldof, the rock musician best known for putting together the Live Aid benefit in 1985, and Ultan Guilfoyle, a television producer. The ceremony was taped for broadcast tonight by the BBC.

title: City Makes Effort to Settle Suits at OTB
description: In a break from the position of former Mayor David N. Dinkins, the Giuliani administration has indicated its willingness to settle more than a dozen Federal discrimination suits that were filed by white employees who were dismissed by Hazel N. Dukes, the former President of the Offtrack Betting Corporation.

title: Society Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an after-tax restructuring charge of $ 39.6 million, or 33 cents a share, related to the pending merger with KeyCorp. in the quarter and year.c-Included a restructuring charge of $ 50,016,000.

title: Cable Industry Endorses Ratings And Devices to Lock Out Violence
description: The nation's cable television companies have drafted a plan to create a new rating system for violent programming, along with independent monitors to grade them with regular report cards. The four broadcast networks appear likely to accept part of the plan.

title:
FOOTBALL;
San Francisco Left Its Heart With No. 16
description: Everywhere you go in the Bay Area, they say that it's still Joe's Place. Joe Montana may be the quarterback of the Kansas City Chiefs, but those who cheered him will never let him leave San Francisco.

title: Mother of Boy Missing in '91 Vanishes Too
description: The mother of a 5-year-old boy whose remains were found in a New Jersey marsh nearly two years ago after being missing for a year was reported missing herself yesterday by the Middlesex County Prosecutor.

title: Health Care Plan Isn't Cast in Stone
description: Health care experts in Congress and the Clinton Administration have begun to identify areas of possible compromise as they prepare for negotiations over President Clinton's plan to redesign the nation's health care system.

title: To Close or Not to Close?
description: Pity the poor suburban school superintendent in weeks like this. Call off school and you're a snow wimp, intent on robbing young minds of valuable classroom time. Open up and you're putting children's lives in danger. No matter what you decide, snow means angry parents.

title: Advanced Marketing Services Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
Corrections
description: A dance review on Thursday about a performance by the choreographer Donna Uchizono on Tuesday at the Joyce Theater in Manhattan misidentified the lighting designer for "Desiree." He is Stan Pressner, not Dave Feldman.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-5 JAPAN LAWMAKERS REJECT REFORM The upper house of Japan's Parliament rejected a political reform package, a stunning defeat for the Prime Minister, who had promised to end corruption. The vote left the Government in chaos. 1 THE FALLOUT ON TOKYO'S ECONOMY News analysis: Although Japan's vote on reform caused a political storm, its greater impact may be on the country's economy and on relations with the United States. 5 CHINA MOVING ON PRISON VISITS China has given the most serious indications to date that it will open its prisons and jails to inspections by the Red Cross, the international relief agency said. 3 BALKAN POLICY FOUNDERS Ten days after NATO voted to support strong action to halt Bosnian violence, the policy on the Balkans is in disarray again, with the United Nations and allies bickering over who is to blame. 1 WESTERN AIDES TO RUSSIA RESIGN Two leading Western economists resigned as advisers to the Russian Government, saying that the policies announced by the Prime Minister fundamentally would mean the end of economic reform. 4 GLIMPSE OF SOUTH AFRICA'S FUTURE The African National Congress published a list of people it has nominated to replace the current all-white Government. The list of wildly disparate personalities was prepared after weeks of negotiating. 3 ARABS MAY END ISRAEL BOYCOTT The Arab League's leader said after meeting with American officials that the group would consider at a March meeting whether to drop its 43-year-old boycott of companies that do business with Israel. 2 The son of the Syrian President died in an automobile crash. 2 Pashchana Journal: Making do in Ukraine's countryside. 4 National 6-9 LORENA BOBBITT ACQUITTED A jury cleared Lorena Bobbitt of all criminal charges, concluding she was temporarily insane last June when she cut off her husband's penis with a kitchen knife. 1 RELIEF FOR QUAKE VICTIMS Public officials ordered the erection of tent cities for earthquake victims and promised other new relief efforts as long lines of angry aid applicants formed outside Federal centers for a second day. 1 A COMMUTING NIGHTMARE Thousands who work in the Los Angeles area but live in the Antelope Valley are facing a nightmarish drive on freeways, down residential side streets, and past homes damaged by the earthquake. 8 As aftershocks rattle Los Angeles, people ask, "When will it end?" 8 CABLE TV PLANS RATINGS The cable television industry, in an effort to stave off Federal legislation aimed at restricting violent programming, plans to create a rating system with independent monitors who would grade programmers with a regular report card. 1 COURT TO REVIEW FREE SPEECH The Supreme Court has agreed to decide whether judicial orders that keep anti-abortion protesters away from abortion clinics violate the constitutional right to free speech. 6 Abortion foes rallied in the capital, but in smaller numbers. 6 FRONTRUNNER FOR DEFENSE POST President Clinton has narrowed his search for a new Defense Secretary to Deputy Defense Secretary William Perry, and will weigh his decision over the weekend, White House officials said. 6 CLINTON TO FILL CIVIL RIGHTS POST President Clinton is expected to offer the post of Assistant Attorney General for Civil Rights to Deval Patrick, a lawyer with ties to the NAACP Legal Defense and Education Fund, officials said. 6 NEGOTIATING OVER HEALTH CARE Health care experts in Congress and the Clinton Administration have begun to identify areas of possible compromise as they prepare to redesign the nation's health care system. 9 COUNSEL LOOKS FOR STAFF Robert Fiske Jr., the new independent counsel in the case of President Clinton's Arkansas land dealings, is looking for seasoned prosecutors and intends to open an office in Little Rock, Ark. 9 Beliefs: Assessing "The Moral State of the Union." 7 Metro Digest 23 WATER MAIN RUPTURES A 135-year-old water main ruptured in the 6-degree stillness before dawn in South Brooklyn, collapsing half a block of roadway, flooding dozens of houses, cutting off utilities to scores of buildings and closing the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel for the morning rush. 1 A BUSY COMMISIONER New York City's Police Commissioner, William J. Bratton, has personally evicted a panhandler from a subway car and made an impassioned speech about civil rights in a busy two weeks. For the next nine months, he has more ambitious plans. 1 Neediest Cases 24 Business Digest 37 Arts/Entertainment 11-17, 49 Beverly Sills may be nominated as Lincoln Center chairwoman. 11 Benjamin Luxon, with faded hearing but strong voice. 11 Cold cuts theater-ticket sales. 13 Music: Kronos Quartet. 11 Sports 29-34 Obituaries 10 Allan G. Odell; Burma Shave executive who linked beards to bards. Editorials/Op-Ed 20-21 Editorials Slower, but surer, arms curbs. Violence and the Bobbitts. To close or not to close. Where the sun never sets. Letters Anna Quindlen: The $ port$ report. Russell Baker: Of course crime pays. Stephen Koch: The Dimitrov conspiracy. Lynn Woolsey: Reinvent warfare, humanely. Bridge 17 Chronicle 22 Crossword 16

title: GENERAL DATACOMM SHARES SURGE ON FINNISH CONTRACT
description: Shares of General Datacomm Industries, based in Middlebury, Conn., rose 34 percent yesterday after the company said its Netcomm subsidiary had been awarded a contract to provide switches to Telecom Finland Ltd. The stock gained $3.125, to $12.125, on the New York Stock Exchange, where it had the best percentage gain of the day. The asynchronous transfer mode switches covered in the contract are said to send complex video images, voice and computer information across fiber optic phone networks.

title: Allan G. Odell, 90; Burma Shave Executive Linked Beards to Bards
description: Allan G. Odell, who developed the roadside advertising campaign of rhyming jingles for Burma Shave that became a fixture of rural America for almost 40 years, died on Monday at his home in Edina, Minn. He was 90.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Thursday about Rosemary Glyde, a violist and composer, misstated the given name of a surviving sister. She is Judith Glyde.

title: Q & A
description: I.R.A. Withdrawals

title: ASSAD'S SON KILLED IN AN AUTO CRASH
description: The eldest son of President Hafez al-Assad of Syria, widely mentioned as a potential successor to his father, was killed early today in an automobile accident outside Damascus.

title: Lawyer Says Credibility Of Bodyguard Is Key
description: As a grand jury continued hearing evidence today in the assault against the figure skater Nancy Kerrigan, the lawyer for Tonya Harding's one-time bodyguard, Shawn E. Eckardt, said Eckardt's credibility would be a major factor in whether anyone is prosecuted in the case.

title: High Noon In the Post: Shaq Over Ewing
description: It was the last-minute showdown the fans had come to see: Patrick Ewing versus Shaquille O'Neal in the low post. And tonight's battle was won by O'Neal.

title: Regulations for Sex Clubs Are Strengthened in Effort to Curb AIDS Risk
description: The New York State Public Health Council decided yesterday to amend state regulations to strengthen regulations intended to avoid transmission of the AIDS virus. The council added vaginal intercourse to the activities banned in commercial sex establishments.

title: Putting Household Help on the Books
description: At the end of the month, working parents with household help owe the Government a sheaf of papers.

title: Review/Dance; Ritual to a 1970's Beat
description: Time seemed to have stopped in "Polyphonic Warrior Woman," a program of dance by four women that was presented on Thursday night at the Ohio Theater. For better or worse, the premiere of a work of the same name was not dance's answer to Charles Busch but rather a ritual loaded with the kind of simple-minded sloganeering that in the 1970's helped set back the women's movement.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Dr. SPENCER CREW, who has been the acting director of the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of American History for the last year, has been appointed its director, Robert Adams, the secretary of the Smithsonian, said yesterday.

title: Observer; Of Course Crime Pays
description: Every politician in the United States obviously intends to run against crime as soon as possible. It is a noble strategy with a fatal flaw; to wit, it leaves a dearth of pro-crime candidates for crime-hating statesmen to run against.

title: Peoples Energy Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
USX Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $ 92 million from an adjustment in accounting.c-Net lossd-After a charge from an accounting adjustment of $ 1,666,000,000.

title: Mets' Olson Injured
description: GREG OLSON, the catcher the Mets signed as a free agent late last month, had a cast placed on his left hand yesterday to repair a broken hamate bone, the wedgelike bone on the outside of the wrist. The team said Olson would wear the cast for two weeks and then have a rehabilitation period of another four to six weeks.

title: Andrew Corp. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Shootout to Be Tested If All-Star Game Is Tied
description: When the National Hockey League plays its All-Star Game at Madison Square Garden this afternoon, the Eastern and Western Conference teams will use a shootout to decide a winner if the score is still tied after five minutes of overtime.

title: DRESSER INDUSTRIES COMPLETES ACQUISITION OF BAROID
description: Dresser Industries has completed its $1 billion acquisition of the Baroid Corporation, solidifying its position as the fourth-largest oil service company in the United States. Baroid, the leading drilling-fluids maker, will operate as a unit of Dresser, which ranks behind Halliburton, Schlumberger and Baker Hughes in the industry. Dresser said the purchase price consisted of about $830 million for Baroid's 92.5 million shares, and $178 million for the company's long-term debt. Each Baroid share will be converted into the right to receive four-tenths of a Dresser common share. Shares of Dresser were unchanged at $22.50, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

title: CYRIX WINS A COURT ROUND IN DISPUTE WITH INTEL
description: The Cyrix Corporation, based in Richardson, Tex., won a round yesterday in its court fight with the Intel Corporation over its ability to make microprocessors that are compatible with Intel's chips. The Federal District Court in Sherman, Tex., ruled that Intel cannot collect a licensing fee from Cyrix's customers related to a key patent covering the Intel chip. In July 1992, the court ruled that Cyrix's products manufactured by SGS-Thomson were covered by a cross license that SGS-Thomson had signed with Intel. The two companies return to court on Monday.

title: Reinvent Welfare, Humanely
description: It's time to end welfare as I knew it.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale on Dec. 26 misidentified his last published book. It was "Bible Power for Successful Living," edited by Donald T. Kauffman, who assisted in the writing; it was not "This Incredible Century." The obituary also misstated the total sales of "This Incredible Century." The number was 74,373 through December -- not nearly 20 million, which is the figure for "The Power of Positive Thinking." And the obituary misstated the number of languages in which "This Incredible Century" has been published. It has come out only in English, not in 41 languages.

title: Fulton Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $ 2,790,000 from an accounting adjustment.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Dr. MATHILDE KRIM and Dr. JUNE OSBORN have been named the winners of the Scientific Freedom and Responsibility Award, given by the American Association for the Advancement of Science, which has 140,000 members from 121 countries.

title: Aubrey S. Newman, 90, Colonel Famed for 'Follow Me!' Battle Cry
description: Aubrey S. Newman, the infantry colonel whose World War II battle cry of "Follow me!" became a watchword for infantry leadership and bravery, died here on Wednesday. He was 90 and had lived in Sarasota since 1960.

title: The New Quest: Funds That Are Tax-Efficient
description: WEALTHY Americans who watched Washington raise their taxes last summer are just beginning to feel the impact.

title: Sills May Get The Top Job At Lincoln Center
description: Beverly Sills, the soprano who followed a stellar career on the opera stage with a decade as general director of the New York City Opera, is expected to be nominated as chairwoman of Lincoln Center, several people close to the search committee of the board have said.

title: Mandela Group Issues Parliament-in-Waiting List
description: After weeks of speculation, dissent and deal-cutting, the African National Congress published today the list of wildly disparate people it has nominated to replace the current homogeneous Government of whites.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: WATER MAIN BREAKS IN BROOKLYN

title: Whitman Concedes Chance Of Higher Property Taxes
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said today that her plan to cut income taxes should not force New Jersey municipalities to raise property taxes to make up for reductions in state aid. But she warned that she would not hold herself responsible if local spending decisions prompted higher taxes.

title: Let Merit Prevail
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Arab League May End Its Boycott Of Businesses Dealing With Israel
description: The Arab League will consider scrapping its 43-year-old boycott of companies that do business with Israel at a meeting of its Foreign Ministers in March, the League's Secretary General said today.

title: Lederle President Named to Head Immunex
description: The Immunex Corporation, a biotechnology company that merged with Lederle Laboratories' oncology business in June, said today that Lederle's president would take over as chairman and chief executive.

title: Pope Has Long Shown Concern for Jerusalem; Pregnant Omission
description: To the Editor:

title: Lorena Bobbitt Acquitted In Mutilation of Husband
description: In a verdict that highlighted the plight and rights of abused women, a jury today found Lorena L. Bobbitt not guilty of all criminal charges, concluding that she was temporarily insane last June when she cut off her husband's penis with a kitchen knife.

title: Red Cross Says the Chinese Are Seriously Discussing Prison Visits
description: Delegates from the International Committee of the Red Cross said this week that Chinese officials had given the agency the most serious indications to date that they were planning to open prisons and detention centers to Red Cross inspections this year in what would be the first outside inspections in 45 years of Communist rule.

title: Falcons Eye Coughlin
description: The Atlanta Falcons have talked this week to TOM COUGHLIN, the Boston College coach, and SHERM LEWIS, the offensive coordinator for the Green Bay Packers, about their vacant head coaching position. Earlier, the Falcons interviewed JUNE JONES, their assistant head coach for offense, and GARY STEVENS, the Miami Dolphins' quarterback coach. (AP)

title: Home Is the Hero: Anderson Sparks Nets
description: Returning to the site of his college heroics at Georgia Tech for the first time this season, Kenny Anderson played hero again tonight. New Jersey's point guard made a running jump shot that hit off the rim twice and finally went through with 1.3 seconds left in overtime to give the Nets a 113-111 victory over the Atlanta Hawks.

title: Sports of The Times; Don't Rally 'Round This Flag, Boys
description: WHEN players, coaches and officials begin to arrive in Atlanta on Monday for Super Bowl week, they will step into an intriguing conflict over a symbol. Some argue that the symbol is deeply rooted in racism; others call it an artifact of Southern culture.

title: In Frozen Earth, Seeking Peace; A Father's Painful Search Continues for Sara Anne Wood
description: In a basin of snow and thick trees, Robert Wood dropped his shovel by his side and leaned against a small pine this afternoon. He rested a few seconds, then bent again to the frozen earth, stopping for a moment to twist off a branch that had scraped his head.

title: Bills Set Their Focus Just Beyond Montana
description: The American Conference championship game on Sunday has been portrayed as a battle between Joe Montana of the Kansas City Chiefs and the Buffalo Bills' defense. Stop the passing of Montana, the 37-year-old master quarterback, and the Chiefs have nowhere to go.

title: CHOICE EXPECTED FOR RIGHTS CHIEF
description: President Clinton, who was forced to pull back from two previous attempts at filling the Administration's top civil rights post, has settled on a 37-year-old Boston lawyer for the position, senior White House officials said today.

title: Summerall And Madden Bound for Fox
description: The Fox Network has snared John Madden after a month of wooing. And it's getting his broadcast partner, Pat Summerall, too.

title: Cragin Financial Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $ 3,520,000, or 24 cents a share.

title: First American Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $ 1,300,000, or 5 cents a share, and $ 84,000, for the quarter and year, respectively, from a change in accounting for postretirement benefits other than pensions.First American said that per share earnings, adjusted to exclude the loan loss provision reversal, a $ 10 million foundation contribution and the cumulative effect of accounting changes, equaled 83 cents and $ 3.08 for the 1993 fourth quarter and year, respectively.

title: Pishchana Journal; Soviet Breadbasket Digs for Crumbs
description: In the fertile countryside here, where mist-shrouded fields of black soil await new plantings and pigs are being fattened for market, village life is in many ways lurching backward.

title: Official in Shoplifting Case To End Duties for Pentagon
description: John W. Shannon, the former acting Army Secretary who was hired as a high-paid Pentagon consultant last year shortly after he was put on administrative leave for a shoplifting arrest, will leave the job at the end of the month, Defense Department officials said.

title: Judge Silences Lawyers In Drug Program Suit
description: A Federal judge ordered lawyers today not to discuss with news organizations a class-action suit filed on behalf of pregnant, drug-addicted women in Charleston against the Medical University of South Carolina.

title: Bridge
description: The most famous superstition in the bridge world is the Rabbi's Rule, which states that the king of clubs is always bare. Statistics do not support this, but nevertheless a superstitious player, conscious of the singleton possibility, might well have found the winning road on the diagramed deal.

title: Special Prosecutor to Open Office in Little Rock for Inquiry on Clintons' Land Deal
description: After being briefed by Federal officials on what has been learned so far about President Clinton's land dealings in Arkansas, the new independent counsel in the case was back at his Wall Street law firm today, completing personal business and taking the first steps toward finding a staff of prosecutors.

title: New York City, Go Home
description: New York City high school athletes in track and field and four other sports will not be allowed in statewide competitions, effective with the 1994-95 season, the state's largest scholastic sports organization decided yesterday in Syracuse. The decision affects more than 30,000 athletes in 157 schools.

title: INSIDE
description: Clinton Narrows Choices

title: Kellogg Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $ 251,600,000, or $ 1.05 a share, from an accounting adjustment.Kellogg said that the latest quarter included a pretax gain of $ 33.7 million, equal to 10 cents a share, on the sale of its Argentine snack food business, and a pretax charge of $ 34.8 million, or 10 cents a share, primarily from the write-down of certain European assets.Fiscal 1993 and 1992 revenues represent net sales. The company reported revenues in the latest year of $ 6.294 billion, compared with $ 6.227 billion a year ago, following ''other revenue deductions'' of $ 1.5 million in the latest quarter and ''other revenue'' of $ 36.8 million in the previous year.The company also said that other revenue in the latest year included a total after-tax gain of $ 46.3 million, or 20 cents a share, and a total after-tax charge of $ 41.1 million, or 18 cents a share. On an after-tax basis, the gain includes $ 24.1 million, or 10 cents a share, from the sale of Cereal Packaging Ltd. in the first quarter and the earlier reported 10 cents a share gain from the fourth quarter sale of the Argentine snack food business.After tax, the charge included $ 18.5 million, or 8 cents a share, primarily from the write-down of certain North American assets in the first quarter, and the earlier reported 10 cent a share charge primarily from the fourth quarter write-down of certain European assets.In the previous year, other revenue included an after-tax gain of $ 39.2 million, or 16 cents a share, from sale of Fearn International Inc., and an after-tax charge of $ 13.5 million, or 5 cents a share, from disposition of certain operations and assets in North America.

title: Theaters Are Burned By the Cold
description: The big chill is turning Broadway into Siberia.

title: Dangerous Territory for Mutual Funds
description: Some mutual fund watchers are a bit edgy about the tactics being used by funds to bolster returns. If the bull market in stocks and bonds collapses, they contend, these funds could be left with securities worth far less than traditional investments and hard to unload.

title: U.S. Is Setting Up Tent Cities As Nerves Fray After Quake
description: The National Guard began erecting tent cities for earthquake victims today as jittery public officials promised other relief efforts for angry residents waiting in long lines to apply for aid.

title: Roles and Goals for an Energetic Bratton
description: In his first two weeks in office, Police Commissioner William J. Bratton has personally evicted a panhandler from a subway car, read the riot act to a precinct under scrutiny for corruption and gone to Harlem to make an impassioned speech about civil rights.

title: Violence and the Bobbitts
description: The jury in the Lorena Bobbitt trial reached a human judgment rather than a narrow legal one when it acquitted her of malicious wounding yesterday. That's clear to anyone who watched the trial on television or read accounts of the proceedings. Ms. Bobbitt, after all, did indeed sever her husband's penis with a kitchen knife. But why?

title: New England Business Service Inc. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 24
Boy Finds a Role Model, Thanks to Neediest Cases
description: By his own admission, 11-year-old Tyrone Kindred is a live wire. Even as he talks about his seemingly boundless energy, he finds it difficult to remain in one place for more than a couple of minutes.

title: The Dimitrov Conspiracy
description: Even today, it is widely believed that during the 1930's Stalin may have been tyrannical and treacherous but at least his anti-Fascism was genuinely anti-Fascist. Wasn't it? The Communists may have done monstrous things, but about Hitler they were ahead of the complacent, appeasing democracies. Weren't they? There is good reason to doubt it.

title: Beliefs; Index of Good Deeds: Down 25. Index of Good Thoughts: Up 4. Index of Prejudice: Unchanged.
description: President Clinton will deliver his State of the Union Message this Tuesday from the Speaker's rostrum of the House of Representatives. But symbolically he will also be occupying the Presidency's bully pulpit. It will be surprising if the President does not seek to assess the moral and spiritual state of the nation as well as its political and economic condition.

title: Finger-Pointing by NATO Allies Delays Help for a Bosnian Town
description: Just 10 days after NATO leaders called for urgent action, including possible air strikes, to aid besieged towns in Bosnia, allied policy on the former Yugoslav republic is once again in open disarray, with the United States, France and the United Nations bickering over who is to blame.

title: G.M. UNIT TO ACQUIRE STAKE IN VIDEO LOTTERY CONCERN
description: Video Lottery Technologies Inc. said yesterday that the General Motors Corporation's Electronic Data Systems unit had agreed to acquire a minority stake in the gaming company. Under the accord, the E.D.S. unit agreed to buy 545,454 common shares of Video Lottery for $27.50 a share. The E.D.S. unit will also buy 1,912,728 shares of a newly created series of a nonvoting Video Lottery preferred stock. The companies reached a 10-year technology partnership to expand the gaming company's research and development efforts. Shares of Video Lottery, based in Bozeman, Mont., rose $1.50, to $21.25, in Nasdaq trading.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League CLEVELAND INDIANS -- Agreed to terms with Russ Swan, pitcher, on a minor-league contract and invited him to spring training. National League COLORADO ROCKIES -- Agreed to terms with Kent Bottenfield, pitcher, and Pedro Castellano, infielder, on one-year contracts.

title: CONTINENTAL AIRLINES TO CUT DENVER SERVICE AND JOBS
description: Continental Airlines said yesterday that it would cut service at its Denver hub by 23 percent and expects to trim its work force there by 300 jobs. The carrier said that effective on March 9, it would suspend service to six cities from Denver, and cut its daily flights to 107 from 139. The cuts are intended to help Continental achieve profitability, the company said. The affected employees in Denver will be able to bid for jobs in other cities.

title: Reynolds & Reynolds reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss, which was after a charge of $ 19,106,000, or 87 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.(Loss)

title: FPL Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an an after-tax charge from cost-reduction program of $ 84,767,000, or 45 cents a share, from FPL Group Inc. said Florida Power & Light Co.'s contribution to 1993 income, excluding the charge, was $ 510 million, or $ 2.73 a share.

title: Cards With Stats in Multiples of $1.25
description: Will a mint-condition Times Square ever be worth a slightly dog-eared Honus Wagner?

title: Classical Music in Review
description: John Aler Tenor Merkin Concert Hall

title: Where the Sun Never Sets
description: Whatever the weather without, the sun never sets in museums. They are the ultimate storm cellars. Those who brave the blasts to enter their portals reap a seasonal reward: uncrowded galleries. One can escape to the Nile at the Brooklyn Museum, whose newly renovated West Wing displays the curatorial prizes from a superb collection of Pharaonic art. Here it is perpetually summer, and tinted friezes recapture a world without boots, overcoats, snow shovels or the rest of January's dreary impedimenta.

title: Abortion Foes Fail to Attract Crowds of Past
description: When they gathered in past years on the anniversary of the Supreme Court's Roe v. Wade decision, participants in the "March for Life" would hear telephone messages from Presidents who supported their anti-abortion cause. Last year, they were provided an instant rallying point when newly inaugurated President Clinton marked the occasion by signing several executive orders overturning anti-abortion edicts of his predecessors.

title: JAPANESE PREMIER LOSES SHOWDOWN ON VOTING REFORM
description: In a stunning defeat for Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa, the upper house of Parliament today voted down a political reform package that was at the center of his bid to end corruption in Japan's political system.

title: Jefferies Group Inc. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 1,358,000, or 26 cents a share, from accounting for FASB 109.

title: Judge Approves Big Prudential Settlement
description: A Federal district judge today approved the largest class-action settlement stemming from the limited-partnership fraud scandal at Prudential Securities, a decision that will return money to some investors and limit Prudential's potential liability.

title: School Building Agency Official Pleads Guilty to Taking Bribes
description: An official of an agency established to erase graft in New York City's school-building program pleaded guilty yesterday to accepting bribes from contractors in a bid-rigging scheme.

title:
COMPANY REPORTS;
Caterpillar's Shares Jump On a Strong Profit Report
description: Caterpillar Inc. reported strong earnings today that indicate the heavy-equipment manufacturer is back on track. Caterpillar, which had a net loss of $2.8 billion in 1991 and 1992, reported earnings of $652 million, or $6.43 a share, for 1993, including a $29 million charge to retire debt.

title: Pope & Talbot reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $ 562,000, or 5 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.c-Net loss(Loss)

title: Search for Defense Chief Narrows to Pentagon Deputy
description: President Clinton has focused his search for a new Defense Secretary on William J. Perry, the current Deputy Secretary, and will weigh his decision over the weekend, White House officials said today.

title: In Cold, Brooklyn Water Main Bursts and Floods
description: A 135-year-old water main ruptured in the early morning, 6-degree stillness in South Brooklyn yesterday, collapsing half a block of roadway, flooding dozens of homes, cutting off utilities to scores of buildings and closing the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel for the morning rush.

title: Review/Music; Quartet Offers Light, Poetry, Motion, Even Ideology
description: Any concert by the Kronos Quartet is partly a sociological affair in which extramusical effects and ideology have as large a role as the compositions. The group's first recital in Carnegie Hall on Thursday night was no exception. It brought together Allen Ginsberg and mystical Minimalism, shards of rock music and iconoclastic compositional methods, along with all the customary Kronos accouterments.

title: CUNY Says Speech by Jeffries Hurt Fund Raising
description: Lawyers for the City University of New York told an appeals court yesterday that a speech by Dr. Leonard Jeffries, the head of the black studies department at City College, had disrupted the university and hurt its fund-raising efforts.

title: Precision Castparts Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
description: b-After a charge of $ 2.9 million, or 22 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.c-Net lossThe latest 9 months included a tax benefit of $ 2.4 million, or 18 cents a share, from an agreement with the Internal Revenue Service concerning research and development tax credits in prior years.The year-ago quarter and 9 months included a provision for restructuring charges of $ 27.2 million, or 95 cents a share, and a provision for environmental charges of $ 9.9 million, or 34 cents a share.Year-ago periods ended Dec. 27, 1992.(Loss)

title: A Pressured Bill White Delays His Resignation
description: National League club owners yesterday tried to persuade Bill White not to quit as their league president immediately. They succeeded at least for the day, and White's resignation was not announced.

title: CORDIS PLANS TO PURCHASE WEBSTER LABORATORIES
description: The Cordis Corporation agreed yesterday to buy Webster Laboratories Inc., based in Baldwin, Calif., a provider of heart catheters, in a stock swap. Shareholders of Webster, which is privately held, would receive 1.63 million to 2 million common shares of Cordis, which is based in Miami. The final number would be based on the price of Cordis shares before the acquisition is completed, Cordis said. The transaction would be worth $78 million to $96 million, based on Cordis's closing share price yesterday of $48, down 37.5 cents. Webster provides electrophysiology catheters, devices designed to diagnose and treat abnormal heart rhythms. Cordis's products include catheters used to inject dye into patients. It also sells balloon catheters used to unclog blood vessels.

title: Review/Dance; Mirthfulness and Passion In Three Works by Robbins
description: The New York City Ballet offered three major works by Jerome Robbins on Thursday night at the New York State Theater. Each was distinguished in its own right, and they complemented one another wonderfully.

title: When Does Reform Toward Indian Peoples of the U.S. Begin?
description: To the Editor:

title: On a Brooklyn Street, Witnesses to a Catastrophe
description: At 514 Clinton Street, life will probably return to normal. Someday.

title: Johnson Stands Ground, Every Hair in Place
description: People make jokes about Jimmy Johnson's prolific use of hair spray and how that hair never moves, and he laughs along with them. They say he is cocky, arrogant. He shrugs it off. Coaches around the National Football League think he has a big mouth. So what, he says. Johnson's motto is: Everyone chill out and let me be.

title: Toyota to Hire Designers On a Contractual Basis
description: Japan's big blue-chip companies are known for their loyal lifetime employees. But the nation's largest auto maker apparently thinks some such employees can get a little stale.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Gwendolyn Toth Harpsichordist St. Michael's Church Manhattan

title: PACIFIC TELESIS GROUP
description: The Pacific Telesis Group said yesterday that it lost $391 million in the fourth quarter, mostly as a result of a reorganization, but its profits from operations were also below expectations.

title: Ruddick Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
description: b-After a gain of $ 3,869,000, or 16 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.Year-ago first quarter ended Dec. 27, 1992.

title: Bell Atlantic Corp.
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation reported nearly a 3 percent rise in fourth-quarter operating profit yesterday to $337.2 million, compared with $327.5 million a year earlier.

title: Hamilton Southworth, 86, Dies; Internist Promoted Living Wills
description: Dr. Hamilton Southworth, an internist who was prominent in medical ethics groups and the administration of Presbyterian Hospital and did early research in sulfa drugs, died yesterday in Presbyterian Hospital. He was 86 and lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan and in Quogue, L.I.

title: Bandag Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $ 220,000, or 1 cent a share, from accounting for FASB 106.

title: 2 Western Economists Quit Russia Posts
description: Two leading Western economists resigned today as advisers to the Russian Government, saying the "aims and policies" announced by Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin mean the end of fundamental economic reform.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ALPINE LACE BRANDS INC., Maplewood, N.J., a specialty cheese concern, plans to sell 65 percent of its Mountain Farms unit to J. R. Simplot Co., Boise, Idaho, to focus on its core Alpine Lace cheese business and to reduce debt. The terms were not disclosed. RALSTON-CONTINENTAL BAKING GROUP shares representing a 6.27 percent stake have been acquired by investment funds controlled by the New York investor Mario Gabelli. The stock, now at $9.125, was purchased at $8.08 to $9.62 a share between Dec. 6 and Jan. 19. Ralston-Continental is a unit of Ralston Purina of St. Louis.

title: Dividing Pension Funds In Divorce Settlements
description: WHEN couples in their 50's and 60's divorce, retirement benefits can be an important part of the financial arrangement.

title: Kenneth Utt, 72, Producer of Films Who Also Acted
description: Kenneth Utt, a film producer whose credits include "The Silence of the Lambs" and "Philadelphia," died on Wednesday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. He was 72 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Standard Federal Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Big Electric Concern Has Large Loss
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation yesterday reported a steep loss of $478 million, or $1.38 a share, for the fourth quarter of 1993 and a loss for the year.

title: Review/Dance; Speed and Nuance, Speed and Daring
description: George Balanchine's "Sylvia Pas de Deux" is associated with two expert technicians, Maria Tallchief and Andre Eglevsky, who performed the duet frequently. And certainly this little oddity of a duet calls for a strong classical technique. But technique must be used here in the service of lightness, charm and almost finicky detail. Danced to a wonderfully gooey ballet score by Delibes, the duet is all pizzicato and candied violet. It is a very French ballet, and Kyra Nichols and Nikolaj Hubbe captured those nuances in a performance presented by the New York City Ballet on Wednesday night at the New York State Theater.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: And Oh, How the Many Have Fallen
description: DR. JOHN LYDEN, the director of the fracture service at New York Hospital, has long observed the fall of man (and woman), but he can't remember a patch of broken bones as bad as the one that started with the current cold spell.

title: Indonesian Official Opposes Johnson's Visit
description: MAGIC JOHNSON will not be allowed into Indonesia with a basketball team next month because he has the virus that causes AIDS, an Indonesian official said yesterday. Johnson's agent, however, said that other officials of the country have assured him that there will be no problem.

title: Arthur Altman, 83; Was Hit Songwriter
description: Arthur Altman, a songwriter whose credits include the music for "All or Nothing at All," died on Tuesday in Lake Worth, Fla. He was 83.

title: Public & Private; The $ port$ Report
description: Figure skating is like a dream, grace and beauty in slow motion, what the body could be if released from the everyday burdens of gravity. "Everything was beautiful at the ballet," three dancers with fractured childhoods sing in "A Chorus Line" of their refuge in toe shoes and tutus. That's what skating evokes, when the ice is silver-bright, the blades swift, the skater accomplished -- a beautiful momentary release from the tatters of real life.

title: SouthTrust Corp. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about a tax dispute between the Pennzoil Company and the Internal Revenue Service misstated the amount of back taxes and interest the I.R.S. wants to collect on Pennzoil's investment in the Chevron Corporation. The total is $785 million, not $885 million.

title: When Hearing Has Faded but Voice Is Strong
description: The occasion hardly needs more drama. From their inception three years ago, Robert Shaw's annual choral workshops at Carnegie Hall and the resulting performances have been acclaimed highlights of the musical season in New York.

title: Kimball International Inc.  (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 1.2 million, or 5 cents a share, from adoption of FASB 109.c-Included a charge of $ 2,850,000, or 13 cents a share, for restructuring European piano operations.

title: Justices to Review Order Curbing Abortion Protest
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether judicial orders that keep anti-abortion protesters away from abortion clinics violate the demonstrators' constitutional right to free speech.

title: Dr. A. T. Jersild, 91, Teacher and Expert In Child Psychology
description: Dr. Arthur Thomas Jersild, a developmental psychologist who wrote about how schools can foster self-awareness and self-understanding in children and teachers, died on Monday at a nursing home in Beaufort, S.C. A former resident of Middletown, N.J., he was 91.

title: USX-U.S. Steel Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included after-tax gain of $ 83 million. No. 112, charges recorded by equity affiliates, other charges related to prior periods and several 1993 tax adjustments.c-Included pretax charges totaling $ 364 million, consisting of charges from B&LE and Energy Buyers suits, restructuring charges, current-period costs from adoption of S.F.A.S. 112, certain litigation and environmental charges and gains from utilization of insurance reserves to pay certain employee insurance benefits. The period was also after a charge of $ 69 million, or $ 1.08 a share, from an adjustment in accounting.d-Net loss, which included $ 166 million charge from the effect of certain legal, environmental and other contingency accruals, provisions for loan losses, restructuring charges, market value provisions for foreclosed real estate assets and certain other charges related to prior periods.e-After a charge of $ 1,335,000,000, or $ 23.93 a share, from an adjustment in accounting, and includes pretax charges totaling $ 273 million for certain legal, environmental and other contingent liabilities, provisions for loan losses related to USX Credit, restructuring charges and market value provisions for foreclosed real estates.(Loss)

title: A Setback for Economy and U.S. Trade
description: Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa's devastating loss in Parliament today set off an upheaval in Japan's politics, but in practical terms, it seems likely to have an even greater impact on the country's faltering economy and its frayed relations with the United States.

title: Aftershocks Rumble On, Prompting an Agitated Question: Isn't It Over Yet?
description: As aftershocks from Monday's earthquake continue to rattle this city, many residents who once prided themselves on their laid-back style jump at the slightest rumble, avoid going inside buildings and refuse to leave their children's side. One question is on their mind: When is it going to end?

title: Sports of The Times; Politically Incorrect Johnson Could Make Pro Football Fun Again
description: It has always been a mystery to me why college football had the scamps while pro football had the headmasters. I have never understood why so-called institutions of higher learning nurtured great quotable characters like Barry Switzer and Lou Holtz and Jackie Sherrill while the open market of pro ball generally encouraged cautious leaders like Don Shula and Tom Landry.

description: BOTH novice and experienced buyers know they should have a home inspected before buying it. But it doesn't necessarily follow that they will use the professional service wisely or get the most out of it.

title: IMPERIAL CONGRESS
description: Congress has become the King Cong of Washington's political jungle, dominating an executive branch that can no longer claim the coequal status that the Founding Fathers saw as crucial. Those who blame Bill Clinton for this sorry imbalance of power fail to take into account the stunning ascendancy of Congressional clout since the years of Lyndon Johnson.

title: SARAJEVO SHELLING KILLS SIX CHILDREN
description: Exploding artillery shells killed six children and wounded at least three others today while they were sledding and playing on icy streets in the western suburb of Alipasino Polje, witnesses and hospital and morgue officials said.

title: 'Home,' Uplifting Tale Of Young Black Farmer
description: THEATER Three in Port Jefferson is one of the few theaters on Long Island to make an effort to produce drama by black playwrights on a regular basis.

title:
ART;
'Taking the Temperature of His Own Ideas'
description: IF MARCEL DUCHAMP PROVED that art can be anything -- an inverted urinal, a bottle rack, a bicycle wheel -- his admirer Robert Morris has gone on to prove that art can be everything -- a sculpture of steam or mirror or felt, a drawing done with one's eyes blindfolded, an earthwork, a dance performance, even one's body. Since he arrived in New York in 1960, the 62-year-old Mr. Morris, now the subject of a two-part retrospective organized by the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, has been at once a stalwart of the New York art scene and yet one of its most elusive personalities. Like his often ambiguous art, it's a duality he is not at all uncomfortable with.

title: Gastein Skiing
description: To the Editor: Reading Wayne Curtis's article about skiing in the Gastein Valley (Nov. 21) reminded both father and son of a decidedly different experience at Sportgastein, the highest of the five peaks, at Christmas in 1992. We arrived by bus from Badgastein on a beautiful sun-filled day. Although it was early in the season, snow conditions above the chairlift, aided by grooming, were the best in the valley. The ride on the Kreuzkogellift was exhilarating and the alpine scene from the peak was the most spectacular in the valley. We enjoyed a hot lunch at midstation in a modern cafeteria, using precisely the method the author described, ordering via the attractive photos of the selections.

title: In Search of Edith Wharton

title: Fly-Fishing In the Vastness Of Patagonia
description: WE started out on horseback, 20 miles south of the town of El Boson, under an afternoon sun, crossing fields where cows grazed and hawks flew overhead. Our party of five -- three fishermen and two ranch hands -- forded a raging river, the ice-blue water covering our boots, the horses struggling to keep their footing. When we headed up into the foothills of the Andes, scaling inclines it was hard to imagine the animals could maneuver.

title: When the Piano Came of Age: A Sonic Museum
description: IN 1888, A CUSTOMER COULD HAVE bought a Steinway upright piano for the then considerable sum of $1,500. It would have had, as a catalogue of the time put it, "an extra fancy case, designed and executed in the highest style of art, richly carved [ with ] ornamented and engraved consoles and pilasters." It cost the same as the company's seven-foot grand piano and was, in fact, simply a grand stood on its end, with a different action; the upright was called a cabinet grand.

title: Just Locks
description: WHEN Bob Marley, the reggae star, shook his long, matted ropelike tresses, scores of black Americans ran to the sink to imitate his dreadlock look. What they discovered, however, was that dreadlocks, a hairstyle associated with the Rastafarian religion, wasn't like the Afro, which involves simply washing the hair and letting it dry and assume its natural texture. Dreadlocks required years of not combing one's hair, letting it mat naturally.

title: Unwed Mothers: The Scarlet Letter Returns in Pink
description: If there is a movie embodiment of society's ambivalence about unwed motherhood, it is "The Snapper," Stephen Frears's current film about a working-class Irish family coming to terms with their unmarried daughter's pregnancy. When Sharon Curley announces that she is pregnant, her father, Dessie (played by Colm Meany), moans in dismay, flares up, demands to know who the father is, paces, jokes weakly, and finally persuades his daughter to join him for a pint at the pub.

title: Mother of Boy Slain in 1991 Reports She Was Abducted
description: In a puzzling new chapter in the mysterious disappearance and death of a 5-year-old, Timothy Wiltsey, in 1991, the boy's mother told the authorities today that she was abducted at gunpoint outside her home in Middlesex County on Friday morning and driven nearly nonstop to Detroit by two men who identified themselves as law-enforcement officials.

title: Generosity of Young Helps the Needy
description: At an age when many of their peers have nothing more serious to think about than comic-book plots or homework, New York City children are confronted daily with the difficult realities of urban life.

title: Circus and Animal Performances at the Peekskill Armory
description: ANIMALS, whether they are stranded whales, ailing harbor seals or horses headed for the slaughterhouse, are a special concern of the North Wind Museum, an organization that runs an undersea institute on City Island in the Bronx and a private farm in Somers. The nonprofit group uses a variety of animals, including rarities like a llama, a buffalo and a Brahma bull, to teach children about the environment.

title: The World; Iran, the Sequel: New Actors, but the Same Lines
description: WOVEN almost invisibly through the Iran-contra report on the Reagan Administration's arms-for-hostages trading and the cover-up that followed are reminders of the two fallacies that governed American dealings with the revolutionary regime in Teheran at the time.

title: Northwest Saga: Getting Rich by Losing a Billion
description: LET'S say you buy a company, putting down a few million and borrowing billions. Through fees and management contracts, you take out of it more than you invested. The company proceeds to lose almost $2 billion, avoiding bankruptcy only through concessions by workers, suppliers and creditors.

title: Discord in an 'Oasis of Tranquillity'
description: Residents of Turtle Bay Gardens are vigilantly protective of their neighborhood. One of the last enclaves of old town houses around the United Nations, the historic district consists of two rows of stately 1860's brownstones, on 48th and 49th Streets between Second and Third Avenues. Residents include the likes of Katharine Hepburn, Stephen Sondheim and the Consul General of Ukraine.

title: A Cornfield in Manhattan?
description: To commemorate the 200th anniversary of Madison Square Park, the sculptor Melinda Hunt plans to install a work in the spring entitled "Circle of Hope," a ring of planted corn 45 feet in diameter. Once the corn is grown, members of the public will be invited to inscribe their vision of the future on small plaster tablets hung on a surrounding steel fence.

title: Echoes of Pre-Renaissance Italy and Crumbling Walls
description: OF the three Rockland County shows under review, the first is a joint effort by Sister Adele Myers and Todd Stone at the Blue Hill Cultural Center in Pearl River. The others are solos by Francesca Greene and Eric Laxman at, respectively, Piermont Flywheel and Piermont Fine Arts, two galleries adjoining each other at 223 and 218 Ash Street in Piermont Landing.

title: U.S. ASKS INCREASE ON BIRTH CONTROL
description: The Clinton Administration is seeking a substantial increase in spending next year on population control programs with the goal of providing birth control to every woman in the developing world who wants it by the end of the decade.

title: Profile; The 'Iron Lady' Keeping Lotus on Track
description: JUNE L. ROKOFF dislikes nicknames, but at the Lotus Development Corporation, where she is senior vice president for software development and a cult hero, Ms. Rokoff is known as St. June, or sometimes the Iron Lady.

title: A Jazz Griot With a Sense Of Civility
description: THE PHONE IN ARTHUR Taylor's spacious Harlem apartment was ringing off the hook. In an editing mix-up, Musician magazine had included the drummer and author in its year-end obituaries, and Mr. Taylor, fit and muscular at 64, was spending the afternoon assuring horrified relatives and friends that reports of his death were greatly exaggerated. He laughed and shook his head. "This is Phillie Joe's work," he said, invoking the shade of Phillie Joe Jones, like Mr. Taylor a first-rate jazz drummer of the 1950's. "That man was a born trickster."

title: Palm Beach's Majestic Grande Dame
description: FOR years the Breakers reflected Palm Beach society -- rich, grand, conservative, a little ostentatious and more than a little intimidating to mortals of lesser, or newer, wealth. Many of the better-known names of the American dynasties spent the winter at the hotel and guests for the most part were members in good standing of the White Anglo-Saxon Protestant establishment.

title: Meanwhile, on the Extremely Late Show
description: TED HAS ALREADY SIGNED OFF and David and Jay are winding down for the night when Thalia Assuras is revving up. She is on the phone, checking story lineups. She is riffling through a script. She is on the phone again. She is drinking strong, strong coffee -- cup No. 3 or 4 of the 10 or so she guzzles between dusk and dawn. "And then," she says, "I start on the decaf."

title: The Bronte Bunch
description: "So hopeless is the world without, / The world within I doubly prize," Emily Bronte wrote in a poem that reflected the tragic, insulated, inward-turned life experience of her sisters Charlotte and Anne and her brother, Bramwell, as much as her own. In THE BRONTES AT HAWORTH: The World Within (Clarkson Potter, $30), Juliet Gardiner adeptly chronicles both the outer world of the grim Yorkshire town of Haworth, where the Bronte children spent most of their lives with their highly educated but eccentric father, the Rev. Patrick Bronte, and the inner world of the imagination to which each sibling turned, first in childhood and then throughout adulthood, for solace in the wake of relentless tragedy. As young children, they witnessed the sudden deaths of their mother and then of their two oldest sisters, Maria and Elizabeth. In the years that followed, with the exception of brief forays at schools, a few trips, scattered attempts at positions outside of Haworth and Charlotte's marriage only a few months before her death at the age of 38, the Bronte siblings spent their time cloistered on the one hand by the secluded atmosphere of their father's austerely furnished parsonage, and surrounded on the other by the vast, windswept expanse of the Yorkshire moors. All four children conjured fantastical characters and kingdoms in miniature "novels," diaries, poems and mock newspapers -- so-called juvenilia that would put many adult writers to shame. Ms. Gardiner, the author of "The People's War" and "Over Here: The G.I.'s in Wartime Britain," quotes generously from these documents, as well as from the Bronte sisters' novels, family letters and Elizabeth Gaskell's classic biography of Charlotte Bronte. The books also include fascinating drawings and watercolors by the multitalented family. Ms. Gardiner provides an excellent overview of the Brontes and an insightful journey into the artistic imagination. DIANE COLE

High-tech startups were sprouting everywhere, and if things didn't work out in one place, you could always cross the street and maybe even get a raise.

title: Queens Museum of Art Drives Into Cultural Crossroads
description: The Queens Museum of Art is entering the final stages of a three-year, $13.5 million overhaul, and officials are developing programs and exhibitions intended to draw new visitors from the borough's growing ethnic population.

title: Selina Peyser, David Lamb
description: SELINA PEYSER and David Lamb met last March on a blind date that went spectacularly well even though, as Ms. Peyser recalled, "he brought me one rose, which he admitted he pulled out of an arrangement in his office before walking out the door." Mr. Lamb, 33, a managing director at Veronis, Suhler & Associates Inc., a New York investment banking firm, sent her 11 more the next day.

title: Higher Taxes Imperil a Hamburger Shrine
description: IT is shortly before noon on a weekday, and already people are jamming into a tiny pub-like establishment on Crown Street in New Haven. The crowd is, as usual, a democratic one: guys in leather jackets, Yalies in Reeboks, business and professional people in suits, and visitors to the city who had heard about the place and arrived to try the well-known specialty of the house, its hamburger.

title: No Alterations
description: To the Editor:

title: Seton Hall Falls Because Its Shots Don't
description: The Seton Hall crowd cheered for "dee-fense," the Pirates' strength this season, but the needed call was for offense, more of it. Seton Hall came up short near the end today in another tingling Big East contest and lost to Syracuse, 78-74, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Enthralling Missives From Sondheim's World
description: AN INTRIGUING PARADOX OF Stephen Sondheim's theater music is the extent to which his meticulously tailored-to-character songs enthrall when taken out of context. A knotty soliloquy that seems inextricably linked to a dramatic situation can expand into a deeper reflection on love and death. A high-velocity patter song, popped into the middle of a revue, can be savored as a virtuosic wordgame. The quintessential Sondheim ballad -- "Send In the Clowns," "Losing My Mind" or "Not a Day Goes By" -- conveys a yearning that transcends words and evokes Puccini filtered through Freud.

title: The Reformers' Tragedy
description: The Communist old guard has reasserted political dominance in Russia. The resignations of two key reformers, Yegor T. Gaidar and Boris G. Fyodorov, from Boris Yeltsin's Cabinet last week were not just a failure for the Clinton Administration, which has blithely accepted President Yeltsin's commitment to reform, but a serious setback for Russia's move toward democracy. Western governments are now likely to spend much more on their military budgets than they would have on direct aid to Russia.

title: Conversations/Frank Sweeney; Prison Graduate Sells 'New Fish' Words to Live (or Do Time) By
description: THE classified advertisement in USA Today and The National Law Journal was a model of brevity and wit:

title: Postcards From the Sun
description: Like anything exotic, tropical fruit in the winter shocks first and lures later. The soft, satiny flesh of a papaya, banana or mango summons a world that is neither cold nor brittle. Their flavors, like those of pineapples, litchi nuts and grapefruits, are peregrines from a place in the sun.

title: 'Charlie Chan Is Dead'
description: To the Editor:

title: County's Wish List For Albany
description: A NEWLY formed regional alliance of the top officeholders of New York City and Westchester, Rockland, Nassau and Suffolk Counties -- all Republicans -- could provide the political edge necessary this year to achieve a state takeover of local Medicaid costs, long sought by the elected officials.

title: A Mansion Warming
description: Christie's, Jan. 17.

title: Rush Hour in the N.F.L.
description: Kansas City, Buffalo, San Francisco and Dallas reached this afternoon's conference championship games with quarterbacks immersed in playoff experience. Each team has a star running back who grinds out critical yards and receivers who make fingertip catches. Each has special teams that produce game-swinging plays. Each has a defense that can arouse. Each knows plenty about exploiting matchups.

title: Return of the Mondegreens
description: To my horror and embarrassment," writes Yisroel Epstein of New York, "I was informed recently -- and in public -- that the phrase I had always thought was for all intensive purposes was, in fact, for all intents and purposes. After the revelation, of course, the phrase began to make some sense."

title: UP AND COMING: Jeff Williams; On TV, He's Brilliant On Stage, He's Twisted
description: IN "BIRDLAND," THE NEW ABC series set in a mental hospital, the actor Jeff Williams plays Dr. Lewis Niles, a very young, very nerdy, very physiology-oriented psychiatrist about whom everybody, including the audience, asks: "How can such a brilliant, caring clinician be so naive and out of touch with his feelings?"

title: Hit-and-Run Victim Improves; Inquiry Stalled
description: Two days before Thanksgiving, Sonya Kim went out for a jog near the Hudson River piers, tried to cross what may be Manhattan's most daunting road for pedestrians -- the West Street and 12th Avenue corridor -- but never made it to the other side.

title: Let Memory Speak
description: BEYOND DESPAIR Three Lectures and a Conversation With Philip Roth. By Aharon Appelfeld. Translated by Jeffrey M. Green. 80 pp. New York: Fromm International. $17.50. UNTO THE SOUL By Aharon Appelfeld. Translated by Jeffrey M. Green. 211 pp. New York: Random House. $21.

title: Amsterdam Celebrates Its Golden Past
description: Amsterdam is recalling its Golden Age, that time in the early part of the 17th century when the arts flourished in the Dutch capital. The celebration, which started last summer, reached its apex with the December opening of "Dawn of the Golden Age" at the Rijksmuseum.

title: Florida Hopes Fears Will Fade From Memory
description: FLORIDA'S $31 billion a year tourist industry began 1994 hoping that the memory of violent attacks on visitors to the state, including the murders of 10 foreigners, might finally be receding. The results for 1993 were "clearly mixed," said Mayco Villafana of the Greater Miami Convention and Visitor's Bureau. The state estimates that the number of visitors to Florida increased by 1.9 percent, to about 41.3 million, but acknowledges that the bulk of that growth came before September, when the killing of first a German and then a British tourist produced a wave of canceled trips in markets around the world.

title: The Other Side of the Wall
description: ON THE EDGE A History of Poor Black Children and Their American Dreams. By Carl Husemoller Nightingale. 254 pp. New York: Basic Books. $24. HARDBALL A Season in the Projects. By Daniel Coyle. 317 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $22.95.

title: World Markets; Helsinki Soars Amid Signs of Recovery
description: SCANDINAVIA has had a rough time economically for the past several years, and nowhere have times been tougher than in Finland. Only now, after a three-year downturn that could justifiably be called a depression, is the Finnish economy showing signs of life.

title: SUNDAY, January 23, 1994; Top Secret Plane -- Now at a Store Near You
description: It's supposed to be top secret. According to the military, the plane doesn't exist. But scientists, aircraft buffs, and secrecy groupies insist that the Aurora hypersonic spy plane is real. According to an analyst with the Federation of American Scientists, John Pike, the Government has spent $10 billion to $15 billion to produce one or two prototypes.

title: Ecology Unit To Get Home Of Its Own
description: After years of being shifted from one school to another, an ecology center in School District 22 is going to have a home of its own, complete with greenhouse.

title: Man Killed in Subway
description: A man was killed yesterday about 10 A.M. in the 59th Street station of the Lexington Avenue subway line when he walked along a track into an oncoming train, a Transit Authority official said. The incident was apparently a suicide, the official said. The man was unidentified yesterday.

title: Jan. 16-22; 'I Can Sell You A Garden Rake'
description: Take large dollops of snow. Add inch-thick ice. Put in deep-freeze (in any state from Kentucky to Maine), add a shortage of snow shovels and rock salt, and you have a recipe for helplessness.

title: Not All Arts Groups Have Felt Left Out
description: Regarding "When Arts Proponents and Educators Clash" [ Dec. 12 ] , we are writing to emphasize that the Westchester Arts Council, under the leadership of Janet Langsam, has consistently involved Youth Theater Interactions, an arts affiliate and a down-county arts organization, in the process for participating in Arts Excel. Y.T.I. was present not only at the most recent meeting at Manhattanville College but also at the meeting held there last summer as well as the recent Arts Expo.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article in the Westchester Weekly today about political power in Albany mentions Saul Weprin, the Assembly Speaker, and his influence on legislation. The section went to press before the announcement on Thursday that Mr. Weprin had suffered a stroke, raising doubts about his ability to continue in office.

title: In 'Tangents,' a Woman With 5 Identities
description: CONSIDER "Tangents," the showy new play at the George Street Playhouse, as a workout for actresses, and you're in unassailable territory. Five young women are portraying five distinct identities, inhabiting a single being. Each, it might be said, is a self, uncontained.

title: Songs of Conscience Plus Storytelling
description: AN array of free concerts (some accepting free-will donations) brightens the afternoon today, starting at 2:30 when Friends of the Westport Public Library present the folksinging, storytelling and multiple instrument-playing duo of Aubrey Atwater and Elwood Donnelly. The audience can expect a mix of Irish ballads and American songs of social commentary as well as accompaniment on Australian monkey pods and toy xylophones, for example.

title:
In the Region/New Jersey;
New Law Doubles Number of Enterprise Zones, to 20
description: THE movement to form more Urban Enterprise Zones took a leap forward this month with a new law that doubles, to 20, the number able to offer tax incentives to businesses and lower sales taxes to customers to increase jobs and investment within their borders.

title: Don't Use Behemoths As Airport Model
description: I read Richard P. Duffy's Jan. 2 letter [ "The County Airport Needs Mass Transit" ] , signed in his capacity of Westchester Coordinator, Empire State Passenger Association, with something akin to horror.

title: Kiss Me Deadly
description: MURDERING MR. MONTI A Merry Little Tale of Sex and Violence.By Judith Viorst.254 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $21.

title: Quake and Freeze May Interrupt Economy's Growth in Short Term
description: The California earthquake and the Arctic cold in the East together may shear as much as half a percentage point or more from economic growth this quarter, some economists say, but later this year they may actually give the economy a boost.

title: Nuggets Can Talk to Manning
description: The Denver Nuggets have received permission from the Los Angeles Clippers to talk with DANNY MANNING about whether he would agree to sign a long-term contract if Denver traded for him. Denver is on a long list of teams interested in the 6-foot-10-inch Manning, who can become an unrestricted free agent on July 1.

title: Real? Fake?
description: Spotting fur trim.

title: A Little Help From Some Friends
description: In 1988, the Parks Department completed the $1.7 million first phase of a major rehabilitation of Madison Square.
