description: The St. Louis Blues moved to strengthen their defense yesterday, trading three players to the Quebec Nordiques for defenseman STEVE DUCHESNE and a minor leaguer.

title: Syrian Capital Is Still a Center Of Exiles, Rebels and Secrets
description: For all the talk of peace with Israel and a new and more open relationship with the West, this ancient capital remains a city of shadows and secrets, not only for Palestinian guerrilla organizations but also for both exiled Arab leaders and rebellious Kurds.

title: Suncor Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss, which included an asset restructuring charge of $ 238 million, or $ 4.38 a share.(Loss)Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: U.S. AGAIN WARNS BEIJING ON RIGHTS
description: Despite conciliatory gestures by China's leaders aimed at convincing the United States that they are improving their human rights record, Secretary of State Warren Christopher told reporters today that Beijing had not yet done enough to win renewal of trade benefits.

title: Needle Exchanges Can Work
description: The case for distributing clean needles to drug addicts in an effort to slow the spread of the AIDS virus is growing stronger. The rationale for such programs is simple. The AIDS epidemic is ravaging addicts who inject drugs. The virus is spread through the sharing of contaminated needles and syringes. Therefore, even without curing addicts of their addiction, one can slow the epidemic by giving addicts clean needles in exchange for used ones.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Not long after KATHLEEN CHALFANT , who plays six roles in the two plays that comprise "Angels in America" and ELLEN McLAUGHLIN , who plays the angel and three other parts, met, they discovered that they had something in common: their love for the writing of Virginia Woolf. That encounter, at a rehearsal in 1989 for "Part I: Millennium Approaches" at the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles, and a discussion about the writer, set in motion an unexpected collaboration.

title: Federica Montseny, Spanish Minister, 88
description: Federica Montseny, the first woman to serve as a Cabinet minister in Spain, where she secured passage of a law in 1937 allowing women to have abortions, died on Jan. 14 in Toulouse, France, where she and other Spanish Republicans settled as exiles in the late 1930's. She was 88.

title: Russian Reform, Gasping
description: Russian economic reform is barely breathing. President Boris Yeltsin last week named a Cabinet stacked with officials who want to keep the economy firmly under government control. Gone is Yegor Gaidar, the primary architect of market reform; gone, for now, is Boris Fyodorov, who, as Finance Minister, was the only Russian standing in the way of hyperinflation. Mr. Yeltsin appointed only one reformer, Anatoly Chubais, but he is rumored to want out in a few months after he completes his ambitious privatization program.

title: Woman's Abduction Is Doubted by F.B.I.
description: Federal investigators in Michigan expressed skepticism yesterday over the account of a New Jersey woman who said she was abducted at gunpoint and driven to Detroit by two men who called themselves law-enforcement officials and who told her the police did not believe her version of her son's unsolved 1991 murder.

title: Former Executive at Macy May Get Top Spot at A.& S.
description: Federated Department Stores is expected to name a former executive of R. H. Macy & Company this week as the new chairman of its Abraham & Straus department store chain, people in the retailing business said yesterday. Chaim Y. Edelstein, the head of A.& S. since 1985, resigned on Friday.

title: Grand Valley Gas Co. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
The State of the Speech
description: In his State of the Union Message, President Clinton will try to appeal to middle-class voters by focusing on crime and health, aides say. Page B6.

title: Review/Music; The Emerson Explores Late-Quartet Affinities
description: This seems to be the year for dual Beethoven and Shostakovich cycles. The New York Philharmonic is juxtaposing the composers' symphonies, repeating a dual cycle that Kurt Masur presented in Leipzig in the mid-1970's. And the Emerson String Quartet is exploring the late Beethoven and Shostakovich quartets in three concerts at the 92d Street Y. It offered the second installment on Saturday evening.

title: U.N. SEEKS TO HELP TWO BOSNIAN BOYS
description: United Nations relief workers said today that they would try to evacuate two young brothers who were severely wounded here on Saturday, despite threats from Bosnian Serb forces to block such departures.

title: No Headline
description: "We're not going to the Super Bowl just to be going. We have some unfinished business. The ultimate goal is to win the Super Bowl." -- BRUCE SMITH, Buffalo Bills defensive end. [ C1:2. ]

title: Paramount Publishing to Cut Jobs and Books
description: In their first public discussion of plans for the soon-to-be-acquired Macmillan Inc., officials at Paramount Publishing said last week that they would reorganize divisions, reduce the number of imprints and published titles and lay off up to 10 percent of the two companies' combined work force of 10,000.

title: Skating Officials Still Waiting
description: Figure-skating officials are still in a holding pattern concerning the case of Tonya Harding as their deadline for making a decision about her Olympic eligibility approaches a week from today.

title: Equity Issues This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: DMR Group reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.The company said its equity in the loss of Reservation Quebec-CRTQ Inc. reduced after-tax earnings by $ 380,000 during the quarter.

title: U.S. Issues a Warning to Russia To Keep Economic Reform Going
description: In a sharp change of tone, the Clinton Administration's top specialist on Russia, testifying on Capitol Hill, sternly warned today that the Government of President Boris N. Yeltsin must press full speed ahead with economic reforms or risk an inflation rate high enough to "topple governments, sometimes with the ugliest and most dangerous of results."

title: Faster Decisions Are Sought on Bosnia Air Strikes
description: The top United Nations general in the Balkans said today that he wants the decision-making process for NATO air strikes in Bosnia to be shrunk to no more than 30 minutes. He said the shorter time frame would be needed if there was a large-scale attack on a United Nations "safe area" or if United Nations personnel were in peril.

title: Yugoslavia Fishing for Hidden Caches
description: Will the "super dinar" fly?

title: Temple-Inland Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an accounting gain of $ 50 million, or 90 cents a share, due to adoption of F.A.S.B. 106 and 109.

title: Siemens Georgia Plant
description: The automotive unit of Siemens A.G. plans to build a $30 million plant by this summer in Gainesville, Ga., to supply United States auto makers with electric motors for window lifts. The Gainesville plant will employ about 50 workers at first and eventually have about 200 employees.

title: Health Plan's Foes Tap Well of Public Fear
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton passed through town two months ago campaigning on behalf of health care reform, but "Libby" and "Louise" are on the airwaves now, courtesy of the latest advertising campaign of the Health Insurance Association of America.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Jean-Pierre Rampal Flutist Metropolitan Museum of Art Michael Parloff Flutist Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church

title: Apple to Offer a Paging Plan for Newtons
description: In an effort to pick up sluggish sales of its Newton hand-held computer, Apple Computer said yesterday that it would begin offering the system with a paging service under a two-year lease program with Mobilecomm, a subsidiary of BellSouth that offers a nationwide paging system.

title: They Went to Amazon Before Cousteau
description: To the Editor:

title: Suburban Towns And Politics of Salt
description: In this incorrigible winter, the most precious mineral in the communities ringing New York City has been neither gold nor diamonds but simple salt.

title: Varian Associates Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Health Insurance Lobbyist Sits Down With White House, but Critical Ads Continue
description: A top lobbyist for the health insurance industry met today with senior White House officials to see if they could work together on any parts of President Clinton's health plan. But at the same time, the industry unveiled new commercials criticizing Mr. Clinton's proposal.

title: Abraham Gellinoff, for 16 Years A New York Justice, Is Dead at 91
description: Abraham J. Gellinoff, a State Supreme Court justice for 16 years, beginning in 1961, died on Friday at his home in Washington Heights. He was 91.

title: Some Research Must Have Voluntary Subjects
description: To the Editor:

title: First Interstate Chooses Riney
description: First Interstate Bancorp in Los Angeles said yesterday that it had selected Hal Riney & Partners in San Francisco to handle its account, with billings estimated at $25 million to $30 million. Riney was awarded the account after a four-month review that was narrowed to that agency and DDB Needham Los Angeles.

title: Tests Show Growing Gap For Schools
description: Reading and math tests given to New York City schoolchildren last May show a widening split between middle-class and poor schools, according to school-by-school scores released yesterday by the Board of Education.

title: Huizenga Bids to Buy 3d Team: Dolphins
description: In a move that reflects the continuing strong market for sports franchises, H. Wayne Huizenga, the chairman of Blockbuster Entertainment, agreed yesterday to buy his third professional team, the Miami Dolphins of the National Football League, from the family of the late Joe Robbie.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Bulls Back on Top Scottie Pippen scored 23 points and the Chicago Bulls overcame a 14-point deficit last night to win their seventh straight game, 92-86, over the Detroit Pistons at Auburn Hills, Mich. The victory boosted the Bulls into first place in the Eastern Conference standings, half a game ahead of the Atlanta Hawks and one game in front of the Knicks. Pippen also finished with 9 rebounds and 9 assists, just missing his third triple-double of the season. (AP)

title: PENTAGON DEPUTY IS CLINTON'S CHOICE FOR DEFENSE CHIEF
description: After searching unsuccessfully outside the Pentagon, President Clinton today nominated William J. Perry, the Deputy Defense Secretary, for the department's top post, choosing a candidate who had expressed initial reluctance to take the job.

title: Peco Energy Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Peco Energy, which changed its name from the Philadelphia Electric Co. on Jan. 1, said that the decrease in earnings in the latest quarter from a year ago is primarily because of higher federal taxes, and partially offset by lower operating and maintenance expenses.The company said that net income rose in the latest year from a year ago primarily because the previous year included the settlement of the Peach Bottom litigation, which reduced 1992 earnings by 27 cents a share.It said ''favorable weather'' in 1993 increased earnings by 26 cents a share from a year ago, while an ongoing debt and preferred stock refinancing program increased 1993 earnings by 18 cents a share. The company said 1992 earnings were increased 10 cents a share by ''non-recurring federal tax settlements,'' while a higher 1993 federal income tax rate decreased earnings by 4 cents a share.

title: A Mutiny in Little Lesotho Is Rattling Big South Africa
description: Even in southern Africa, the kingdom of Lesotho is rarely big news, but in the last week an intensifying army mutiny has given its neighbor the jitters.

title: SOUTHWESTERN BELL CORP. (N)
description: The Southwestern Bell Corporation said yesterday that fourth-quarter earnings rose more than 10 percent, to a record $385.9 million, helped by a rapid expansion in its cellular business.

title: The Return of High Heels
description: The high-heel shoe is back in the Paris repertory, having nudged clunky work boots out of the limelight.

title: Notre Dame Gets a Most Unlikely Recruit: Gus Ornstein
description: Gus Ornstein, the heavily recruited quarterback from the Fieldston prep school in the Bronx's Riverdale section, announced yesterday that he had verbally committed to attend Notre Dame next season.

title: Books of The Times; Tristan and Iseult as Latin Lovers
description: Brazil By John Updike 260 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $23.

title: A Clue Is Found to a Puzzle In the Life of Single-Sex Fish
description: FOR the female fish, the need has always been clear and compelling. If she is to complete her bizarre reproductive cycle of cloning her eggs into a brood of offspring -- all female replicas of herself -- she must have a male fish's sperm. And she needs his sperm, not for its genetic content, as most would-be mothers do, but to serve as a simple chemical trigger that sets her embryos growing. From the male's point of view, however, the bargain has seemed less than appealing. Mate with a female but not pass on one's genes to future generations? What a waste, what a risk and what a bore.

title: Kelly Set for Cowboys After 2 Prime Games
description: Center Kent Hull of the Bills thought he saw Jim Kelly at his best when the quarterback completed 73 percent of his passes and threw for two touchdowns against the Raiders to put Buffalo in the American Football Conference championship game.

title: Spanish Bank Bailout Hinges on Assessments
description: Regulators and bankers designated by the Spanish Government last month to bail out the Banco Espanol de Credito were putting final touches on a a plan to restructure the bank in preparation for a formal presentation Tuesday to Spain's leading banks, which will shoulder a major part of the rescue.

title: Travelers Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included gain of $ 21.3 million, or 9 cents a share, on the reversal of a deferred tax liability no longer required with 100 percent ownership of Travelers Corp., now the Travelers Insurance Companies subsidiary.c-Included a $ 65 million provision for one-time expenses for the Smith Barnery and Shearson merger, a gain of $ 8.1 million from the sale of units and affiliates, and $ 109.2 million in reported investment portfolio gains. The period was also after an accounting charge of $ 17.7 million for postemployment benefits, net of tax, and an accounting charge of $ 16.7 million for postretirement benefits other than pensions, net of tax.d-Included gain of $ 68 million, or 30 cents a share, on the sale of various subsidiaries and affiliates.e-Included $ 163.2 million in reported investment portfolio gains and net gains from sales of units and affiliates. The period was also after a charge of $ 28.1 million, or 13 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of change in accounting for income taxes.Travelers Inc. is a new company formed by the acquisition on Dec. 31, 1993 by Primerica Corporation of the Travelers Corporation.

title: Judge Grants Panel Right To View Packwood Diaries
description: A Federal district judge today granted the Senate ethics committee the right to examine five years of Senator Bob Packwood's personal diaries, rejecting every facet of Mr. Packwood's attempt to fend off what has become an ever-expanding, and ever more serious, inquiry into his conduct.

title: Review/Music; Sufi Ceremony of Devotion, Without the Whirling Ritual
description: Merkin Concert Hall was packed on Saturday night for a concert of Sufi music from Turkey by the Cinucen Tanrikorur Ensemble, whose program included music from the ayin, the whirling ritual of the Mevlevi order of dervishes. For the first part of the concert, the five-man group appeared in traditional black robes and conical hats and performed a complete ceremony, with a call to prayer, short instrumental improvisations and songs of praise and a final incantation from the Koran. There were, however, no whirling dancers.

title: Anti-Abortion Protests To Continue, Groups Say
description: Anti-abortion groups say they will not be stopped by a Supreme Court decision yesterday allowing the Federal racketeering law to be used against protesters who block access to abortion clinics.

title: Aikman Gets the All-Clear Signal
description: Troy Aikman, given a clean bill of health by doctors at Baylor Medical Center in Texas, checked out of the hospital today and accompanied the Cowboys here for preparations for Super Bowl XXVIII on Sunday.

title: Four Dead, and Family's Charred Dream as Well
description: The fire engines had left, the scent of smoke was fading and Sonia Bishop stood on the sidewalk on Staten Island yesterday, looking up at the charred window frames of the apartment building across the street and trying to remember the sound of her son's voice.

title: Intel Plans a Data System
description: The Intel Corporation plans to introduce an integrated hardware and software system today intended to allow personal computer users to share voice, video and data communications over special telephone lines.

title: Fact-Finding Trip on Harding Is Canceled
description: The executive director of the United States Figure Skating Association canceled a trip to Portland, Ore., last night, which was to have served as a fact-finding mission concerning the Nancy Kerrigan assault case.

title: Fear and Prayer in a Quake Tent City
description: When a strong aftershock struck at 8:15 in the evening, thumping the ground several times under the tent city in Lanark Park, Maria Rodriguez staggered out of the dinner line, wobbled a moment under the eucalyptus trees and then slumped to the ground.

title: Giuliani Urges Street Policing Refocused on Crime
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that the community policing program that was a hallmark of the Dinkins administration must be redefined toward fighting crime and away from putting neighborhoods in touch with social services.

title: On My Mind; Rabin and Sharon
description: Yitzhak Rabin, a renowned general in Israel's wars, looks at maps of Israel and its Arab neighbors, studies military and political realities, and decides current peace negotiations are the road to lasting peace and security for his nation.

title: Japan: The Old Order Fights Back
description: It was high-order treachery when 17 old-line Socialists sabotaged Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa's do-or-die political reform bill. But those who staged the ambush could yet turn out to be among its victims. The Japanese public is tired of corrupt money politics and is deeply angry at politicians who stand in the way of reform.

title: Federal Paper Board Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: b-Included charge of 8 cents a diluted share from write-offs of property, plant and equipment related to mill modernizations; losses on foreign currency transactions and a gain on a timber transaction in both the quarter and year, and the year also included a included noncash charge of 23 cents a diluted share from change in Federal statutory tax rate to 35 percent, from 34 percent.c-Included charge of 5 cents a diluted share from write-offs of property, plant and equipment related to mill modernizations in both the quarter and year, and the year also included a gain of $ 9,000,000, or 22 cents a share, from adoption of FASB 109.

title: Surprise Switch By Nutri/System
description: Nutri/System Inc., the franchised diet center company based in Horsham, Pa., has unexpectedly changed agencies for the second time in five months, moving the creative portion of its estimated $30 million account to Gray Kirk/VanSant Advertising in Baltimore from the Philadelphia office of Foote, Cone & Belding.

title: New Yorker Admits Errors But Denies Fabrication
description: The New Yorker magazine published an unusual apology yesterday admitting that there were "errors of reporting, checking and editing" in an article last week about Court TV, the cable-television network that specializes in trial coverage.

title: Deluxe Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a credit of $ 11 million. The company said the 1993 results included a $ 60 million pretax restructuring charge that was taken in the second quarter to close 16 check printing facilities. At year end, 14 of the facilities were closed at a cost less than previously estimated. As a result, management has reduced its estimate of the total restructuring charge to $ 49 million and recorded the $ 11 million credit.c-Included a $ 49 million pretax restructuring charge. The charge's amount was originally $ 60 million and was taken in the second quarter to close 16 check printing facilities. At year end, 14 of the facilities were closed at a cost less than previously estimated. As a result, management reduced its estimate of the total restructuring charge to $ 49 million and took an $ 11 million credit in the fourth quarter.

title: 9 Hurt in Elevator Crash At Welfare Office Site
description: Nine people were injured yesterday morning when an elevator in a troubled Manhattan building that houses some of the city's Human Resources Administration offices plummeted two stories to the building's basement.

title: Wham! Madden Gives Fox An Image
description: Who could have conceived that the Philadelphia Eagles' 21st-round draft choice of 1958, who believes it isn't too cold to play if your spit doesn't freeze before it hits the ground and doesn't think Nate Newton, the Cowboys' immense offensive lineman, is fat, would be paid nearly as much as Troy Aikman, the Cowboys' $50 million quarterback?

title: Review/Theater; In a Setting Not Lacking in Intimacy, Two Unhappy Marriages Have Dinner
description: You have a choice.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The fallout from KARL LAGERFELD's use of a verse from the Koran in his spring couture collection for Chanel continues to spread, despite apologies from the designer and the fashion house.

title: BELLSOUTH CORP. (N)
description: The BellSouth Corporation said yesterday that its fourth quarter was the strongest operating quarter in its 10-year history. Before one-time charges, it had earnings of $1.56 a share, an increase of about 35 percent from the corresponding 1992 quarter.

title: No Headline
description: "Our whole attitude toward the telephone has changed. In our grandparents' day, they would think nothing of waiting five minutes for a coast-to-coast call to go through. Now if we have to wait three seconds, it's like some form of archaic torture." -- DR. JAMES KATZ, a sociologist who studies the telephone culture. [ B6:1. ]

title: BOEING CO. (N)
description: The Boeing Company reported substantial declines in fourth-quarter revenues and earnings yesterday, which it attributed to continuing weakness in commercial airline sales. But the company said that these factors were partly offset by increased income from customer financing and improved military and space earnings, despite about a 20 percent drop in sales in that segment.

title: U.S. Data On AIDS To Be Free
description: TO expand public knowledge about AIDS and to help ease the financial burden on private AIDS organizations, the Government will provide unlimited free access to its AIDS-related electronic data bases.

title: Crawford & Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Crawford & Co. said income tax changes reduced 1993 earnings by 3 cents a share.

title: A Pentagon Promotion for Mr. Perry
description: After several other candidates spurned his offer to be nominated as the next Secretary of Defense, President Clinton has settled on a sensible and safe fallback choice: William Perry, currently Deputy Secretary. Mr. Perry brings three considerable assets to his appointment -- years of Pentagon experience, recent confirmation by the Senate and a soft-spokenness that may help avoid needlessly inflammatory clashes over defense policy.

title: Harland (John) Co. (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
International Recovery Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net lossc-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 2,764,000, or 58 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 3,715,000, or 78 cents a share, in the 9 months.(Loss)

title: U.S. REJECTS PLEA TO ACT IN BOSNIA
description: The United States and France clashed openly today over a French request that the Clinton Administration pressure the Bosnian Government to accept a European peace plan dividing Bosnia and Herzegovina along ethnic lines.

title: Caremark International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net lossc-Included a restructuring charge of $ 54.3 million, pretax, for both the quarter and year.(Loss)

title: Sale Rules Proposed For Banks
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation proposed new guidelines today for the sale of depositor-owned savings institutions, deals that have come under criticism for enriching executives at the expense of depositors.

title: Bills Will Worry About History After They're Done With Game
description: The Bills arrived in town this afternoon confident that they were going to be able to put the past behind them and start with a clean slate heading into their fourth consecutive Super Bowl.

title: BIG AIRLINES MATCH FARE CUT
description: United Airlines, American Airlines and Delta Air Lines said yesterday that in markets where they compete with Northwest Airlines they would match the discounts of as much as 30 percent being offered by Northwest on overseas travel from April 1 to Oct. 31. The airlines joined USAir and Trans World Airlines in matching the fares, which were announced on the weekend by Northwest and its European partner, KLM Royal Dutch Airlines.

title: Wright Is Arrested
description: The man was all by himself at an interstate rest stop, not a car or another soul in sight, waving his arms wildly, so when RON MATEKAL , a Tooele County, Utah, deputy sheriff, happened by, he thought he ought to investigate.

title: Man Is Killed in a Struggle With an Off-Duty Officer
description: A 29-year-old Long Island man was shot in the head and killed late Sunday in a struggle with an off-duty New York City police officer after the man jumped from a van that had been careering down the street where the officer lived.

title: Silicon Graphics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Prior periods have been restated to reflect the adoption of F.A.S.B.All shares outstanding and per-share data have been restated for all periods to reflect the 2-for-1 stock split distributed Dec. 15, 1993.

title: Japan Set to Launch Rocket to Match West
description: IN 1543, a Portuguese ship bound for Macao was blown off course and landed on this island, exposing the isolated Japanese people for the first time to the gun. In a few years, Japanese craftsmen were making muskets superior to the Portuguese ones.

title: Focus on Crime
description: Along with health care, another domestic issue is expected to figure prominently in President Clinton's State of the Union message tonight: crime. The President is likely to voice support for the latest popular tactic in the war on crime -- mandatory life sentences without parole for criminals convicted of a third violent felony.

title: Oliver Smith, Set Designer, Dead at 75
description: Oliver Smith, one of the most prolific and imaginative designers in the history of the American theater and a former co-director of American Ballet Theater, died on Sunday at his home in Brooklyn Heights. He was 75.

title: Clinton Speech On Television
description: Seven national television networks have scheduled live coverage of President Clinton's State of the Union Message tonight.

title: Lloyd's Settlement Rejected
description: A large group of investors in the Lloyd's of London insurance market refused last week to drop litigation against their advisers and agents, threatening Lloyd's with years of lawsuits.

title: TELIOS PHARMACEUTICAL SHARES FALL 22%
description: The shares of Telios Pharmaceutical Inc. fell 22 percent after the Food and Drug Administration asked for additional material for a premarket approval application for a treatment of diabetic foot ulcers. The stock dropped $1.375, to $4.875, in Nasdaq trading, where its decline was among the steepest of the day.

title: Canary Chicks: Not All Created Equal
description: HATCHLING canaries defy the truism that all baby animals are cute. Born just 14 hours earlier and each weighing hardly more than an aspirin tablet, the three little birds now balled together in a nest are extravagantly repellent, squirming grubs of flesh and fuzz that look less avian than larval. They seem too feeble to be taken seriously, yet simulate the arrival of a parent canary with a puff of air and they start behaving as young birds should: lifting their heads, opening their microbeaks and begging for dinner.

title: Ex-Opera Manager Named To Cultural Post by Giuliani
description: Calling the arts an economic engine vital to New York City's recovery, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday named a former manager of the Metropolitan Opera and dean of Columbia University's School of the Arts to be the city's Cultural Affairs Commissioner.

title: Jenny Craig Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EASTERN COLLEGE REPORT
description: St. John's This could be a make-or-break week for the Redmen. They face Boston College tomorrow and then take on Minnesota on Sunday, with both games at Madison Square Garden.

title: Cirrus Logic Inc. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: b-Included pretax gains from portion of investment in Media Vision of $ 11,226,000 and $ 13,682,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the 9 months also included a gain of $ 7,550,000, or 29 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment.

title: Patterns
description: Black and Making It

title: A Tug-of-War on Bank Regulation
description: Companies lobby the Government all the time, but in recent weeks the Federal Reserve and the Treasury Department have turned the tables by lobbying the banks they regulate.

title: Only Your Own DNA Makes a Perfect Clone
description: To the Editor:

title: Man in the News; A Wide-Ranging Insider: William James Perry
description: In choosing William J. Perry as his nominee for Defense Secretary, President Clinton has turned to a highly skilled manager whose broad experience in Government, academia and high-technology companies has earned praise in Congress and in the Pentagon -- even from critics of the Administration's foreign policy.

title: In Surprise, Gitano Says It's for Sale
description: The Gitano Group, the financially strained jeans company, announced yesterday that it had put itself up for sale -- a move that puzzled analysts and cast a pall over the struggling business's future.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices Rebuff Airlines in Industry's Effort to Restrict Landing Fees
description: The Supreme Court today rejected an airline industry attack on airport landing fees in a ruling that could strengthen the hand of airports seeking to exact more revenue from commercial airline operations.

title: Grow Group Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 391,000, or 3 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 269,000, or 2 cents a share, in year, and extraordinary charges which reflects repurchase of debt of $ 97,000, or 1 cent a share, in the quarter and $ 446,000, or 3 cents a share, in the year.Fiscal 1992 income from continuing operations included an after-tax gain of $ 150,000, or one cent a share, from insurance claims.Grow Group noted that the June 1993 conversion of $ 25.9 million of 81/2 percent convertible debentures resulted in the issuance of 2.05 million common shares and savings of about $ 660,000 in the 6 months ended Dec. 31, 1993.

title: Leftist Terrorists in Greece Kill Ex-Chief of State Bank
description: Members of the far-left November 17 organization, Europe's most elusive terrorist group, shot dead the former president of the state-run National Bank of Greece today.

title: Chess
description: Many top players are most pleased with their games in which it is difficult to discern where the opponent went wrong. They value subtlety more than stormy execution. That was true in the case of the Manhattan grandmaster John Fedorowicz, who picked his encounter with Alexander Ivanov, a Brookline, Mass., grandmaster, as his best production from the United States Championship, held Dec. 2 to 14 in Long Beach, Calif.

title: No-Frills Tutor for Handling Words
description: KIM KOMANDO is a personable and attractive woman who is not an expert typist. That little flaw gives her more opportunities than are strictly necessary in a tutorial to demonstrate how to correct typing errors with a word-processing program, by backspacing over the error and tapping in the intended letters.

title: Gifts Keep Alive Search for Other Life in Universe
description: JUST as Congress was pulling the plug, an infusion of private money has kept alive the search for intelligent life elsewhere in the universe.

title: TYSON OFFERS TO BUY WLR FOODS
description: Tyson Foods Inc. said yesterday that it had offered to buy WLR Foods Inc., a poultry processor, for $30 a share in a deal valued at about $328.7 million. Tyson announced the proposal after the stock market had closed. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, shares of WLR closed at $19, down 25 cents, while class A shares of Tyson closed at $23.125, unchanged. Executives at WLR, based in Hinton, Va., could not be reached for comment. WLR had sales of $617 million for the year that ended on July 3. Tyson, based in Springdale, Ark., had sales of $4.71 billion in its fiscal year that ended in September.

title: Why '3-Strike' Sentencing Is a Solid Hit This Season
description: President Bill Clinton is not the first Democrat to embrace a new anti-crime proposal with a punchy nickname and a national appeal among conservatives. For a month now, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, a former center fielder who may face a hard battle for re-election this year, has been talking almost nonstop about "three strikes, you're out."

title: Schedule Is Not Kind As Rangers Go West
description: Fresh from their weeklong rest during the All-Star Game break, the Rangers hope to have Esa Tikkanen and Greg Gilbert back in the lineup tonight when they begin a three-game California trip by playing the Sharks in San Jose.

title: Santa Fe Pacific Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a pretax gain of $ 204.9 million related to the sale of rail lines in southern California. The company said that adjusted net income in the year-ago fourth quarter, excluding the gain and charge, was $ 43.9 million, or 24 cents a share. The period also included an extraordinary charge of $ 5 million, or 3 cents a share, from the early retirement of debt.c-Net loss, which included an extraordinary charge of $ 5 million, or 3 cents a share, from early retirement of debt, and after a charge of $ 163 million, or 88 cents a share, from changes in accounting for income taxes and for postretirement benefits.The latest year included a $ 32 million increase in tax expense for the retroactive effect of the increase in the maximum corporate federal income tax rate to 35 percent from 34 percent, $ 12.2 million in pretax expense for the company's portion of environmental and litigation charges at Santa Fe Pacific Pipeline Partners L.P., and $ 21.6 million in pretax gains related to the favorable outcome of arbitration and litigation settlements, all reflected in the third quarter.The latest year also included a second-quarter noncash pretax gain of $ 217.5 million on the asset exchange with Hanson and a first-quarter pretax gain of $ 145.4 million from the sale of rail lines in southern California to various transit agencies.The 1992 year included a gain in the fourth quarter on the sale of rail lines and the extraordinary charge, as well as third-quarter pretax charges totaling $ 324.9 million related to Railway unit's crew consist agreement and operations centralization and increased environmental accruals at Railway and Pipeline units.(Loss)

title: Safeco Corp. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an accounting gain of $ 2,877,000, or 5 cents a share, from the adoption of S.F.A.S. 106 and 109. The period also included a charge of 41 cents a share for the deduction for the California Proposition 103 settlement announced in August 1993.The latest periods included investment gains of $ 33,335,000, or 53 cents a share, for the quarter and $ 118,915,000, or $ 1.89 a share, for the year. Year-ago periods included investment gains of $ 12,735,000, or 20 cents a share, and $ 39,745,000, or 63 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Forcing Schools to Help Themselves
description: A New York State panel recently recommended that the state be given authority, through legislation, to take over failing schools. New York City's Schools Chancellor, Ramon Cortines, isn't prepared to go that far but he proposes an aggressive program to intervene to help failing schools succeed.

title: Equifax Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included pretax charges totaling $ 48,438,000 ($ 30.9 million, or 41 cents a share after taxes) for write-down of assets of High Integrity Systems and for costs associated with litigation against California State Lottery. Excluding items, net income would have been $ 1.26 a share.

title: Japanese Market Gets Lift From Overseas Investors
description: Strong buying from foreign investors gave the stock market a lift today after a plunge on Monday caused by Japan's political crisis.

title: Court Rules Abortion Clinics Can Use Rackets Law to Sue
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that abortion clinics can invoke the Federal racketeering law to sue violent anti-abortion protest groups for damages.

title: Westinghouse Science Contest Honors 14 New York Students
description: Fourteen of the 40 finalists announced yesterday in the 53d Westinghouse Science Talent Search, the nation's oldest science contest, are from New York State, double last year's number. Winners of the Westinghouse search are considered some of the brightest, most promising scientists of the future. Five Westinghouse scholars have gone on to win Nobel prizes. In 1992, 20 finalists were from New York State.

title: Farrakhan Is Warned Over Aide's Invective
description: Four months after warily embracing Louis Farrakhan, the minister of the Nation of Islam, a number of prominent blacks are now urging him to distance himself from anti-Semitic comments made by a senior aide.

title: Treasuries Lower in Slow Trading
description: Prices of Treasury securities were mostly lower yesterday as traders and investors said they were leery of trading ahead of President Clinton's State of the Union address tonight and Government note auctions today and Wednesday.

title: Quake Could Be Costliest U.S. Disaster
description: Government agencies and the insurance industry are still tallying the cost of devastation from the earthquake here a week ago Monday, but Federal and state officials agree that it may be the most expensive natural disaster in American history.

title: Duke Power Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a charge of $ 90 million, or 32 cents a share, for an order from the North Carolina Supreme Court remanding the company's 1986 rate case to the North Carolina Utilities Commission.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: FARRAKHAN SPEAKS AGAINST VIOLENCE Addressing more than 10,000 black and Hispanic men in Harlem, Louis Farrakhan, the minister of the Nation of Islam, urged his audience to take steps to end black-on-black crime. A12. A number of prominent blacks are urging Mr. Farrakhan to distance himself from anti-Semitic comments made by a senior aide in a speech at Kean College in Union, N.J. A12.

title: Sealed Air Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $ 1,459,000, or 8 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: It Won't Be Over by Halftime. Honest.
description: Repeat after me: This Super Bowl will be different.

description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $ 26 million, or 16 cents a share, from legal settlements, and after an accounting credit of $ 230 million, or $ 1.39 a share, from the adoption of F.A.S.B. 106 and 109.c-Included extraordinary credits of $ 38 million, or 23 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 65 million, or 40 cents a share, for the year, both from tax-loss carryforwards.

title: Crane Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included charge of $ 39,444,000, or 78 cents a share.

title: Market Place; Insurer's stock suffers quake damage despite little exposure.
description: AFTER the Northridge earthquake last week, some insurance stocks experienced their own seismic shock.

title: Review/Dance; Debuts With Little to Disappoint
description: Young talent dazzled in a series of debuts at the New York City Ballet over the weekend, which also included the season's first performance of "Harlequinade," one of George Balanchine's rare story ballets and certainly his cheeriest.

title: Memos Fault Community Policing
description: A program that has put 3,000 more police officers on the beat has failed to significantly increase arrests of drug dealers and prostitutes and has done little to improve police relations with the neighborhoods the new special units serve, according to a series of internal police memos prepared between January and August 1993.

title: Gunfire Shatters A Boston Haven For Teen-Agers
description: For years the Chez Vous Roller Skating Rink offered children a refuge from the streets of Dorchester and Mattapan, two of Boston's tougher neighborhoods.

title:
COMPANY NEWS;
Denny's Parent Has Loss After a Large Write-Off
description: Reacting to "disappointing" 1993 results, Flagstar Companies Inc., the food-service giant, said yesterday that it would write off $1.5 billion in good will and would take a restructuring charge of $225 million to close or sell 14 percent of its restaurants, mainly in the Denny's group.

title: Rochester Gas & Electric Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Rochester Gas & Electric said that the 1993 results included charges of $ 8.2 million, or 15 cents a share, associated with early retirement programs implemented during the third and fourth quarters.The company also said that a provisional agreement regarding undercharges to gas customers will mean the recovery of $ 3.2 million over three years. Rochester G. & E. chose not to seek recovery of $ 2.3 million which had already been expensed, and $ 2 million was written off in December, reducing 1993 earnings by 4 cents a share.The company also said that 1993 earnings were reduced by $ 5 million, or 9 cents a share, due to accrual of performance awards to employees for meeting corporate performance objectives that resulted in savings of $ 13 million less than forecast for the year.

title: Lewis to Defend Title Against Jackson in May
description: Lennox Lewis will defend his World Boxing Council heavyweight title against Phil Jackson of Miami in May, Main Events, which promotes Lewis's fights, said yesterday in Totowa, N.J.

title: 15 Face Federal Charges In Poker-Machine Racket
description: A reputed former acting boss of the Bonanno organized-crime family and 14 associates were charged in a Federal indictment in Manhattan yesterday with crimes ranging from murder to extortion in what prosecutors called a lucrative gambling racket that forced hundreds of small businesses to maintain poker-playing video games.

title: Grand Valley Gas Co. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
St. Paul Cos.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a one-time, pretax charge of $ 21 million, or 31 cents a share after-tax, related to the restructuring of its U.S. underwriting operations, in the quarter and year. The periods also included after-tax realized investment gains of $ 9.9 million, or 22 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 41 million, or 92 cents a share, for the year.c-Net loss, and included a $ 365 million write-down of Minet goodwill in the quarter and year, and the year included one-time Minet reorganization and other non-recurring charges of $ 39 million, the cumulative effect of two accounting changes, which reduced the loss in the period by $ 76.5 million, or $ 1.81 a share. The periods also included gains of $ 8.7 million, or 21 cents a share, for the quarter and $ 101.3 million, or $ 2.39 a share, for the year.(Loss)

title: Banishing the Busy Signal; The Telephone Revolution Refuses to Wait for the Beep
description: Rod Granger has banished the busy signal. If you call him at his Manhattan office and he is on the phone, you get his voice mail. If the line at home is busy, your call jumps the track to call waiting, and if he and his wife are out, there is an answering machine.

title: Miler Alone on the Oval
description: It has been a lonely indoor season for the miler MARCUS O'SULLIVAN . An engaging 32-year-old Irish-born athlete from Philadelphia, O'Sullivan shows up, gabs with his rivals, and as soon as the starting gun goes off, the other runners hang back, shunning O'Sullivan and making him run alone. "I've been running by myself," O'Sullivan said yesterday, blaming the lack of company in part for a somewhat lackluster showing in four Mobil Grand Prix races this month. His times, 4 minutes 5.1 seconds, 4:02.40, 3:59.72 and 3:59.16, aren't much to brag about for a man who ran the third-fastest indoor mile in history (3:50.94) in 1988.

title: Company Briefs
description: CARMIKE CINEMAS INC., Columbus, Ga., has acquired six movie theaters in Virginia, West Virginia and Georgia from the GC Companies of Boston for an undisclosed amount. MONTGOMERY WARD HOLDING CORP., Chicago, has bought all rights to the Ship 'n Shore brand name from Ship 'n Shore Inc., Aston, Pa., for undisclosed terms.

title: Taxi Drivers Facing New License Rule
description: New Yorkers facing suspension of their driver's licenses for drunken driving or too many moving violations have always had a last-ditch remedy, applying for a "hardship license," good only for driving to and from work and in the course of their jobs.

title: Louis Sheaffer Memorial
description: A memorial tribute to Louis Sheaffer, a Pulitzer Prize-winning biographer of the playwright Eugene O'Neill, is to be held on Thursday at 6 P.M. in the Guild Hall of the Church of St. Ann and the Holy Trinity, 122 Pierrepont Street, in Brooklyn Heights. Among those scheduled to participate are the writer Nora Sayre and William D. Phillips, editor in chief of Little, Brown. Mr. Sheaffer died on Aug. 7 at the age of 80.

title: Valero Energy Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a write-down of $ 17.9 million, or 42 cents a share, of the value of Valero's refinery inventories due to significant decline in feedstock and refined product prices.c-Net income(Loss)

title: Lyondell Petrochemical reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 22 million from cumulative effect of accounting changes. Before the gain, net income was $ 4 million, or 6 cents a share.c-Included a charge of $ 10 million from cumulative effect of accounting changes. Before the charge, income was $ 26 million, or 32 cents a share.

title: DPL Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Corrections
description: A report on Sunday in The City, section 13, about a series of writers' lectures at Marymount Manhattan College misstated the telephone number for ticket information. The number is (212) 517-0564. The series begins at 7:30 tonight with a lecture by Pico Iyer.

title: Hudson Foods Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
McCann Buys Out Japanese Partner
description: McCann-Erickson Worldwide Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired the 49 percent of its Japanese joint-venture agency that it did not already own from its partner, Hakuhodo Inc. in Tokyo. Terms were not disclosed.

title: AILEEN FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY-LAW PROTECTION
description: Aileen Inc. and its Aileen Stores Inc. unit filed voluntary petitions yesterday for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. The filing in the United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan came after the women's apparel maker was unable to reach an agreement with its lender on terms for additional lending. The company said its cash shortage became more critical in the last two weeks when severe winter weather further depressed already-disappointing sales. Aileen operates 144 retail outlet stores in 40 states. To begin its reorganization under Chapter 11, Aileen said it had received a commitment for up to $4.5 million of debtor-in-possession financing from the Sterling National Bank and Trust Company of New York.

title: U.S. Robotics Inc. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $ 215,000, or 2 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: No Headline
description: Companies

title: Consolidated Papers Inc.  (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge from an accounting adjustment of $ 38,048,000, or 87 cents a share.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 15 about the scene as President Clinton appeared on Russian television during his visit to Moscow, adjoining the main article about the day's events, misstated the year of his Presidential campaign. It was 1992, not 1988.

title: Irving B. Kahn, 76, a Founder Of Teleprompter and Cable TV
description: Irving B. Kahn, a founder of the Teleprompter Corporation and a pioneer in cable television, died on Saturday at the New England Medical Center in Boston. He was 76 years old and lived in Mamaroneck, N.Y., and West Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Surplus Plutonium Called Big Threat
description: Huge stocks of surplus plutonium constitute "a clear and present danger to national and international security," said a report issued yesterday by the National Academy of Sciences. But no country has found a long-term solution to that threat, it said, and events around the world make the problem more worrisome as time goes on.

title: Clorox Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain on sale of discontinued operations of $ 32,064,000, or 59 cents a share.c-Included gain on sale of discontinued operations of $ 211,000 in the quarter and $ 414,000, or 1 cent a share, in the 6 months.

title: Observer; Going For Eternity
description: Steven Jobs, onetime boy computer genius, was telling a radio reporter the other evening that when he started out he never feared his business might fail because the old crocks of the world would refuse to adapt to the personal computer. Experience showed that children loved the things, and history, Mr. Jobs said, taught that sooner or later old crocks always died.

title: Parent Sets A Spinoff Of Lehman
description: The American Express Company said yesterday that it would pump more than $1 billion into its Lehman Brothers investment firm, then spin it off to its shareholders, finally closing the door on its unsuccessful effort to become a supermarket of financial services.

title: Beverly Sills Is Named By Unanimous Vote To Head Lincoln Center
description: Thirteen years after her last opera performance and five years after stepping down as general director of the New York City Opera, Beverly Sills will return to the world of arts administration as chairwoman of Lincoln Center. She was elected unanimously to the unsalaried post yesterday at a special meeting of the Lincoln Center board, and is to succeed George Weissman as head of the arts complex on June 13. Mr. Weissman will become chairman emeritus.

title: Baseball Game for Those Who Love Player Stats
description: BASEBALL season began again last week for Hal Richman and his legions of fans. On Opening Day, the faithful cut work, sat on planes, fought the ice (a slugfest) and waited in line for hours outside a cinderblock building to meet the season head-on. It was madness. It always is.

title: Bonn Journal; What's an Asia Hand Doing in Germany? Plenty!
description: When President Clinton nominated Richard C. Holbrooke to be Ambassador to Germany last summer on the same day he named former Vice President Walter F. Mondale Ambassador to Japan, some German officials who knew that Mr. Holbrooke was an Asia expert wondered whether they had won second prize.

title: Northwest Natural Gas Co.  (NMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes charge of 11 cents a share from write-down of value of oil and gas properties owned by its Oregon Natural Gas Development Corp. unit, in the quarter and year.

title: GIULIANI REVAMPS MINORITY PROGRAM ON CITY CONTRACTS
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that the city had eliminated a significant element of a Dinkins administration affirmative action program that has directed a fifth of city contracts to companies owned by minorities and women.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League CLEVELAND INDIANS -- Agreed to terms with Derek Lilliquist, pitcher, on a one-year contract.

title: In Paris, Italians Are the Heroes
description: The French haute couture shows were predictably either very, very good or horrible. A little less predictable was the fact that the heroes of the showing season were both Italian.

title: Nitroglycerin and Shoe at Center of Blast Trial Testimony
description: With a tale of a shoe stained with sulfuric acid and some speculation about frozen nitroglycerin, an F.B.I. forensic chemist resumed his testimony in the World Trade Center bombing trial yesterday.

title: Medusa Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $ 711,000, or 4 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Nynex to Cut 22% of Work Force
description: In the third big job reduction announced this month in the telephone industry, the Nynex Corporation said yesterday that it planned to cut 16,800 employees, or 22 percent of its payroll, in New York and New England by the end of 1996, but that it hoped to avoid sweeping layoffs.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Tinkering with success, Visa tries to create new, invigorating installments of a longtime campaign.
description: SINCE 1985, Visa has been proclaiming, through advertising by BBDO New York, that "It's everywhere you want to be."

description: In recommending a new approach to police corruption in New York -- an independent audit commission to monitor the Police Department's anticorruption activities -- the Mollen Commission prompted a reasonable question: why should anyone think this approach would succeed where so many others have failed?

description: b-Included a charge of $ 10 million, or 10 cents a share, for the early retirement of debt for both the quarter and year.c-Included a charge of $ 56 million for a joint venture divestiture.

title: Man in the News; Groomed for Leadership in Assembly: Sheldon Silver
description: To his colleagues, there was a sense of inevitability about Sheldon Silver's ascendancy today to Assembly Speaker, one of the most powerful positions in state government.
