title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-8 U.S. SHIFTS POLICY ON RUSSIA President Clinton's top expert on Russia told Moscow that it must rapidly pursue economic reforms or risk a disastrous inflation rate. A1

title: Diagnostek Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a pretax loss of $ 1.1 million on the sale of mutual funds and a $ 1 million charge for legal costs related to an aborted merger agreement with Medco Containment Services for both the quarter and 9 months.During fiscal 1993, the company began to classify as revenue certain drug and medical items supplied to contract pharmacy service customers that had previously netted against cost of sales. Amounts have been reclassified for prior periods and had no impact on earnings.Diagnostek said that its latest 9 months earnings included higher than customary gains on the sales of marketable securities, which offset increased sales and marketing expenses associated mainly with the introduction of its RxChoice and CapRX products.

title: Farrakhan Calls on Black Men To Act Against Street Violence
description: Against the backdrop of two recent events that have renewed the controversy surrounding his organization, Louis Farrakhan, the minister of the Nation of Islam, came to Harlem last night to address a crowd of more than 10,000 black and Hispanic men and to offer an urgent plea for his audience to take steps to end black-on-black crime.

title: People
description: * Maureen Ryan, executive vice president and director of client services and operations at Lally, McFarland & Pantello U.S.A., New York, was promoted to president, succeeding Ron Pantello, who was appointed chairman. He continues as chief executive. * Richard Roher, the chief operating officer at Daniel S. Roher Inc., New York, was promoted to president, succeeding Daniel S. Roher, who was named to the new position of senior counselor.

title: Russian Finance Minister Who Resigned (Sort of) Is Still Bargaining
description: The search for a Russian Finance Minister took on bizarre proportions today as Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin met with the recalcitrant reformer Boris G. Fyodorov and said his resignation as Finance Minister was still not accepted, even though he has refused the job twice.

title: Data Delayed On Short Sales
description: The release of data on open positions on short sales for issues trading on Nasdaq from mid-December to mid-January has been delayed. The information, which was scheduled to be published in The New York Times tomorrow, will appear on Saturday instead.

title: Jostens Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $ 4,150,000, or 9 cents a share, from a change in accounting principles.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Another position has been filled in Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's administration: THOMAS A. PALLOZZI, 29, has been named the executive chef at Gracie Mansion, it was announced yesterday by Joannie Danielides, the press secretary to Donna Hanover Giuliani.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, is offering $200 million of medium-term notes due in 1999 at 100 to yield 5.18 percent through Merrill Lynch. The issue is callable in two years.

title: By Design; Let the Games Begin
description: Athletic wear has come out of the locker room and onto the high-fashion runways. And it isn't just a matter of sneakers and cashmere sweat pants.

title: Accounts
description: * Viatel Ltd., New York, to Cox Landey & Partners, New York, to handle the multinational telecommunications company's account, previously handled in-house. Billings were estimated at $3 million to $5 million.

title: DMR Group reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.The company said its equity in the loss of Reservation Quebec-CRTQ Inc. reduced after-tax earnings by $ 380,000 during the quarter.

title: American Brands Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 2,600,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and a loss of $ 198,400,000, or 98 cents a share, for the year, both from an accounting adjustment.

title: Construction Worker Falls to Death in Brooklyn
description: A dilapidated floor in a building under renovation in Brooklyn collapsed yesterday morning, sending a construction worker falling two stories to his death and injuring two other workers, the police said.

title: Travelers Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss; the year was after an accounting gain of $ 169.5 million from the adoption of S.F.A.S. 109 and 106.Travelers Corp. said that 1993 fourth-quarter results included a $ 55 million charge for costs associated with the Primerica merger, and $ 25 million of investment losses, reflecting a $ 111 million addition to reserve for foreclosed properties held for sale.The company said that 1993's year results included $ 59 million in merger charges and $ 211 million in a third-quarter addition to reserves for litigation, asbestos and environmental claims. It also included a $ 40 million benefit related to the change in income tax rate, and realized net investment gains of $ 137.9 million, reflecting the foreclosed properties reserve.Year-ago periods included investment losses of $ 460.2 million for the quarter and $ 416.3 million for the year.The results reflected the operations of Travelers Corp. on a historical accounting basis prior to its acquisition by Primerica Corp. and the formation of the new company, Travelers Inc.The former Travelers Corp. is now a unit known as Travelers Insurance Cos., and starting in the first quarter 1994, its financial results will be reported on a purchase accounting adjusted basis.

title: Coaches' Boycott Is Still Possible
description: The future of the postponed boycott of basketball games organized by members of the Black Coaches Association could be determined by the outcome of discussions with a potential mediator. Representatives of the Community Relations Service of the Justice Department, after meeting last Saturday in Denver with leaders of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, are expected to talk soon with B.C.A. leaders in an effort to determine whether they can help resolve the organization's differences with the N.C.A.A.

title: Kwan Is Young, Graceful And an Alternate, for Now
description: Of all the skaters, the youngest was the most gracious. When 13-year-old Michelle Kwan was bumped from the Olympic figure-skating team in favor of Nancy Kerrigan, she said: "I think it's fair. What I've gotten already is incredible."

title: Detroit Edison reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After the payment of preferred dividends of $ 123,257,000 in the quarter and $ 491,066,000 in the year.c-After the payment of preferred dividends of $ 143,353,000 in the quarter and $ 557,549,000 in the year.

title: Ziff to Offer A Computer Data Service
description: The Ziff-Davis Publishing Company, seeking to take advantage of its strength in computer publications, said yesterday that it would create an electronic information service that it hoped would become a model for publishing in the electronic age.

title: OCCIDENTAL AGREES TO SELL 2 PLANTS
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation has agreed to divest itself of two plants as a condition for its acquisition of certain assets of Tenneco Polymers Inc., the Federal Trade Commission said yesterday. The company will shed polyvinyl chloride plants in Addis, La., and Burlington, N.J., the commission said. The New Jersey plant was acquired from Tenneco. The divestitures must be completed within a year to a purchaser suitable to the F.T.C., and Occidental cannot acquire any interest in a United States polyvinyl chloride producer within the next 10 years without F.T.C. approval.

title: A Pre-Olympic Gold Drain as Budget Surplus Dwindles
description: Officials are expected to report a shrinking budget surplus, estimated at about $60 million, when the board of the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games meets Tuesday.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article by Senator Bob Dole yesterday about the United Nations misstated the level of U.S. spending on the peacekeeping mission to Somalia. He wrote $1.5 billion, not $1.5 million.

title: Dynatech Corp. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
INSIDE
description: Ruling on Packwood Diaries

title: 3 Oil Companies Show Profit Gains
description: Texaco said its fourth-quarter earnings from continuing operations were $349 million, or $1.25 a share, up from $341 million, or $1.22 a share, in the fourth quarter of 1992; total net income, including discontinued operations, was $339 million, or $1.21 a share, compared with $313 million, or $1.11 a share, a year earlier. During the same period, Amoco's earnings rose to $584 million, or $1.17 a share, compared with $548 million, or $1.10 a share, and Ashland posted net income of $58 million, or 90 cents a share, in its first fiscal quarter, up from $25 million, or 41 cents a share.'Met Our Target'

title: King's Wrath: Morocco Family Tale of 2 Decades
description: Morocco is a country where human rights violations have been commonplace and speaking against the King is a risk few dare to take. But after two decades in secret prisons in Morocco, Maria-Inan Oufkir feels that she has little to lose.

title: Merrill and Paine Webber Show Accelerating Profits
description: Surprising no one, Merrill Lynch & Company and the Paine Webber Group said yesterday that fourth-quarter earnings were very strong, capping a third straight year of record profits. A third brokerage firm, Smith Barney Shearson, a subsidiary of the Travelers Corporation, also posted strong results.

title: We Can't Cover Everyone for Every Ailment
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro-Richelieu reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 18
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Q&A
description: Snowflakes

title: Review/Fashion; Belgian Dares Paris Runways
description: With the aging of the mainstream couturiers -- Saint Laurent, Givenchy and Ungaro, for example, are all in their 50's or 60's -- there is constant concern about attracting younger designers to bring couture styles more up to date. Two 30-year-olds showed collections this season. Maurizio Galante of Rome emphasized the intricate handwork of the artisan in his second Paris show. Gerald Watelet arrived unheralded on the last day and voila, there is a new name to cope with.

title: Amerada Hess Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included charge of $ 54.5 million, or 59 cents a share, from mothballing Purvis, Miss., refinery, implementing cost-cutting programs, reducing carrying value of exploration and production assets and surrendering joint venture in Abu Dhabi in both the quarter and year, and the year also included a refinancing charge of $ 10.5 million, or 11 cents a share.c-After a gain of $ 29,500,000, or 31 cents a share, from adoption of FASB 109.d-Net income and the year included a gain on income tax refunds and related interest of $ 25.4 million, or 29 cents a share.(Loss)

title: ARCO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $ 392,000,000, or $ 2.43 a share, from an accounting adjustment.ARCO said the latest year included net charges of $ 545 million after tax primarily related to reorganization of its Lower 48 oil and gas operations.

title: Sports of The Times; Rooting Against 4 Monkeys
description: SOME people call it the Super Bowl rematch "nobody wanted," but the Bills wanted it and so did everybody wearing a red-white-and-blue parka in Buffalo.

title: Alltrista Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an after-tax, noncash accounting charge of $ 714,000, or 9 cents a share.c-Included a $ 4.9 million pretax charge, or 41 cents a share after tax, to consolidate two plastic packaging operations.

title: The Worry: Germ Warfare. The Target: Us.
description: Senator John Glenn's Committee on Governmental Affairs, which begins hearings on radiation experiments involving human subjects today, should also consider the effects of past and present biological warfare testing on unwary citizens.

title: Bridge
description: The Cap Volmac World Top tournament, which ended Sunday in The Hague, was sponsored by a major software company based in Paris and won plaudits from the players. "Everyone here is of the opinion that this was the best field ever anywhere," reports Larry Cohen of Little Falls, N.J. The 16 pairs included all those who would be considered the very best in the world, and there were no relatively weak pairs. The Dutch pair that finished last helped the Netherlands win the world team title in September.

title: Union Camp Corp. (N)
description: COMPANY REPORTS ** Union Camp Corp. (N)

title: Amphenol Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net lossc-Included a $ 3,139,000, or 10 cents a share, after-tax charge for costs incurred in the acquisition of LPL Technologies Inc.The company acquired LPL Technologies and its Times Fiber Communications Inc. unit on Dec. 22, 1992. On a pro forma basis, as if the acquisition occurred Jan. 1, 1992, net income for the 1992 fourth quarter was $ 4.6 million, or 11 cents a share, on sales of $ 139.8 million. The net income for 1992 was $ 19.5 million, or 46 cents a share, on sales of $ 573 million.(Loss)

title: Classical Music in Review
description: I Musici Avery Fisher Hall

title: BC Telecom reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the increase in fourth-quarter revenue reflects an increase in customer lines and cellular telephone service, plus a non-recurring $ 16 million adjustment to shared long-distance revenues.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: In City of Motorcycle-Cop Mystique, an Officer, and Quake Victim, Is Laid to Rest
description: In Los Angeles, there are cops -- and then, as every television fan knows, there are motorcycle cops.

title: Setting Out on the Trail of the Wily Computer
description: IN their 14 years of marriage, Jonathan Katz and Toby Mardis have bought and sold a weekend house, purchased a home in a suburb of New York City, bought and sold four cars and had two daughters. Yet the prospect of buying their first personal computer filled them with anxiety, insecurity and confusion.

title: Bruno's Inc. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: b-After an extraordinary charge from early extinguishment of debt and the prepayment penalty on the redemption of subordinated debentures of $ 3,288,000, or 4 cents a share.

title: Bemis Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge from an accounting adjustment of $ 1,746,000, or 3 cents a share, in both the quarter and year.c-After a charge from an accounting adjustment of $ 274,000, or 1 cent a share, in both the quarter and year.

title: American Freightways Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a charge of $ 400,000 or 1 cent a share, for increased corporate federal income taxes effective in 1993.c-Included a $ 338,000 charge for accounting change.Year-ago share earnings and shares oustanding are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid in May 1993.

title: Lee Alvin DuBridge, 92, Ex-President of Caltech
description: Dr. Lee Alvin DuBridge, president emeritus of the California Institute of Technology, died on Sunday at a retirement center in Duarte, Calif. He was 92 and formerly lived in Pasadena.

title: Meteoroids Hit Atmosphere In Atomic-Size Blasts
description: SECRET data from military satellites in orbit thousands of miles above Earth show that the planet is continually bombarded by big meteoroids that explode in blasts the size of atomic detonations. The data, from spacecraft meant to watch for rocket firings and nuclear explosions, were declassified recently by the Defense Department and are to appear later this year in a book.

title: Tennis Center Scores Again
description: The controversial plans for the $180 million expansion of the National Tennis Center at Flushing Meadows-Corona Park have survived another hurdle by incurring no legal suits during a four-month period that followed the project's Sept. 23 acceptance by the City Council.

title: Regulators Thwart Plan for Big Payouts In Bank Conversion
description: The New York State Banking Department said yesterday that executives and trustees of the Green Point Savings Bank, based in Flushing, Queens, may not receive the multimillion-dollar compensation packages that they had arranged for themselves as Green Point converts from a mutual savings bank to an institution owned by stockholders.

title: Critic's Notebook; A Lesson in Humanity From a Master of It
description: Robert Shaw's performance of Britten's "War Requiem" on Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall, the culmination of a weeklong choral workshop sponsored by Carnegie and led by Mr. Shaw, was, as expected, a sublime event, sure to live in the memory. But to a listener who had followed the sessions leading up to it, the concert seemed almost beside the point. For by then Mr. Shaw, in his inimitably earthy manner, had presided over a weeklong humanistic exercise of the highest order.

title: Rollins Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Knicks Not Equal to the Sum of Their Parts
description: Charles Smith is back. The Knicks have obtained help for their ailing backcourt. So what exactly is the matter with them?

title: Nationalist Vote Toughens Russian Foreign Policy
description: A year ago, Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev stunned an international conference in Stockholm with a sword-rattling anti-Western speech that for a brief moment had diplomats thinking that Russia had reverted to its old imperialist ways.

title: Lett Won't Allow 2 Plays to Break Him
description: Leon Lett was alone in the Texas Stadium parking lot Sunday night. The Dallas Cowboys had just beaten the San Francisco 49ers in the National Conference championship game, and the shy defensive lineman had a smile on his face as bright as the sun. What player wouldn't, knowing he was going to the Super Bowl? Then Lett was asked about a play he has tried to forget, and the smile quickly disappeared.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Gregg Smith Singers St. Peter's Church

title: Classical Music in Review
description: New Haven Symphony Orchestra Carnegie Hall

title: Mastercard Chief to Go To Advanta
description: Mastercard International Inc. said yesterday that Alex W. Hart, its president and chief executive, would leave in March to join a leading bank card issuer, the Advanta Corporation, as executive vice chairman and a member of the board.

title: Bill Clinton's Vital Signs
description: Presidents who pay too much attention to public opinion polls run the same risk as ballplayers who dwell on their batting averages: they waste time they should be spending on hitting and fielding. Still, President Clinton can be forgiven a peek at the most recent surveys marking the end of his first year. They suggest that his vital signs are stable. They also offer timely lessons as Mr. Clinton prepares for a State of the Union address tonight that will define his second year and possibly the rest of his Presidency.

title: Critic's Notebook; For Sundance, Struggle to Survive Success
description: "Success is a tricky mistress," Robert Redford said. "It's nice to have, but it's a tricky thing to embrace." He ought to know. Though he was talking about the Sundance Film Festival, the festival's problems are the kinds that usually nag at movie stars: How to survive the pressures of fame? How to avoid being typecast?

title: We Can't Cover Everyone for Every Ailment; Cooper Plan's Flaws
description: To the Editor:

title: Mouse Study Raises Doubts on Sunscreens
description: A NEW study using mice has raised questions about whether sunscreens can protect against melanoma, the deadliest of all skin cancers. At the same time, experts are asking what it is about sun exposure that increases the chances that people will get melanoma and are re-examining strategies for protection.

title: Flood Damage Stops Revival of a Dance Piece
description: The Erick Hawkins Dance Company has canceled six performances of "8 Clear Pieces," a major revival of a 1960 piece by Mr. Hawkins that was to have opened tomorrow, because of flood damage to the company's studio in SoHo. A water pipe that burst on Sunday caused damage to costumes, props and scenery, a company spokesman said yesterday.

title: Cuomo Appoints a New Head Of New York Power Authority
description: Seeking to put the foundering New York Power Authority on a sharply different course, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo named S. David Freeman, who has brought radical innovations to several public power agencies, to head the authority yesterday.

title: Conde Nast's Visionary to Bow Out
description: Alexander Liberman, editorial director of Conde Nast Publications for 31 years and one of the most influential editors in America, will step down from that job on April 1.

title: Accounting Settlement In Australia
description: In one of the largest settlements agreed to by an accounting firm, KPMG Peat Marwick of Australia will pay $97 million to the State of Victoria, Australia, to settle charges involving its audit of a merchant bank that failed in 1990.

title: Threat at Holland Tunnel
description: Traffic at the Holland Tunnel was delayed for 45 minutes yesterday after a man warned a toll collector at the New Jersey entrance that he had a hand grenade in his car. The police arrested the man when he emerged in lower Manhattan from the tunnel about noon but did not find any grenade, said Sgt. John Mariano of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey police. The man, who was unidentified, was charged with disorderly conduct. All traffic was diverted to one tunnel for 45 minutes.

title: Civil Rights Statute Presents Legal Obstacles
description: The law under which Attorney General Janet Reno will seek indictments in the 1991 killing of a Hasidic student, Yankel Rosenbaum, in Crown Heights is a Federal civil rights statute that has previously been used against the killers of a Jewish radio talk show host in Denver and against students who bombed buildings to protest the Vietnam War.

title: NORWEST TO REPURCHASE UP TO 8 MILLION COMMON SHARES
description: The Norwest Corporation said yesterday that it planned to repurchase up to eight million shares, or about 2.6 percent of the common stock outstanding. The repurchased shares will be used for the company's benefit and shareholder dividend reinvestment plan and for the conversion of convertible securities. The company, based in Minneapolis, also increased its quarterly dividend to 18.5 cents a share from 16.5 cents. The increased dividend is payable on March 1 to shareholders of record on Feb. 4. Shares of Norwest rose 50 cents, to $25.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Phelps Dodge Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income of $ 36.4 million, or 52 cents a share, from sale of 20 percent stake of copper-gold project in Chile, and after a charge of $ 79.9 million, or $ 1.13 a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: BayBanks Inc. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Trinity Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $ 5.8 million, or 15 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of accounting change.

title: Chaos? Creativity? The Scardino Era At Playwrights
description: "People are saying to me, 'I hear it's chaos,' " Don Scardino said. "I look at them and I say, 'It is?' "

title: RENO TO TAKE OVER INQUIRY IN SLAYING IN CROWN HEIGHTS
description: Yielding to strong political pressure, Attorney General Janet Reno agreed today to take over the investigation of the slaying of a rabbinical student during the unrest in Crown Heights in 1991 and try to bring Federal civil rights charges against those who killed him.

title: Nalco Chemical Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary charge of $ 10.6 million and after a charge of $ 56.5 million from an adjustment in accounting. The charges totaled 96 cents a share.

title: Lynne Murray Johnson; King Ranch Heir, 50
description: Lynne Murray Johnson, the wife of Belton Kleberg Johnson, an heir to the King Ranch in Kingsville, Tex., died on Sunday at her home in San Antonio. She was 50.

title: The Pop Life
description: Feliciano Anniversary

title: Angry Echoes of Campus Speech
description: Only several dozen students at Kean College actually heard the words spoken on Nov. 29 by Khalid Abdul Muhammad, a senior official of the Nation of Islam, in a speech that has since been roundly denounced as cruelly abusive of whites, Jews, Catholics, some black leaders and homosexuals.

title: A Hatter Who's Mad but Still Coping
description: SOME undertakings in this city require faith and optimism. Things like opening a school for Linotypists, becoming a Fuller brush man or shoeing horses. Selling men's hats is like that. What we are talking about is selling grown-up serious men's hats to grown-up serious men, Borsalinos, homburgs, fedoras, snap-brim felts -- not baseball caps to be worn with the bill to aft.

title: COLLEGE HOCKEY REPORT
description: Dartmouth

title: Harris Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted.Accounting adjustment in the first quarter resulted in a one-time, after-tax charge of $ 10.1 million, or 25 cents a share.

title: Seymour Samuels; Community Leader, 74
description: Seymour Samuels, a founder and past president of the Queens Jewish Community Council, died last Wednesday at North Shore University Hospital. He was 74 and lived in Bayside.

title: Review/Television; What? Eat Pretzels With All This on the Screen?
description: THERE'S a new 24-hour pit stop on the information superhighway. It's the Television Food Network, servicing cooks and eaters day and night. Sponsors are promised that the network will reach 22 million cable subscribers by the end of 1997.

title: Book Notes
description: Confidentiality Ruling

title: '93 Wages and Benefits Held to 3.5%, U.S. Says
description: Aided by moderation in the cost of health insurance, the nation's employers held wage and benefit increases to 3.5 percent last year, matching 1992's record low advance, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Dr. W. M. Hewlett, Who Broke Barriers Of Race, Dies at 74
description: Dr. William M. Hewlett, a pioneering black physician in Jamaica, Queens, died on Thursday at Jamaica Hospital. He was 74.

title: Theater in Review
description: As You Like It Playhouse at Saint Clement's Church 423 West 46th Street Clinton Through Feb. 19 By William Shakespeare; directed by Mark Rylance; sets and costumes by Jenny Tiramani; lighting by Frances Aronson; composer and pianist, Claire van Kampen; sound by Eric Liljestrand; choreography by Darryl Quinton; fight director, J. Allen Suddeth; production stage manager, Alyson Augustin; dramaturge, James Leverett. Presented by Theater for a New Audience, Jeffrey Horowitz, artistic/producing director; Peter M. Kindlon, general manager. WITH: Leon Addison Brown, David Dossey, Miriam Healy-Louie and Mark Rylance.

title: Russian Premier's Star Is Rising Fast
description: At a time when serious questions are being raised about the course of Russian politics, a former Communist Party bureaucrat who has been Prime Minister for little more than a year is more often than not these days making decisions for President Boris N. Yeltsin.

title: Bruce, Sir, Please Get That Man Off Me
description: Linebacker Mark Maddox faced his first moment of truth as the Bills' defensive signal caller when he asked defensive end Bruce Smith, one of the most feared and dominant pass rushers in the National Football League, to handle an offensive lineman so that Maddox could get a better shot at the ballcarrier.

title: George Keble Hirst, 84, Is Dead; A Pioneer in Molecular Virology
description: George Keble Hirst, a scientist who discovered a way to see the footprints of viruses, died on Saturday in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 84 and lived in Palo Alto.

title: First Financial Management Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net lossc-After income from discontinued operations of $ 1,500,000, or 2 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 30,100,000, or 51 cents a share, in the year.(Loss)

title: Actors Take Leading Role in Helping the Neediest
description: At a time when donations to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are lagging more than $100,000 behind where they were a year ago, several sizable gifts sent in recently by well-known contributors, many of them actors, have buoyed efforts to help the poorest New Yorkers.

title: To the Knicks' Joy, Mr. Smith Goes to the Hoop
description: Making his first start since returning from knee surgery, Charles Smith made the difference last night.

title: Exercise Therapy Can Help Dizziness From Inner-Ear Ills
description: JEFFREY LEVIN was on a commuter train to Manhattan one morning in May 1992 when he suddenly felt unsteady and lightheaded, he said, as if "my head was in a bowl of Jell-O." Doctors told him the dizziness would probably pass, but Mr. Levin only felt worse as the weeks went by.

title: SunAmerica Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an accounting charge of $ 33.5 million, or 80 cents a share, from the adoption of F.A.S.B. 109.The latest period included an investment loss of $ 5,367,000, compared with an investment loss of $ 3,748,000 in year-ago period.

title: Public & Private; A Tale of Two Women
description: Valerie Wilson, a cop's daughter from Queens, was watching the news when she got a powerful sense of deja vu, the emotional equivalent of a shot to her midsection.

title: Sports of The Times; Looking To Level The Field
description: ONE of the first lessons a young athlete learns is that sports life isn't fair. Just when you're primed for the biggest race of your life, you pull a muscle. A day before the big game, your team's most important player suffers an injury. An official misses a critical call that costs you the game. Sometimes you encounter an opponent who's bigger, faster, stronger and more skillful. The beauty of competition is finding a way to win, finding a way to beat the unbeatable.

title: Hannaford Brothers reports earnings for 14wks to Jan 1
description: b-Included a gain of $ 2,100,000, or 5 cents a share, from cumulative effect of change in accounting for income taxes.The company said the year-ago quarter and year consisted of 13 weeks and 52 weeks, respectively, of operations.

title: Paccar Inc. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: All per share figures have been restated for effect of the 15 percent stock dividend declared in 1993.Paccarsaid that the increase in the corporate tax rate reduced 1993 earnings by $ 3.5 million, or 9 cents a share.

title: Air Cleared Over Attack On Riley's Strategy
description: Concerned about a published report in which unnamed players were quoted as questioning the team's offensive philosophy, the Knicks held a clear-the-air team meeting after yesterday morning's shoot-around.

title: C.I.A. HEAD SURVEYS WORLD'S HOT SPOTS
description: In a tour of the world's horizons from his perspective as Director of Central Intelligence, R. James Woolsey said today that his major concerns include the possibility of destructive hyperinflation in Russia, political and ethnic tensions that could fragment Ukraine and a military buildup in North Korea.

title: Review/Film; The Blind Woman Gets Tougher In a Familiar and Deadly Formula
description: Whenever Hollywood trots out its favorite premise about the beautiful blind woman and the deadly stalker, the audience discovers something new. So "Blink," the latest variation on this discreetly sadistic formula, brings its share of little revelations. That even a mystery story can be overpowered by high-tech special effects. That if a stalker wants to be scary he'd better show a little style. And that beautiful blind women are a lot tougher than they used to be.

title: Johnson Won't Make A Visit to Indonesia
description: MAGIC JOHNSON's planned tour of Indonesia was canceled yesterday after immigration officials said they would block his entry because he has the virus that causes AIDS.

title: Cowboy Offensive Line Sheds Anonymity but Not Pounds
description: The Dallas Cowboys' center, John Gesek, took off a $5,000 Rolex watch, a gift from running back Emmitt Smith, and twirled it in his hands with pride. He wasn't so enamored of the watch; it was the idea of feeling appreciated.

title: Merck and Warner-Lambert Split on Results for Quarter
description: Two large drug companies reported mixed results for the fourth quarter yesterday as pressures on prices by large buyers continued to slow earnings growth in the pharmaceutical industry.

title: Yankees Won't Get Harnisch
description: Cross Pete Harnisch off the list of starters the Yankees might bring to the Bronx. Although General Manager Gene Michael is enamored of Harnisch and has had several conversations with the Astros, Bob Watson, Houston's general manager, yesterday characterized trade talks with New York as dead. Toronto is still pursuing Harnisch.

title: Dean Witter Discover & Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $ 32.1 million gain on the sale of subsidiary stock and a $ 28.6 million charge from a change in the method of accounting for postretirement benefits.Year-ago share earnings are pro forma. The company had its initial public offering in February 1993.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, is offering $250 million of medium-term notes due in 2004 at 100 to yield 6.28 percent through Lehman Brothers. The issue is callable in three years.

title: Health Reform -- "Now!"
description: Bill Clinton had one overriding task in his State of the Union address last night: to re-ignite a fire under the proposal for health care reform that he has chosen as the defining issue of his Presidency. Victory will not come easily. Bitter battles lie ahead in Congress and the country. But no one who heard his demands for immediate action -- "now, not next year or the year after . . . now!" -- or his threat to veto any legislation that falls short of universal coverage can fault him for squandering the chance to state his case, plainly and passionately.

title: People
description: * Paul Meijer, creative director at PMSvW/Young & Rubicam, Amsterdam, will join Young & Rubicam Advertising, New York, in a similar position. In addition to his responsibilities as a creative director, he will also head a new group being established to work on applications for new technologies and communications, including infomercials.

title: Off-Duty Officer Is Killed in Queens as Police Chase a Stolen Car
description: An off-duty police officer who joined fellow officers in chasing a driver in a stolen car was killed Monday night in Queens when the suspect's vehicle crashed into the officer's car at over 70 miles per hour, the police said yesterday.

title: Community Police Officers Cited on Hours and Training
description: The thousands of New York City officers working in community policing do not work enough weekends or late at night and are not coordinating well with other police units and other city agencies, according to nearly two dozen internal police reports that analyze the program.

title: Suncor Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss, which included an asset restructuring charge of $ 238 million, or $ 4.38 a share.(Loss)Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Ralph E. Knutti, 92, Heart Institute Leader
description: Dr. Ralph Eddy Knutti, a former director of the National Heart Institute of the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md., died last Wednesday at Chester-Crozier Hospital in Upland, Pa. He was 92 and lived in Kennett Square, Pa.

title: Giuliani and Bratton Begin Push To Shift Police Aims and Leaders
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and his new Police Commissioner began a top-to-bottom reorganization of the New York City Police Department yesterday, intended to give borough and precinct commanders more authority and staff to concentrate on quality-of-life offenses ranging from open-air drug markets to panhandling squeegee men.

title: Nonya Cuisine: Asian but With a Light and Delicate Stripe
description: THE Shanghai Restaurant, a bakery in the Katong district of Singapore, offers a treasure-trove of freshly made pastries. Like Singapore itself, the foods reflect an exotic and colorful blending of Chinese, Malay, Indian, Thai and Indonesian cultures.

title: U.S. Pondering Its Options As Japan Trade Talks Falter
description: Despite last week's warning by Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen that Japan had to make more concessions on opening its markets, the latest round of trade negotiations between the two sides ended today with no tangible progress, American officials said.

title: A Team a Master Builder Would Really Love
description: Four months after Michael Jordan jilted them for a batting glove and a chaw of tobacco, the Chicago Bulls awakened yesterday with the best record in the Eastern Conference. Meanwhile, back at Madison Square Garden, Pat Riley was reading his offensively disgruntled Knicks the riot act.

title: Theater in Review
description: Birdbones The Kitchen 512 West 19th Street Chelsea Through Feb. 6 A solo performance by Dudley Saunders; lighting by Alex Kahn; sound by John Frazier. Presented by the Kitchen.

title: Can We Afford So Many Unskilled Immigrants?
description: To the Editor:

title: STATE OF THE UNION: The Scene; Looking for Rhapsody? Try a Different Address
description: Thomas Jefferson helped compose the Declaration of Independence, designed Monticello, invented countless useful devices and refused outright to deliver a State of the Union speech. He was perhaps our wisest President.

title: Review/Theater; A Midlife Crisis as a Hallucinogenic Mystery Story
description: Though all sorts of music and exotic sound effects swirl throughout the production of Philip Kan Gotanda's "Day Standing on Its Head" at Stage 2 of the Manhattan Theater Club, the loudest noise one is aware of is very familiar: that of a man hitting middle age with a hollow thud.

title: MCI Joins Mexican Phone Venture
description: MCI Communications said today that it was teaming up with Mexico's biggest banking company to build a long-distance network in Mexico, a move intended to create a seamless communications system that would cover most of North America.

title: For Every Ingredient There Is a Season
description: "A GREAT restaurant in the old days was one where you could get anything at any time of year, but that's no longer true," said Michael Romano, chef at Union Square Cafe, at a meeting of chefs last fall to promote the use of local, seasonal and organic produce. "What counts now is what is freshest, most locally available and seasonal."

title: STATE OF THE UNION: The Overview; Clinton Vows Fight for His Health Plan
description: President Clinton offered a broad new defense of his health care plan tonight and vowed to veto any health insurance proposal that did not provide coverage for all citizens.

title: Food Notes
description: Pastries on the Move

title: UConn Soars Amid Visions Of the Top
description: They have never been this way before. Not the Final Eight Connecticut Huskies of four years ago, the group of Tate George, Chris Smith and Scott Burrell. Cliff Robinson's Huskies never came this way. Nor did Toby Kimball's teams, nor Wes Bialosuknia's, nor Vincent Yokabaskas's.

title: Personal Health
description: ONE friend tells me he needs at least eight hours of sleep each night to avoid feeling "dead tired" the next day. Another says that if she gets more than six hours a night she wakes up "feeling like a lead balloon."

title: Frank Morelli, 59; Led a Large Union For Public Workers
description: Frank Morelli, the president of New York City's largest public employees' coalition, died on Friday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 59 and lived in Bohemia, L.I.

title: Michigan National (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 9.3 million from sales of mortgaging service servicing rights, including $ 7.8 million attributable to a second quarter sale postponed to the fourth quarter for accounting purposes.c-Included one-time gains of $ 10 million in the quarter and year. The year also included a gain of $ 6,265,000, or 42 cents a share, from a change in accounting principle.

title: Penn State's Women Roll
description: Jackie Donovan scored 25 points and Tina Nicholson 22 to lead the No. 1 Penn State women's basketball team to a 74-66 victory over No. 17 Ohio State last night in Columbus, Ohio.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HOLLYWOOD PARK INC., Inglewood, Calif., has signed a letter of intent to acquire the Woodlands, a thoroughbred and greyhound racing facility in Kansas City, Kan.

title: Smith and Thomas: Innovators in Pass Catching
description: Mention Thurman Thomas and Emmitt Smith Super Bowl XXVIII's sensational pair of running backs -- and the first thing that comes to mind is what both do best: snatch a handoff from the quarterback and run for glory.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about a bailout plan for Banco Espanol de Credito of Spain misstated J. P. Morgan & Company's ownership interest in the bank. The Corsair Partnership, an investment fund created by Morgan to invest in banks, owns about an 8 percent interest in Banesto, as the Spanish bank is commonly known. Morgan holds a 10 percent stake in Corsair; it does not hold an 8 percent stake in Banesto.

title: A Dispute Over Officer Numbers
description: Amid mounting criticism about the effectiveness of New York's community policing program, an old dispute resurfaced yesterday over whether the Police Department was putting enough new officers financed through special taxes on the streets.

title: Excerpts From President Clinton's Message on the State of the Union
description: Following is a transcript of President Clinton's State of the Union Message tonight, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Cereal sticker shock is forcing makers of well-known brands to emphasize their value.
description: THE Kellogg Company is responding for the first time to the competitive challenges posed by cheaper cereals that are growing in popularity among consumers who complain their favorite brands are overpriced.

title: Martin Marietta reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $ 17,432,000, or 18 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting, for the quarter; the year was after a charge of $ 429,432,000, or $ 4.51 a share, which included a charge of $ 412 million for change in accounting for postretirement benefits other than pensions and charge of $ 17,432,000 for change in accounting for postemployment benefits.(Loss)

title: Prices Dip for Treasury Securities
description: Prices of government securities ended mostly lower yesterday after a less than sterling two-year note auction. The yield on the 30-year bond jumped to 6.34 percent, its highest level in three weeks.

title: Golden West Financial Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The bank said the latest quarter included a gain of $ 17 million on the reduction in a valuation allowance on investments charged against income in previous years, and a $ 9 million reserve established in anticipation of the costs of relocating certain savings branches and the company's data processing and operations center.

title: Press Ahead in Bosnia, 3 Nations Urge the U.N.
description: The United States, Britain and France urged Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali today to press ahead with plans to reopen the besieged Bosnian Government-controlled airport at Tuzla for mercy flights and send new troops to guard Srebrenica, a "safe area" for Muslim refugees in eastern Bosnia.

title: Hancock Holding Co. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A Common N.F.L. Question: How Many Fingers Do You See?
description: What does Troy Aikman remember about the concussion that knocked him out of the Dallas Cowboys' 38-21 victory over the San Francisco 49ers Sunday?

title: Can We Afford So Many Unskilled Immigrants?; Spectrum of Support
description: To the Editor:

title: In School; A public school in Harlem that takes the time, and the trouble, to be family.
description: On West 121st Street in Harlem is a public elementary school small enough for things to be taken into consideration. For example, Malachi Reece is a perfectly decent, upstanding kindergartener who will not nap.

title: Channel Surfers Get a Snack Bar
description: Food, glorious food. Beginning next week, it can be consumed 24 hours a day.

title: New York Police Officer Gets a Standing Ovation
description: President Clinton and a joint session of Congress gave a New York City police officer a standing ovation last night for his effort in fighting street crime in one of the toughest precincts in the Bronx.

title: The Bishop and the Rebels
description: The Mexican Government has never been very fond of Bishop Samuel Ruiz Garcia, so it is surprising -- but fortunate -- that it has asked him to mediate the uprising in Chiapas state.

title: FoxMeyer Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included a charge of $ 42.8 million against amounts owed by Phar-Mor Inc., anticipated legal and collection costs and the writeoff of certain software development costs.(Loss)

title: Bridge
description: If a player is in a hospital with a major physical problem, it does not follow that he, or she, must give up the game altogether. He can, for example, read books and magazines, or solve double-dummy problems. If these are not available he can construct bridge hands with pen and paper.

title: Eugene Kamenka, 65, An Australian Thinker
description: Dr. Eugene Kamenka, an Australian philosopher and social thinker, died last Wednesday in his home in Canberra. He was 65.

title: A Big Step for Seafood Safety
description: For several years now, Congress has bogged down in efforts to enact seafood-safety legislation. Now the Food and Drug Administration chief, Dr. David Kessler, has announced a plan to keep contaminated seafood off the market, using his agency's existing authority.

title: Milk Helps to Combat Bone Loss From Coffee
description: WOMEN who drink at least one glass of milk each day throughout their adult lives can largely counter the bone-thinning effects of a lifetime of coffee drinking, according to a new study of 980 women past menopause.

title: BLACK & DECKER TO CUT 480 JOBS IN EUROPE CONSOLIDATION
description: The Black & Decker Corporation said yesterday that it would discontinue manufacturing in Limburg, Germany, causing 480 people to lose their jobs. The company said the closing was part of its plan to consolidate European manufacturing of consumer power tools in Britain. It said costs associated with the consolidation were provided in a 1992 restructuring charge. Black & Decker, based in Towson, Md., also said it planned to establish headquarters for its European professional power tools unit and to strengthen research and development operations at its facility in Idstein, Germany.

title: American Savings of Florida (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge for the early extinguishment of debt of $ 4,300,000, or 36 cents a share, for both the quarter and year, and the year also included a gain of $ 2,141,000, or 18 cents a share, from change in method of accounting for income taxes.c-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $ 5,145,000, or 43 cents a share, in the quarter and the year included an extraordinary gain of $ 17,400,000, or $ 1.50 a share, which included an operating loss carryforward, a gain of $ 18 million from sale of assets, $ 8.9 million of litigation recoveries, and $ 4 million cash recovery from a bankrupt estate.Year-ago income from continuing operations of $ 6,831,000, or 58 cents a share, is adjusted to reflect the 1-for-5 reverse stock split effected April 27, 1993.

title: President Seeking $6.6 Billion For California Quake Victims
description: President Clinton will ask Congress for at least $6.6 billion in emergency financing to help the victims of last week's California earthquake.

title: David Chandler, 56, Newspaper Reporter Who Won Pulitzer
description: David Leon Chandler, a journalist and author, died on Sunday at his home in Denver. He was 56.

title: No Headline
description: "These changes are intended to do one thing. Get this department, shake it up, shake off the lethargy, shake off the drift and passivity and laissez faire that I sense in this organization." WILLIAM J. BRATTON, Police Commissioner of New York City. [ A1:1. ]

title: AT LUNCH WITH: Ed Koch; How's He Doing? Fine. Just Ask Him.
description: IT sounds like a wail.

title: Off the Menu
description: Chef Shifts in SoHo

title: CHRONICLE
description: Another presidential medal at another branch of the City University will be awarded to a different kind of hero next month. FERNANDO MATEO, the originator of the Toys for Guns campaign aimed at reducing urban violence, will receive the Presidential Medal of John Jay College of Criminal Justice on Feb. 2 from the school's president, GERALD W. LYNCH.

title: Oka Journal; In Canada, Too, the Indians Look Back in Anger
description: Teharahkoken Cree, whose first name means "in between two moons," was describing the peace tree at the Mohawk-immersion elementary school a few hundred yards from the spot where a barricade made Oka a symbol of Indian rights in the summer of 1990.

title: Holyfield-Moorer Site
description: EVANDER HOLYFIELD has given his approval to Caesars Palace in Las Vegas, Nev., as the site for his heavyweight title fight against MICHAEL MOORER on April 22.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JOHN F. KENNEDY JR., who has been known to harbor theatrical ambitions, will be a host on a series of television programs celebrating unsung heros of New York, both individuals and organizations.

title: Review/Television; PBS Offers a New Life of Malcolm X
description: Since Malcolm X's death in 1965, he has taken on a glow of glory. For most of his career, he was a threatening figure to many whites and to blacks who put their hopes in integration and their faith in the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. But the ferocious image, which began to soften in Malcolm's last years, has been burnished by the times.

title: A THIRD ROUND OF CUTBACKS AT BRITISH AEROSPACE
description: For the third time in three weeks, British Aerospace P.L.C. is cutting jobs. The British military and aerospace company said yesterday that it would shed 421 jobs at its Royal Ordnance unit's operations in Chorley, Lancashire, in northern England. The cuts will be made between now and 1995. British Aerospace said earlier that it was cutting 510 jobs at its Defense Dynamics weapons plants and 830 at its Avro International regional jets business.

title: In America; Are We Awake Yet?
description: Is there reason for hope, or is that naive?

title: The 'Rescue' Racket
description: In reinstating a lawsuit by abortion clinics on Monday, the Supreme Court did not say the members of Operation Rescue and similar groups were racketeers. But it did rule, unanimously, that the clinics had a legal right to try to prove they were. If they can prove a pattern of criminal violence, the clinics will have acquired a useful legal tool against "rescue" efforts to shut them down.

title: Quantum Corp. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: b-Included $ 22,753,000 pretax restructuring charge.c-Net incomeLatest periods ended Jan. 1, 1994 and year-ago periods ended Dec. 27, 1992.(Loss)

title: Northern Telecom reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included pretax restructuring and other charges totaling $ 1.16 billion.c-Net incomeYear-ago periods were restated.(Loss)

title: Johnson Is Getting Down to Business
description: To offensive lineman John Gesek, it was no big deal. But that didn't stop the Dallas coach, Jimmy Johnson, from giving him and defensive end Chad Hennings an earful this morning about being late for a team meeting.

title: Consolidated Edison Co. of N.Y.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Same Old Tune: Rangers Know the Way to San Jose's Goal
description: A week off for the All-Star Game didn't stall the Rangers' momentum, it merely refreshed them, especially Mark Messier, their captain.

title: Eating Well
description: MEATLESS does not necessarily mean low in fat. It never has. Cheese, cream, butter, nuts and seeds have plenty of fat and calories. And just because a dish has the name of a vegetable in the title, don't assume it is more healthful than a sirloin steak. Eggplant parmigiana comes immediately to mind.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-9 U.S. MAY SEND MISSILES TO SEOUL The United States is planning to send Patriot antimissile batteries to South Korea, since North Korea has responded to pressure for nuclear site inspection by threatening to end the Korean peninsula armistice. A1 A NEW POWER IN RUSSIA Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, a former Communist who was chosen as Russia's Prime Minister during a revolt against reformers, has become increasingly influential in the Yeltsin administration. A6

title: Basket, Then a Bounce
description: Less than 48 hours after MANUTE BOL scored his first basket of the season, the Miami Heat released him yesterday.

title:
Real Estate;
Here's one Wall Street company that New York didn't let get away to Jersey City.
description: IN one of the largest lease transactions in downtown Manhattan in recent months, Spear, Leeds & Kellogg, a brokerage firm, is taking 149,120 square feet of office space at 120 Broadway and Pine Street.

title: Robert E. Matteson; Disarmament Adviser, 79
description: Robert E. Matteson, a Government specialist in disarmament and intelligence from 1953 to 1972, died on Monday at his home in St. Paul. He was 79.

title: Abbott Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a pretax gain of $ 70 million related to product withdrawal.c-Included a $ 215 million charge related to product withdrawal, and a pretax gain of $ 271,986,000 from the sale of an investment.Abbott Labs said that its latest fourth quarter included net losses on foreign exchange of $ 10,304,000, compared with a net gain from foreign exchange of $ 6,049,000 in year-ago period. For the full 1993 year, the foreign exchange loss was $ 41,298,000, against a loss from foreign exchange of $ 93,205,000 in 1992.Corrected from Tuesday, Jan. 18, editions.

title: CHRONICLE
description: CHRISTIAN FETTEROLF, a Hunter College student who was stabbed when he went to help a woman and her child as they were being mugged on the subway in May, will receive Hunter College's highest award at commencement tomorrow. He will be given the President's Medal along with his degree, in ceremonies in the college.

title: Smith (A.O.) (A) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss, which included an accounting gain of $ 1.6 million, or 8 cents a share, from F.A.S.B. 109, and a charge of $ 46,122,000, or $ 2.25 a share, from a change in accounting for postretirement benefits.Share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted.Due to the absense of any materially dilutive securities, the fully diluted earnings-per-share amounts are the same as the primary earnings-per-share amounts for 1993.(Loss)

title: Confronting a Hate Speech
description: Late last November a senior aide to Louis Farrakhan, the leader of the Nation of Islam, gave a hate speech at Kean College in Union, N.J., in which he castigated Jews, whites, homosexuals and the Pope. The speaker, Khalid Abdul Muhammad, justified the Nazi Holocaust, called for the murder of whites in South Africa and sprinkled his rambling, three-hour speech with such phrases as "Columbia Jewniversity" and "Jew York City."

title: British Business Legend Loses His Empire
description: Roland W. (Tiny) Rowland, the 76-year-old British financier who came to prominence for his failed attempt to buy the famed Harrods department store in London, effectively lost control today of Lonrho P.L.C., the 700-company conglomerate he ran like a personal fief.

title: Assessing Community Policing
description: Internal reports detail a range of problems in the effort to make New York City's police more responsive to community concerns. Page B3.

title: U.S. Urged to Bar Narcotic Lollipop for Children
description: A group of doctors asked the Government today to block final approval of a narcotic lollipop intended to calm children before surgery.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: A Classic Tuscan Dish With an American Twist
description: VARIATIONS on the Tuscan dish of tuna with peas and tomatoes are found in many Italian cookbooks. Like all Italian dishes, it has no single correct version. Sometimes hot pepper is an ingredient; sometimes onions; sometimes sage. But I have never seen a recipe in which the tuna and peas are served over pasta.

title: 2 Leading House Democrats Are Retiring
description: Two leading liberals in the House, each representing a fundamental constituency of the Democratic Party, announced today that they would retire after three decades in Congress.

title: Standing Tall, Passers Are an Easy Target
description: Quarterback-concussion syndrome might not yet be a recognized medical term like, say, punch-drunk syndrome, which has its own entry in the Bantam Medical Dictionary. But if quarterbacks in the National Football League continue to hit the deck as hard and as often as they have during the 1993 season and its accompanying playoffs, it might not be long before it is listed.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Clippers Stop Sonics Ron Harper scored a season-high 37 points and Danny Manning had 27 as the Los Angeles Clippers beat host Seattle, 111-103, last night, the SuperSonics' season-worst third consecutive loss. The Clippers broke a 19-game losing streak at Seattle with their first victory here since Dec. 28, 1985. Despite their three straight defeats, the Sonics' 30-8 record is still the league's best. Since their 26-3 start after a victory over Utah in Seattle on Jan. 8, the Sonics are 4-5. Harper hit 15 of 21 shots, including two of three 3-point attempts, to come within 3 points of his career-best 40 points. Harper, who had 24 points in the opening half, also finished with 10 rebounds. Heat 119, Hornets 98: Rony Seikaly scored 26 points and led a third-quarter run that sent Miami past visiting Charlotte. Seikaly had 11 points during a 20-4 burst that put the Heat ahead, 84-57, with five minutes left in the third period. Seikaly shot 10 for 12 over all and had 13 rebounds.(AP)

title: Dick Tracy Takes It on Chin: Wife Splits
description: First it was Donald and Ivana. Then Loni and Burt. Now Dick and Tess.

title: Special Pupils, Regular Classes, Thorny Issues
description: Flopping on the family couch, his glasses sliding down his nose, Aaron Moreland looked like any 9-year-old, perhaps a future doctor, pilot or accountant. Yet he cannot read or write or follow basic third-grade drills. And as his parents spoke of his learning disabilities, his attention deficit disorder and episodic tantrums, he nodded glumly and agreed, "The bad things."

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about the Anti-Defamation League's report on anti-Semitism in America misstated a finding in some editions. Although vandalism against synagogues and other Jewish institutions declined last year, the number of anti-Semitic acts over all increased, the report said.

title: Walsh Report on Iran-Contra Case Is Only One Man's Opinion
description: To the Editor:

title: Capitol Hill Fight Erupting Over Ending Vietnam Curbs
description: As President Clinton makes tentative moves toward lifting the trade embargo on Vietnam, a fight has broken out on Capitol Hill over the politically sensitive issue, with some Republicans proposing to create strict conditions before the embargo can be removed.

title: STATE OF THE UNION: News Analysis; Economic Safety Zone
description: According to the polls, President Clinton stepped before the nation tonight with his political strength back where it stood when he was inaugurated a year and five days ago, before Zoe Baird, before tax increases, before Cristophe's haircuts, before Somalia and Haiti.

title: MTV Networks to Test Home-Shopping Service
description: Looking to take advantage of increasing interest in shopping via television, MTV Networks this spring will test a home-shopping service directed at its young, music-oriented audience, the chairman of the company said yesterday.

title: Michael Jackson Settles Suit For Sum Said to Be in Millions
description: Michael Jackson, the music superstar who was accused of sexual molestation by a 14-year-old boy, agreed today to pay the boy an undisclosed amount that was said to be in the millions of dollars.

title: Books of The Times; Growing Up Amid the Conflicts of Ideology and Life
description: Red Azalea By Anchee Min 306 pages. Pantheon. $29.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Science Times yesterday about the National Library of Medicine's provision of free access to data on AIDS omitted the library director's given name and initials. He is Dr. Donald A. B. Lindberg.

title: Progress Is Being Made On New York Competition
description: The two sides in a dispute over the ouster of New York City high school athletes from statewide competitions agreed yesterday to discuss a compromise that could restore New York State championships in five sports to include the city athletes.

title: Can We Afford So Many Unskilled Immigrants?; The Mood Turns Ugly
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Where Apocalypse Is Never Far Away
description: Surveying the damage in Los Angeles, Bill Clinton confessed to being amazed by the collapsed freeways and miles of damaged buildings. Like many forgetful natives and startled visitors, he discovered the fearfulness California can display -- a combination of the sublime and the apocalyptic sufficient to sharpen anyone's sense of an ending.

title: I.B.M. Has First Profit In a Year
description: I.B.M. reported its first quarterly profit in more than a year yesterday, a sign that the struggling computer company may be starting to recover.

title: STATE OF THE UNION: The Republicans; In G.O.P. Response to Clinton, Dole Denies There Is 'Crisis' in Health Care
description: Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, tonight assailed President Clinton's health care plan as "a massive overdose of Government control."

title: Silence Order Lifted for Trial Over Drug-Testing Program
description: A Federal judge today lifted his four-day-old order stopping lawyers from discussing with news organizations a class-action suit filed on behalf of pregnant, drug-addicted women against the Medical University of South Carolina.

title: Japanese Stocks Post Solid Gains
description: About the only question left unanswered on the Tokyo Stock Exchange was: what political crisis?

title: Many Ideas but Not All to Detroit's Liking
description: Karl H. Hellman is Detroit's most feared kind of E.P.A. official: a "technology-forcing" bureaucrat.

title: Political Rifts Slow Japanese Reforms
description: For five years now, Japan has immersed itself in the issue of how to rid the political system of the rivers of cash from private businesses that have led to scandal and corruption. Four Prime Ministers have fallen in the process and a fifth may be consumed this week.

title: Burger King Narrows Review
description: The Burger King Corporation said yesterday that it had narrowed the review on its estimated $180 million national account and had decided to separate the account into creative and media portions.

title: Nicaraguan Lawmakers Meet In Effort to Break Deadlock
description: Nicaragua's rival political factions attended the National Assembly together for the first time in 16 months today as the country's leaders tried to end a bitter deadlock that has contributed to the country's political instability.

title: Chevron Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included special items which reduced earnings by $ 221 million for a one-time cash bonus to employees, losses on asset sales and writeoffs, LIFO inventory liquidation losses, tax adjustments and environmental remediation provisions.c-Included charges totaling $ 883 million, due primarily to a $ 543 million second quarter restructuring charge for U.S. downstream operations.d-Included benefits of $ 546 million from special items, primarily gains from asset dispositions in the quarter and the year included a charge of $ 641,000,000, or $ 1.89 a share, from an accounting adjustment.

title: Los Angeles Schools Reopen, With Safety Lesson
description: Shaken by earthquake destruction that has deepened chronic financial woes, the Los Angeles public school system limped back into session today, but many schools remained without water and scores of others were too damaged to open at all.

title: I.B.M. Chairman's Reward Is Linked to Stock Price
description: I.B.M. stock tends to jump around, as it has this week, based on the hopes, expectations and concerns about the company's chances for a comeback. Few investors have more at stake, in the long term, than the man leading that effort, Louis V. Gerstner Jr., who came to the computer maker from RJR Nabisco last spring.

title: Once Again, Reactions Differ in Crown Heights
description: The decision by the United States Attorney General to begin a Federal civil rights investigation in the killing of Yankel Rosenbaum in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, has set off what every development in the case before it has: strong words, mixed feelings, differing suspicions and talk of politics. In short, everything short of complete satisfaction that justice is going to be done.

title: Putting Car-Exhaust Tests on the Road to Reality
description: The way the Environmental Protection Agency tests the emissions of a car looks a lot more like a game in a video arcade than actual driving. The driver sits behind the wheel of a car on a treadmill and, using only the accelerator and the brake pedal, tries to keep the car on a course that scrolls by on a computer screen outside the driver's side window.

title: Mexico Leader, in Chiapas, Hears the Peasants' Wrath
description: At the invitation of Indian and agrarian leaders who did not join in the peasant uprising that has rocked Mexico, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari ventured to the embattled state of Chiapas today for the first time since the fighting began on Jan. 1 to hear about some of its problems.

title: Change in Direction for Pentagon
description: With great fanfare, Defense Secretary Les Aspin set out last year to develop a mini-State Department at the Pentagon. He created posts on human rights, peacekeeping and arms proliferation in an outward-looking effort to widen the Pentagon's influence in international policy.

title: Armstrong World Industries Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included a net charge of $ 167,800,000, or $ 4.51 a share, which included a loss of $ 135,400,000, or $ 3.64 cents a share, for adoption of new accounting standards for post-retirement benefits and a loss of $ 32,400,000, or 87 cents a share, for new accounting standard for post-employment benefits.Armstrong World Industries said the 1993 fourth quarter included an after-tax restructuring charge of $ 60 million, or $ 1.59 a share.The company said the year-ealier fourth quarter included an after-tax restructuring charges of $ 24.3 million, or 65 cents a share.Full year 1993 results also included the $ 60 million, or $ 1.59 a share, restructuring charges included in the fourth quarter. And full year 1992 results included total after-tax restructuring charges of $ 123.8 million, or $ 3.33 a share.(Loss)

title: "DISNEY (WALT) CO. (N)
description: The Walt Disney Company yesterday reported net income of $368.6 million, or 68 cents a share, in the first quarter, in contrast to a loss of $96 million, or 16 cents a share, in the comparable period a year ago.

title: R. A. Radley, 43, Dies; National AIDS Leader
description: R. A. Radley, a national figure in the fight against AIDS, died on Friday at Cabrini Hospice in Manhattan. He was 43 and lived in Manhattan.

title:
Market Place;
Siemens gets ready for tomorrow but must navigate a rocky today.
description: DESPITE a jolt of surprisingly bad news earlier this month, some gutsy analysts are sticking with Siemens A.G., Germany's largest electronics company. They argue that the worst is behind Siemens, making the company a solid blue-chip pick over the next year.

title: The Talk of Vienna: President's Affair
description: The private lives of politicians are usually considered unsuitable for public discussion in most European countries, but the President of Austria broke that taboo recently by announcing in a magazine interview that his wife, to whom he has been married for 37 years, had left him.

title: CMS Energy Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included a one-time, after-tax write-off of $ 343 million associated with the settlement of regulatory issues involving power purchases by its unit, Consumers Power Co., from the Midland Cogeneration Venture for both the quarter and year.(Loss)

title: Walbro China Venture
description: The Walbro Corporation said today that its engine-management subsidiary would form a joint venture in China to produce carburetors for scooters and motorized bicycles. Walbro, based in Cass City, said it had signed an agreement with two privately held Chinese corporations that gave it a 60 percent stake in a new company that will operate out of Fuding, in Fujian Province. Walbro makes fuel injection systems and carburetors for cars, boats and tractors and fuel injection and carburetor parts for outdoor power equipment, outboard motors and lawn-and-garden equipment.

title: Review/Met Opera: Le Nozze di Figaro; Figaro Returns With His Bag of Tricks
description: Mozart and Da Ponte gave "Le Nozze di Figaro" a bit of everything: comic antics and deeply moving soliloquies; conspiracies that backfire and others that succeed, if only by accident; sexual tensions and passions that do their best to run wild, yet that eventually give way to the graceful veneer of classical decorum. There is even subversive social comment in the uneasily casual relationship between the Count and his retainers. Add to that some top-drawer Mozart, with hardly a wasted gesture in either the vocal or the orchestral writing, and you have a work that should be a high point of the opera season.

title: Roadway Services (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: Jury Stymied in Brother's Trial
description: The jury pondering murder charges against Lyle Menendez told the judge today that it was deadlocked after more than three weeks of deliberations and an earthquake, but the judge sent it back to try ruling out any of the counts. The jury has the option of finding first- or second-degree murder or voluntary or involuntary manslaughter.

description: The Clinton Administration is planning to ship Patriot antimissile batteries to South Korea, senior Administration officials said today.

title: Air War Breaks Out Over Rerouting Plan; Newark Flights Are at Issue in 2 States
description: Pit a group of suburban New Jerseyans, irked at airplane noise and backed by an influential senator, against a group of scrappy New Yorkers, weary of even more noise from more planes, and what do you get? A proposal for rerouting flights from Newark over Staten Island, Long Island and Westchester County, and a first-class border air war.

title: Bradshaw Heads for Fox TV
description: Terry Bradshaw, who was introduced by Jay Leno Monday night on "The Tonight Show" as "newly unemployed," has unsurprisingly found new work with the Fox Network, which will announce his hiring tomorrow. The former studio analyst for CBS's "The N.F.L. Today," will be signing a four-year contract probably worth at least twice the $650,000 a year he was paid by CBS.

title: Review/Music; Classical Weill: The Quartet
description: Although it is tempting to draw a line between Kurt Weill's "public" and his "private" composing, the String Quartet of 1923, which the Orion Quartet played at the Walter Reade Theater on Monday night, yields on examination almost all the idiosyncratic elements that were to churn mass audiences into a frenzy five years later. It goes without saying that stage pieces like "Mahagonny" and "The Threepenny Opera" made Weill famous in a way that his earlier pursuit of the classical European tradition never would have.

title: Helping Hands
description: To the Editor: At the height of the Jan. 17 storm, descending from a Third Avenue bus that could not get to the curb at 72d Street, I found myself on a sleet-lashed, ice-glazed incline in danger, at age 86, of losing my footing. From nowhere, a girl in her early teens was at my side, grasped my arm and helped me on the treacherous surface. I spied another codger, heavier than I, about to crash land, when two younger men dashed to his aid. Humanity dwells beneath the cool of New Yorkers. KEN ACKERMAN New York, Jan. 18, 1994

title: TransCanada Pipe Line reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Craft Launched on First Moon Mission Since '72
description: In an unusual joint military-scientific undertaking, a small, unmanned spacecraft was launched yesterday on the first American mission to the Moon since 1972.

title: Response on Wright
description: LUTHER WRIGHT, the rookie center of the Utah Jazz, was having a bad reaction to a prescription drug when he was arrested for disorderly conduct at a highway rest stop, his agent says.

title: Review/Jazz; A Former Band Pianist Steps Into the Spotlight
description: Cyrus Chestnut's engagement at the Village Vanguard this week is a special event. It's his debut, his introduction into society. Mr. Chestnut, a 31-year-old pianist who has spent time in the bands of Betty Carter, Wynton Marsalis and others, has led his own trio in other clubs around the city, most notably Bradley's. But now he has a new album out, called "Revelation," his first for an American label (Atlantic), and for his show on Tuesday night, the company packed the club and made the set an event. Position in the jazz world is the product of all sorts of things, including record-company support, and Mr. Chestnut seems on his way.

title: Judge Halts Green Point Stock Offer
description: A Federal judge abruptly ordered the Green Point Savings Bank yesterday to halt its long-delayed initial public stock offering.

title: HOSPITALS' CHIEF TO REDUCE STAFFS
description: Under pressure from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the chairman of New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation said yesterday that he would eliminate 1,300 jobs immediately through attrition and layoffs to help close an unexpected $160 million shortfall in the corporation's budget this year.

title: Helmsley Has Served Her Time
description: Leona Helmsley finally became a free woman yesterday after serving 18 months in a Federal prison in Connecticut, one month in a mid-Manhattan halfway house, and two months in the relatively plush confinement of her penthouse apartment on Central Park South, where she had to return every night by a 9 o'clock curfew.

title: Winning a Prize for Best Fall. It's All for Charity.
description: There are two ways to approach ski racing. You can sit in front of a television with the remote zeroed in on Alberto Tomba thundering down a slope. Or you can stand at the top of a hill yourself, palms clenched tightly around your ski poles, ready to go.

title: CHRONICLE
description: RUDY F. DE LEON, one of the top aides to Les Aspin, the departing Secretary of Defense, is staying at the Pentagon and getting a promotion.

title: Review/Music: El Gato Montes; After Seven Decades, a Spanish Opera Regains Its Voice
description: Opera has its own version of multiculturalism, which in recent decades has led to an increasing awareness of such diverse national traditions as the Finnish and Czech. Now, with the Los Angeles Music Center Opera production of "El Gato Montes" ("The Wild Cat"), which opened here last week, our complacent neglect of the Spanish opera may be in for a revision, too. This zarzuela, written in 1916 by Manuel Penella and, the Los Angeles company says, never before sung in this country in its original language, is dramatic, vigorous and lyrically inventive.

title: BORDEN INC. (N)
description: As expected, Borden reported yesterday that it took a huge fourth-quarter restructuring charge that effectively wiped out its 1993 earnings and chopped its dividend in half. The food company, which recently replaced its chief executive because of shareholder discontent, promised earlier this month it would embark on its fourth restructuring in less than five years.

title: Tough and Smart on Crime?
description: In a State of the Union address designed mainly to mobilize support for his universal health insurance proposals, President Clinton was careful not to slight an issue that, the polls tell us, troubles the public even more than health care: crime.

title: Bronx Man Arrested In 2 Murder Cases
description: With the arrest yesterday of a Bronx man, the police said they had solved two murders, committed nine months apart in the same South Bronx neighborhood.

description: b-Net loss and after a charge of $ 590,000,000, or $ 5.19 a share, from an accounting adjustment.(Loss)

title: Forecast: Snow, Followed by Short Tempers
description: Bob Sarferty hates having to thaw the locks on his cookie-delivery truck with an acetylene torch. He hates shivering in the cab because the heater quit. He hates driving all day because his partner won't. He hates bickering with stock boys in grocery stores because he tracks dirt on just-mopped floors. He hates feeling the snow in the bottom of his shoe.

title: At Last, Maybe, A Vision
description: Theodore Roosevelt once said that a good political speech is "a poster, not an etching." More important than fine details are broad, bold themes that stand out from a distance. But through most of American history, State of the Union Messages -- even Theodore Rove almost always been more like etchings than posters, often dreary, seldom memorable.

title: Esther Ralston, 91, A Featured Actress Of Silent-Film Era
description: Esther Ralston, a silent-screen actress and vaudeville star who was known for a time as "the American Venus" for her starring role in the 1926 film of that name, died on Jan. 14 at her home in Ventura, Calif. She was 91.

title: Aqueduct Canceled Again
description: Not to sound like a broken record, but racing was canceled at Aqueduct again yesterday and for the usual reason: snow.
