title: A Mean Political Hangover for Seagram in Ukraine
description: The Seagram Company arrived in Ukraine two years ago, eager to do business in a vast, untapped market where the people were known for their fondness for vodka. The company was pushed along on a romantic notion -- that it was returning to the homeland of its founder -- and it had grand plans for a new vodka that could be sold here and exported to Russia, as well as to the West. There would be a plush showcase store in decaying downtown Kiev.

title: A Retailer's Value Rises In Chapter 11
description: Fidelity Investments' interest in Merry-Go-Round Enterprises, the trendy retailer that filed for bankruptcy protection earlier this month, has caused something tantamount to a riot in the market for distressed investments, spiking the price of the company's debt and equity to levels that analysts believe are unrealistic.

title: Gillooly Is Interviewed By Authorities
description: Tonya Harding's former husband, Jeffery Gillooly, spoke to Federal and state investigators at length today -- his first interview with the authorities -- in a possible prelude to a plea bargain.

title: The Cowboys Are a Direct Reflection Of Their Coach
description: Michael Irvin played for Dallas under Tom Landry, the former Cowboy coach, for one season. Irvin was a rambunctious rookie who wanted to prove he belonged, which may explain why he got into many fights his first season. He was so scrappy that on a plane ride home one day, Landry pulled him aside for a heart to heart.

title: Police Appeal for Help in Girl's Disappearance
description: Frustrated in their two-week effort to find the remains of Sara Anne Wood, the 12-year-old who disappeared last summer, the state police today made an unusual plea for help from anyone who was on vacation in the Adirondacks on Aug. 18.

title: Atlanta Journal; Boosterism Isn't Gone With the Wind
description: Sure, the Super Bowl rematch of Dallas and Buffalo has all the magic of Bucknell versus Colgate. And, yes, there is the spectacle of blacks and whites haggling over the Confederate battle flag as if the Civil War were still going on.

title: Duquette to Be Red Sox General Manager
description: DAN DUQUETTE, who had one year remaining on his contract as general manager of the Montreal Expos, will return home and realize his dream job as general manager of the Boston Red Sox. The Red Sox will announce this morning that Duquette, a native of Dalton, Mass., will take over from LOU GORMAN, who was promoted to director of baseball operations. The Expos will name their director of scouting, KEVIN MALONE, as Duquette's successor.

title: Calendar: Artists Of Many Stripes
description: Modern Illuminations Humanities Gallery, Engineering Building, Cooper Union, 51 Astor Place; (212) 353-4273.

title: Machinists Pass United Deal
description: Members of United Airlines' machinists union approved a plan yesterday to give employees 53 percent control of the airline in exchange for cost savings and the flexibility to create a low-fare carrier.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: Sleep, Uninterrupted

title: Review/Dance; A Hawkins Premiere, To Internal Rhythms
description: If Erick Hawkins has taught audiences to see dance in a radical new way, it is largely because he has infused his works with a sense of time more commonly found in Asian theater.

title:
COMPANY REPORTS;
Scott Paper Will Reduce Jobs by 25%
description: The Scott Paper Company, continuing to struggle with price discounting and a global overcapacity of paper production, said yesterday that it would reduce its work force 25 percent.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11 RUSSIAN REFORMER QUITS The man who had come to symbolize the future of economic reform in Russia stepped down definitively as Finance Minister. In resigning, Boris Fyodorov warned that economic disaster would result if Soviet-era managers kept the upper hand. A1

title: Pop and Jazz in Review
description: Eric Reed Pianist The Blue Note

title: In the Shadows of the Casinos
description: Fortune smiled for so long on this coastal island city, a bedroom community to Atlantic City's casino industry, that it was perhaps inevitable that things would take a turn for the worse, like a gambler's hot streak that suddenly turns cold.

title: Council Votes Historic District In 38-Block Section of Queens
description: After years in which preservationists said their efforts were frustrated in Queens, the City Council voted unanimously yesterday to designate as a historic district an elegant swath of almost 500 apartment buildings and homes in Jackson Heights that in the early 1900's gave garden apartments their name.

title: Better Late Than Never
description: After months of ducking the difficult task, Attorney General Janet Reno has finally yielded to intense political pressure and agreed to take over the investigation of the killing of a rabbinical student during riots in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn in 1991. She made the right decision. Whether or not she is successful in bringing indictments or winning convictions, the public needs to be convinced that no avenue has been left unexplored in attempting to resolve this incendiary case.

title: Grants to Help Groups Form Ties With Choreographers
description: The New York Foundation for the Arts has announced the creation of a $3 million program to encourage long-term residencies and collaborations between choreographers and dance companies. It will be called the National Dance Residency Program, and will enable 30 professional companies to work with choreographers over the next three to five years.

title: Lord, Dentsu Chosen By AST Research
description: AST Research Inc., the personal computer manufacturer in Irvine, Calif., said yesterday that it had selected Lord, Dentsu & Partners in Los Angeles to handle its account, which had been at Team One Advertising in El Segundo, Calif., for the last year and a half. Billings were estimated at $15 million to $16 million.

title: Sumio Uematsu; Neurosurgeon, 59
description: Dr. Sumio Uematsu, a neurosurgeon at Johns Hopkins Hospital who advanced the treatment of epilepsy, died on Tuesday at his home in Lutherville, Md. He was 59.

title: U.S. Inquiry on Solarz Is Ended Without Charges
description: A Justice Department investigation of former Representative Stephen J. Solarz that had delayed his nomination as Ambassador to India ended without charges this week, but the White House indicated that it was not yet prepared to nominate him.

title: Senator Asks End to Threats Against China
description: A leading Democratic voice on trade in the Senate says the policy of annually threatening China with trade sanctions is ineffective, harmful to the reform process in China and should be permanently scrapped this June if China meets the Administration's demands.

title: Essay; Kozyrev & Talbott
description: Two relatively young and sophisticated men, both setting policy at their nations' foreign ministries, have changed their positions radically in the past few months. Their shifts reveal much about the deterioration of Russian-American relations.

description: The Democrat who will preside over the Clinton Administration's welfare plan in the House of Representatives today denounced one of its central provisions: a work program that is set at the minimum wage.

title: Front and Center for Front 5 in Bills' Game Plan

HARDEST CHOICES SHIFT TO PATIENTS New technology offers medical patients a fantastic explosion of information and treatment possibilities. But it has also increasingly required patients to make decisions that tear at their very souls. A1.

description: The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company has been fined $300,000 by Massachusetts regulators for use of misleading sales letters.

title: Bobsledder Has Friends in Low Places
description: Chip Minton is mingling with a different class of people these days -- having forsaken, for the time being, the murderers, robbers, gangsters, forgers, swindlers, thieves, thugs and assorted other felons and reprobates he is normally in contact with.

title: New York Stock Exchange Censures a Prudential Broker
description: The New York Stock Exchange yesterday censured a stockbroker with Prudential Securities in the Big Board's first regulatory case stemming from the firm's limited partnership fraud scandal.

title: Fostering Togetherness
description: To The Home Section:

title: Kovalev Is Young, Slumping and Tradable
description: At the end of practice today, most of his Rangers teammates were already in the locker room, but not Aleksei Kovalev. He stood by himself in a corner of the rink with a puck on his stick, bouncing it off the blade as if it were a paddle ball. His face revealed a small smile. The Rangers' youngest and most troubled player seemed content.

title: Brooklyn Union Gas reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CHEVRON PROPOSES STOCK SPLIT AND RAISES DIVIDEND
description: The Chevron Corporation said its board had proposed a 2-for-1 split of the company's stock, which hit an all-time high of $98.75 on Oct. 1. Chevron's board also increased the company's quarterly dividend payment 5.7 percent, to 92.5 cents a share, from 87.5 cents. Dividends would be payable on March 10 to shareholders of record on Feb. 10. Chevron shares closed yesterday down 50 cents at $92.

title: France Bluntly Calls for NATO To Relieve Two Bosnian Towns
description: France said today that the time had come for NATO to carry out its decision to relieve two Bosnian towns encircled by Serbian troops, using force if necessary.

title: Anytime is Bedtime
description: WHEN Edith Wharton gave her "Age of Innocence" character Mrs. Manson Mingott a first-floor bedroom hard by the entrance hall of the lady's Fifth Avenue mansion, she insured that Mrs. Mingott's society friends were properly shocked. In direct defiance of Victorian mores -- the bedroom then was a sanctum sanctorum, tucked away upstairs and free from intrusion -- the obese Mrs. Mingott's bohemian quarters were considered scandalously convenient.

title: Awaiting Quake Aid, and Riot Aid, Too
description: On battered streets where vacant lots display the unhealed damage of the 1992 riots, earthquake survivors in South-Central Los Angeles are again struggling to recover from disaster, even as public sympathy dwells on their wealthier neighbors in the San Fernando Valley.

title: S.E.C. Backing a Change for Stock Quotes
description: In a report scheduled to be released today, the Securities and Exchange Commission is recommending that the minimum quote on stock prices be cut in half, to 6.25 cents from 12.5 cents, officials familiar with the details of the report said yesterday.

title: U.S. OFFICIALS HINT AT NEW FLEXIBILITY OVER HEALTH PLAN
description: The Administration is willing to compromise on important elements of President Clinton's health plan, Federal officials said today.

title: 4.5 MILLION SHARES OF USX-U.S. STEEL GROUP TO BE OFFERED
description: The USX Corporation said yesterday that it was offering 4.5 million shares of its USX-U.S. Steel Group common stock at $41 a share. The sale is expected to generate $180.8 million, which could increase to $200.9 million if an overallotment option is exercised, the company said. Proceeds will be used for general business purposes, it said. The offering, through Morgan Stanley & Company, is expected to be made on or about Feb. 2. As of Dec. 31, USX had 70.3 million shares outstanding. Company shares fell 75 cents yesterday, to $41.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Conrail Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included loss of $ 50 million from disposition of subsidiary and a $ 34 million increase in deferred income taxes recorded in the third quarter for the retroactive effects of the federal corporate income tax rate increase. The period was also after a charge of $ 74 million, or 92 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Dow Jones & Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included charge of $ 8 million, or 8 cents a share, from writedowns of investments in both the quarter and year, and the year included a charge of $ 10,805,000, or 11 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment.

title: For Kitchens: the Good, the Odd, the Silly
description: One's first impulse is to applaud the National Housewares Manufacturers Association, sponsor of the annual International Housewares Show here, for honesty. In the huge four-day exhibition last week, the trade group gave the name "Design Oasis" to the one small display that showed off prize-winning product concepts by industrial design students.

title: Browning-Ferris Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LOTUS DEVELOPMENT CORP. (NMS)
description: The Lotus Development Corporation reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings had doubled to $29.6 million, as strong growth from new software products lifted its results above Wall Street's estimates.

title: Books of The Times; Exploring the Body and the Mind
description: They Whisper By Robert Olen Butler 333 pages. Henry Holt & Company. $22.50.

title:
CURRENTS;
Arrivederci, Baroque! Guten Tag, Functionalism!
description: FOR years, Milan, Italy, was to furniture design what Paris is to fashion. But in the 90's, the spotlight has shifted to Cologne, Germany, because of its attraction to buyers. The 29th International Furniture Fair in Cologne, which ended its six-day run on Sunday, drew 1,444 exhibitors from 45 countries. Milan's International Furniture Fair, on the other hand, is a predominantly Italian event.

title: Compaq Net And Sales Set Records
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation, continuing to outpace the personal computer industry in market share growth and consistent profitability, today reported record fourth-quarter earnings and sales that exceeded Wall Street's highest estimates.

title: President Named By Industry Group
description: O. Burtch Drake, executive vice president and chief operating officer at the American Association of Advertising Agencies, was named yesterday to succeed John O'Toole as president and chief executive. Mr. O'Toole, 65, who has held the position since 1989, will retire on Monday.

title: Clinton Has a Plan That Would Pay Some People for Not Driving to Work
description: If President Clinton has his way, many commuters will have bigger paychecks if they give up their parking spaces.

title: The Johnson Journey: Excoriated to Imitated
description: Five years ago, when Jimmy Johnson became the Dallas Cowboys' coach, you could hear snickering throughout the National Football League. His brash style at the University of Miami would simply not work in the N.F.L., his critics said. The difference in coaching strategies in college compared with the N.F.L. was as wide as the Grand Canyon.

title: Explosion at Queens Diner Traps Waitress in Rubble
description: An explosion apparently caused by a natural-gas leak tore open the floor of a Queens diner yesterday morning, plunging six employees and customers into a fiery basement and beginning a dramatic three-hour ordeal for a waitress pinned beneath huge slabs of concrete and steel.

title: Panhandle Eastern Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a charge of $ 60.2 million for certain regulatory issues and a gain of $ 28.7 million on the sale of assets.c-Included a gain of $ 57.7 million from the settlement of regulatory issues.Year-ago periods were restated to reflect accounting changes.

title: Christian Bishop in Iran Is Reported Missing
description: A leader of Iranian Christians has disappeared in Teheran after speaking out against persecution of Christians, a New York-based human rights group said today.

title: Hardest Medical Choices Shift to Patients
description: When Bonnie G. scheduled a sonogram in the middle of her pregnancy she was looking forward to what modern technology could offer her: a peek at her fetus and the chance to be reassured that her child -- a boy, she discovered -- would be fine.

title: Hunt for Just the Right Words Has Clinton Straining for Any
description: That raspy State of the Union Message, it turns out, came only after practice, practice, practice, and by the time President Clinton woke up this morning, he could speak only in a whisper.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HANGER ORTHOPEDIC GROUP INC., Bethesda, Md., an orthotics and prosthetics concern, has acquired M-D Orthotics and Prosthetics, from Health Industries, Phoenix. Terms were not disclosed. NORTH AMERICAN BIOLOGICALS INC., Miami, a provider of human blood plasma elements, signed a definitive agreement to acquire Premier Bioresources Inc., Fort Worth, a supplier of plasma used for human therapeutics. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about reaction at Kean College in New Jersey to a campus speech by a Nation of Islam official referred imprecisely in some editions to the significance of 1989 in the college's history. It was the year Dr. Elsa Gomez became president of the college, not the year Kean became a state college.

title: New Look for a Fast Plane
description: IT was not the usual trip to the airport: no luggage to check in, no carry-on, no ticket. Just an intriguing invitation to see how Andree Putman, the French designer, had put her distinctive signature on the interior of the Air France Concorde.

title: Phyllis Goodhart Gordan; Library Trustee, 80
description: Phyllis Goodhart Gordan, a benefactor and former trustee of the New York Public Library, died on Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 80.

title: NEC Technologies Begins a Review
description: NEC Technologies Inc., the computer and peripheral products manufacturer, said yesterday that it had placed its estimated $30 million to $35 million North American account in review. The account has been handled by DDB Needham New York for the last eight years.

title: G.O.P.'s 'No Crisis' Position
description: After months of struggling to stake out a position on health care, the Republicans now have a party line: there is no crisis. Page A16.

title: Americans Rebel At Official Art
description: To the Editor:

title: Longer Treasuries Pare Losses
description: Government securities recovered yesterday, with longer maturities paring about half of their losses for the week. With no economic news on the calendar, traders and dealers focused on the five-year note auction.

title: Marion Merrell Dow Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a net gain of $ 21 million, or 7 cents a share, which included gain of $ 54 million from change in accounting for income taxes and loss of $ 33 million from change in accounting for postretirement benefits.The net income figures excluded effect of preferred stock dividends.Share earnings and shares outstanding were fully diluted.

title: Bausch & Lomb reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
description: b-After an extraordinary restructuring charge of $ 36,463,000, or 61 cents a share, in both the quarter and year.

title: Four Patients At TB Center Are Arrested In Attack
description: Four tuberculosis patients in long-term detention at Goldwater Memorial Hospital on Roosevelt Island were arrested yesterday and charged with attacking several staff members and security officers, hospital officials said.

title: Assessing Changes In Point-and-Shoots
description: IF your idea of a snapshot camera still runs along the lines of the Kodak Instamatic, it's time to catch up with the many changes in the field. Amateur cameras these days can be as complicated as computers, which is no surprise given that most of them use electronic circuitry to control light meters, shutter speeds and many other aspects of picture taking.

title: Market Place; Weighing the value of an obscure but valuable asset of R. H. Macy.
description: LOST amid the drama of Federated Department Stores' surprise bid to merge with its rival, R. H. Macy & Company, is an obscure accounting issue that would seem to have big implications for a combination of the two retailers.

title: Rodman Set to Play After Nose Surgery
description: DENNIS RODMAN of the San Antonio Spurs underwent surgery for a deviated septum yesterday. Rodman was injured Saturday night against the Dallas Mavericks when he was accidentally elbowed in the nose by POPEYE JONES. Blood streaming down his face, Rodman left the game for about five minutes before returning wearing a bandage.

title: Union Carbide Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an after-tax charge of $ 6 million, or 4 cents a share, from the write-down of a Canadian business and a gain of $ 5 million, or 3 cents a share, from the sale of a corporate aircraft.c-After an accounting charge of $ 97 million, or 64 cents a share, from the adoption of FAS 112.d-Included an after-tax charge of $ 22 million, or 16 cents a share, for severance expenses related to the company's profit improvement program. This charge was offset by after-tax income of $ 15 million, or 11 cents a share, from the settlement of a patent infringement case; $ 8 million, or 6 cents a share, from the sale of the company's investment in an insurance company and $ 6 million, or 4 cents a share, from the 1992 sale of a corporate aircraft.e-Net loss, which included income from discontinued operations of $ 67 million, or 51 cents a share, reflecting earnings of Praxair Inc., prior to its spinoff, and after a charge of $ 361 million, or $ 2.73 a share, on the adoption of FAS 106 and FAS 109.The latest year and 1992 year reflected the OrganoSilicon business that was included in the results until its sale July 9, 1993. In addition, certain costs aggregating $ 20 million in 1993 and $ 14 million in 1992 have been reclassified from other expense (income) to cost of sales. The restatement did not affect the fourth quarters of 1993 and 1992.(Loss)

title: Yugoslav Army Reported Fighting In Bosnia to Help Serbian Forces
description: Yugoslav Army units have been operating inside Bosnia in recent weeks, apparently in an effort to counter recent advances by Bosnian Government forces, United Nations officials and Yugoslav journalists say.

title: Sibley W. Hoobler, 82, Expert in Hypertension
description: Dr. Sibley Worth Hoobler, a retired cardiologist who founded one of the country's first hypertension clinics, died on Tuesday in Tucson, Ariz. He was 82 and lived in Cleveland.

title: Feud Between Canada Airlines Eases
description: Peace appears to be breaking out in a long war between Canada's two troubled airlines, which had been scrapping over routes, computer reservations and a proposal made to one of them by a big United States carrier.

title: PHILADELPHIA STORES TO SHIFT TO FAST-SERVICE FORMAT
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said yesterday that it would convert 13 Philadelphia-area tire stores to an express format to serve time-pressed shoppers. The Just Tires outlets will offer tires and related services like tire mounting, wheel balancing and alignment. The stores will guarantee faster service on tire sales, with a 20 percent discount if tire installation takes more than 30 minutes. In the Philadelphia area, the stores are now called Goodyear Auto Service Centers and Atomic Tire Outlets.

title: PEPSI INVESTING $350 MILLION IN CHINA PLANTS
description: Pepsi-Cola International, a unit of Pepsico, said yesterday that it would invest $350 million in the next five years to open 10 bottling plants in what it called "largely untapped regions of China." The new plants, which will be operated as joint ventures with local government agencies, will let Pepsi roughly double its sales in China.

title: Clinton in Bind Over Visa for I.R.A. Wing Leader
description: President Clinton has found himself in a political bind over Northern Ireland, caught between powerful Irish-Americans in Congress and the British Government over whether to grant a visa to an Irish Republican Army wing leader.

title: Review/Fashion; The Cheery Depression Look
description: SOME 65 years ago, there were men who loosened their ties -- just a bit -- stepped to the ledges of their office buildings and jumped. Now, the look of the Depression era -- the fashion, that is, not the desperation -- is coming back. The New York men's collections this week offered chalk-stripe suits, flecked fabrics, wide corduroys and tie patterns that look as if they had been taken from the counter tops of diners. Almost every collection had one jacket of a solid tweed with little flecks in it. You know the jacket. Your grandfather had one.

title: Chief of Continental Can Charged in Insider Suit
description: Donald J. Bainton, the president and chief executive of the Continental Can Corporation, was sued yesterday by the Securities and Exchange Commission, which accused him of tipping off a close friend in March 1992 that the company was about to report poor profits.

title: Mayors Uneasy On Plan to Shift Aid for Transit
description: A Clinton Administration budget proposal for a 25 percent reduction in mass transit operating subsidies received a cool reception today from many mayors and city officials. They said the plan would force them to increase subway and bus fares and curtail routes and services.

title: Sports of The Times; Kerrigan And 'Super' Security
description: AS soon as Jim Kelly sauntered into the ballroom of the Stouffer Waverly Hotel yesterday, a bearded security guard in a blue satin windbreaker, Bob Hall, glanced down at about two dozen members of the news media below the small platform where the Bills' quarterback would sit at a table for a Super Bowl XXVIII interrogation.

title: Bridge
description: Immigrants from Russia are starting to make an impact on the American bridge scene. At a regional tournament in Orlando, Fla., earlier this month, Vladimir Fleyshgakker of Manhattan and Alex Ladyzhensky of Bradenton, Fla., won two major events and finished second in a third. They were all pairs events, making it a very rare combination of successes.

title: Bitter Epilogue in Afghanistan
description: Remember Afghanistan? Not so long ago, Democrats vied with Republicans in supporting a "good" war waged by freedom fighters against the Evil Empire. In April 1992 its Communist rulers were finally evicted, and an interim Government assumed power. Refugees began returning from camps in Pakistan and Iran; the State Department proclaimed a triumph for justice and self-determination.

title: It Can't Happen Here?
description: To the Editor:

title: Smooth Landing for Economy
description: For the first time in 30 years, the United States economy has pulled itself out of recession without benefit of a significant tax cut or burst of new Government spending. And although the recovery has skipped some regions and left many workers still without jobs -- as President Clinton noted in his State of the Union address -- others have hailed it as a model expansion with noninflationary growth and falling unemployment.

title: Political Memo; 'New Democrats' Giving Liberals a Cold Shoulder
description: As Bill Clinton leans ever more urgently into a centrist agenda that urges an overhaul of the welfare system, the passage of tough anti-crime legislation and a strong defense, he has left a forlorn band of liberals standing on the sidelines, fighting among themselves.

title: Coaches Leaning Toward Mediation
description: The Black Coaches Association is leaning toward accepting an offer from the Federal government to mediate its dispute with the National Collegiate Athletic Association over basketball scholarships and other matters. The association's director, RUDY WASHINGTON, met yesterday with a mediation team from the Justice Department to discuss how the process would work. N.C.A.A. officials had a similar meeting with mediators in Denver last Saturday. (AP)

title: Building Chief Was Officer In Company Under Inquiry
description: The newly appointed New York City Buildings Commissioner, Frank A. Luzi, was the treasurer and partner in a Boston asbestos-removal company that was indicted last August on charges that it falsified Federal records about employee safety.

title: Gant a Special-Team Man With a Mission
description: When the Dallas Cowboys punt to the Buffalo Bills in Super Bowl XVIII Sunday, there may be a battle within the battle -- a special-teams showdown involving Russell Copeland, the Bills' dangerous punt returner, and Kenny Gant, one of the Cowboys' two gunners, or outside cover men, on punt coverage.

title: Credit Union Placed Millions With Seized Spanish Bank
description: The U.S. Central Credit Union, which provides financial services for the country's 13,000 credit unions, acknowledged yesterday that it had deposited $255 million in uninsured accounts in Banco Espanol de Credito months before the Spanish Government seized the institution last month.

title: An Architectural Eye on Classical Italian Landscaping
description: WHEN the American etcher and landscape painter Charles A. Platt took his younger brother on a six-month tour of the great Renaissance villas of Italy in 1892, he was intent on a bit of brainwashing.

title: Ruling Gives Reprieve to Dog On Death Row
description: New Jersey's highest court, the State Supreme Court, today spared the life of the state's celebrated death-row dog, Taro, until March 1, apparently to give officials time to find some way to save the animal from execution.

title: Crown Hts. Tension Persists Despite Healing Effort
description: Crown Heights, divided by antagonisms long before it was torn by violence in the summer of 1991, is a neighborhood that today continues to operate under the strains of suspicion and anger, poverty and fear.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The boycott of Colorado over a measure to forbid legal protection for homosexuals may be over, but the repercussions continue.

title: Thinking Globally; A Little City Trolls for Trade
description: With new trade agreements breaking down the barriers between continents and nations, consider the case of East Orange. After decades of economic malaise, this city is making an unlikely pitch to be a center of global commerce.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: More Arrests, More Therapy In Drug Plan
description: The New York City Police Department is developing a plan to fulfill Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's campaign pledge to sweep thousands of drug dealers off the streets, but without swamping the courts and prisons, the department's chief spokesman said yesterday.

title: Review/Jazz; A One-Night French Horn Festival
description: The oddest thing about the first Julius Watkins Jazz French Horn Festival, which took place at the Knitting Factory on Sunday night, wasn't the appearance of four jazz-influenced French horn players, it was the music's tameness. The players, Mark Taylor, Tom Varner, John Clark and Vincent Chancey, have fairly impressive avant-garde credentials, ranging from associations with Sun Ra, Muhal Richard Abrams and Henry Threadgill to John Zorn and LaMonte Young. But they left those credentials at home, for the most part working a soft instrumental area that mixed jazz improvising with pop textures.

title: Article 997200 -- No Title
description: The Brooklyn Museum has received a pledge of $5 million, the largest single gift in its history. The pledge was made by the investment banker Morris A. Schapiro in honor of his brother, the art historian Meyer Schapiro. In recognition of the gift, the museum will rename its recently renovated West Wing the Morris A. and Meyer Schapiro Wing.

title: Dow Climbs 12.66 Points As Utility Stocks Rebound
description: A rally in utility stocks and a decline in interest rates helped the stock market to an advance yesterday. Telephone, retail, bank and tobacco issues also climbed.

title: Louisiana-Pacific reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $ 4.4 million, or 4 cents a share, charge to account for the impact of the higher tax rate on deferred tax accruals. Before the tax adjustment, the company's income was $ 258.8 million, or $ 2.36 a share. The earnings does not include the cumulative effects of the company's adoption of accounting changes in January 1993.

title: General Dynamics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 30,000,000, or 95 cents a share, and an extraordinary gain of $ 645,000,000, or $ 20.39 a share, c-After a loss of $ 4,000,000, or 13 cents a share, in the quarter and income of $ 136,000,000, or $ 3.60 a share, in the year, both from discontinued operations, and an extraordinary gain on the disposal of discontinued operations of $ 9,000,000, or 29 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 374,000,000, or $ 9.89 a share.Year-ago quarter and year's income from continuing operations of $ 169,000,000, or $ 5.43 a share, and $ 305,000,000, or $ 8.07 a share, respectively, both included tax credit of $ 95 million and an after-tax gain of $ 14 million from the sales of securities.

title: Muslims Again Try to Loot Aid Convoy
description: Crowds of hungry Muslims attacked an aid convoy in central Bosnia today with guns and a hand grenade, wounding six Government police guards and prompting United Nations officials to suspend deliveries of food along the region's main road, United Nations officials here said.

title: Isles Lose Turgeon, Then Lose Game, Too
description: Just when it seemed the plight of the last-place Islanders couldn't get any grimmer, it did, and the latest setback hit long before the team got down to the unfulfilling business of trying to ward off tonight's 4-3 road loss to the Toronto Maple Leafs.

title: Utah Puts Wright on Injured List
description: The Utah Jazz yesterday placed their rookie center, LUTHER WRIGHT, on its injured reserve list for treatment of attention deficit disorder, which causes an inability to concentrate. The 7-foot-2-inch former Seton Hall player was arrested in Tooele County Monday for disorderly conduct. He was jailed for 12 hours before the Jazz posted his $100 bond. His agent, SAL DiFAZIO, said the 22-year-old Wright apparently had experienced a reaction to the medication he takes for his ailment.

title: NCR RENAMED AS AN A.T.& T. UNIT
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company renamed its NCR computer division A.T.& T. Global Information Solutions yesterday, as part of what NCR executives called a "new strategic direction." Officials said more NCR operations would merge with A.T.& T.'s businesses, though no operations would move from NCR's Dayton, Ohio, headquarters and none of its 51,000 employees would be dismissed.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Centex Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Benes Avoids Arbitration by Signing Pact
description: ANDY BENES, one of the pitchers the Yankees covet, reached agreement yesterday with the San Diego Padres on a salary of $3,005,000 for the 1994 season, a raise of nearly $1 million from the $2,050,000 salary he won in salary arbitration last year. Benes, who had a 15-15 record with a 3.78 earned run average last season, had sought $3.1 million to the Padres' offer of $2.85 million.

title: Economic Scene; An ugly subject: the prejudice against hiring homely people.
description: DO blondes have more fun? Social scientists have yet to nail down the answer. But economists now have good reason to believe that blondes make more money -- or at least the trim, attractive ones do. New studies show that men and women (with any hair color) who are rated below average in attractiveness by survey interviewers typically earn 10 to 20 percent less than those rated above average.

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article yesterday about President Clinton's State of the Union Message misstated the timing of the economic recovery. Although the labor market did not recover significantly until fall 1992, the recovery began in the second quarter of 1991.

title: Williams Cos.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included pretax gains on sales of assets of $ 97.5 million in 1993 and $ 14.6 million in 1992 and a one-time credit of $ 9.9 million for early debt retirement in 1992.Latest fourth quarter's revenue included reclassification to revenues from costs of $ 35.3 million in the third quarter.Year-ago periods' shares outstanding and per-share amounts restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split Nov. 5, 1993.

title: FINANCE MINISTER SHUNS YELTSIN PLEA AND QUITS CABINET
description: Warning that the economy should not be left in the hands of "Red managers," Russia's Finance Minister rejected the entreaties of President Boris N. Yeltsin today and said he would not remain in the current Government.

title: C. W. Schurmann, Dutch Envoy, 91, At U.N. and U.S.
description: Carl W. A. Schurmann, a former Dutch representative at the United Nations and Ambassador to Washington, died on Friday at his home in Geneva. He was 91.

title: U.S. Seeks to Curb Large Payouts To Mutual Savings Bank Officials
description: Federal regulators and lawmakers moved today to stop the reaping of huge profits by executives and trustees when mutual savings and loans sell stock to the public or merge with commercial banks.

title: Jones Leads Wilson In Sound Bites Gained
description: "Jer-ree! Jer-ree!" shouted the fans from the lobby of the Hyatt Regency Hotel. "Cow-boys! Cow-boys!" they yelled at the man in the cocktail lounge-turned ESPN2 studio.

title: EG&G Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
description: b-After a net charge of $ 20,500,000, or 36 cents a share, which included charges of $ 7.3 million, or 13 cents a share, for change in accounting for income taxes; and $ 13.2 million, or 23 cents a share, for change in accounting for postretirement benefits.

title: Emiliano Zapata Journal; In the War Cry of the Indians, Zapata Rides Again
description: He rode a storm of righteousness and rebellion that still, more than 80 years later, makes men go to war.

title: Hate-Literature Documents Weighed in Bombing Trial
description: More than 200 witnesses have testified in the World Trade Center bombing trial, but nothing has been heard from the four men actually on trial, who merely sit quietly in their business suits day after day, silently and impassively watching the proceedings unfold before them.

title: Review/Music; Sammy Cahn's Wit, In Songs and in Clips
description: "The word is only as great as the note it sits under," said the song lyricist Sammy Cahn when he appeared at the 92d Street Y's Lyrics and Lyricists series more than two decades ago.

title: SUPER BOWL: Notebook; Dallas's Haley Probable At Defensive End Spot
description: A Dallas defensive end, Charles Haley, is listed as probable for Super Bowl XVIII Sunday, despite muscle spasms in his lower back that have bothered him all season.

title: Kodak to Offer a Discount Film and New Photo Equipment
description: In an effort to increase consumer interest in photography, the Eastman Kodak Company announced yesterday that it would introduce its first discount film to compete with private-label brands that have been nibbling away at the market share of its premium brands.

title: No Headline
description: "You have 750 million people around the world that will see the Super Bowl -- and Atlanta -- on television. Watching the games last weekend, you'd just hear 'Atlanta! Atlanta! Atlanta!' It just puts chills up and down your back." -- SPURGEON RICHARDSON an Atlantan who is paid to love it. [ A12:4. ]

title: Scouting Makes Room For Minorities
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Deficit Eases in Month
description: The Federal budget deficit narrowed to $8.252 billion in December as taxes and other revenue increased while spending slowed in comparison with a year earlier, the Treasury said this week. In December 1992 the deficit totaled $38.947 billion.

title: Pop and Jazz in Review
description: World Saxophone Quartet Sweet Basil 88 Seventh Avenue South (above Bleecker Street) Greenwich Village Through Sunday

title: Sherry Mathis; Actress, 44
description: Sherry Mathis, an actress who performed on Broadway and in the daytime soap opera "Search for Tomorrow," died on Jan. 23 in Memphis. She was 44.

title: Acid Rain Efforts Found to Undercut Themselves
description: New studies have uncovered a surprising and unsettling twist in continuing efforts to reduce the harmful effects of acid rain on ecosystems.

title: Cray Research Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included restructuring charge of $ 42.8 million in both the quarter and year.(Loss)

title: Executive Changes
description: AMOCO CORP., Chicago, promoted John L. Carl, senior vice president for finance and controller, to executive vice president and chief financial officer, succeeding Frederick S. Addy, who is retiring. CHEVRON SHIPPING CO., San Francisco, a subsidiary of the Chevron Corporation, named Thomas R. Moore president, succeeding Douglas C. Wolcott, who is retiring.

title: PHILIP MORRIS COS. (N)
description: The continued effect of a cigarette price war and a costly restructuring took a big bite out of the Philip Morris Companies' profit in the last quarter of 1993, Philip Morris reported yesterday. Revenue was down slightly for the quarter, at $14.7 billion, while profit fell nearly 72 percent, to $339 million.

title: From a Child's View
description: To The Home Section:

title: Checks in Mail, Vanguard Says
description: The Vanguard Group said yesterday that it was sending out "hundreds" of replacement mutual-fund dividend checks through overnight mail to shareholders who have not yet received theirs.

title: Spectrum Says It Is Target Of Investigation by S.E.C.
description: Spectrum Information Technologies Inc., whose shares plunged on Tuesday, confirmed yesterday that it was being investigated by the Securities and Exchange Commission, possibly relating to management statements in May, when the company's stock price abruptly tripled.

title: Asarco Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain from an accounting adjustment of $ 86,300,000, or $ 2.08 a share, and a gain of $ 104.5 million related to previously unrecognized results of the company's investments in Peru and an after-tax charge of $ 16.7 million related to the valuation of certain inventories and additions to reserves for closed plant and environmental matters, principally for assets planned for disposition.Latest periods also included LIFO profits of $ 3.7 million after tax resulting from the reduction of inventories accounted for on a LIFO basis due principally to the completion of the integration of the company's copper business.c-Net loss and included a $ 44 million charge for environmental costs and a $ 21.1 million charge for the reduction in carrying value of certain facilities in both the quarter and year, and the year also included a charge from an accounting adjustment of $ 54,000,000, or $ 1.31 a share.(Loss)

title:
PRO BASKETBALL;
Benjamin Is Placed in a Major Role With the Nets
description: With All-Star caliber players such as Derrick Coleman and Kenny Anderson, it would be a stretch to say that as Benoit Benjamin goes, so go the Nets. But for the Nets to rise from the rabble, they need a strong presence from Benjamin.

title: Brandt Dispute Unsettles German Socialists
description: With Germany's opposition Social Democratic Party hoping to make a comeback under a new leader after 12 years in the national elections next October, the last thing it wanted was to be confronted with the skeletons in its closet.

title: Occidental Petroleum Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 40 million, or 13 cents a share, for the quarter and $ 221 million, or 72 cents a share, for the year. The year also included extraordinary charge of $ 12 million, or 4 cents a share, for early redemption of debt.

title: CHRONICLE
description: PINCHAS ZUKERMAN was walking to a concert on Saturday evening in Vancouver, British Columbia, dressed in tails and carrying his violin, when an unkempt man with a plastic bag approached him.

title: Stephen C. Kleene Is Dead at 85; Was Leader in Computer Science
description: Stephen C. Kleene, a mathematician whose work help lay the foundations of theoretical computer science, died on Tuesday in Madison, Wis. He was 85 and lived in Madison.

title: Let's Look for Abuse Behind Depression; Other Therapies
description: To the Editor:

title: Arms for the Revolution: The Bulgaria Connection
description: During the cold war, members of the Soviet bloc provided covert assistance to fellow revolutionaries throughout the world. The country most often accused was Bulgaria, whose leader for 35 years, Todor Zhivkov, was a hard-liner committed to Lenin's call for international revolution.

title: GENERAL MAGIC ATTRACTS INVESTMENT BY N.T.T.
description: Japan's main telephone company has become the latest investor in General Magic Inc., the Silicon Valley start-up that is developing software for portable communications devices and services. The Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation said yesterday that it would make an undisclosed investment in General Magic and would license the company's technologies. N.T.T. said it hoped to develop new services based on the software of the Mountain View, Calif. company. Formed by engineers from Apple Computer Inc. in 1990, General Magic has attracted investments from Apple, A.T.& T., Motorola, Matsushita, Philips and Sony. General Magic is developing Telescript, which is software that will help people find information on vast computer networks, and Magic Cap, a user interface device aimed at making hand-held computing and communicating instruments easier to use.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the special Outlook '94 issue of Business Day on Jan. 3, about the development of electric cars, misstated the headquarters location of U.S. Electricar/Solar Electric Engineering Inc. The company is based in Sebastopol, Calif., not Athol, Mass.

title: Critic's Notebook; Sundance: Some Surprises Amid the Frivolity
description: Just when you think the show-biz mania at the Sundance Film Festival can't get more intense, when it seems that every other person on Main Street is carrying a cellular phone, the atmosphere turns loopier. Now people are making their cellular power calls from their seats in the movie theaters. "I will talk to them," a young woman promised her office minutes before a 9:30 screening the other morning. "I'll deal with it." The problem had to do with underlings who were letting too many rotten scripts move up the chain.

title: Sarajevo Reports Raise Fears of Serbian Offensive
description: The Sarajevo radio tonight reported new concentrations of Serbian forces near Brcko and Gorazde, raising fears that the Serbs are preparing major offensives to widen a critical supply corridor and crush the last Bosnian Army forces in the Drina River valley.

title: DRESSER TO SELL STAKE IN DRILLING FLUIDS COMPANY
description: Dresser Industries of Dallas said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its 64 percent interest in the M-I Drilling Fluids Company of Houston to Smith International Inc. for $160 million. Dresser said it was selling the stake as part of an agreement with the Justice Department's antitrust division. The department questioned Dresser's majority ownership in M-I Drilling after Dresser purchased Baroid Drilling Fluids Inc., which competes with M-I Drilling.

title: Alberto-Culver Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Airgas Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings were determined by using the treasury stock method which assumes the exercise of all outstanding options and warrants.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Drummer Plus Essentials

title: 18,000 Investors Submit Claims to Prudential
description: About 18,000 investors have submitted claims so far to a fund established by Prudential Securities to compensate hundreds of thousands of customers for losses suffered because of fraud in the sale of limited partnerships, according to a report by the fund's administrator.

title: Home Video
description: Message Received

title: Critic's Choice/Dance; Unscientific Research
description: Movement Research, the Little Engine That Could of New York dance, has been enlarging the horizons of audiences and performers for 16 years with innovative seminars and workshops conducted by artists including Bill Irwin, Meredith Monk, and Eiko and Koma, as well as with a provocative journal and performances.

title: Media General Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: b-Included a gain of $ 15,066,000 from a change in accounting, and a charge of $ 14,379,000. The net effect of the gain and charge was a gain of $ 700,000, or 3 cents a share.

title: MEXICAN PARTIES AGREE TO REFORMS
description: Bowing to pressure for political change that has been heightened by the peasant uprising in the southern state of Chiapas, Mexico's governing party agreed today to much tougher campaign spending limits and a more impartial choice of election officials.

title: Carolina Power & Light Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Carolina Power & Light Co. said earnings in the latest full year were lowered 16 cents a share by retail fuel settlements with the public utility commissions of North Carolina and South Carolina, and were lowered 9 cents share by a settlement with the North Carolina Eastern Municipal Power Agency.

title: What the Plumber Told the Doctor's Wife
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Fading Light Of the Brilliant Henie
description: Depending on the viewpoint, Fritzi Burger had the great luck or misfortune of being the world's second-best figure skater in the late 1920's and early 1930's. She finished second to Sonja Henie at the 1928 Winter Olympics, and had to settle for a silver medal again in 1932. Four more times, Burger competed against Henie in various European and world championships. All four times, she settled for second place.

title: Japan's Leader Broadens His Battle to Win Reform
description: Struggling to salvage his proposals for political reform and avert a collapse of his Government, Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa took the extraordinary step today of appealing for popular support and international pressure to force Parliament to endorse a broad realignment of the electoral system by Saturday.

title: Abroad at Home; Whistling Past Weimar
description: President Clinton was impressive when he talked about domestic issues in his State of the Union address because he connected. When he told of Americans who were sick or needed family leave, he related to their pain. More than that, he seemed to be drawing from his own life, his own hopes and hurts.

title: For Children
description: Jazz Concert The Mike Ledonne Trio The Museum of the City of New York Fifth Avenue at 103d Street (212) 534-1672, extension 215 Recommended ages: 8 and up Sunday

title: Florio Made Tough Choices for the Benefit of New Jerseyans; Didn't Do the Job
description: To the Editor:

title:
Marketing of Housing;
Apartment Not Selling? Some Turn to an Auction
description: Banks and government agencies routinely sell foreclosed properties at auction. Less common is the private seller who uses the auction, not as a distress sale but as a marketing tool to sell houses or apartments -- including Manhattan co-op apartments -- as quickly as possible.

title: Enron Oil & Gas reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a benefit of $ 12 million associated with a reduction in deferred tax liability in both the quarter and year, and the year also included and a $ 7 million increase in deferred taxes in the third quarter and a $ 8.7 million in after-tax gains from the sale of oil and gas properties.c-Included $ 3.9 million in after-tax gains on the sale of oil and gas properties.

title: E-Systems Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and after a charge of $ 178,510,000, or $ 5.42 a share, which reflects cumulative effect of the adoption of SFAS 106.(Loss)

title: Sherwin-Williams Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $ 81,771,000, or 92 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

description: b-After a gain of $ 489,000, or 2 cents a share, from cumulative effect of change in accounting for income taxes.Fiscal 1993's income from continuing operations of $ 44,638,000, or $ 1.39 a share, included pretax charge of $ 3,980,000 on discontinued operations.

title: Adolph Baller; Pianist
description: Adolph Baller, a pianist who accompanied the violinist Yehudi Menuhin and other soloists, died on Saturday at his home in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 84.

title: Justin Industries (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 1,106,000, or 4 cents a share, from cumulative effect of an accounting change.Year-ago share earnings are restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective May 18, 1993.

title: People
description: * Brian Johnson, executive vice president and director of business development at J. Walter Thompson North America, New York, was named to the additional new position of worldwide new business director. * Penny Baldwin-Spear was named to the new position of senior vice president and director of communications planning at McCann-Erickson San Francisco. She was previously a senior vice president and director of client services at Ogilvy & Mather Direct, San Francisco.

title: Minnesota Mining & Mfg. Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $ 3 million, or 2 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of changes in accounting for income taxes and postretirement benefits, and a change in the financial reporting period for international operations from a fiscal year ened Oct. 31 to a calendar year ended Dec. 31.

title: Singer Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $ 1.9 million from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Danka Business Systems (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Reactor's Status Upgraded
description: James A. FitzPatrick nuclear reactor has shown "sustained improvement," the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said yesterday, and the agency has removed the plant from its list of the worst-run in the United States. But the performance of the authority's other reactor, the Indian Point 3 plant in Westchester County, "has not significantly changed" since the last review in June, the commission said. The report was another indication that the Buchanan plant, which was shut 11 months ago, is nowhere near ready to resume operation. FitzPatrick, in Scriba, N.Y., near Oswego, went on the commission's list of plants that require close monitoring in February 1992. Because of management problems it was shut from November of 1991 until January 1993, but has been operating fairly reliably since then. It was running yesterday.

title: New England Electric Sys reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Latest fourth quarter's share earnings included 28 cents a share in gains.The increase in fourth quarter earnings was primarily due to the October 1993 rate agreement involving Massachusetts Electric. Because reserves against earnings had previously been provided for these costs, the resolution of rate recovery resulted in a one-time increase to fourth quarter earnings of 11 cents a share.The rate agreement also provided for an 11-month rate decrease effective Dec. 1, 1993. This decrease will be offset by the recognition for accounting purposes, over a period of time, of revenues for electricity delivered but not yet billed. The net effect of these revenue provisions increased fourth quarter earnings by 9 cents a share. Lastly, the rate agreement provided for the rate recovery of certain storm restoration and other costs previously charged to expense, which added 8 cents a share to fourth quarter earnings.

title: RENO'S TOP DEPUTY RESIGNS ABRUPTLY, CITING DIFFERENCES
description: The second-highest official at the Justice Department, Philip B. Heymann, announced his resignation today, an abrupt departure that added to the long list of personnel problems that have plagued the Clinton Administration.

title: Cornell Coach Re-Signs
description: Coach JIM HOFHER of Cornell has signed a multiyear extension on his contract, the university's Athletic Director, LAING KENNEDY announced yesterday. Terms of the new contract were not released.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Serendipity in Yorktown

title: Cortines to Cut Board Staff With Layoffs
description: New York City Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines said yesterday that he would cut up to a thousand jobs from Board of Education headquarters staff through attrition and layoffs, reduce the use of consultants and temporary workers, and give community districts responsibility for hundreds of curriculum and staff development experts.

title: Rollins to Aid Black in Race For the Senate
description: Edward J. Rollins Jr., who boasted last fall that he suppressed the black vote in Christine Todd Witman's victorious drive for the New Jersey governorship, will be an unpaid consultant for a black Philadelphia businessman who is running for the Senate.

title: Market Proposals by S.E.C. Receive a Tepid Response
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission's proposals to amend the way the nation's stock markets go about their business got a cautious review from market participants yesterday, even though the changes the S.E.C. seeks are, by its own admission, fairly modest.

title: 2 Held in Attempt to Kill Car-Towing Rival
description: Two brothers, one a Port Authority police officer and the other the owner of a private security business, were charged yesterday with trying to kidnap and murder a business rival.

title: Who Can Make Peace in Bosnia?
description: A war of words over Bosnia is raging between Washington and Paris, revealing a fundamental difference over the plight of the Muslim-led Government and the urgency of ending the 22-month war.

title: Abbott and Yanks Have an Easy Inning
description: The Yankees reached agreement with Jim Abbott on a 1994 contract yesterday, a mild surprise considering their past dealings with the pitcher's agent. In a relatively brief, relatively easy negotiation, Abbott agreed to $2,775,000, precisely halfway between the figures the two sides had submitted for arbitration.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: F.C.C. RETREATS ON INFINITY PURCHASE

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; In a new campaign, Gap Inc. sheds its usual attire for a look at its charitable giving.
description: A CAMPAIGN coming from Gap Inc. is devoid of celebrities clad in customized versions of Gap T-shirts, bereft of archival photographs of famous people in khaki pants and lacking in smiling young models wearing denim. Yet somehow it is still quintessentially Gap.

title: Corrections
description: A restaurant review in Weekend on Jan. 14 about Barolo described its wheelchair accessibility incompletely. While its main restrooms are down a flight of stairs, Barolo has a restroom on the main floor for handicapped customers.

title: 'Knight' Enters Italian Politics
description: After weeks of teasing hints, Silvio Berlusconi, media magnate and soccer club owner, has announced that he is entering politics to save the land from "men tied to past political and economic failure."

title: Intertan Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss(Loss)

title: Boston Edison reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Latest quarter's share earnings reflects a change in the months for which certain customers were billed at ''summer surcharge'' rates as mandated by state regulators. This change in billing reduced net income by 23 cents a share.

title: Rutgers Sued for Ban on Health Benefits to Gay Partners
description: As one college after another extends employee benefits to gay and lesbian faculty members and their dependents, Rutgers University has steadfastly refused to offer health benefits to same-sex domestic partners.

title: Russian in Chemical Arms Expose Arrested
description: A Russian scientist who wrote about Moscow's chemical weapons program and who has refused to testify at his own trial on charges of divulging state secrets was arrested today, his wife said.

title: Defense Time Bomb
description: Many Americans still treat the defense budget as a symbol of strength. Politicians therefore spend more money than necessary to shield themselves from charges of weakness. President Clinton brandished the budget as a shield in his State of the Union address when, with surprising fervor, he drew the line against further cuts.

title: Accounts
description: * Dell Computer Corp. Canada, Toronto, to Goldberg Moser O'Neill, San Francisco, to handle its account, previously at the Cohen Group, Toronto. Goldberg Moser already handles the account for the parent, Dell Computer Corp. Billings were estimated at $3 million to $5 million.

title: Red, White And Who? It's Martin Vs. Sampras
description: Todd Martin, a lanky 6-foot-6-inch Midwesterner, guaranteed an all-American Australian Open singles final today by dispatching the No. 4 seeded Stefan Edberg of Sweden in a riveting semifinal match, 3-6, 7-6 (9-7), 7-6 (9-7), 7-6 (7-4).

title: Los Angeles Bracing For Losses in Tourism
description: When Alvin Dollar of Atlanta told his wife that he was headed for Los Angeles to attend a convention and asked if she wanted to come along, her reply was an emphatic "no!"

title: Stanley Adams, 86, Ex-Ascap President
description: Stanley Adams, a lyricist who was president of Ascap for 24 years, died yesterday at North Shore Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He lived in Great Neck, L.I., and was 86.

title: Ameritech Sets $4.4 Billion More for Video
description: In one of the largest applications of advanced communications services to consumers, the Ameritech Corporation said yesterday that it planned to spend an additional $4.4 billion to take video conferencing and other video services to the home, for a total expenditure of $29 billion in the next 15 years.

title: No Headline
description: "So far as we know, no one in the history of the United States Senate, since 1789, has ever sat in this chamber that was convicted of a felony." SENATOR JOHN WARNER, Republican of Virginia. [ A20:2. ] "Most people don't give a rat's patootie." OLIVER NORTH. [ A20:2. ]

title: Review/Theater; A Battlefield Of Words And Wills
description: THE passage of time has not elucidated the mysteries at the heart of Harold Pinter's "No Man's Land," which remains as much a theatrical Rorschach test as it ever was. What is abundantly clear at the Criterion Center, where the Roundabout Theater Company revived the 1975 drama last night, is that the right actors can have a field day exploring its opaque depths.

title: Art in Review
description: David Salle Gagosian Gallery 136 Wooster Street (near Prince Street) SoHo Through Feb. 19 Mary Boone Gallery 417 West Broadway (near Spring Street) SoHo Through Feb. 26

title: Papa Wilson: 34 Years and Still Counting
description: Ralph Wilson has seen his share of football -- plenty of odd bounces and frolicking runs, big games, big plays, you name it.

title: Unifi Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
QVC Talks Are Seen On New Bid
description: Representatives of QVC Network Inc. and the BellSouth Corporation met the last two days to discuss the possibility of QVC revising its bid for Paramount Communications Inc., people close to the talks said yesterday.

title: Harding to Get Olympic Spot but Inquiry Continues
description: Tonya Harding will be named to the United States Olympic team, figure skating and Olympic officials said yesterday. But skating officials have begun their own investigatory process, and it remains uncertain whether she will actually skate next month in the Winter Games in Norway.

title: Phillips Petroleum Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included net gains of $ 39 million from asset sales, $ 14 million from a windfall profits tax refund, and $ 31 million from other items, primarily tax benefits from a capital-loss carryforward. These items were partly offset by a $ 12 million write-down in connection with the company's previously announced exit from the catalyst business.c-Included a net gain of $ 47 million from asset sales, tax loss carryforwards, windfall profits tax refund, a business interruption insurance settlement and a plastics lecensing settlement. Partly offsetting these items were the catalyst write-down in the fourth quarter, costs for workforce reduction, litigation claims, charges for pipeline abandonment and an incinerator write-down. Foreign currency losses for the year were $ 2 million.d-Included extraordinary losses of $ 20 million, or 8 cents a share, for the quarter and $ 46 million, or 18 cents a share, for the year. The year was also after a charge of $ 44 million, or 17 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of change in accounting.

title: Gannett Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: b-After a net charge of $ 146,000,000, or $ 1.101 a share, which included a charge of $ 180 million for the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for Retiree health and life insurance benefits, less a credit of $ 34 million for the cumulative effect of a change in acconting for income taxes.Gannett Co. said its results for 1993 included a profit from USA Today and a ''significant'' earnings recovery in its broadcast operations.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the U.S. Central Credit Union's deposits in a Spanish bank misstated the scope of the organization's membership. U.S. Central helps administer a network providing financial and investment services for 90 percent of the nation's 13,000 credit unions, not all of them.

title: Dreyfus Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Kelly Defends Record as Head Of Police Dept.
description: Former Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly yesterday defended himself and his leadership of the New York City Police Department against a week of attacks from the Giuliani administration, which has labeled the department as lethargic and one of its cornerstones, community policing, as grossly mismanaged.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The stakes are a bit higher when Gov. EDWIN W. EDWARDS of Louisiana places bets: he won more than $200,000 gambling in 1993, according to an amended personal financial statement filed Wednesday with the state ethics board.

title: Kerr-McGee reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and after an extraordinary net charge of $ 132,300,000, or $ 2.74 a share, and $ 204,500,000, or $ 4.24 a share, for the quarter and year, respectively, and both included $ 130 million charge for an environmental provision; the quarter included charge for early debt redemption of $ 2.3 million and the year included $ 4.7 million, and the year also included $ 69.8 million charge for cumulative effect of accounting changes on prior years.(Loss)

title: Sports of The Times; Harding, The Games, And Us
description: "Attending the Olympics, representing the U.S., should go to persons in whom the U.S. is proud," a man in Naples, Fla., wrote to me recently. He went on to say that the United States Olympians represent America and its values.

title: Corrections
description: An editorial on Monday incorrectly identified the Metrolink commuter rail system as part of the Los Angeles Metropolitan Transportation Authority; it is an independent agency. A Topic of the Times the same day misquoted lines from a poem by Robert Frost. The lines should read: "Some say the world will end in fire,/ Some say in ice."

title: Servicemaster L.P.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain on the sale of a subsidiary's shares of $ 30.2 million, or 39 cents a share.c-Included $ 70,235,000 in restructuring charges, a $ 105,306,000 gain on the sale of a subsidiary's shares and a charge from an accounting change of $ 7.5 million, unusual charges of $ 8.7 million and minority interest effects of $ 8.8 million. The net result is a gain of $ 27,671,000, or 36 cents a share.Some year-earlier figures have been restated.

description: Mark Morrisroe Pat Hearn Gallery 39 Wooster Street (near Broome Street) SoHo Through Feb. 19

title: Sara Lee Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: b-After a charge of $ 35 million, or 7 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of change in accounting for income taxes.

title: 'Annie' Sequel Closing
description: "Annie Warbucks," the long-beleaguered, undeniably plucky Off Broadway musical sequel to "Annie," is to close after its second show on Sunday. The producers, who were seriously considering moving the show from the Variety Arts Theater to Broadway until two weeks ago, said the persistent cold weather had cut into the show's dwindling ticket sales, prompting the decision to shut down. The show, by Thomas Meehan, Charles Strouse and Martin Charnin, will have had 200 performances and 38 previews.

title: After 13 Seasons And 8 Pro Bowls, Long Calls It Quits
description: In a surprise decision the Los Angeles Raiders defensive lineman Howie Long retired today after 13 seasons in the National Football League.

title: In 2 Lines of Jeeps, 115,000 Are Recalled
description: The sidewalks are slippery, the parking lots are skating rinks, but at least your trusty 4 by 4 sport-utility vehicle will keep you safe and secure in this winter of schussing down the interstate and bumping through the moguls on Main Street, right?

title: Destec Energy reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $ 11,305,000, or 18 cents a share.

title: Solid Sales Increases For MCI and A.T.& T.
description: A.T.& T. and the MCI Communications Corporation both reported solid increases in sales and operating earnings for the last quarter of 1993 today, but MCI continued to gain on its larger rival by growing twice as quickly as the long-distance industry as a whole.

title: Who Owns Savings Bank Riches?
description: Almost like a state lottery, mutual savings banks have created instant millionaires among their managers and directors in recent years when the banks have been sold to other institutions or taken public through stock offerings. But the bounty paid to bank insiders has begun to outrage some depositors, members of Congress and banking regulators.

title: Belden Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $ 9,772,000, or 38 cents a share, from cumulative effect of changes in accounting for postretirement benefits, income taxes and postemployment benefits.Fiscal 1992 income from continuing operations of $ 27,245,000, or $ 1.05 a share, included nonrecurring charge of $ 1,781,000, or 4 cents a share, resulting from a charge of $ 5,200,000 for the closing of a manufacturing facility and income of $ 3,419,000 for the reversal of vacation accrual due to a change in policy.Fiscal 1993 and 1992 are pro forma, as if Belden had been an independent public company for each period. The company was taken public by Cooper Industries Inc. in October 1993.

title: AMC Entertainment Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-After an extraordinary loss on early extinguishment of debt of $ 6,483,000, or 42 cents a share.

title: Jets Hope They've Struck Gold in 49ers' Sherman
description: Hoping to lift a sagging offense, the Jets hired Ray Sherman, the 49ers' receivers coach for the last two years, as their offensive coordinator today.

title: Schlumberger Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $ 248 million, or $ 1.03 a share, from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting principle for postretirement benefits.Revenue represented operating revenue.

title: Tecumseh Products Co.  (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss, which was after a charge of $ 95 million, or $ 4.34 a share. from an adjustment in accounting.Per share amounts have been adjusted to reflect 100 percent stock dividends paid in June 1993, and June 1992.(Loss)

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. A Debut to Forget It certainly wasn't the way Jim Schoenfeld wanted to make his debut as coach of the Washington Capitals. Replacing fired coach Terry Murray just minutes before Washington's game with the Sabres last night, Schoenfeld watched as his new team was blasted at Buffalo, 7-2. It was Washington's fourth straight loss. "You never want to start out like this," Schoenfeld said. (AP) Red Wings 4, Blackhawks 3: Ray Sheppard scored 51 seconds into overtime as Detroit beat Chicago and set a club mark with its sixth consecutive road triumph. (AP)

title: Curtice Burns Foods reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
description: Latest 6 months' share earnings included a non-recurring gain equivalent to 38 cents a share, which is primarily related to the sale of the oats business of the National Oats Division and a non-recurring charge of 6 cents a share for adoption of SFAS 109.Year-ago 6 months' share earnings included a non-recurring loss, equivalent to 7 cents a share, related to the sale of the frozen foods portion of Lucca Packing.

title: SCI Systems (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
RALSTON PURINA DESCRIBES PLAN FOR A SPINOFF
description: The Ralston Purina Corporation has outlined a plan to spin off its cereal, Beech-Nut baby food, cracker, cookie, resort and coupon redemption businesses. The units will form a new company called Ralcorp Holdings Inc. Holders of Ralston Purina Group stock will receive one share of Ralcorp for every three Ralston Purina Group shares, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: United and Delta Narrow Losses for the Quarter
description: The UAL Corporation and Delta Air Lines reported improved results yesterday for the most recent quarter, but still lost money in what is usually a money-losing quarter for airlines.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 5 about Palestinian tolerance of dissent misstated the ethnic origin of Saladin, the 12th-century military and political leader, who is a character in a play recently staged in the Gaza Strip. The historical Saladin led armies that included Arabs and other groups, but he was of Kurdish descent, not Arab.

title: Ford Plans Lease Program for Used Cars
description: The Ford Motor Company is hammering out the details of a program to lease used Ford vehicles through its dealers. The auto maker said it might announce the plan within a week.

title: "COCA-COLA CO. (N)"
description: The Coca-Cola Company attributed the increases of 20 percent in its fourth-quarter earnings and 33 percent for the full year to growth in the company's bottling operation investments and increases in domestic and international soft-drink sales.

title: College Accreditors Feeling Criticism
description: For almost a century, the oversight of colleges, universities and professional schools in this country has rested largely with a group of private accrediting organizations, whose judgments usually went unchallenged and carried the academic equivalent of the Good Housekeeping seal of approval.

title: American President Cos.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a charge of $ 21.6 million, or $ 1.29 a share, from a change in accounting for revenues and expenses.All share earnings and shares outstanding amounts are prior to the 2-for-1 stock split the company declared in the form of a stock dividend, to be distributed on Jan. 28 to stockholders of record on Dec. 31, 1993.

title: In Virginia, Innocent Man Stays in Prison
description: To the Editor:

title: Sounds Around Town
description: On Familiar Ground

title: Stock Fund Investment Soaring in January
description: Having ended 1993 with a record volume of stock-fund investment, the mutual fund industry got off to a great start in 1994, fund managers and executives said yesterday.

A Long-Running Role as the Bills' Heart and Soul
description: When the Bills drafted Darryl Talley in the second round of the 1983 draft, they had just come off a strike-shortened 4-5 season. In the next five seasons, they would finish 8-8, 2-14, 2-14, 4-12 and 7-8.

title: Laclede Gas Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The Mayor's Badly Aimed Ax
description: In announcing his wrongheaded -- and hardheaded -- decision to eliminate New York City's minority contracting program, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani at least had the grace to say that one could disagree with his view that there is no need to remedy past discrimination.
